verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:1
verses.text: Letter I.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:2
verses.text: To Eustathius the Philosopher.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:3
verses.text: Much distressed as I was by the flouts of what is called fortune, who always seems to be hindering my meeting you, I was wonderfully cheered and comforted by your letter, for I had already been turning over in my mind whether what so many people say is really true, that there is a certain Necessity or Fate which rules all the events of our lives both great and small, and that we human beings have control over nothing; or, that at all events, all human life is driven by a kind of luck.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:4
verses.text: You will be very ready to forgive me for these reflexions, when you learn by what causes I was led to make them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:5
verses.text: On hearing of your philosophy, I entertained a feeling of contempt for the teachers of Athens, and left it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:6
verses.text: The city on the Hellespont I passed by, more unmoved than any Ulysses, passing Sirens' songs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:7
verses.text: Asia I admired; but I hurried on to the capital of all that is best in it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:8
verses.text: When I arrived home, and did not find you,—the prize which I had sought so eagerly,—there began many and various unexpected hindrances.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:9
verses.text: First I must miss you because I fell ill; then when you were setting out for the East I could not start with you; then, after endless trouble, I reached Syria, but I missed the philosopher, who had set out for Egypt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:10
verses.text: Then I must set out for Egypt, a long and weary way, and even there I did not gain my end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:11
verses.text: But so passionate was my longing that I must either set out for Persia, and proceed with you to the farthest lands of barbarism, (you had got there; what an obstinate devil possessed me!) or settle here at Alexandria.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:12
verses.text: This last I did.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:13
verses.text: I really think that unless, like some tame beast, I had followed a bough held out to me till I was quite worn out, you would have been driven on and on beyond Indian Nyssa, or any more remote region, and wandered about out there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:14
verses.text: Why say more?  On returning home, I cannot meet you, hindered by lingering ailments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:15
verses.text: If these do not get better I shall not be able to meet you even in the winter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:16
verses.text: Is not all this, as you yourself say, due to Fate? Is not this Necessity? Does not my case nearly outdo poets' tales of Tantalus? But, as I said, I feel better after getting your letter, and am now no longer of the same mind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:17
verses.text: When God gives good things I think we must thank Him, and not be angry with Him while He is controlling their distribution.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:18
verses.text: So if He grant me to join you, I shall think it best and most delightful; if He put me off, I will gently endure the loss.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 1:19
verses.text: For He always rules our lives better than we could choose for ourselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:1
verses.text: Letter II.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:2
verses.text: Basil to Gregory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:4
verses.text: [I recognised your letter, as one recognises one's friends' children from their obvious likeness to their parents.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:5
verses.text: Your saying that to describe the kind of place I live in, before letting you hear anything about how I live, would not go far towards persuading you to share my life, was just like you; it was worthy of a soul like yours, which makes nothing of all that concerns this life here, in comparison with the blessedness which is promised us hereafter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:6
verses.text: What I do myself, day and night, in this remote spot, I am ashamed to write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:7
verses.text: I have abandoned my life in town, as one sure to lead to countless ills; but I have not yet been able to get quit of myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:8
verses.text: I am like travellers at sea, who have never gone a voyage before, and are distressed and seasick, who quarrel with the ship because it is so big and makes such a tossing, and, when they get out of it into the pinnace or dingey, are everywhere and always seasick and distressed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:9
verses.text: Wherever they go their nausea and misery go with them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:10
verses.text: My state is something like this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:11
verses.text: I carry my own troubles with me, and so everywhere I am in the midst of similar discomforts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:12
verses.text: So in the end I have not got much good out of my solitude.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:13
verses.text: What I ought to have done; what would have enabled me to keep close to the footprints of Him who has led the way to salvation—for He says, "If any one will come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross, and follow me"—is this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:15
verses.text: We must strive after a quiet mind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:16
verses.text: As well might the eye ascertain an object put before it while it is wandering restless up and down and sideways, without fixing a steady gaze upon it, as a mind, distracted by a thousand worldly cares, be able clearly to apprehend the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:17
verses.text: He who is not yet yoked in the bonds of matrimony is harassed by frenzied cravings, and rebellious impulses, and hopeless attachments; he who has found his mate is encompassed with his own tumult of cares; if he is childless, there is desire for children; has he children? anxiety about their education, attention to his wife, care of his house, oversight of his servants, misfortunes in trade, quarrels with his neighbours, lawsuits, the risks of the merchant, the toil of the farmer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:18
verses.text: Each day, as it comes, darkens the soul in its own way; and night after night takes up the day's anxieties, and cheats the mind with illusions in accordance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:19
verses.text: Now one way of escaping all this is separation from the whole world; that is, not bodily separation, but the severance of the soul's sympathy with the body, and to live so without city, home, goods, society, possessions, means of life, business, engagements, human learning, that the heart may readily receive every impress of divine doctrine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:20
verses.text: Preparation of heart is the unlearning the prejudices of evil converse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:21
verses.text: It is the smoothing the waxen tablet before attempting to write on it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:22
verses.text: Now solitude is of the greatest use for this purpose, inasmuch as it stills our passions, and gives room for principle to cut them out of the soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:23
verses.text: [For just as animals are more easily controlled when they are stroked, lust and anger, fear and sorrow, the soul's deadly foes, are better brought under the control of reason, after being calmed by inaction, and where there is no continuous stimulation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:24
verses.text: ] Let there then be such a place as ours, separate from intercourse with men, that the tenour of our exercises be not interrupted from without.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:25
verses.text: Pious exercises nourish the soul with divine thoughts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:26
verses.text: What state can be more blessed than to imitate on earth the choruses of angels? to begin the day with prayer, and honour our Maker with hymns and songs? As the day brightens, to betake ourselves, with prayer attending on it throughout, to our labours, and to sweeten our work with hymns, as if with salt? Soothing hymns compose the mind to a cheerful and calm state.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:27
verses.text: Quiet, then, as I have said, is the first step in our sanctification; the tongue purified from the gossip of the world; the eyes unexcited by fair colour or comely shape; the ear not relaxing the tone or mind by voluptuous songs, nor by that especial mischief, the talk of light men and jesters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:28
verses.text: Thus the mind, saved from dissipation from without, and not through the senses thrown upon the world, falls back upon itself, and thereby ascends to the contemplation of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:29
verses.text: [When that beauty shines about it, it even forgets its very nature; it is dragged down no more by thought of food nor anxiety concerning dress; it keeps holiday from earthly cares, and devotes all its energies to the acquisition of the good things which are eternal, and asks only how may be made to flourish in it self-control and manly courage, righteousness and wisdom, and all the other virtues, which, distributed under these heads, properly enable the good man to discharge all the duties of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:31
verses.text: The study of inspired Scripture is the chief way of finding our duty, for in it we find both instruction about conduct and the lives of blessed men, delivered in writing, as some breathing images of godly living, for the imitation of their good works.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:32
verses.text: Hence, in whatever respect each one feels himself deficient, devoting himself to this imitation, he finds, as from some dispensary, the due medicine for his ailment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:33
verses.text: He who is enamoured of chastity dwells upon the history of Joseph, and from him learns chaste actions, finding him not only possessed of self-command over pleasure, but virtuously-minded in habit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:34
verses.text: He is taught endurance by Job [who, not only when the circumstances of life began to turn against him, and in one moment he was plunged from wealth into penury, and from being the father of fair children into childlessness, remained the same, keeping the disposition of his soul all through uncrushed, but was not even stirred to anger against the friends who came to comfort him, and trampled on him, and aggravated his troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:35
verses.text: ] Or should he be enquiring how to be at once meek and great-hearted, hearty against sin, meek towards men, he will find David noble in warlike exploits, meek and unruffled as regards revenge on enemies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:36
verses.text: Such, too, was Moses rising up with great heart upon sinners against God, but with meek soul bearing their evil-speaking against himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:37
verses.text: [Thus, generally, as painters, when they are painting from other pictures, constantly look at the model, and do their best to transfer its lineaments to their own work, so too must he who is desirous of rendering himself perfect in all branches of excellency, keep his eyes turned to the lives of the saints as though to living and moving statues, and make their virtue his own by imitation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:39
verses.text: Prayers, too, after reading, find the soul fresher, and more vigorously stirred by love towards God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:40
verses.text: And that prayer is good which imprints a clear idea of God in the soul; and the having God established in self by means of memory is God's indwelling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:41
verses.text: Thus we become God's temple, when the continuity of our recollection is not severed by earthly cares; when the mind is harassed by no sudden sensations; when the worshipper flees from all things and retreats to God, drawing away all the feelings that invite him to self-indulgence, and passes his time in the pursuits that lead to virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:43
verses.text: This, too, is a very important point to attend to,—knowledge how to converse; to interrogate without over-earnestness; to answer without desire of display; not to interrupt a profitable speaker, or to desire ambitiously to put in a word of one's own; to be measured in speaking and hearing; not to be ashamed of receiving, or to be grudging in giving information, nor to pass another's knowledge for one's own, as depraved women their supposititious children, but to refer it candidly to the true parent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:44
verses.text: The middle tone of voice is best, neither so low as to be inaudible, nor to be ill-bred from its high pitch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:45
verses.text: One should reflect first what one is going to say, and then give it utterance: be courteous when addressed; amiable in social intercourse; not aiming to be pleasant by facetiousness, but cultivating gentleness in kind admonitions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:46
verses.text: Harshness is ever to be put aside, even in censuring.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:47
verses.text: [The more you shew modesty and humility yourself, the more likely are you to be acceptable to the patient who needs your treatment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:48
verses.text: There are however many occasions when we shall do well to employ the kind of rebuke used by the prophet who did not in his own person utter the sentence of condemnation on David after his sin, but by suggesting an imaginary character made the sinner judge of his own sin, so that, after passing his own sentence, he could not find fault with the seer who had convicted him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:50
verses.text: From the humble and submissive spirit comes an eye sorrowful and downcast, appearance neglected, hair rough, dress dirty; so that the appearance which mourners take pains to present may appear our natural condition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:51
verses.text: The tunic should be fastened to the body by a girdle, the belt not going above the flank, like a woman's, nor left slack, so that the tunic flows loose, like an idler's.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:52
verses.text: The gait ought not to be sluggish, which shews a character without energy, nor on the other hand pushing and pompous, as though our impulses were rash and wild.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:53
verses.text: The one end of dress is that it should be a sufficient covering alike in winter and summer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:54
verses.text: As to colour, avoid brightness; in material, the soft and delicate.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:55
verses.text: To aim at bright colours in dress is like women's beautifying when they colour cheeks and hair with hues other than their own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:56
verses.text: The tunic ought to be thick enough not to want other help to keep the wearer warm.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:57
verses.text: The shoes should be cheap but serviceable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:58
verses.text: In a word, what one has to regard in dress is the necessary.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:59
verses.text: So too as to food; for a man in good health bread will suffice, and water will quench thirst; such dishes of vegetables may be added as conduce to strengthening the body for the discharge of its functions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:60
verses.text: One ought not to eat with any exhibition of savage gluttony, but in everything that concerns our pleasures to maintain moderation, quiet, and self-control; and, all through, not to let the mind forget to think of God, but to make even the nature of our food, and the constitution of the body that takes it, a ground and means for offering Him the glory, bethinking us how the various kinds of food, suitable to the needs of our bodies, are due to the provision of the great Steward of the Universe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:61
verses.text: Before meat let grace be said, in recognition alike of the gifts which God gives now, and which He keeps in store for time to come.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:62
verses.text: Say grace after meat in gratitude for gifts given and petition for gifts promised.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:63
verses.text: Let there be one fixed hour for taking food, always the same in regular course, that of all the four and twenty of the day and night barely this one may be spent upon the body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:64
verses.text: The rest the ascetic ought to spend in mental exercise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:65
verses.text: Let sleep be light and easily interrupted, as naturally happens after a light diet; it should be purposely broken by thoughts about great themes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:66
verses.text: To be overcome by heavy torpor, with limbs unstrung, so that a way is readily opened to wild fancies, is to be plunged in daily death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 2:67
verses.text: What dawn is to some this midnight is to athletes of piety; then the silence of night gives leisure to their soul; no noxious sounds or sights obtrude upon their hearts; the mind is alone with itself and God, correcting itself by the recollection of its sins, giving itself precepts to help it to shun evil, and imploring aid from God for the perfecting of what it longs for.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:1
verses.text: Letter III.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:2
verses.text: To Candidianus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:4
verses.text: When I took your letter into my hand, I underwent an experience worth telling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:5
verses.text: I looked at it with the awe due to a document making some state announcement, and as I was breaking the wax, I felt a dread greater than ever guilty Spartan felt at sight of the Laconian scytale.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:6
verses.text: When, however, I had opened the letter, and read it through, I could not help laughing, partly for joy at finding nothing alarming in it; partly because I likened your state of affairs to that of Demosthenes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:7
verses.text: Demosthenes, you remember, when he was providing for a certain little company of chorus dancers and musicians, requested to be styled no longer Demosthenes, but "choragus".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:8
verses.text: You are always the same, whether playing the "choragus" or not.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:9
verses.text: "Choragus" you are indeed to soldiers myriads more in number than the individuals to whom Demosthenes supplied necessaries; and yet you do not when you write to me stand on your dignity, but keep up the old style.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:10
verses.text: You do not give up the study of literature, but, as Plato has it, in the midst of the storm and tempest of affairs, you stand aloof, as it were, under some strong wall, and keep your mind clear of all disturbance; nay, more, as far as in you lies, you do not even let others be disturbed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:11
verses.text: Such is your life; great and wonderful to all who have eyes to see; and yet not wonderful to any one who judges by the whole purpose of your life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:12
verses.text: Now let me tell my own story, extraordinary indeed, but only what might have been expected.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:14
verses.text: One of the hinds who live with us here at Annesi, on the death of my servant, without alleging any breach of contract with him, without approaching me, without making any complaint, without asking me to make him any voluntary payment, without any threat of violence should he fail to get it, all on a sudden, with certain mad fellows like himself, attacked my house, brutally assaulted the women who were in charge of it, broke in the doors, and after appropriating some of the contents himself, and promising the rest to any one who liked, carried off everything.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:15
verses.text: I do not wish to be regarded as the ne plus ultra of helplessness, and a suitable object for the violence of any one who likes to attack me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:16
verses.text: Shew me, then, now, I beg you, that kindly interest which you have always shewn in my affairs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:17
verses.text: Only on one condition can my tranquillity be secured,—that I be assured of having your energy on my side.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:18
verses.text: It would be quite punishment enough, from my point of view, if the man were apprehended by the district magistrate and locked up for a short period in the gaol.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 3:19
verses.text: It is not only that I am indignant at the treatment I have suffered, but I want security for the future.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 4:1
verses.text: Letter IV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 4:2
verses.text: To Olympius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 4:3
verses.text: What do you mean, my dear Sir, by evicting from our retreat my dear friend and nurse of philosophy, Poverty? Were she but gifted with speech, I take it you would have to appear as defendant in an action for unlawful ejectment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 4:4
verses.text: She might plead "I chose to live with this man Basil, an admirer of Zeno, who, when he had lost everything in a shipwreck, cried, with great fortitude, 'well done, Fortune! you are reducing me to the old cloak;' a great admirer of Cleanthes, who by drawing water from the well got enough to live on and pay his tutors' fees as well; an immense admirer of Diogenes, who prided himself on requiring no more than was absolutely necessary, and flung away his bowl after he had learned from some lad to stoop down and drink from the hollow of his hand".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 4:5
verses.text: In some such terms as these you might be chidden by my dear mate Poverty, whom your presents have driven from house and home.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 4:6
verses.text: She might too add a threat; "if I catch you here again, I shall shew that what went before was Sicilian or Italian luxury: so I shall exactly requite you out of my own store".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 4:7
verses.text: But enough of this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 4:8
verses.text: I am very glad that you have already begun a course of medicine, and pray that you may be benefited by it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 4:9
verses.text: A condition of body fit for painless activity would well become so pious a soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:1
verses.text: Letter V.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:2
verses.text: To Nectarius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:4
verses.text: I heard of your unendurable loss, and was much distressed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:5
verses.text: Three or four days went by, and I was still in some doubt because my informant was not able to give me any clear details of the melancholy event.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:6
verses.text: While I was incredulous about what was noised abroad, because I prayed that it might not be true, I received a letter from the Bishop fully confirming the unhappy tidings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:7
verses.text: I need not tell you how I sighed and wept.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:8
verses.text: Who could be so stony-hearted, so truly inhuman, as to be insensible to what has occurred, or be affected by merely moderate grief? He is gone; heir of a noble house, prop of a family, a father's hope, offspring of pious parents, nursed with innumerable prayers, in the very bloom of manhood, torn from his father's hands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:9
verses.text: These things are enough to break a heart of adamant and make it feel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:10
verses.text: It is only natural then that I am deeply touched at this trouble; I who have been intimately connected with you from the beginning and have made your joys and sorrows mine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:11
verses.text: But yesterday it seemed that you had only little to trouble you, and that your life's stream was flowing prosperously on.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:12
verses.text: In a moment, by a demon's malice, all the happiness of the house, all the brightness of life, is destroyed, and our lives are made a doleful story.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:13
verses.text: If we wish to lament and weep over what has happened, a lifetime will not be enough and if all mankind mourns with us they will be powerless to make their lamentation match our loss.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:14
verses.text: Yes, if all the streams run tears they will not adequately weep our woe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:16
verses.text: But we mean,—do we not?—to bring out the gift which God has stored in our hearts; I mean that sober reason which in our happy days is wont to draw lines of limitation round our souls, and when troubles come about us to recall to our minds that we are but men, and to suggest to us, what indeed we have seen and heard, that life is full of similar misfortunes, and that the examples of human sufferings are not a few.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:17
verses.text: Above all, this will tell us that it is God's command that we who trust in Christ should not grieve over them who are fallen asleep, because we hope in the resurrection; and that in reward for great patience great crowns of glory are kept in store by the Master of life's course.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:18
verses.text: Only let us allow our wiser thoughts to speak to us in this strain of music, and we may peradventure discover some slight alleviation of our trouble.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:19
verses.text: Play the man, then, I implore you; the blow is a heavy one, but stand firm; do not fall under the weight of your grief; do not lose heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:20
verses.text: Be perfectly assured of this, that though the reasons for what is ordained by God are beyond us, yet always what is arranged for us by Him Who is wise and Who loves us is to be accepted, be it ever so grievous to endure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:21
verses.text: He Himself knows how He is appointing what is best for each and why the terms of life that He fixes for us are unequal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:22
verses.text: There exists some reason incomprehensible to man why some are sooner carried far away from us, and some are left a longer while behind to bear the burdens of this painful life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:23
verses.text: So we ought always to adore His loving kindness, and not to repine, remembering those great and famous words of the great athlete Job, when he had seen ten children at one table, in one short moment, crushed to death, "The Lord gave and the Lord hath taken away".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:24
verses.text: As the Lord thought good so it came to pass.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:25
verses.text: Let us adopt those marvellous words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:26
verses.text: At the hands of the righteous Judge, they who show like good deeds shall receive a like reward.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:27
verses.text: We have not lost the lad; we have restored him to the Lender.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:28
verses.text: His life is not destroyed; it is changed for the better.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:29
verses.text: He whom we love is not hidden in the ground; he is received into heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:30
verses.text: Let us wait a little while, and we shall be once more with him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:31
verses.text: The time of our separation is not long, for in this life we are all like travellers on a journey, hastening on to the same shelter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:32
verses.text: While one has reached his rest another arrives, another hurries on, but one and the same end awaits them all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:33
verses.text: He has outstripped us on the way, but we shall all travel the same road, and the same hostelry awaits us all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 5:34
verses.text: God only grant that we through goodness may be likened to his purity, to the end that for the sake of our guilelessness of life we may attain the rest which is granted to them that are children in Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:1
verses.text: Letter VI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:2
verses.text: To the wife of Nectarius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:4
verses.text: I hesitated to address your excellency, from the idea that, just as to the eye when inflamed even the mildest of remedies causes pain, so to a soul distressed by heavy sorrow, words offered in the moment of agony, even though they do bring much comfort, seem to be somewhat out of place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:5
verses.text: But I bethought me that I should be speaking to a Christian woman, who has long ago learned godly lessons, and is not inexperienced in the vicissitudes of human life, and I judged it right not to neglect the duty laid upon me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:6
verses.text: I know what a mother's heart is, and when I remember how good and gentle you are to all, I can reckon the probable extent of your misery at this present time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:7
verses.text: You have lost a son whom, while he was alive, all mothers called happy, with prayers that their own might be like him, and on his death bewailed, as though each had hidden her own in the grave.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:8
verses.text: His death is a blow to two provinces, both to mine and to Cilicia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:9
verses.text: With him has fallen a great and illustrious race, dashed to the ground as by the withdrawal of a prop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:10
verses.text: Alas for the mighty mischief that the contact with an evil demon was able to wreak! Earth, what a calamity thou hast been compelled to sustain! If the sun had any feeling one would think he might have shuddered at so sad a sight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:11
verses.text: Who could utter all that the spirit in its helplessness would have said?  2.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:12
verses.text: But our lives are not without a Providence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:13
verses.text: So we have learnt in the Gospel, for not a sparrow falls to the ground without the will of our Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:14
verses.text: Whatever has come to pass has come to pass by the will of our Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:15
verses.text: And who can resist God's will? Let us accept what has befallen us; for if we take it ill we do not mend the past and we work our own ruin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:16
verses.text: Do not let us arraign the righteous judgment of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:17
verses.text: We are all too untaught to assail His ineffable sentences.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:18
verses.text: The Lord is now making trial of your love for Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:19
verses.text: Now there is an opportunity for you, through your patience, to take the martyr's lot.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:20
verses.text: The mother of the Maccabees saw the death of seven sons without a sigh, without even shedding one unworthy tear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:21
verses.text: She gave thanks to God for seeing them freed from the fetters of the flesh by fire and steel and cruel blows, and she won praise from God, and fame among men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:22
verses.text: The loss is great, as I can say myself; but great too are the rewards laid up by the Lord for the patient.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:23
verses.text: When first you were made a mother, and saw your boy, and thanked God, you knew all the while that, a mortal yourself, you had given birth to a mortal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:24
verses.text: What is there astonishing in the death of a mortal? But we are grieved at his dying before his time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:25
verses.text: Are we sure that this was not his time? We do not know how to pick and choose what is good for our souls, or how to fix the limits of the life of man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:26
verses.text: Look round at all the world in which you live; remember that everything you see is mortal, and all subject to corruption.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:27
verses.text: Look up to heaven; even it shall be dissolved; look at the sun, not even the sun will last for ever.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:28
verses.text: All the stars together, all living things of land and sea, all that is fair on earth, aye, earth itself, all are subject to decay; yet a little while and all shall be no more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:29
verses.text: Let these considerations be some comfort to you in your trouble.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:30
verses.text: Do not measure your loss by itself; if you do it will seem intolerable; but if you take all human affairs into account you will find that some comfort is to be derived from them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:31
verses.text: Above all, one thing I would strongly urge; spare your husband.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:32
verses.text: Be a comfort to others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:33
verses.text: Do not make his trouble harder to bear by wearing yourself away with sorrow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:34
verses.text: Mere words I know cannot give comfort.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 6:35
verses.text: Just now what is wanted is prayer; and I do pray the Lord Himself to touch your heart by His unspeakable power, and through good thoughts to cause light to shine upon your soul, that you may have a source of consolation in yourself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 7:1
verses.text: Letter VII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 7:2
verses.text: To Gregory my friend.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 7:3
verses.text: When I wrote to you, I was perfectly well aware that no theological term is adequate to the thought of the speaker, or the want of the questioner, because language is of natural necessity too weak to act in the service of objects of thought.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 7:4
verses.text: If then our thought is weak, and our tongue weaker than our thought, what was to be expected of me in what I said but that I should be charged with poverty of expression? Still, it was not possible to let your question pass unnoticed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 7:5
verses.text: It looks like a betrayal, if we do not readily give an answer about God to them that love the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 7:6
verses.text: What has been said, however, whether it seems satisfactory, or requires some further and more careful addition, needs a fit season for correction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 7:7
verses.text: For the present I implore you, as I have implored you before, to devote yourself entirely to the advocacy of the truth, and to the intellectual energies God gives you for the establishment of what is good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 7:8
verses.text: With this be content, and ask nothing more from me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 7:9
verses.text: I am really much less capable than is supposed, and am more likely to do harm to the word by my weakness than to add strength to the truth by my advocacy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:1
verses.text: Letter VIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:2
verses.text: To the Caesareans.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:3
verses.text: A defence of his withdrawal, and concerning the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:5
verses.text: I have often been astonished at your feeling towards me as you do, and how it comes about that an individual so small and insignificant, and having, may be, very little that is lovable about him, should have so won your allegiance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:6
verses.text: You remind me of the claims of friendship and of fatherland, and press me urgently in your attempt to make me come back to you, as though I were a runaway from a father's heart and home.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:7
verses.text: That I am a runaway I confess.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:8
verses.text: I should be sorry to deny it; since you are already regretting me, you shall be told the cause.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:9
verses.text: I was astounded like a man stunned by some sudden noise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:10
verses.text: I did not crush my thoughts, but dwelt upon them as I fled, and now I have been absent from you a considerable time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:11
verses.text: Then I began to yearn for the divine doctrines, and the philosophy that is concerned with them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:12
verses.text: How, said I, could I overcome the mischief dwelling with us? Who is to be my Laban, setting me free from Esau, and leading me to the supreme philosophy? By God's help, I have, so far as in me lies, attained my object; I have found a chosen vessel, a deep well; I mean Gregory, Christ's mouth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:13
verses.text: Give me, therefore, I beg you, a little time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:14
verses.text: I am not embracing a city life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:15
verses.text: I am quite well aware how the evil one by such means devises deceit for mankind, but I do hold the society of the saints most useful.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:16
verses.text: For in the more constant change of ideas about the divine dogmas I am acquiring a lasting habit of contemplation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:17
verses.text: Such is my present situation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:19
verses.text: Friends godly and well beloved, do, I implore you, beware of the shepherds of the Philistines; let them not choke your wills unawares; let them not befoul the purity of your knowledge of the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:20
verses.text: This is ever their object, not to teach simple souls lessons drawn from Holy Scripture, but to mar the harmony of the truth by heathen philosophy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:21
verses.text: Is not he an open Philistine who is introducing the terms "unbegotten" and "begotten" into our faith, and asserts that there was once a time when the Everlasting was not; that He who is by nature and eternally a Father became a Father; that the Holy Ghost is not eternal? He bewitches our Patriarch's sheep that they may not drink "of the well of water springing up into everlasting life," but may rather bring upon themselves the words of the prophet, "They have forsaken me, the fountain of living waters, and hewed them out cisterns, broken cisterns, that can hold no water;" when all the while they ought to confess that the Father is God, the Son God, and the Holy Ghost God, as they have been taught by the divine words, and by those who have understood them in their highest sense.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:22
verses.text: Against those who cast it in our teeth that we are Tritheists, let it be answered that we confess one God not in number but in nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:23
verses.text: For everything which is called one in number is not one absolutely, nor yet simple in nature; but God is universally confessed to be simple and not composite.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:24
verses.text: God therefore is not one in number.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:25
verses.text: What I mean is this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:26
verses.text: We say that the world is one in number, but not one by nature nor yet simple; for we divide it into its constituent elements, fire, water, air, and earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:27
verses.text: Again, man is called one in number.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:28
verses.text: We frequently speak of one man, but man who is composed of body and soul is not simple.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:29
verses.text: Similarly we say one angel in number, but not one by nature nor yet simple, for we conceive of the hypostasis of the angel as essence with sanctification.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:30
verses.text: If therefore everything which is one in number is not one in nature, and that which is one and simple in nature is not one in number; and if we call God one in nature how can number be charged against us, when we utterly exclude it from that blessed and spiritual nature? Number relates to quantity; and quantity is conjoined with bodily nature, for number is of bodily nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:31
verses.text: We believe our Lord to be Creator of bodies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:32
verses.text: Wherefore every number indicates those things which have received a material and circumscribed nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:33
verses.text: Monad and Unity on the other hand signify the nature which is simple and incomprehensible.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:34
verses.text: Whoever therefore confesses either the Son of God or the Holy Ghost to be number or creature introduces unawares a material and circumscribed nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:35
verses.text: And by circumscribed I mean not only locally limited, but a nature which is comprehended in foreknowledge by Him who is about to educe it from the non-existent into the existent and which can be comprehended by science.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:36
verses.text: Every holy thing then of which the nature is circumscribed and of which the holiness is acquired is not insusceptible of evil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:37
verses.text: But the Son and the Holy Ghost are the source of sanctification by which every reasonable creature is hallowed in proportion to its virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:39
verses.text: We in accordance with the true doctrine speak of the Son as neither like, nor unlike the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:40
verses.text: Each of these terms is equally impossible, for like and unlike are predicated in relation to quality, and the divine is free from quality.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:41
verses.text: We, on the contrary, confess identity of nature and accepting the consubstantiality, and rejecting the composition of the Father, God in substance, Who begat the Son, God in substance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:42
verses.text: From this the consubstantiality is proved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:43
verses.text: For God in essence or substance is co-essential or con-substantial with God in essence or substance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:44
verses.text: But when even man is called "god" as in the words, "I have said ye are gods," and "daemon" as in the words, "The gods of the nations are daemons," in the former case the name is given by favour, in the latter untruly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:45
verses.text: God alone is substantially and essentially God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:46
verses.text: When I say "alone" I set forth the holy and uncreated essence and substance of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:47
verses.text: For the word "alone" is used in the case of any individual and generally of human nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:48
verses.text: In the case of an individual, as for instance of Paul, that he alone was caught into the third heaven and "heard unspeakable words which it is not lawful for a man to utter," and of human nature, as when David says, "as for man his days are as grass," not meaning any particular man, but human nature generally; for every man is short-lived and mortal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:49
verses.text: So we understand these words to be said of the nature, "who alone hath immortality" and "to God only wise," and "none is good save one, that is God," for here "one" means the same as alone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:50
verses.text: So also, "which alone spreadest out the heavens," and again "Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God and Him only shalt thou serve".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:51
verses.text: "There is no God beside me".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:52
verses.text: In Scripture "one" and "only" are not predicated of God to mark distinction from the Son and the Holy Ghost, but to except the unreal gods falsely so called.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:53
verses.text: As for instance, "The Lord alone did lead them and there was no strange god with them," and "then the children of Israel did put away Baalim and Ashtaroth, and did serve the Lord only".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:54
verses.text: And so St.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:55
verses.text: Paul, "For as there be gods many and lords many, but to us there is but one god, the Father, of whom are all things; and one Lord Jesus Christ by Whom are all things".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:56
verses.text: Here we enquire why when he had said "one God" he was not content, for we have said that "one" and "only" when applied to God, indicate nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:57
verses.text: Why did he add the word Father and make mention of Christ? Paul, a chosen vessel, did not, I imagine, think it sufficient only to preach that the Son is God and the Holy Ghost God, which he had expressed by the phrase "one God," without, by the further addition of "the Father," expressing Him of Whom are all things; and, by mentioning the Lord, signifying the Word by Whom are all things; and yet further, by adding the words Jesus Christ, announcing the incarnation, setting forth the passion and publishing the resurrection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:58
verses.text: For the word Jesus Christ suggests all these ideas to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:59
verses.text: For this reason too before His passion our Lord deprecates the designation of "Jesus Christ," and charges His disciples to "tell no man that He was Jesus, the Christ".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:60
verses.text: For His purpose was, after the completion of the oeconomy, after His resurrection from the dead, and His assumption into heaven, to commit to them the preaching of Him as Jesus, the Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:61
verses.text: Such is the force of the words "That they may know Thee the only true God and Jesus Christ whom thou hast sent," and again "Ye believe in God, believe also in me".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:62
verses.text: Everywhere the Holy Ghost secures our conception of Him to save us from falling in one direction while we advance in the other, heeding the theology but neglecting the oeconomy, and so by omission falling into impiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:64
verses.text: Now let us examine, and to the best of our ability explain, the meaning of the words of Holy Scripture, which our opponents seize and wrest to their own sense, and urge against us for the destruction of the glory of the Only-begotten.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:65
verses.text: First of all take the words "I live because of the Father," for this is one of the shafts hurled heavenward by those who impiously use it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:66
verses.text: These words I do not understand to refer to the eternal life; for whatever lives because of something else cannot be self-existent, just as that which is warmed by another cannot be warmth itself; but He Who is our Christ and God says, "I am the life".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:67
verses.text: I understand the life lived because of the Father to be this life in the flesh, and in this time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:68
verses.text: Of His own will He came to live the life of men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:69
verses.text: He did not say "I have lived because of the Father," but "I live because of the Father," clearly indicating the present time, and the Christ, having the word of God in Himself, is able to call the life which He leads, life, and that this is His meaning we shall learn from what follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:70
verses.text: "He that eateth me," He says, "he also shall live because of me;" for we eat His flesh, and drink His blood, being made through His incarnation and His visible life partakers of His Word and of His Wisdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:71
verses.text: For all His mystic sojourn among us He called flesh and blood, and set forth the teaching consisting of practical science, of physics, and of theology, whereby our soul is nourished and is meanwhile trained for the contemplation of actual realities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:72
verses.text: This is perhaps the intended meaning of what He says.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:74
verses.text: And again, "My Father is greater than I".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:75
verses.text: This passage is also employed by the ungrateful creatures, the brood of the evil one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:76
verses.text: I believe that even from this passage the consubstantiality of the Son with the Father is set forth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:77
verses.text: For I know that comparisons may properly be made between things which are of the same nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:78
verses.text: We speak of angel as greater than angel, of man as juster than man, of bird as fleeter than bird.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:79
verses.text: If then comparisons are made between things of the same species, and the Father by comparison is said to be greater than the Son, then the Son is of the same substance as the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:80
verses.text: But there is another sense underlying the expression.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:81
verses.text: In what is it extraordinary that He who "is the Word and was made flesh" confesses His Father to be greater than Himself, when He was seen in glory inferior to the angels, and in form to men? For "Thou hast made him a little lower than the angels," and again "Who was made a little lower than the angels," and "we saw Him and He had neither form nor comeliness, his form was deficient beyond all men".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:82
verses.text: All this He endured on account of His abundant loving kindness towards His work, that He might save the lost sheep and bring it home when He had saved it, and bring back safe and sound to his own land the man who went down from Jerusalem to Jericho and so fell among thieves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:83
verses.text: Will the heretic cast in His teeth the manger out of which he in his unreasonableness was fed by the Word of reason? Will he, because the carpenter's son had no bed to lie on, complain of His being poor? This is why the Son is less than the Father; for your sakes He was made dead to free you from death and make you sharer in heavenly life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:84
verses.text: It is just as though any one were to find fault with the physician for stooping to sickness, and breathing its foul breath, that he may heal the sick.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:86
verses.text: It is on thy account that He knows not the hour and the day of judgment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:87
verses.text: Yet nothing is beyond the ken of the real Wisdom, for "all things were made by Him;" and even among men no one is ignorant of what he has made.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:88
verses.text: But this is His dispensation because of thine own infirmity, that sinners be not plunged into despair by the narrow limits of the appointed period, no opportunity for repentance being left them; and that, on the other hand, those who are waging a long war with the forces of the enemy may not desert their post on account of the protracted time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:89
verses.text: For both of these classes He arranges by means of His assumed ignorance; for the former cutting the time short for their glorious struggle's sake; for the latter providing an opportunity for repentance because of their sins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:90
verses.text: In the gospels He numbered Himself among the ignorant, on account, as I have said, of the infirmity of the greater part of mankind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:91
verses.text: In the Acts of the Apostles, speaking, as it were, to the perfect apart, He says, "It is not for you to know the times or the seasons which the Father hath put in His own power".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:92
verses.text: Here He implicitly excepts Himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:93
verses.text: So much for a rough statement by way of preliminary attack.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:94
verses.text: Now let us enquire into the meaning of the text from a higher point of view.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:95
verses.text: Let me knock at the door of knowledge, if haply I may wake the Master of the house, Who gives the spiritual bread to them who ask Him, since they whom we are eager to entertain are friends and brothers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:97
verses.text: Our Saviour's holy disciples, after getting beyond the limits of human thought, and then being purified by the word, are enquiring about the end, and longing to know the ultimate blessedness which our Lord declared to be unknown to His angels and to Himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:98
verses.text: He calls all the exact comprehension of the purposes of God, a day; and the contemplation of the One-ness and Unity, knowledge of which He attributes to the Father alone, an hour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:99
verses.text: I apprehend, therefore, that God is said to know of Himself what is; and not to know what is not; God, Who is, of His own nature, very righteousness and wisdom, is said to know righteousness and wisdom; but to be ignorant of unrighteousness and wickedness; for God who created us is not unrighteousness and wickedness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:100
verses.text: If, then, God is said to know about Himself that which is, and not to know that which is not; and if our Lord, according to the purpose of the Incarnation and the denser doctrine, is not the ultimate object of desire; then our Saviour does not know the end and the ultimate blessedness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:101
verses.text: But He says the angels do not know; that is to say, not even the contemplation which is in them, nor the methods of their ministries are the ultimate object of desire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:102
verses.text: For even their knowledge, when compared with the knowledge which is face to face, is dense.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:103
verses.text: Only the Father, He says, knows, since He is Himself the end and the ultimate blessedness, for when we no longer know God in mirrors and not immediately, but approach Him as one and alone, then we shall know even the ultimate end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:104
verses.text: For all material knowledge is said to be the kingdom of Christ; while immaterial knowledge, and so to say the knowledge of actual Godhead, is that of God the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:105
verses.text: But our Lord is also Himself the end and the ultimate blessedness according to the purpose of the Word; for what does He say in the Gospel? "I will raise him up at the last day".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:106
verses.text: He calls the transition from material knowledge to immaterial contemplation a resurrection, speaking of that knowledge after which there is no other, as the last day: for our intelligence is raised up and roused to a height of blessedness at the time when it contemplates the One-ness and Unity of the Word.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:107
verses.text: But since our intelligence is made dense and bound to earth, it is both commingled with clay and incapable of gazing intently in pure contemplation, being led through adornments cognate to its own body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:108
verses.text: It considers the operations of the Creator, and judges of them meanwhile by their effects, to the end that growing little by little it may one day wax strong enough to approach even the actual unveiled Godhead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:109
verses.text: This is the meaning, I think, of the words "my Father is greater than I," and also of the statement, "It is not mine to give save to those for whom it is prepared by my Father".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:110
verses.text: This too is what is meant by Christ's "delivering up the kingdom to God even the Father;" inasmuch as according to the denser doctrine which, as I said, is regarded relatively to us and not to the Son Himself, He is not the end but the first fruits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:111
verses.text: It is in accordance with this view that when His disciples asked Him again in the Acts of the Apostles, "When wilt thou restore the kingdom of Israel?" He replied, "It is not for you to know the times or the seasons which the Father hath put in His own power".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:112
verses.text: That is to say, the knowledge of such a kingdom is not for them that are bound in flesh and blood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:113
verses.text: This contemplation the Father hath put away in His own power, meaning by "power" those that are empowered, and by "His own" those who are not held down by the ignorance of things below.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:114
verses.text: Do not, I beg you, have in mind times and seasons of sense but certain distinctions of knowledge made by the sun apprehended by mental perception.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:115
verses.text: For our Lord's prayer must be carried out.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:116
verses.text: It is Jesus Who prayed "Grant that they may be one in us as I and Thou are one, Father".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:117
verses.text: For when God, Who is one, is in each, He makes all out; and number is lost in the in-dwelling of Unity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:118
verses.text: This is my second attempt to attack the text.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:119
verses.text: If any one has a better interpretation to give, and can consistently with true religion amend what I say, let him speak and let him amend, and the Lord will reward him for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:120
verses.text: There is no jealousy in my heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:121
verses.text: I have not approached this investigation of these passages for strife and vain glory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:122
verses.text: I have done so to help my brothers, lest the earthen vessels which hold the treasure of God should seem to be deceived by stony-hearted and uncircumcised men, whose weapons are the wisdom of folly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:124
verses.text: Again, as is said through Solomon the Wise in the Proverbs, "He was created;" and He is named "Beginning of ways" of good news, which lead us to the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:125
verses.text: He is not in essence and substance a creature, but is made a "way" according to the oeconomy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:126
verses.text: Being made and being created signify the same thing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:127
verses.text: As He was made a way, so was He made a door, a shepherd, an angel, a sheep, and again a High Priest and an Apostle, the names being used in other senses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:128
verses.text: What again would the heretics say about God unsubjected, and about His being made sin for us? For it is written "But when all things shall be subdued unto Him, then shall the Son also Himself be subject unto Him that put all things under Him".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:129
verses.text: Are you not afraid, sir, of God called unsubjected? For He makes thy subjection His own; and because of thy struggling against goodness He calls himself unsubjected.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:130
verses.text: In this sense too He once spoke of Himself as persecuted—"Saul, Saul," He says, "why persecutest thou me?" on the occasion when Saul was hurrying to Damascus with a desire to imprison the disciples.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:131
verses.text: Again He calls Himself naked, when any one of his brethren is naked.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:132
verses.text: "I was naked," He says, "and ye clothed me;" and so when another is in prison He speaks of Himself as imprisoned, for He Himself took away our sins and bare our sicknesses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:133
verses.text: Now one of our infirmities is not being subject, and He bare this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:134
verses.text: So all the things which happen to us to our hurt He makes His own, taking upon Him our sufferings in His fellowship with us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:136
verses.text: But another passage is also seized by those who are fighting against God to the perversion of their hearers: I mean the words "The Son can do nothing of Himself".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:137
verses.text: To me this saying too seems distinctly declaratory of the Son's being of the same nature as the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:138
verses.text: For if every rational creature is able to do anything of himself, and the inclination which each has to the worse and to the better is in his own power, but the Son can do nothing of Himself, then the Son is not a creature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:139
verses.text: And if He is not a creature, then He is of one essence and substance with the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:140
verses.text: Again; no creature can do what he likes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:141
verses.text: But the Son does what He wills in heaven and in earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:142
verses.text: Therefore the Son is not a creature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:143
verses.text: Again; all creatures are either constituted of contraries or receptive of contraries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:144
verses.text: But the Son is very righteousness, and immaterial.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:145
verses.text: Therefore the Son is not a creature, and if He is not a creature, He is of one essence and substance with the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:147
verses.text: This examination of the passages before us is, so far as my ability goes, sufficient.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:148
verses.text: Now let us turn the discussion on those who attack the Holy Spirit, and cast down every high thing of their intellect that exalts itself against the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:149
verses.text: You say that the Holy Ghost is a creature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:150
verses.text: And every creature is a servant of the Creator, for "all are thy servants".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:151
verses.text: If then He is a servant, His holiness is acquired; and everything of which the holiness is acquired is receptive of evil; but the Holy Ghost being holy in essence is called "fount of holiness".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:152
verses.text: Therefore the Holy Ghost is not a creature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:153
verses.text: If He is not a creature, He is of one essence and substance with the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:154
verses.text: How, tell me, can you give the name of servant to Him Who through your baptism frees you from your servitude? "The law," it is said, "of the Spirit of life hath made me free from the law of sin".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:155
verses.text: But you will never venture to call His nature even variable, so long as you have regard to the nature of the opposing power of the enemy, which, like lightning, is fallen from heaven and fell out of the true life because its holiness was acquired, and its evil counsels were followed by its change.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:156
verses.text: So when it had fallen away from the Unity and had cast from it its angelic dignity, it was named after its character "Devil," its former and blessed condition being extinct and this hostile power being kindled.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:157
verses.text: Furthermore if he calls the Holy Ghost a creature he describes His nature as limited.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:158
verses.text: How then can the two following passages stand? "The Spirit of the Lord filleth the world;" and "Whither shall I go from thy Spirit?" But he does not, it would seem, confess Him to be simple in nature; for he describes Him as one in number.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:159
verses.text: And, as I have already said, everything that is one in number is not simple.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:160
verses.text: And if the Holy Spirit is not simple, He consists of essence and sanctification, and is therefore composite.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:161
verses.text: But who is mad enough to describe the Holy Spirit as composite, and not simple, and consubstantial with the Father and the Son?  11.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:162
verses.text: If we ought to advance our argument yet further, and turn our inspection to higher themes, let us contemplate the divine nature of the Holy Spirit specially from the following point of view.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:163
verses.text: In Scripture we find mention of three creations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:164
verses.text: The first is the evolution from non-being into being.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:165
verses.text: The second is change from the worse to the better.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:166
verses.text: The third is the resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:167
verses.text: In these you will find the Holy Ghost cooperating with the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:168
verses.text: There is a bringing into existence of the heavens; and what says David? "By the word of the Lord were the heavens made and all the host of them by the breath of His mouth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:169
verses.text: Again, man is created through baptism, for "if any man be in Christ he is a new creature".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:170
verses.text: And why does the Saviour say to the disciples, "Go ye therefore and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost"? Here too you see the Holy Ghost present with the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:171
verses.text: And what would you say also as to the resurrection of the dead when we shall have failed and returned to our dust? Dust we are and unto dust we shall return.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:172
verses.text: And He will send the Holy Ghost and create us and renew the face of the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:173
verses.text: For what the holy Paul calls resurrection David describes as renewal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:174
verses.text: Let us hear, once more, him who was caught into the third heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:175
verses.text: What does he say? "You are the temple of the Holy Ghost which is in you".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:176
verses.text: Now every temple is a temple of God, and if we are a temple of the Holy Ghost, then the Holy Ghost is God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:177
verses.text: It is also called Solomon's temple, but this is in the sense of his being its builder.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:178
verses.text: And if we are a temple of the Holy Ghost in this sense, then the Holy Ghost is God, for "He that built all things is God".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:179
verses.text: If we are a temple of one who is worshipped, and who dwells in us, let us confess Him to be God, for thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and Him only shalt thou serve.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:180
verses.text: Supposing them to object to the word "God," let them learn what this word means.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:181
verses.text: God is called Θεὸς either because He placed (τεθεικέναι) all things or because He beholds (Θεᾶσθαι) all things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:182
verses.text: If He is called Θεὸς because He "placed" or "beholds" all things, and the Spirit knoweth all the things of God, as the Spirit in us knoweth our things, then the Holy Ghost is God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:183
verses.text: Again, if the sword of the spirit is the word of God, then the Holy Ghost is God, inasmuch as the sword belongs to Him of whom it is also called the word.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:184
verses.text: Is He named the right hand of the Father? For "the right hand of the Lord bringeth mighty things to pass;" and "thy right hand, O Lord, hath dashed in pieces the enemy".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:185
verses.text: But the Holy Ghost is the finger of God, as it is said "if I by the finger of God cast out devils," of which the version in another Gospel is "if I by the Spirit of God cast out devils".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:186
verses.text: So the Holy Ghost is of the same nature as the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:188
verses.text: So much must suffice for the present on the subject of the adorable and holy Trinity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:189
verses.text: It is not now possible to extend the enquiry about it further.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:190
verses.text: Do ye take seeds from a humble person like me, and cultivate the ripe ear for yourselves, for, as you know, in such cases we look for interest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:191
verses.text: But I trust in God that you, because of your pure lives, will bring forth fruit thirty, sixty, and a hundred fold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:192
verses.text: For, it is said, Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:193
verses.text: And, my brethren, entertain no other conception of the kingdom of the heavens than that it is the very contemplation of realities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:194
verses.text: This the divine Scriptures call blessedness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:195
verses.text: For "the kingdom of heaven is within you".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:196
verses.text: The inner man consists of nothing but contemplation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:197
verses.text: The kingdom of the heavens, then, must be contemplation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:198
verses.text: Now we behold their shadows as in a glass; hereafter, set free from this earthly body, clad in the incorruptible and the immortal, we shall behold their archetypes, we shall see them, that is, if we have steered our own life's course aright, and if we have heeded the right faith, for otherwise none shall see the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:199
verses.text: For, it is said, into a malicious soul Wisdom shall not enter, nor dwell in the body that is subject unto sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:200
verses.text: And let no one urge in objection that, while I am ignoring what is before our eyes, I am philosophizing to them about bodiless and immaterial being.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:201
verses.text: It seems to me perfectly absurd, while the senses are allowed free action in relation to their proper matter, to exclude mind alone from its peculiar operation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:202
verses.text: Precisely in the same manner in which sense touches sensible objects, so mind apprehends the objects of mental perception.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:203
verses.text: This too must be said that God our Creator has not included natural faculties among things which can be taught.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:204
verses.text: No one teaches sight to apprehend colour or form, nor hearing to apprehend sound and speech, nor smell, pleasant and unpleasant scents, nor taste, flavours and savours, nor touch, soft and hard, hot and cold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:205
verses.text: Nor would any one teach the mind to reach objects of mental perception; and just as the senses in the case of their being in any way diseased, or injured, require only proper treatment and then readily fulfil their own functions; just so the mind, imprisoned in flesh, and full of the thoughts that arise thence, requires faith and right conversation which make "its feet like hinds' feet, and set it on its high places".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:206
verses.text: The same advice is given us by Solomon the wise, who in one passage offers us the example of the diligent worker the ant, and recommends her active life; and in another the work of the wise bee in forming its cells, and thereby suggests a natural contemplation wherein also the doctrine of the Holy Trinity is contained, if at least the Creator is considered in proportion to the beauty of the things created.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 8:207
verses.text: But with thanks to the Father, the Son and the Holy Ghost let me make an end to my letter, for, as the proverb has it, πᾶν μέτρον ἄριστον.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:1
verses.text: Letter IX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:2
verses.text: To Maximus the Philosopher.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:4
verses.text: Speech is really an image of mind: so I have learned to know you from your letters, just as the proverb tells us we may know "the lion from his claws".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:5
verses.text: I am delighted to find that your strong inclinations lie in the direction of the first and greatest of good things—love both to God and to your neighbour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:6
verses.text: Of the latter I find proof in your kindness to myself; of the former, in your zeal for knowledge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:7
verses.text: It is well known to every disciple of Christ that in these two all is contained.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:9
verses.text: You ask for the writings of Dionysius; they did indeed reach me, and a great many they were; but I have not the books with me, and so have not sent them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:10
verses.text: My opinion is, however, as follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:11
verses.text: I do not admire everything that is written; indeed of some things I totally disapprove.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:12
verses.text: For it may be, that of the impiety of which we are now hearing so much, I mean the Anomoean, it is he, as far as I know, who first gave men the seeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:13
verses.text: I do not trace his so doing to any mental depravity, but only to his earnest desire to resist Sabellius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:14
verses.text: I often compare him to a woodman trying to straighten some ill-grown sapling, pulling so immoderately in the opposite direction as to exceed the mean, and so dragging the plant awry on the other side.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:15
verses.text: This is very much what we find to be the case with Dionysius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:16
verses.text: While vehemently opposing the impiety of the Libyan, he is carried away unawares by his zeal into the opposite error.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:17
verses.text: It would have been quite sufficient for him to have pointed out that the Father and the Son are not identical in substance, and thus to score against the blasphemer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:18
verses.text: But, in order to win an unmistakable and superabundant victory, he is not satisfied with laying down a difference of hypostases, but must needs assert also difference of substance, diminution of power, and variableness of glory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:19
verses.text: So he exchanges one mischief for another, and diverges from the right line of doctrine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:20
