verses.text: In his writings he exhibits a miscellaneous inconsistency, and is at one time to be found disloyal to the homoousion, because of his opponent who made a bad use of it to the destruction of the hypostases, and at another admitting it in his Apology to his namesake.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:21
verses.text: Besides this he uttered very unbecoming words about the Spirit, separating Him from the Godhead, the object of worship, and assigning Him an inferior rank with created and subordinate nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:22
verses.text: Such is the man's character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:24
verses.text: If I must give my own view, it is this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:25
verses.text: The phrase "like in essence," if it be read with the addition "without any difference," I accept as conveying the same sense as the homoousion, in accordance with the sound meaning of the homoousion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:26
verses.text: Being of this mind the Fathers at Nicaea spoke of the Only-begotten as "Light of Light," "Very God of very God," and so on, and then consistently added the homoousion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:27
verses.text: It is impossible for any one to entertain the idea of variableness of light in relation to light, of truth in relation to truth, nor of the essence of the Only begotten in relation to that of the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:28
verses.text: If, then, the phrase be accepted in this sense, I have no objection to it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:29
verses.text: But if any one cuts off the qualification "without any difference" from the word "like," as was done at Constantinople, then I regard the phrase with suspicion, as derogatory to the dignity of the Only-begotten.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:30
verses.text: We are frequently accustomed to entertain the idea of "likeness" in the case of indistinct resemblances, coming anything but close to the originals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:31
verses.text: I am myself for the homoousion, as being less open to improper interpretation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:32
verses.text: But why, my dear sir, should you not pay me a visit, that we may talk of these high topics face to face, instead of committing them to lifeless letters,—especially when I have determined not to publish my views? And pray do not adopt, to me, the words of Diogenes to Alexander, that "it is as far from you to me as from me to you".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:33
verses.text: I am almost obliged by ill-health to remain like the plants, in one place; moreover I hold "the living unknown" to be one of the chief goods.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:34
verses.text: You, I am told, are in good health; you have made yourself a citizen of the world, and you might consider in coming to see me that you are coming home.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:35
verses.text: It is quite right for you, a man of action, to have crowds and towns in which to show your good deeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:36
verses.text: For me, quiet is the best aid for the contemplation and mental exercise whereby I cling to God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:37
verses.text: This quiet I cultivate in abundance in my retreat, with the aid of its giver, God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 9:38
verses.text: Yet if you cannot but court the great, and despise me who lie low upon the ground, then write, and in this way make my life a happier one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 10:1
verses.text: Letter X.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 10:2
verses.text: To a widow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 10:3
verses.text: The art of snaring pigeons is as follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 10:4
verses.text: When the men who devote themselves to this craft have caught one, they tame it, and make it feed with them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 10:5
verses.text: Then they smear its wings with sweet oil, and let it go and join the rest outside.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 10:6
verses.text: Then the scent of that sweet oil makes the free flock the possession of the owner of the tame bird, for all the rest are attracted by the fragrance, and settle in the house.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 10:7
verses.text: But why do I begin my letter thus? Because I have taken your son Dionysius, once Diomedes, and anointed the wings of his soul with the sweet all of God, and sent him to you that you may take flight with him, and make for the nest which he has built under my roof.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 10:8
verses.text: If I live to see this, and you, my honoured friend, translated to our lofty life, I shall require many persons worthy of God to pay Him all the honour that is His due.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 11:1
verses.text: Letter XI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 11:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 11:3
verses.text: To some friends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 11:4
verses.text: After by God's grace I had passed the sacred day with our sons, and had kept a really perfect feast to the Lord because of their exceeding love to God, I sent them in good health to your excellency, with a prayer to our loving God to give them an angel of peace to help and accompany them, and to grant them to find you in good health and assured tranquillity, to the end that wherever your lot may be cast, I to the end of my days, whenever I hear news of you, may be gladdened to think of you as serving and giving thanks to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 11:5
verses.text: If God should grant you to be quickly freed from these cares I beg you to let nothing stand in the way of your coming to stay with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 11:6
verses.text: I think you will find none to love you so well, or to make more of your friendship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 11:7
verses.text: So long, then, as the Holy One ordains this separation, be sure that you never lose an opportunity of comforting me by a letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 12:1
verses.text: Letter XII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 12:2
verses.text: To Olympius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 12:3
verses.text: Before you did write me a few words: now not even a few.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 12:4
verses.text: Your brevity will soon become silence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 12:5
verses.text: Return to your old ways, and do not let me have to scold you for your laconic behaviour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 12:6
verses.text: But I shall be glad even of a little letter in token of your great love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 12:7
verses.text: Only write to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 13:1
verses.text: Letter XIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 13:2
verses.text: To Olympius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 13:3
verses.text: As all the fruits of the season come to us in their proper time, flowers in spring, corn in summer, and apples in autumn, so the fruit for winter is talk.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:1
verses.text: Letter XIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:2
verses.text: To Gregory his friend.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:3
verses.text: My brother Gregory writes me word that he has long been wishing to be with me, and adds that you are of the same mind; however, I could not wait, partly as being hard of belief, considering I have been so often disappointed, and partly because I find myself pulled all ways by business.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:4
verses.text: I must at once make for Pontus, where, perhaps, God willing, I may make an end of wandering.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:5
verses.text: After renouncing, with trouble, the idle hopes which I once had, [about you] or rather the dreams, (for it is well said that hopes are waking dreams), I departed into Pontus in quest of a place to live in.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:6
verses.text: There God has opened on me a spot exactly answering to my taste, so that I actually see before my eyes what I have often pictured to my mind in idle fancy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:7
verses.text: There is a lofty mountain covered with thick woods, watered towards the north with cool and transparent streams.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:8
verses.text: A plain lies beneath, enriched by the waters which are ever draining off from it; and skirted by a spontaneous profusion of trees almost thick enough to be a fence; so as even to surpass Calypso's Island, which Homer seems to have considered the most beautiful spot on the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:9
verses.text: Indeed it is like an island, enclosed as it is on all sides; for deep hollows cut off two sides of it; the river, which has lately fallen down a precipice, runs all along the front and is impassable as a wall; while the mountain extending itself behind, and meeting the hollows in a crescent, stops up the path at its roots.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:10
verses.text: There is but one pass, and I am master of it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:11
verses.text: Behind my abode there is another gorge, rising into a ledge up above, so as to command the extent of the plains and the stream which bounds it, which is not less beautiful, to my taste, than the Strymon as seen from Amphipolis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:12
verses.text: For while the latter flows leisurely, and swells into a lake almost, and is too still to be a river, the former is the most rapid stream I know, and somewhat turbid, too, from the rocks just above; from which, shooting down, and eddying in a deep pool, it forms a most pleasant scene for myself or any one else; and is an inexhaustible resource to the country people, in the countless fish which its depths contain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:13
verses.text: What need to tell of the exhalations from the earth, or the breezes from the river? Another might admire the multitude of flowers, and singing birds; but leisure I have none for such thoughts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:14
verses.text: However, the chief praise of the place is, that being happily disposed for produce of every kind, it nurtures what to me is the sweetest produce of all, quietness; indeed, it is not only rid of the bustle of the city, but is even unfrequented by travellers, except a chance hunter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:15
verses.text: It abounds indeed in game, as well as other things, but not, I am glad to say, in bears or wolves, such as you have, but in deer, and wild goats, and hares, and the like.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 14:16
verses.text: Does it not strike you what a foolish mistake I was near making when I was eager to change this spot for your Tiberina, the very pit of the whole earth?  Pardon me, then, if I am now set upon it; for not Alcmaeon himself, I suppose, could endure to wander further when he had found the Echinades.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 15:1
verses.text: Letter XV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 15:2
verses.text: To Arcadius, Imperial Treasurer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 15:3
verses.text: The townsmen of our metropolis have conferred on me a greater favour than they have received, in giving me an opportunity of writing to your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 15:4
verses.text: The kindness, to win which they have received this letter from me, was assured them even before I wrote, on account of your wonted and inborn courtesy to all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 15:5
verses.text: But I have considered it a very great advantage to have the opportunity of addressing your excellency, praying to the holy God that I may continue to rejoice, and share in the pleasure of the recipients of your bounty, while you please Him more and more, and while the splendour of your high place continues to increase.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 15:6
verses.text: I pray that in due time I may with joy once more welcome those who are delivering this my letter into your hands, and send them forth praising, as do many, your considerate treatment of them, and I trust that they will have found my recommendation of them not without use in approaching your exalted excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 16:1
verses.text: Letter XVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 16:2
verses.text: Against Eunomius the heretic.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 16:3
verses.text: He who maintains that it is possible to arrive at the discovery of things actually existing, has no doubt by some orderly method advanced his intelligence by means of the knowledge of actually existing things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 16:4
verses.text: It is after first training himself by the apprehension of small and easily comprehensible objects, that he brings his apprehensive faculty to bear on what is beyond all intelligence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 16:5
verses.text: He makes his boast that he has really arrived at the comprehension of actual existences; let him then explain to us the nature of the least of visible beings; let him tell us all about the ant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 16:6
verses.text: Does its life depend on breath and breathing? Has it a skeleton? Is its body connected by sinews and ligaments? Are its sinews surrounded with muscles and glands? Does its marrow go with dorsal vertebrae from brow to tail? Does it give impulse to its moving members by the enveloping nervous membrane? Has it a liver, with a gall bladder near the liver? Has it kidneys, heart, arteries, veins, membranes, cartilages? Is it hairy or hairless? Has it an uncloven hoof, or are its feet divided? How long does it live? What is its mode of reproduction? What is its period of gestation? How is it that ants neither all walk nor all fly, but some belong to creeping things, and some travel through the air? The man who glories in his knowledge of the really-existing ought to tell us in the meanwhile about the nature of the ant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 16:7
verses.text: Next let him give us a similar physiological account of the power that transcends all human intelligence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 16:8
verses.text: But if your knowledge has not yet been able to apprehend the nature of the insignificant ant, how can you boast yourself able to form a conception of the power of the incomprehensible God?.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 17:1
verses.text: Letter XVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 17:2
verses.text: To Origenes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 17:3
verses.text: It is delightful to listen to you, and delightful to read you; and I think you give me the greater pleasure by your writings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 17:4
verses.text: All thanks to our good God Who has not suffered the truth to suffer in consequence of its betrayal by the chief powers in the State, but by your means has made the defence of the doctrine of true religion full and satisfactory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 17:5
verses.text: Like hemlock, monkshood, and other poisonous herbs, after they have bloomed for a little while, they will quickly wither away.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 17:6
verses.text: But the reward which the Lord will give you in requital of all that you have said in defence of His name blooms afresh for ever.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 17:7
verses.text: Wherefore I pray God grant you all happiness in your home, and make His blessing descend to your sons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 17:8
verses.text: I was delighted to see and embrace those noble boys, express images of your excellent goodness, and my prayers for them ask all that their father can ask.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 18:1
verses.text: Letter XVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 18:2
verses.text: To Macarius and John.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 18:3
verses.text: The labours of the field come as no novelty to tillers of the land; sailors are not astonished if they meet a storm at sea; sweats in the summer heat are the common experience of the hired hind; and to them that have chosen to live a holy life the afflictions of this present world cannot come unforeseen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 18:4
verses.text: Each and all of these have the known and proper labour of their callings, not chosen for its own sake, but for the sake of the enjoyment of the good things to which they look forward.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 18:5
verses.text: What in each of these cases acts as a consolation in trouble is that which really forms the bond and link of all human life,—hope.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 18:6
verses.text: Now of them that labour for the fruits of the earth, or for earthly things, some enjoy only in imagination what they have looked for, and are altogether disappointed; and even in the case of others, where the issue has answered expectation, another hope is soon needed, so quickly has the first fled and faded out of sight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 18:7
verses.text: Only of them that labour for holiness and truth are the hopes destroyed by no deception; no issue can destroy their labours, for the kingdom of the heavens that awaits them is firm and sure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 18:8
verses.text: So long then as the word of truth is on our side, never be in any wise distressed at the calumny of a lie; let no imperial threats scare you; do not be grieved at the laughter and mockery of your intimates, nor at the condemnation of those who pretend to care for you, and who put forward, as their most attractive bait to deceive, a pretence of giving good advice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 18:9
verses.text: Against them all let sound reason do battle, invoking the championship and succour of our Lord Jesus Christ, the teacher of true religion, for Whom to suffer is sweet, and "to die is gain".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 19:1
verses.text: Letter XIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 19:2
verses.text: To Gregory my friend.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 19:3
verses.text: I received a letter from you the day before yesterday.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 19:4
verses.text: It is shewn to be yours not so much by the handwriting as by the peculiar style.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 19:5
verses.text: Much meaning is expressed in few words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 19:6
verses.text: I did not reply on the spot, because I was away from home, and the letter-carrier, after he had delivered the packet to one of my friends, went away.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 19:7
verses.text: Now, however, I am able to address you through Peter, and at the same time both to return your greeting, and give you an opportunity for another letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 19:8
verses.text: There is certainly no trouble in writing a laconic dispatch like those which reach me from you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:1
verses.text: Letter XX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:2
verses.text: To Leontius the Sophist.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:3
verses.text: I too do not write often to you, but not more seldom than you do to me, though many have travelled hitherward from your part of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:4
verses.text: If you had sent a letter by every one of them, one after the other, there would have been nothing to prevent my seeming to be actually in your company, and enjoying it as though we had been together, so uninterrupted has been the stream of arrivals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:5
verses.text: But why do you not write? It is no trouble to a Sophist to write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:6
verses.text: Nay, if your hand is tired, you need not even write; another will do that for you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:7
verses.text: Only your tongue is needed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:8
verses.text: And though it does not speak to me, it may assuredly speak to one of your companions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:9
verses.text: If nobody is with you, it will talk by itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:10
verses.text: Certainly the tongue of a Sophist and of an Athenian is as little likely to be quiet as the nightingales when the spring stirs them to song.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:11
verses.text: In my own case, the mass of business in which I am now engaged may perhaps afford some excuse for my lack of letters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:12
verses.text: And peradventure the fact of my style having been spoilt by constant familiarity with common speech may make me somewhat hesitate to address Sophists like you, who are certain to be annoyed and unmerciful, unless you hear something worthy of your wisdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:13
verses.text: You, on the other hand, ought assuredly to use every opportunity of making your voice heard abroad, for you are the best speaker of all the Hellenes that I know; and I think I know the most renowned among you; so that there really is no excuse for your silence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:14
verses.text: But enough on this point.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:15
verses.text: I have sent you my writings against Eunomius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:16
verses.text: Whether they are to be called child's play, or something a little more serious, I leave you to judge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:17
verses.text: So far as concerns yourself, I do not think you stand any longer in need of them; but I hope they will be no unworthy weapon against any perverse men with whom you may fall in.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:18
verses.text: I do not say this so much because I have confidence in the force of my treatise, as because I know well that you are a man likely to make a little go a long way.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:19
verses.text: If anything strikes you as weaker than it ought to be, pray have no hesitation in showing me the error.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 20:20
verses.text: The chief difference between a friend and a flatterer is this; the flatterer speaks to please, the friend will not leave out even what is disagreeable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:1
verses.text: Letter XXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:2
verses.text: To Leontius the Sophist.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:3
verses.text: The excellent Julianus seems to get some good for his private affairs out of the general condition of things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:4
verses.text: Everything nowadays is full of taxes demanded and called in, and he too is vehemently dunned and indicted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:5
verses.text: Only it is a question not of arrears of rates and taxes, but of letters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:6
verses.text: But how he comes to be a defaulter I do not know.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:7
verses.text: He has always paid a letter, and received a letter—as he has this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:8
verses.text: But possibly you have a preference for the famous "four-times-as-much".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:9
verses.text: For even the Pythagoreans were not so fond of their Tetractys, as these modern tax-collectors of their "four-times-as-much".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:10
verses.text: Yet perhaps the fairer thing would have been just the opposite, that a Sophist like you, so very well furnished with words, should be bound in pledge to me for "four-times-as-much".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:11
verses.text: But do not suppose for a moment that I am writing all this out of ill-humour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:12
verses.text: I am only too pleased to get even a scolding from you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:13
verses.text: The good and beautiful do everything, it is said, with the addition of goodness and beauty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:14
verses.text: Even grief and anger in them are becoming.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:15
verses.text: At all events any one would rather see his friend angry with him than any one else flattering him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 21:16
verses.text: Do not then cease preferring charges like the last! The very charge will mean a letter; and nothing can be more precious or delightful to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:1
verses.text: Letter XXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:3
verses.text: On the Perfection of the Life of Solitaries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:5
verses.text: Many things are set forth by inspired Scripture as binding upon all who are anxious to please God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:6
verses.text: But, for the present, I have only deemed it necessary to speak by way of brief reminder concerning the questions which have recently been stirred among you, so far as I have learnt from the study of inspired Scripture itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:7
verses.text: I shall thus leave behind me detailed evidence, easy of apprehension, for the information of industrious students, who in their turn will be able to inform others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:8
verses.text: The Christian ought to be so minded as becomes his heavenly calling, and his life and conversation ought to be worthy of the Gospel of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:9
verses.text: The Christian ought not to be of doubtful mind, nor by anything drawn away from the recollection of God and of His purposes and judgments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:10
verses.text: The Christian ought in all things to become superior to the righteousness existing under the law, and neither swear nor lie.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:11
verses.text: He ought not to speak evil; to do violence; to fight; to avenge himself; to return evil for evil; to be angry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:12
verses.text: The Christian ought to be patient, whatever he have to suffer, and to convict the wrong-doer in season, not with the desire of his own vindication, but of his brother's reformation, according to the commandment of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:13
verses.text: The Christian ought not to say anything behind his brother's back with the object of calumniating him, for this is slander, even if what is said is true.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:14
verses.text: He ought to turn away from the brother who speaks evil against him; he ought not to indulge in jesting; he ought not to laugh nor even to suffer laugh makers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:15
verses.text: He must not talk idly, saying things which are of no service to the hearers nor to such usage as is necessary and permitted us by God; so that workers may do their best as far as possible to work in silence; and that good words be suggested to them by those who are entrusted with the duty of carefully dispensing the word to the building up of the faith, lest God's Holy Spirit be grieved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:16
verses.text: Any one who comes in ought not to be able, of his own free will, to accost or speak to any of the brothers, before those to whom the responsibility of general discipline is committed have approved of it as pleasing to God, with a view to the common good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:17
verses.text: The Christian ought not to be enslaved by wine; nor to be eager for flesh meat, and as a general rule ought not to be a lover of pleasure in eating or drinking, "for every man that striveth for the mastery is temperate in all things".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:18
verses.text: The Christian ought to regard all the things that are given him for his use, not as his to hold as his own or to lay up; and, giving careful heed to all things as the Lord's, not to overlook any of the things that are being thrown aside and disregarded, should this be the case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:19
verses.text: No Christian ought to think of himself as his own master, but each should rather so think and act as though given by God to be slave to his like minded brethren; but "every man in his own order".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:21
verses.text: The Christian ought never to murmur either in scarcity of necessities, or in toil or labour, for the responsibility in these matters lies with such as have authority in them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:22
verses.text: There never ought to be any clamour, or any behaviour or agitation by which anger is expressed, or diversion of mind from the full assurance of the presence of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:23
verses.text: The voice should be modulated; no one ought to answer another, or do anything, roughly or contemptuously, but in all things moderation and respect should be shewn to every one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:24
verses.text: No wily glances of the eye are to be allowed, nor any behaviour or gestures which grieve a brother and shew contempt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:25
verses.text: Any display in cloak or shoes is to be avoided; it is idle ostentation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:26
verses.text: Cheap things ought to be used for bodily necessity; and nothing ought to be spent beyond what is necessary, or for mere extravagance; this is a misuse of our property.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:27
verses.text: The Christian ought not to seek for honour, or claim precedence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:28
verses.text: Every one ought to put all others before himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:29
verses.text: The Christian ought not to be unruly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:30
verses.text: He who is able to work ought not to eat the bread of idleness, but even he who is busied in deeds well done for the glory of Christ ought to force himself to the active discharge of such work as he can do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:31
verses.text: Every Christian, with the approval of his superiors, ought so to do everything with reason and assurance, even down to actual eating and drinking, as done to the glory of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:32
verses.text: The Christian ought not to change over from one work to another without the approval of those who are appointed for the arrangement of such matters; unless some unavoidable necessity suddenly summon any one to the relief of the helpless.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:33
verses.text: Every one ought to remain in his appointed post, not to go beyond his own bounds and intrude into what is not commanded him, unless the responsible authorities judge any one to be in need of aid.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:34
verses.text: No one ought to be found going from one workshop to another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:35
verses.text: Nothing ought to be done in rivalry or strife with any one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:37
verses.text: The Christian ought not to grudge another's reputation, nor rejoice over any man's faults; he ought in Christ's love to grieve and be afflicted at his brother's faults, and rejoice over his brother's good deeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:38
verses.text: He ought not to be indifferent or silent before sinners.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:39
verses.text: He who shows another to be wrong ought to do so with all tenderness, in the fear of God, and with the object of converting the sinner.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:40
verses.text: He who is proved wrong or rebuked ought to take it willingly, recognizing his own gain in being set right.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:41
verses.text: When any one is being accused, it is not right for another, before him or any one else, to contradict the accuser; but if at any time the charge seems groundless to any one, he ought privately to enter into discussion with the accuser, and either produce, or acquire, conviction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:42
verses.text: Every one ought, as far as he is able, to conciliate one who has ground of complaint against him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:43
verses.text: No one ought to cherish a grudge against the sinner who repents, but heartily to forgive him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:44
verses.text: He who says that he has repented of a sin ought not only to be pricked with compunction for his sin, but also to bring forth fruits worthy of repentance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:45
verses.text: He who has been corrected in first faults, and received pardon, if he sins again prepares for himself a judgment of wrath worse than the former.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:46
verses.text: He, who after the first and second admonition abides in his fault, ought to be brought before the person in authority, if haply after being rebuked by more he may be ashamed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:47
verses.text: If even thus he fail to be set right he is to be cut off from the rest as one that maketh to offend, and regarded as a heathen and a publican, for the security of them that are obedient, according to the saying, When the impious fall the righteous tremble.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:48
verses.text: He should be grieved over as a limb cut from the body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:49
verses.text: The sun ought not to go down upon a brother's wrath, lest haply night come between brother and brother, and make the charge stand in the day of judgment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:50
verses.text: A Christian ought not to wait for an opportunity for his own amendment, because there is no certainty about the morrow; for many after many devices have not reached the morrow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:51
verses.text: He ought not to be beguiled by over eating, whence come dreams in the night.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:52
verses.text: He ought not to be distracted by immoderate toil, nor overstep the bounds of sufficiency, as the apostle says, "Having food and raiment let us be therewith content;" unnecessary abundance gives appearance of covetousness, and covetousness is condemned as idolatry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:53
verses.text: A Christian ought not to be a lover of money, nor lay up treasure for unprofitable ends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:54
verses.text: He who comes to God ought to embrace poverty in all things, and to be riveted in the fear of God, according to the words, "Rivet my flesh in thy fear, for I am afraid of thy judgments".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 22:55
verses.text: The Lord grant that you may receive what I have said with full conviction and shew forth fruits worthy of the Spirit to the glory of God, by God's good pleasure, and the cooperation of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 23:1
verses.text: Letter XXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 23:2
verses.text: To a Solitary.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 23:3
verses.text: A certain man, as he says, on condemning the vanity of this life, and perceiving that its joys are ended here, since they only provide material for eternal fire and then quickly pass away, has come to me with the desire of separating from this wicked and miserable life, of abandoning the pleasures of the flesh, and of treading for the future a road which leads to the mansions of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 23:4
verses.text: Now if he is sincerely firm in his truly blessed purpose, and has in his soul the glorious and laudable passion, loving the Lord his God with all his heart, with all his strength, and with all his mind, it is necessary for your reverence to show him the difficulties and distresses of the strait and narrow way, and establish him in the hope of the good things which are as yet unseen, but are laid up in promise for all that are worthy of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 23:5
verses.text: I therefore write to entreat your incomparable perfection in Christ, if it be possible to mould his character, and, without me, to bring about his renunciation according to what is pleasing to God, and to see that he receive elementary instruction in accordance with what has been decided by the Holy Fathers, and put forth by them in writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 23:6
verses.text: See too that he have put before him all things that are essential to ascetic discipline, and that so he may be introduced to the life, after having accepted, of his own accord, the labours undergone for religion's sake, subjected himself to the Lord's easy yoke, adopted a conversation in imitation of Him Who for our sakes became poor and took flesh, and may run without fail to the prize of his high calling, and receive the approbation of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 23:7
verses.text: He is wishful to receive here the crown of God's loves, but I have put him off, because I wish, in conjunction with your reverence, to anoint him for such struggles, and to appoint over him one of your number whom he may select to be his trainer, training him nobly, and making him by his constant and blessed care a tried wrestler, wounding and overthrowing the prince of the darkness of this world, and the spiritual powers of iniquity, with whom, as the blessed Apostle says, is "our wrestling".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 23:8
verses.text: What I wish to do in conjunction with you, let your love in Christ do without me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:1
verses.text: Letter XXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:2
verses.text: To Athanasius, father of Athanasius bishop of Ancyra.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:3
verses.text: That one of the things hardest to achieve, if indeed it be not impossible, is to rise superior to calumny, I am myself fully persuaded, and so too, I presume, is your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:4
verses.text: Yet not to give a handle by one's own conduct, either to inquisitive critics of society, or to mischief makers who lie in wait to catch us tripping, is not only possible, but is the special characteristic of all who order their lives wisely and according to the rule of true religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:5
verses.text: And do not think me so simple and credulous as to accept depreciatory remarks from any one without due investigation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:6
verses.text: I bear in mind the admonition of the Spirit, "Thou shalt not receive a false report".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:7
verses.text: But you, learned men, yourselves say that "The seen is significant of the unseen".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:8
verses.text: I therefore beg;—(and pray do not take it ill if I seem to be speaking as though I were giving a lesson; for "God has chosen the weak" and "despised things of the world," and often by their means brings about the salvation of such as are being saved); what I say and urge is this; that by word and deed we act with scrupulous attention to propriety, and, in accordance with the apostolic precept, "give no offence in anything".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:9
verses.text: The life of one who has toiled hard in the acquisition of knowledge, who has governed cities and states, and who is jealous of the high character of his forefathers, ought to be an example of high character itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:10
verses.text: You ought not now to be exhibiting your disposition towards your children in word only, as you have long exhibited its ever since you became a father; you ought not only to shew that natural affection which is shewn by brutes, as you yourself have said, and as experience shews.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:11
verses.text: You ought to make your love go further, and be a love all the more personal and voluntary in that you see your children worthy of a father's prayers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:12
verses.text: On this point I do not need to be convinced.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:13
verses.text: The evidence of facts is enough.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:14
verses.text: One thing, however, I will say for truth's sake, that it is not our brother Timotheus, the Chorepiscopus, who has brought me word of what is noised abroad.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:15
verses.text: For neither by word of mouth nor by letter has he ever conveyed anything in the shape of slander, be it small or great.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:16
verses.text: That I have heard something I do not deny, but it is not Timotheus who accuses you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 24:17
verses.text: Yet while I hear whatever I do, at least I will follow the example of Alexander, and will keep one ear clear for the accused.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:1
verses.text: Letter XXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:2
verses.text: To Athanasius, bishop of Ancyra.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:4
verses.text: I have received intelligence from those who come to me from Ancyra, and they are many and more than I can count, but they all agree in what they say, that you, a man very dear to me, (how can I speak so as to give no offence?) do not mention me in very pleasant terms, nor yet in such as your character would lead me to expect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:5
verses.text: I, however, learned long ago the weakness of human nature, and its readiness to turn from one extreme to another; and so, be well assured, nothing connected with it can astonish me, nor does any change come quite unexpected.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:6
verses.text: Therefore that my lot should have changed for the worse, and that reproaches and insults should have arisen in the place of former respect, I do not make much ado.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:7
verses.text: But one thing does really strike me as astonishing and monstrous, and that is that it should be you who have this mind about me, and go so far as to feel anger and indignation against me, and, if the report of your hearers is to be believed, have already proceeded to such extremities as to utter threats.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:8
verses.text: At these threats, I will not deny, I really have laughed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:9
verses.text: Truly I should have been but a boy to be frightened at such bugbears.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:10
verses.text: But it does seem to me alarming and distressing that you, who, as I have trusted, are preserved for the comfort of the churches, a buttress of the truth where many fall away, and a seed of the ancient and true love, should so far fall in with the present course of events as to be more influenced by the calumny of the first man you come across than by your long knowledge of me, and, without any proof, should be seduced into suspecting absurdities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:12
verses.text: But, as I said, for the present I postpone the case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:13
verses.text: Would it have been too hard a task, my dear sir, to discuss in a short letter, as between friend and friend, points which you wish to raise; or, if you objected to entrusting such things to writing, to get me to come to you? But if you could not help speaking out, and your uncontrollable anger allowed no time for delay, at least you might have employed one of those about you who are naturally adapted for dealing with confidential matters, as a means of communication with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:14
verses.text: But now, of all those who for one reason or another approach you, into whose ears has it not been dinned that I am a writer and composer of certain "pests"? For this is the word which those, who quote you word for word, say that you have used.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:15
verses.text: The more I bring my mind to bear upon the matter the more hopeless is my puzzle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:16
verses.text: This idea has struck me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:17
verses.text: Can any heretic have grieved your orthodoxy, and driven you to the utterance of that word by malevolently putting my name to his own writings? For you, a man who has sustained great and famous contests on behalf of the truth, could never have endured to inflict such an outrage on what I am well known to have written against those who dare to say that God the Son is in essence unlike God the Father, or who blasphemously describe the Holy Ghost as created and made.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 25:18
verses.text: You might relieve me from my difficulty yourself, if you would tell me plainly what it is that has stirred you to be thus offended with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:1
verses.text: Letter XXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:2
verses.text: To Caesarius, brother of Gregory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:3
verses.text: Thanks to God for shewing forth His wonderful power in your person, and for preserving you to your country and to us your friends, from so terrible a death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:4
verses.text: It remains for us not to be ungrateful, nor unworthy of so great a kindness, but, to the best of our ability, to narrate the marvellous works of God, to celebrate by deed the kindness which we have experienced, and not return thanks by word only.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:5
verses.text: We ought to become in very deed what I, grounding my belief on the miracles wrought in you, am persuaded that you now are.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:6
verses.text: We exhort you still more to serve God, ever increasing your fear more and more, and advancing on to perfection, that we may be made wise stewards of our life, for which the goodness of God has reserved us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:7
verses.text: For if it is a command to all of us "to yield ourselves unto God as those that are alive from the dead," how much more strongly is not this commanded them who have been lifted up from the gates of death? And this, I believe, would be best effected, did we but desire ever to keep the same mind in which we were at the moment of our perils.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:8
verses.text: For, I ween, the vanity of our life came before us, and we felt that all that belongs to man, exposed as it is to vicissitudes, has about it nothing sure, nothing firm.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:9
verses.text: We felt, as was likely, repentance for the past; and we gave a promise for the future, if we were saved, to serve God and give careful heed to ourselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:10
verses.text: If the imminent peril of death gave me any cause for reflection, I think that you must have been moved by the same or nearly the same thoughts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:11
verses.text: We are therefore bound to pay a binding debt, at once joyous at God's good gift to us, and, at the same time, anxious about the future.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:12
verses.text: I have ventured to make these suggestions to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 26:13
verses.text: It is yours to receive what I say well and kindly, as you were wont to do when we talked together face to face.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 27:1
verses.text: Letter XXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 27:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 27:3
verses.text: When by God's grace, and the aid of your prayers, I had seemed to be somewhat recovering from my sickness, and had got my strength again, then came winter, keeping me a prisoner at home, and compelling me to remain where I was.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 27:4
verses.text: True, its severity was much less than usual, but this was quite enough to keep me not merely from travelling while it lasted, but even from so much as venturing to put my head out of doors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 27:5
verses.text: But to me it is no slight thing to be permitted, if only by letter, to communicate with your reverence, and to rest tranquil in the hope of your reply.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 27:6
verses.text: However, should the season permit, and further length of life be allowed me, and should the dearth not prevent me from undertaking the journey, peradventure through the aid of your prayers I may be able to fulfil my earnest wish, may find you at your own fireside, and, with abundant leisure, may take my fill of your vast treasures of wisdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:1
verses.text: Letter XXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:2
verses.text: To the Church of Neocaesarea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:3
verses.text: Consolatory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:5
verses.text: What has befallen you strongly moved me to visit you, with the double object of joining with you, who are near and dear to me, in paying all respect to the blessed dead, and of being more closely associated with you in your trouble by seeing your sorrow with my own eyes, and so being able to take counsel with you as to what is to be done.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:6
verses.text: But many causes hinder my being able to approach you in person, and it remains for me to communicate with you in writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:7
verses.text: The admirable qualities of the departed, on account of which we chiefly estimate the greatness of our loss, are indeed too many to be enumerated in a letter; and it is, besides, no time to be discussing the multitude of his good deeds, when our spirits are thus prostrated with grief.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:8
verses.text: For of all that he did, what can we ever forget? What could we deem deserving of silence? To tell all at once were impossible; to tell a part would, I fear, involve disloyalty to the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:9
verses.text: A man has passed away who surpassed all his contemporaries in all the good things that are within man's reach; a prop of his country; an ornament of the churches; a pillar and support of the truth; a stay of the faith of Christ; a protector of his friends; a stout foe of his opponents; a guardian of the principles of his fathers; an enemy of innovation; exhibiting in himself the ancient fashion of the Church, and making the state of the Church put under him conform to the ancient constitution, as to a sacred model, so that all who lived with him seemed to live in the society of them that used to shine like lights in the world two hundred years ago and more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:10
verses.text: So your bishop put forth nothing of his own, no novel invention; but, as the blessing of Moses has it, he knew how to bring out of the secret and good stores of his heart, "old store, and the old because of the new".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:11
verses.text: Thus it came about that in meetings of his fellow bishops he was not ranked according to his age, but, by reason of the old age of his wisdom, he was unanimously conceded precedence over all the rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:12
verses.text: And no one who looks at your condition need go far to seek the advantages of such a course of training.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:13
verses.text: For, so far as I know, you alone, or, at all events, you and but very few others, in the midst of such a storm and whirlwind of affairs, were able under his good guidance to live your lives unshaken by the waves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:14
verses.text: You were never reached by heretics' buffering blasts, which bring shipwreck and drowning on unstable souls; and that you may for ever live beyond their reach I pray the Lord who ruleth over all, and who granted long tranquillity to Gregory His servant, the first founder of your church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:15
verses.text: Do not lose that tranquillity now; do not, by extravagant lamentation, and by entirely giving yourself up to grief, put the opportunity for action into the hands of those who are plotting your bane.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:16
verses.text: If lament you must, (which I do not allow, lest you be in this respect like "them which have no hope,") do you, if so it seem good to you, like some wading chorus, choose your leader, and raise with him a chant of tears.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:18
verses.text: And yet, if he whom you mourn had not reached extreme old age, certainly, as regards his government of your church, he was allowed no narrow limit of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:19
verses.text: He had as much strength of body as enabled him to show strength of mind in his distresses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:20
verses.text: Perhaps some of you may suppose that time increases sympathy and adds affection, and is no cause of satiety, so that, the longer you have experienced kind treatment, the more sensible you are of its loss.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:21
verses.text: You may think that of a righteous person the good hold even the shadow in honour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:22
verses.text: Would that many of you did feel so! Far be it from me to suggest anything like disregard of our friend! But I do counsel you to bear your pain with manly endurance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:23
verses.text: I myself am by no means insensible of all that may be said by those who are weeping for their loss.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:24
verses.text: Hushed is a tongue whose words flooded our ears like a mighty stream: a depth of heart, never fathomed before, has fled, humanly speaking, like an unsubstantial dream.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:25
verses.text: Whose glance so keen as his to look into the future? Who with like fixity and strength of mind able to dart like lightning into the midst of action? O Neocaesarea, already a prey to many troubles, never before smitten with so deadly a loss! Now withered is the bloom of you, beauty; your church is dumb; your assemblies are full of mournful faces; your sacred synod craves for its leader; your holy utterances wait for an expounder; your boys have lost a father, your elders a brother, your nobles one first among them, your people a champion, your poor a supporter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:26
verses.text: All, calling him by the name that comes most nearly home to each, lift up the wailing cry which to each man's own sorrow seems most appropriate and fit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:27
verses.text: But whither are my words carried away by my tearful joy? Shall we not watch? Shall we not meet together? Shall we not look to our common Lord, Who suffers each of his saints to serve his own generation, and summons him back to Himself at His own appointed time? Now in season remember the voice of him who when preaching to you used always to say "Beware of dogs, beware of evil workers".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:28
verses.text: The dogs are many.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:29
verses.text: Why do I say dogs? Rather grievous wolves, hiding their guile under the guise of sheep, are, all over the world, tearing Christ's flock.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:30
verses.text: Of these you must beware, under the protection of some wakeful bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:31
verses.text: Such an one it is yours to ask, purging your souls of all rivalry and ambition: such an one it is the Lord's to show you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:32
verses.text: That Lord, from the time of Gregory the great champion of your church down to that of the blessed departed, setting over you one after another, and from time to time fitting one to another like gem set close to gem, has bestowed on you glorious ornaments for your church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:33
verses.text: You have, then, no need to despair of them that are to come.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:34
verses.text: The Lord knoweth who are His.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:35
verses.text: He may bring into our midst those for whom peradventure we are not looking.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:37
verses.text: I meant to have come to an end long before this, but the pain at my heart does not allow me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:38
verses.text: Now I charge you by the Fathers, by the true faith, by our blessed friend, lift up your souls, each man making what is being done his own immediate business, each reckoning that he will be the first to reap the consequences of the issue, whichever way it turn out, lest your fate be that which so very frequently befalls, every one leaving to his neighbour the common interests of all; and then, while each one makes little in his own mind of what is going on, all of you unwittingly draw your own proper misfortunes on yourselves by your neglect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:39
verses.text: Take, I beg you, what I say with all kindliness, whether it be regarded as an expression of the sympathy of a neighbour, or as fellowship between fellow believers, or, which is really nearer the truth, of one who obeys the law of love, and shrinks from the risk of silence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:40
verses.text: I am persuaded that you are my boasting, as I am yours, till the day of the Lord, and that it depends upon the pastor who will be granted you whether I shall be more closely united to you by the bond of love, or wholly severed from you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:41
verses.text: This latter God forbid.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:42
verses.text: By God's grace it will not so be; and I should be sorry now to say one ungracious word.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:43
verses.text: But this I do wish you to know, that though I had not that blessed man always at my side, in my efforts for the peace of the churches, because, as he himself affirmed, of certain prejudices, yet, nevertheless, at no time did I fail in unity of opinion with him, and I have always invoked his aid in my struggles against the heretics.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 28:44
verses.text: Of this I call to witness God and all who know me best.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:1
verses.text: Letter XXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:2
verses.text: To the Church of Ancyra.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:3
verses.text: Consolatory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:4
verses.text: My amazement at the most distressing news of the calamity which has befallen you for a long time kept me silent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:5
verses.text: I felt like a man whose ears are stunned by a loud clap of thunder.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:6
verses.text: Then I somehow recovered a little from my state of speechlessness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:7
verses.text: Now I have mourned, as none could help mourning, over the event, and, in the midst of my lamentations, have sent you this letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:8
verses.text: I write not so much to console you,—for who could find words to cure a calamity so great?—as to signify to you, as well as I can by these means, the agony of my own heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:9
verses.text: I need now the lamentations of Jeremiah, or of any other of the Saints who has feelingly lamented a great woe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:10
verses.text: A man has fallen who was really a pillar and stay of the Church or rather he himself has been taken from us and is gone to the blessed life, and there is no small danger lest many at the removal of this prop from under them fall too, and lest some men's unsoundness be brought to light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:11
verses.text: A mouth is sealed gushing with righteous eloquence and words of grace to the edification of the brotherhood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:12
verses.text: Gone are the counsels of a mind which truly moved in God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:13
verses.text: Ah! how often, for I must accuse myself, was it my lot to feel indignation against him, because, wholly desiring to depart and be with Christ, he did not prefer for our sakes to remain in the flesh! To whom for the future shall I commit the cares of the Churches? Whom shall I take to share my troubles? Whom to participate in my gladness? O loneliness terrible and sad! How am I not like to a pelican of the wilderness? Yet of a truth the members of the Church, united by his leadership as by one soul, and fitted together into close union of feeling and fellowship, are both preserved and shall ever be preserved by the bond of peace for spiritual communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:14
verses.text: God grants us the boon, that all the works of that blessed soul, which he did nobly in the churches of God, abide firm and immovable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 29:15
verses.text: But the struggle is no slight one, lest, once more strifes and divisions arising over the choice of the bishop, all your work be upset by some quarrel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:1
verses.text: Letter XXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:2
verses.text: To Eusebius of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:3
verses.text: If I were to write at length all the causes which, up to the present time, have kept me at home, eager as I have been to set out to see your reverence, I should tell an interminable story.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:4
verses.text: I say nothing of illnesses coming one upon another, hard winter weather, and press of work, for all this has been already made known to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:5
verses.text: Now, for my sins, I have lost my Mother, the only comfort I had in life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:6
verses.text: Do not smile, if, old as I am, I lament my orphanhood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:7
verses.text: Forgive me if I cannot endure separation from a soul, to compare with whom I see nothing in the future that lies before me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:8
verses.text: So once more my complaints have come back to me; once more I am confined to my bed, tossing about in my weakness, and every hour all but looking for the end of life; and the Churches are in somewhat the same condition as my body, no good hope shining on them, and their state always changing for the worse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:9
verses.text: In the meantime Neocaesarea and Ancyra have decided to have successors of the dead, and so far they are at peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:10
verses.text: Those who are plotting against me have not yet been permitted to do anything worthy of their bitterness and wrath.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:11
verses.text: This we make no secret of attributing to your prayers on behalf of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:12
verses.text: Weary not then in praying for the Churches and in entreating God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 30:13
verses.text: Pray give all salutations to those who are privileged to minister to your Holiness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 31:1
verses.text: Letter XXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 31:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 31:3
verses.text: The death is still with us, and I am therefore compelled to remain where I am, partly by the duty of distribution, and partly out of sympathy for the distressed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 31:4
verses.text: Even now, therefore, I have not been able to accompany our reverend brother Hypatius, whom I am able to style brother, not in mere conventional language, but on account of relationship, for we are of one blood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 31:5
verses.text: You know how ill he is.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 31:6
verses.text: It distresses me to think that all hope of comfort is cut off for him, as those who have the gifts of healing have not been allowed to apply their usual remedies in his case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 31:7
verses.text: Wherefore again he implores the aid of your prayers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 31:8
verses.text: Receive my entreaty that you will give him the usual protection alike for your own sake, for you are always kind to the sick, and for mine who am petitioning on his behalf.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 31:9
verses.text: If possible, summon to your side the very holy brethren that he may be treated under your own eyes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 31:10
verses.text: If this be impossible, be so good as to send him on with a letter, and recommend him to friends further on.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:1
verses.text: Letter XXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:2
verses.text: To Sophronius the Master.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:3
verses.text: Our God—beloved brother, Gregory the bishop, shares the troubles of the times, for he too, like everybody else, is distressed at successive outrages, and resembles a man buffeted by unexpected blows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:4
verses.text: For men who have no fear of God, possibly forced by the greatness of their troubles, are reviling him, on the ground that they have lent Caesarius money.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:5
verses.text: It is not indeed the question of any loss which is serious, for he has long learnt to despise riches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:6
verses.text: The matter rather is that those who have so freely distributed all the effects of Caesarius that were worth anything, after really getting very little, because his property was in the hands of slaves, and of men of no better character than slaves, did not leave much for the executors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:7
verses.text: This little they supposed to be pledged to no one, and straightway spent it on the poor, not only from their own preference, but because of the injunctions of the dead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:8
verses.text: For on his death bed Caesarius is declared to have said "I wish my goods to belong to the poor".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:9
verses.text: In obedience then to the wishes of Caesarius they made a proper distribution of them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:10
verses.text: Now, with the poverty of a Christian, Gregory is immersed in the bustle of a chafferer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:11
verses.text: So I bethought me of reporting the matter to your excellency, in order that you may state what you think proper about Gregory to the Comes Thesaurorum, and so may honour a man whom you have known for many years, glorify the Lord who takes as done to Himself what is done to His servants, and honour me who am specially bound to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:12
verses.text: You will, I hope, of your great sagacity devise a means of relief from these outrageous people and intolerable annoyances.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:14
verses.text: No one is so ignorant of Gregory as to have any unworthy suspicion of his giving an inexact account of the circumstances because he is fond of money.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:15
verses.text: We have not to go far to find a proof of his liberality.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:16
verses.text: What is left of the property of Caesarius he gladly abandons to the Treasury, so that the property may be kept there, and the Treasurer may give answer to those who attack it and demand their proofs; for we are not adapted for such business.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:17
verses.text: Your excellency may be informed that, so long as it was possible, no one went away without getting what he wanted, and each one carried off what he demanded without any difficulty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:18
verses.text: The consequence indeed was that a good many were sorry that they had not asked for more at first; and this made still more objectors, for with the example of the earlier successful applicants before them, one false claimant starts up after another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:19
verses.text: I do then entreat your excellency to make a stand against all this and to come in, like some intervening stream, and solve the continuity of these troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:20
verses.text: You know how best you will help matters, and need not wait to be instructed by me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:21
verses.text: I am inexperienced in the affairs of this life, and cannot see my way out of our difficulties.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:22
verses.text: Of your great wisdom discover some means of help.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:23
verses.text: Be our counsellor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 32:24
verses.text: Be our champion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 33:1
verses.text: Letter XXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 33:2
verses.text: To Aburgius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 33:3
verses.text: Who knows so well as you do how to respect an old friendship, to pay reverence to virtue, and to sympathise with the sick? Now my God-beloved brother Gregory the bishop has become involved in matters which would be under any circumstances disagreeable, and are quite foreign to his bent of mind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 33:4
verses.text: I have therefore thought it best to throw myself on your protection, and to endeavour to obtain from you some solution of our difficulties.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 33:5
verses.text: It is really an intolerable state of things that one who is neither by nature nor inclination adapted for anything of the kind should be compelled to be thus responsible; that demands for money should be made on a poor man; and that one who has long determined to pass his life in retirement should be dragged into publicity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 33:6
verses.text: It would depend upon your wise counsel whether you think it of any use to address the Comes Thesaurorum or any other persons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:1
verses.text: Letter XXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:3
verses.text: How could I be silent at the present juncture? And if I cannot be silent, how am I to find utterance adequate to the circumstances, so as to make my voice not like a mere groan but rather a lamentation intelligibly indicating the greatness of the misfortune? Ah me! Tarsus is undone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:4
verses.text: This is a trouble grievous to be borne, but it does not come alone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:5
verses.text: It is still harder to think that a city so placed as to be united with Cilicia, Cappadocia, and Assyria, should be lightly thrown away by the madness of two or three individuals, while you are all the while hesitating, settling what to do, and looking at one another's faces.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:6
verses.text: It would have been far better to do like the doctors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:7
verses.text: (I have been so long an invalid that I have no lack of illustrations of this kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:8
verses.text: ) When their patients' pain becomes excessive they produce insensibility; so should we pray that our souls may be made insensible to the pain of our troubles, that we be not put under unendurable agony.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:9
verses.text: In these hard straits I do not fail to use one means of consolation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:10
verses.text: I look to your kindness; I try to make my troubles milder by my thought and recollection of you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:11
verses.text: When the eyes have looked intently on any brilliant objects it relieves them to turn again to what is blue and green; the recollection of your kindness and attention has just the same effect on my soul; it is a mild treatment that takes away my pain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:12
verses.text: I feel this the more when I reflect that you individually have done all that man could do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:13
verses.text: You have satisfactorily shewn us, men, if we judge things fairly, that the catastrophe is in no way due to you personally.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:14
verses.text: The reward which you have won at God's hand for your zeal for right is no small one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 34:15
verses.text: May the Lord grant you to me and to His churches to the improvement of life and the guidance of souls, and may He once more allow me the privilege of meeting you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 35:1
verses.text: Letter XXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 35:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 35:3
verses.text: I have written to you about many people as belonging to myself; now I mean to write about more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 35:4
verses.text: The poor can never fail, and I can never say, no.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 35:5
verses.text: There is no one more intimately associated with me, nor better able to do me kindnesses wherever he has the ability, than the reverend brother Leontius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 35:6
verses.text: So treat his house as if you had found me, not in that poverty in which now by God's help I am living, but endowed with wealth and landed property.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 35:7
verses.text: There is no doubt that you would not have made me poor, but would have taken care of what I had, or even added to my possessions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 35:8
verses.text: This is the way I ask you to behave in the house of Leontius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 35:9
verses.text: You will get your accustomed reward from me; my prayers to the holy God for the trouble you are taking in shewing yourself a good man and true, and in anticipating the supplication of the needy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 36:1
verses.text: Letter XXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 36:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 36:3
verses.text: It has, I think, been long known to your excellency that the presbyter of this place is a foster brother of my own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 36:4
verses.text: What more can I say to induce you in your kindness, to view him with a friendly eye, and give him help in his affairs? If you love me, as I know you do, I am sure that you will endeavour, to the best of your power, to relieve any one whom I look upon as a second self.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 36:5
verses.text: What then do I ask? That he do not lose his old rating.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 36:6
verses.text: Really he takes no little trouble in ministering to my necessities, because I, as you know, have nothing of my own, but depend upon the means of my friends and relatives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 36:7
verses.text: Look, then, upon my brother's house as you would on mine, or let me rather say, on your own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 36:8
verses.text: In return for your kindness to him God will not cease to help alike yourself, your house, and your family.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 36:9
verses.text: Be sure that I am specially anxious lest any injury should be done to him by the equalization of rates.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:1
verses.text: Letter XXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:3
verses.text: I look with suspicion on the multiplication of letters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:4
verses.text: Against my will, and because I cannot resist the importunity of petitioners, I am compelled to speak.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:5
verses.text: I write because I can think of no other means of relieving myself than by assenting to the supplications of those who are always asking letters from me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:6
verses.text: I am really afraid lest, since many are carrying letters off, one of the many be reckoned to be that brother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:7
verses.text: I have, I own, many friends and relatives in my own country, and I am placed in loco parentis by the position which the Lord has given me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:8
verses.text: Among them is this my foster brother, son of my nurse, and I pray that the house in which I was brought up may remain at its old assessment, so that the sojourn among us of your excellency, so beneficial to us all, may turn out no occasion of trouble to him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:9
verses.text: Now too I am supported from the same house, because I have nothing of my own, but depend upon those who love me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:10
verses.text: I do then entreat you to spare the house in which I was nursed as though you were keeping up the supply of support for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:11
verses.text: May God in return grant you His everlasting rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:12
