verses.text: One thing however, and it is most true, I think your excellency ought to know, and that is that the greater number of the slaves were given him from the outset by us, as an equivalent for my sustenance, by the gift of my father and mother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 37:13
verses.text: At the same time this was not to be regarded as an absolute gift; he was only to have the use for life, so that, if anything serious happen to him on their account, he is at liberty to send them back to me, and I shall thus in another way be responsible for rates and to collectors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:1
verses.text: Letter XXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:2
verses.text: To his Brother Gregory, concerning the difference between οὐσία and ὑπόστασις.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:4
verses.text: Many persons, in their study of the sacred dogmas, failing to distinguish between what is common in the essence or substance, and the meaning of the hypostases, arrive at the same notions, and think that it makes no difference whether οὐσία or hypostasis be spoken of.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:5
verses.text: The result is that some of those who accept statements on these subjects without any enquiry, are pleased to speak of "one hypostasis," just as they do of one "essence" or "substance;" while on the other hand those who accept three hypostases are under the idea that they are bound in accordance with this confession, to assert also, by numerical analogy, three essences or substances.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:6
verses.text: Under these circumstances, lest you fall into similar error, I have composed a short treatise for you by way of memorandum.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:7
verses.text: The meaning of the words, to put it shortly, is as follows:  2.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:8
verses.text: Of all nouns the sense of some, which are predicated of subjects plural and numerically various, is more general; as for instance man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:9
verses.text: When we so say, we employ the noun to indicate the common nature, and do not confine our meaning to any one man in particular who is known by that name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:10
verses.text: Peter, for instance is no more man, than Andrew, John, or James.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:11
verses.text: The predicate therefore being common, and extending to all the individuals ranked under the same name, requires some note of distinction whereby we may understand not man in general, but Peter or John in particular.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:12
verses.text: Of some nouns on the other hand the denotation is more limited; and by the aid of the limitation we have before our minds not the common nature, but a limitation of anything, having, so far as the peculiarity extends, nothing in common with what is of the same kind; as for instance, Paul or Timothy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:13
verses.text: For, in a word, of this kind there is no extension to what is common in the nature; there is a separation of certain circumscribed conceptions from the general idea, and expression of them by means of their names.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:14
verses.text: Suppose then that two or more are set together, as, for instance, Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy, and that an enquiry is made into the essence or substance of humanity; no one will give one definition of essence or substance in the case of Paul, a second in that of Silvanus, and a third in that of Timothy; but the same words which have been employed in setting forth the essence or substance of Paul will apply to the others also.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:15
verses.text: Those who are described by the same definition of essence or substance are of the same essence or substance when the enquirer has learned what is common, and turns his attention to the differentiating properties whereby one is distinguished from another, the definition by which each is known will no longer tally in all particulars with the definition of another, even though in some points it be found to agree.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:17
verses.text: My statement, then, is this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:18
verses.text: That which is spoken of in a special and peculiar manner is indicated by the name of the hypostasis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:19
verses.text: Suppose we say "a man".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:20
verses.text: The indefinite meaning of the word strikes a certain vague sense upon the ears.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:21
verses.text: The nature is indicated, but what subsists and is specially and peculiarly indicated by the name is not made plain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:22
verses.text: Suppose we say "Paul".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:23
verses.text: We set forth, by what is indicated by the name, the nature subsisting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:24
verses.text: This then is the hypostasis, or "understanding;" not the indefinite conception of the essence or substance, which, because what is signified is general, finds no "standing," but the conception which by means of the expressed peculiarities gives standing and circumscription to the general and uncircumscribed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:25
verses.text: It is customary in Scripture to make a distinction of this kind, as well in many other passages as in the History of Job.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:26
verses.text: When purposing to narrate the events of his life, Job first mentions the common, and says "a man;" then he straightway particularizes by adding "a certain".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:27
verses.text: As to the description of the essence, as having no bearing on the scope of his work, he is silent, but by means of particular notes of identity, mentioning the place and points of character, and such external qualifications as would individualize, and separate from the common and general idea, he specifies the "certain man," in such a way that from name, place, mental qualities, and outside circumstances, the description of the man whose life is being narrated is made in all particulars perfectly clear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:28
verses.text: If he had been giving an account of the essence, there would not in his explanation of the nature have been any mention of these matters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:29
verses.text: The same moreover would have been the account that there is in the case of Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite, and each of the men there mentioned.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:30
verses.text: Transfer, then, to the divine dogmas the same standard of difference which you recognise in the case both of essence and of hypostasis in human affairs, and you will not go wrong.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:31
verses.text: Whatever your thought suggests to you as to the mode of the existence of the Father, you will think also in the case of the Son, and in like manner too of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:32
verses.text: For it is idle to bait the mind at any detached conception from the conviction that it is beyond all conception.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:33
verses.text: For the account of the uncreate and of the incomprehensible is one and the same in the case of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:34
verses.text: For one is not more incomprehensible and uncreate than another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:35
verses.text: And since it is necessary, by means of the notes of differentiation, in the case of the Trinity, to keep the distinction unconfounded, we shall not take into consideration, in order to estimate that which differentiates, what is contemplated in common, as the uncreate, or what is beyond all comprehension, or any quality of this nature; we shall only direct our attention to the enquiry by what means each particular conception will be lucidly and distinctly separated from that which is conceived of in common.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:37
verses.text: Now the proper way to direct our investigation seems to me to be as follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:38
verses.text: We say that every good thing, which by God's providence befalls us, is an operation, of the Grace which worketh in us all things, as the apostle says, "But all these worketh that one and the self same Spirit dividing to every man severally as he will".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:39
verses.text: If we ask, if the supply of good things which thus comes to the saints has its origin in the Holy Ghost alone, we are on the other hand guided by Scripture to the belief that of the supply of the good things which are wrought in us through the Holy Ghost, the Originator and Cause is the Only-begotten God; for we are taught by Holy Scripture that "All things were made by Him," and "by Him consist".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:40
verses.text: When we are exalted to this conception, again, led by God-inspired guidance, we are taught that by that power all things are brought from non-being into being, but yet not by that power to the exclusion of origination.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:41
verses.text: On the other hand there is a certain power subsisting without generation and without origination, which is the cause of the cause of all things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:42
verses.text: For the Son, by whom are all things, and with whom the Holy Ghost is inseparably conceived of, is of the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:43
verses.text: For it is not possible for any one to conceive of the Son if he be not previously enlightened by the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:44
verses.text: Since, then, the Holy Ghost, from Whom all the supply of good things for creation has its source, is attached to the Son, and with Him is inseparably apprehended, and has Its being attached to the Father, as cause, from Whom also It proceeds; It has this note of Its peculiar hypostatic nature, that It is known after the Son and together with the Son, and that It has Its subsistence of the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:45
verses.text: The Son, Who declares the Spirit proceeding from the Father through Himself and with Himself, shining forth alone and by only-begetting from the unbegotten light, so far as the peculiar notes are concerned, has nothing in common either with the Father or with the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:46
verses.text: He alone is known by the stated signs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:47
verses.text: But God, Who is over all, alone has, as one special mark of His own hypostasis, His being Father, and His deriving His hypostasis from no cause; and through this mark He is peculiarly known.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:48
verses.text: Wherefore in the communion of the substance we maintain that there is no mutual approach or intercommunion of those notes of indication perceived in the Trinity, whereby is set forth the proper peculiarity of the Persons delivered in the faith, each of these being distinctively apprehended by His own notes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:49
verses.text: Hence, in accordance with the stated signs of indication, discovery is made of the separation of the hypostases; while so far as relates to the infinite, the incomprehensible, the uncreate, the uncircumscribed, and similar attributes, there is no variableness in the life-giving nature; in that, I mean, of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, but in Them is seen a certain communion indissoluble and continuous.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:50
verses.text: And by the same considerations, whereby a reflective student could perceive the greatness of any one of the (Persons) believed in in the Holy Trinity, he will proceed without variation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:51
verses.text: Beholding the glory in Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, his mind all the while recognises no void interval wherein it may travel between Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, for there is nothing inserted between Them; nor beyond the divine nature is there anything so subsisting as to be able to divide that nature from itself by the interposition of any foreign matter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:52
verses.text: Neither is there any vacuum of interval, void of subsistence, which can make a break in the mutual harmony of the divine essence, and solve the continuity by the interjection of emptiness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:53
verses.text: He who perceives the Father, and perceives Him by Himself, has at the same time mental perception of the Son; and he who receives the Son does not divide Him from the Spirit, but, in consecution so far as order is concerned, in conjunction so far as nature is concerned, expresses the faith commingled in himself in the three together.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:54
verses.text: He who makes mention of the Spirit alone, embraces also in this confession Him of whom He is the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:55
verses.text: And since the Spirit is Christ's and of God, as says Paul, then just as he who lays hold on one end of the chain pulls the other to him, so he who "draws the Spirit," as says the prophet, by His means draws to him at the same time both the Son and the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:56
verses.text: And if any one verily receives the Son, he will hold Him on both sides, the Son drawing towards him on the one His own Father, and on the other His own Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:57
verses.text: For He who eternally exists in the Father can never be cut off from the Father, nor can He who worketh all things by the Spirit ever be disjoined from His own Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:58
verses.text: Likewise moreover he who receives the Father virtually receives at the same time both the Son and the Spirit; for it is in no wise possible to entertain the idea of severance or division, in such a way as that the Son should be thought of apart from the Father, or the Spirit be disjoined from the Son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:59
verses.text: But the communion and the distinction apprehended in Them are, in a certain sense, ineffable and inconceivable, the continuity of nature being never rent asunder by the distinction of the hypostases, nor the notes of proper distinction confounded in the community of essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:60
verses.text: Marvel not then at my speaking of the same thing as being both conjoined and parted, and thinking as it were darkly in a riddle, of a certain new and strange conjoined separation and separated conjunction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:61
verses.text: Indeed, even in objects perceptible to the senses, any one who approaches the subject in a candid and uncontentious spirit, may find similar conditions of things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:63
verses.text: Yet receive what I say as at best a token and reflexion of the truth; not as the actual truth itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:64
verses.text: For it is not possible that there should be complete correspondence between what is seen in the tokens and the objects in reference to which the use of tokens is adopted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:65
verses.text: Why then do I say that an analogy of the separate and the conjoined is found in objects perceptible to the senses? You have before now, in springtime, beheld the brightness of the bow in the cloud; the bow, I mean, which, in our common parlance, is called Iris, and is said by persons skilled in such matters to be formed when a certain moisture is mingled with the air, and the force of the winds expresses what is dense and moist in the vapour, after it has become cloudy, into rain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:66
verses.text: The bow is said to be formed as follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:67
verses.text: When the sunbeam, after traversing obliquely the dense and darkened portion of the cloud-formation, has directly cast its own orb on some cloud, the radiance is then reflected back from what is moist and shining, and the result is a bending and return, as it were, of the light upon itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:68
verses.text: For flame-like flashings are so constituted that if they fall on any smooth surface they are refracted on themselves; and the shape of the sun, which by means of the beam is formed on the moist and smooth part of the air, is round.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:69
verses.text: The necessary consequence therefore is that the air adjacent to the cloud is marked out by means of the radiant brilliance in conformity with the shape of the sun's disc.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:70
verses.text: Now this brilliance is both continuous and divided.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:71
verses.text: It is of many colours; it is of many forms; it is insensibly steeped in the variegated bright tints of its dye; imperceptibly abstracting from our vision the combination of many coloured things, with the result that no space, mixing or paring within itself the difference of colour, can be discerned either between blue and flame-coloured, or between flame-coloured and red, or between red and amber.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:72
verses.text: For all the rays, seen at the same time, are far shining, and while they give no signs of their mutual combination, are incapable of being tested, so that it is impossible to discover the limits of the flame-coloured or of the emerald portion of the light, and at what point each originates before it appears as it does in glory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:73
verses.text: As then in the token we clearly distinguish the difference of the colours, and yet it is impossible for us to apprehend by our senses any interval between them; so in like manner conclude, I pray you, that you may reason concerning the divine dogmas; that the peculiar properties of the hypostases, like colours seen in the Iris, flash their brightness on each of the Persons Whom we believe to exist in the Holy Trinity; but that of the proper nature no difference can be conceived as existing between one and the other, the peculiar characteristics shining, in community of essence, upon each.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:74
verses.text: Even in our example, the essence emitting the many-coloured radiance, and refracted by the sunbeam, was one essence; it is the colour of the phaenomenon which is multiform.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:75
verses.text: My argument thus teaches us, even by the aid of the visible creation, not to feel distressed at points of doctrine whenever we meet with questions difficult of solution, and when at the thought of accepting what is proposed to us, our brains begin to reel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:76
verses.text: In regard to visible objects experience appears better than theories of causation, and so in matters transcending all knowledge, the apprehension of argument is inferior to the faith which teaches us at once the distinction in hypostasis and the conjunction in essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:77
verses.text: Since then our discussion has included both what is common and what is distinctive in the Holy Trinity, the common is to be understood as referring to the essence; the hypostasis on the other hand is the several distinctive sign.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:79
verses.text: It may however be thought that the account here given of the hypostasis does not tally with the sense of the Apostle's words, where he says concerning the Lord that He is "the brightness of His glory, and the express image of His person," for if we have taught hypostasis to be the conflux of the several properties; and if it is confessed that, as in the case of the Father something is contemplated as proper and peculiar, whereby He alone is known, so in the same way is it believed about the Only-begotten; how then does Scripture in this place ascribe the name of the hypostasis to the Father alone, and describes the Son as form of the hypostasis, and designated not by His own proper notes, but by those of the Father? For if the hypostasis is the sign of several existence, and the property of the Father is confined to the unbegotten being, and the Son is fashioned according to His Father's properties, then the term unbegotten can no longer be predicated exclusively of the Father, the existence of the Only-begotten being denoted by the distinctive note of the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:81
verses.text: My opinion is, however, that in this passage the Apostle's argument is directed to a different end; and it is looking to this that he uses the terms "brightness of glory," and "express image of person".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:82
verses.text: Whoever keeps this carefully in view will find nothing that clashes with what I have said, but that the argument is conducted in a special and peculiar sense.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:83
verses.text: For the object of the apostolic argument is not the distinction of the hypostases from one another by means of the apparent notes; it is rather the apprehension of the natural, inseparable, and close relationship of the Son to the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:84
verses.text: He does not say "Who being the glory of the Father" (although in truth He is); he omits this as admitted, and then in the endeavour to teach that we must not think of one form of glory in the case of the Father and of another in that of the Son, He defines the glory of the Only-begotten as the brightness of the glory of the Father, and, by the use of the example of the light, causes the Son to be thought of in indissoluble association with the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:85
verses.text: For just as the brightness is emitted by the flame, and the brightness is not after the flame, but at one and the same moment the flame shines and the light beams brightly, so does the Apostle mean the Son to be thought of as deriving existence from the Father, and yet the Only-begotten not to be divided from the existence of the Father by any intervening extension in space, but the caused to be always conceived of together with the cause.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:86
verses.text: Precisely in the same manner, as though by way of interpretation of the meaning of the preceding cause, and with the object of guiding us to the conception of the invisible by means of material examples, he speaks also of "express image of person".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:87
verses.text: For as the body is wholly in form, and yet the definition of the body and the definition of the form are distinct, and no one wishing to give the definition of the one would be found in agreement with that of the other; and yet, even if in theory you separate the form from the body, nature does not admit of the distinction, and both are inseparably apprehended; just so the Apostle thinks that even if the doctrine of the faith represents the difference of the hypostases as unconfounded and distinct, he is bound by his language to set forth also the continuous and as it were concrete relation of the Only-begotten to the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:88
verses.text: And this he states, not as though the Only-begotten had not also a hypostatic being, but in that the union does not admit of anything intervening between the Son and the Father, with the result that he, who with his soul's eyes fixes his gaze earnestly on the express image of the Only-begotten, is made perceptive also of the hypostasis of the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:89
verses.text: Yet the proper quality contemplated in them is not subject to change, nor yet to commixture, in such wise as that we should attribute either an origin of generation to the Father or an origin without generation to the Son, but so that if we could compass the impossibility of detaching one from the other, that one might be apprehended severally and alone, for, since the mere name implies the Father, it is not possible that any one should even name the Son without apprehending the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:91
verses.text: Since then, as says the Lord in the Gospels, he that hath seen the Son sees the Father also; on this account he says that the Only-begotten is the express image of His Father's person.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:92
verses.text: That this may be made still plainer I will quote also other passages of the apostle in which he calls the Son "the image of the invisible God," and again "image of His goodness;" not because the image differs from the Archetype according to the definition of indivisibility and goodness, but that it may be shewn that it is the same as the prototype, even though it be different.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:93
verses.text: For the idea of the image would be lost were it not to preserve throughout the plain and invariable likeness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:94
verses.text: He therefore that has perception of the beauty of the image is made perceptive of the Archetype.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:95
verses.text: So he, who has, as it were mental apprehension of the form of the Son, prints the express image of the Father's hypostasis, beholding the latter in the former, not beholding in the reflection the unbegotten being of the Father (for thus there would be complete identity and no distinction), but gazing at the unbegotten beauty in the Begotten.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:96
verses.text: Just as he who in a polished mirror beholds the reflection of the form as plain knowledge of the represented face, so he, who has knowledge of the Son, through his knowledge of the Son receives in his heart the express image of the Father's Person.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:97
verses.text: For all things that are the Father's are beheld in the Son, and all things that are the Son's are the Father's; because the whole Son is in the Father and has all the Father in Himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 38:98
verses.text: Thus the hypostasis of the Son becomes as it were form and face of the knowledge of the Father, and the hypostasis of the Father is known in the form of the Son, while the proper quality which is contemplated therein remains for the plain distinction of the hypostases.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:1
verses.text: Letter XXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:2
verses.text: Julian to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:3
verses.text: The proverb says "You are not proclaiming war," and, let me add, out of the comedy, "O messenger of golden words".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:4
verses.text: Come then; prove this in act, and hasten to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:5
verses.text: You will come as friend to friend.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:6
verses.text: Conspicuous and unremitting devotion to business seems, to those that treat it as of secondary importance, a heavy burden; yet the diligent are modest, as I persuade myself, sensible, and ready for any emergency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:7
verses.text: I allow myself relaxations so that even rest may be permitted to one who neglects nothing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:8
verses.text: Our mode of life is not marked by the court hypocrisy, of which I think you have had some experience, and in accordance with which compliments mean deadlier hatred than is felt to our worst foes; but, with becoming freedom, while we blame and rebuke where blame is due, we love with the love of the dearest friends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:9
verses.text: I may therefore, let me say, with all sincerity, both be diligent in relaxation and, when at work, not get worn out, and sleep secure; since when awake I do not wake more for myself, than, as is fit, for every one else.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:10
verses.text: I am afraid this is rather silly and trifling, as I feel rather lazy, (I praise myself like Astydamas) but I am writing to prove to you that to have the pleasure of seeing you, wise man as you are, will be more likely to do me good than to cause any difficulty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:11
verses.text: Therefore, as I have said, lose no time: travel post haste.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 39:12
verses.text: After you have paid me as long a visit as you like, you shall go on your journey, whithersoever you will, with my best wishes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:1
verses.text: Letter XL.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:2
verses.text: Julian to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:3
verses.text: While showing up to the present time the gentleness and benevolence which have been natural to me from my boyhood, I have reduced all who dwell beneath the sun to obedience.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:4
verses.text: For lo! every tribe of barbarians to the shores of ocean has come to lay its gifts before my feet.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:5
verses.text: So too the Sagadares who dwell beyond the Danube, wondrous with their bright tattooing, and hardly like human beings, so wild and strange are they, now grovel at my feet, and pledge themselves to obey all the behests my sovereignty imposes on them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:6
verses.text: I have a further object.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:7
verses.text: I must as soon as possible march to Persia and rout and make a tributary of that Sapor, descendant of Darius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:8
verses.text: I mean too to devastate the country of the Indians and the Saracens until they all acknowledge my superiority and become my tributaries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:9
verses.text: You, however, profess a wisdom above and beyond these things; you call yourself clad with piety, but your clothing is really impudence and everywhere you slander me as one unworthy of the imperial dignity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:10
verses.text: Do you not know that I am the grandson of the illustrious Constantius? I know this of you, and yet I do not change the old feelings which I had to you, and you to me in the days when we were both young.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:11
verses.text: But of my merciful will I command that a thousand pounds of gold be sent me from you, when I pass by Caesarea; for I am still on the march, and with all possible dispatch am hurrying to the Persian campaign.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:12
verses.text: If you refuse I am prepared to destroy Caesarea, to overthrow the buildings that have long adorned it; to erect in their place temples and statues; and so to induce all men to submit to the Emperor of the Romans and not exalt themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:13
verses.text: Wherefore I charge you to send me without fail by the hands of some trusty messenger the stipulated gold, after duly counting and weighing it, and sealing it with your ring.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:14
verses.text: In this way I may show mercy to you for your errors, if you acknowledge, however late, that no excuses will avail.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 40:15
verses.text: I have learned to know, and to condemn, what once I read.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:1
verses.text: Letter XLI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:2
verses.text: Basil to Julian.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:4
verses.text: The heroic deeds of your present splendour are small, and your grand attack against me, or rather against yourself, is paltry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:5
verses.text: When I think of you robed in purple, a crown on your dishonoured head, which, so long as true religion is absent, rather disgraces than graces your empire, I tremble.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:6
verses.text: And you yourself who have risen to be so high and great, now that vile and honour-hating demons have brought you to this pass, have begun not only to exalt yourself above all human nature, but even to uplift yourself against God, and insult His Church, mother and nurse of all, by sending to me, most insignificant of men, orders to forward you a thousand pounds of gold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:7
verses.text: I am not so much astonished at the weight of the gold, although it is very serious; but it has made me shed bitter tears over your so rapid ruin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:8
verses.text: I bethink me how you and I have learned together the lessons of the best and holiest books.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:9
verses.text: Each of us went through the sacred and God-inspired Scriptures.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:10
verses.text: Then nothing was hid from you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:11
verses.text: Nowadays you have become lost to proper feeling, beleaguered as you are with pride.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:12
verses.text: Your serene Highness did not find out for the first time yesterday that I do not live in the midst of superabundant wealth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:13
verses.text: To-day you have demanded a thousand pounds of gold of me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:14
verses.text: I hope your serenity will deign to spare me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:15
verses.text: My property amounts to so much, that I really shall not have enough to eat as much as I shall like to-day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:16
verses.text: Under my roof the art of cookery is dead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:17
verses.text: My servants' knife never touches blood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:18
verses.text: The most important viands, in which lies our abundance, are leaves of herbs with very coarse bread and sour wine, so that our senses are not dulled by gluttony, and do not indulge in excess.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:20
verses.text: Your excellent tribune Lausus, trusty minister of your orders, has also reported to me that a certain woman came as a suppliant to your serenity on the occasion of the death of her son by poison; that it has been judged by you that poisoners are not allowed to exist; if any there be, that they are to be destroyed, or, only those are reserved, who are to fight with beasts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:21
verses.text: And, this rightly decided by you, seems strange to me, for your efforts to cure the pain of great wounds by petty remedies are to the last degree ridiculous.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:22
verses.text: After insulting God, it is useless for you to give heed to widows and orphans.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:23
verses.text: The former is mad and dangerous; the latter the part of a merciful and kindly man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:24
verses.text: It is a serious thing for a private individual like myself to speak to an emperor; it will be more serious for you to speak to God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:25
verses.text: No one will appear to mediate between God and man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:26
verses.text: What you read you did not understand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 41:27
verses.text: If you had understood, you would not have condemned.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:1
verses.text: Letter XLII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:2
verses.text: To Chilo, his disciple.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:4
verses.text: If, my true brother, you gladly suffer yourself to be advised by me as to what course of action you should pursue, specially in the points in which you have referred to me for advice, you will owe me your salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:5
verses.text: Many men have had the courage to enter upon the solitary life; but to live it out to the end is a task which perhaps has been achieved by few.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:6
verses.text: The end is not necessarily involved in the intention; yet in the end is the guerdon of the toil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:7
verses.text: No advantage, therefore, accrues to men who fail to press on to the end of what they have in view and only adopt the solitary's life in its inception.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:8
verses.text: Nay, they make their profession ridiculous, and are charged by outsiders with unmanliness and instability of purpose.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:9
verses.text: Of these, moreover, the Lord says, who wishing to build a house "sitteth not down first and counteth the cost whether he have sufficient to finish it? lest haply after he hath laid the foundation and is not able to finish it," the passers-by "begin to mock him saying," this man laid a foundation "and was not able to finish".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:10
verses.text: Let the start, then, mean that you heartily advance in virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:11
verses.text: The right noble athlete Paul, wishing us not to rest in easy security on so much of our life as may have been lived well in the past, but, every day to attain further progress, says "Forgetting those things which are behind, and reaching forth unto those things which are before, I press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:12
verses.text: So truly stands the whole of human life, not contented with what has gone before and fed not so much on the past as on the future.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:13
verses.text: For how is a man the better for having his belly filled yesterday, if his natural hunger fails to find its proper satisfaction in food to-day? In the same way the soul gains nothing by yesterday's virtue unless it be followed by the right conduct of to-day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:14
verses.text: For it is said "I shall judge thee as I shall find thee".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:16
verses.text: Vain then is the labour of the righteous man, and free from blame is the way of the sinner, if a change befall, and the former turn from the better to the worse, and the latter from the worse to the better.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:17
verses.text: So we hear from Ezekiel teaching as it were in the name of the Lord, when he says, "if the righteous turneth away and committeth iniquity, I will not remember the righteousness which he committed before; in his sin he shall die," and so too about the sinner; if he turn away from his wickedness, and do that which is right, he shall live.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:18
verses.text: Where were all the labours of God's servant Moses, when the gainsaying of one moment shut him out from entering into the promised land? What became of the companionship of Gehazi with Elissaeus, when he brought leprosy on himself by his covetousness? What availed all Solomon's vast wisdom, and his previous regard for God, when afterwards from his mad love of women he fell into idolatry? Not even the blessed David was blameless, when his thoughts went astray and he sinned against the wife of Uriah.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:19
verses.text: One example were surely enough for keeping safe one who is living a godly life, the fall from the better to the worse of Judas, who, after being so long Christ's disciple, for a mean gain sold his Master and got a halter for himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:20
verses.text: Learn then, brother, that it is not he who begins well who is perfect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:21
verses.text: It is he who ends well who is approved in God's sight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:22
verses.text: Give then no sleep to your eyes or slumber to your eyelids that you may be delivered "as a roe from the net and a bird from the snare".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:23
verses.text: For, behold, you are passing through the midst of snares; you are treading on the top of a high wall whence a fall is perilous to the faller; wherefore do not straightway attempt extreme discipline; above all things beware of confidence in yourself, lest you fall from a height of discipline through want of training.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:24
verses.text: It is better to advance a little at a time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:25
verses.text: Withdraw then by degrees from the pleasures of life, gradually destroying all your wonted habits, lest you bring on yourself a crowd of temptations by irritating all your passions at once.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:26
verses.text: When you have mastered one passion, then begin to wage war against another, and in this manner you will in good time get the better of all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:27
verses.text: Indulgence, so far as the name goes, is one, but its practical workings are diverse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:28
verses.text: First then, brother, meet every temptation with patient endurance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:29
verses.text: And by what various temptations the faithful man is proved; by worldly loss, by accusations, by lies, by opposition, by calumny, by persecution! These and the like are the tests of the faithful.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:30
verses.text: Further, be quiet, not rash in speech, not quarrelsome, not disputatious, not covetous of vain glory, not more anxious to get than to give knowledge, not a man of many words, but always more ready to learn than to teach.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:31
verses.text: Do not trouble yourself about worldly life; from it no good can come to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:32
verses.text: It is said, "That my mouth speak not the works of men".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:33
verses.text: The man who is fond of talking about sinners' doings, soon rouses the desire for self indulgence; much better busy yourself about the lives of good men for so you will get some profit for yourself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:34
verses.text: Do not be anxious to go travelling about from village to village and house to house; rather avoid them as traps for souls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:35
verses.text: If any one, for true pity's sake, invite you with many pleas to enter his house, let him be told to follow the faith of the centurion, who, when Jesus was hastening to him to perform an act of healing, besought him not to do so in the words, "Lord I am not worthy that thou shouldest come under my roof, but speak the word only and my servant shall be healed," and when Jesus had said to him "Go thy way; as thou hast believed, so be it done unto thee," his servant was healed from that hour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:36
verses.text: Learn then, brother, that it was the faith of the suppliant, not the presence of Christ, which delivered the sick man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:37
verses.text: So too now, if you pray, in whatever place you be, and the sick man believes that he will be aided by your prayers, all will fall out as he desires.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:39
verses.text: You will not love your kinsfolk more than the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:40
verses.text: "He that loveth," He says, "father, or mother, or brother, more than me, is not worthy of me".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:41
verses.text: What is the meaning of the Lord's commandment? "He that taketh not up his cross and followeth after me, cannot be my disciple?" If, together with Christ, you died to your kinsfolk according to the flesh, why do you wish to live with them again? If for your kinsfolk's sake you are building up again what you destroyed for Christ's sake, you make yourself a transgressor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:42
verses.text: Do not then for your kinsfolk's sake abandon your place: if you abandon your place, perhaps you will abandon your mode of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:43
verses.text: Love not the crowd, nor the country, nor the town; love the desert, ever abiding by yourself with no wandering mind, regarding prayer and praise as your life's work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:44
verses.text: Never neglect reading, especially of the New Testament, because very frequently mischief comes of reading the Old; not because what is written is harmful, but because the minds of the injured are weak.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:45
verses.text: All bread is nutritious, but it may be injurious to the sick.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:46
verses.text: Just so all Scripture is God inspired and profitable, and there is nothing in it unclean: only to him who thinks it is unclean, to him it is unclean.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:47
verses.text: "Prove all things; hold fast that which is good; abstain from every form of evil".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:48
verses.text: "All things are lawful but all things are not expedient".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:49
verses.text: Among all, with whom you come in contact, be in all things a giver of no offence, cheerful, "loving as a brother," pleasant, humble-minded, never missing the mark of hospitality through extravagance of meats, but always content with what is at hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:50
verses.text: Take no more from any one than the daily necessaries of the solitary life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:51
verses.text: Above all things shun gold as the soul's foe, the father of sin and the agent of the devil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:52
verses.text: Do not expose yourself to the charge of covetousness on the pretence of ministering to the poor; but, if any one brings you money for the poor and you know of any who are in need, advise the owner himself to convey it to his needy brothers, lest haply your conscience may be defiled by the acceptance of money.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:54
verses.text: Shun pleasures; seek after continence; train your body to hard work; accustom your soul to trials.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:55
verses.text: Regarding the dissolution of soul and body as release from every evil, await that enjoyment of everlasting good things in which all the saints have part.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:56
verses.text: Ever, as it were, holding the balance against every suggestion of the devil throw in a holy thought, and, as the scale inclines do thou go with it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:57
verses.text: Above all when the evil thought starts up and says, "What is the good of your passing your life in this place? What do you gain by withdrawing yourself from the society of men? Do you not know that those, who are ordained by God to be bishops of God's churches, constantly associate with their fellows, and indefatigably attend spiritual gatherings at which those who are present derive very great advantage? There are to be enjoyed explanations of hard sayings, expositions of the teachings of the apostles, interpretations of the thoughts of the gospels, lessons in theology and the intercourse of spiritual brethren, who do great good to all they meet if only by the sight of their faces.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:58
verses.text: You, however, who have decided to be a stranger to all these good things, are sitting here in a wild state like the beasts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:59
verses.text: You see round you a wide desert with scarcely a fellow creature in it, lack of all instruction, estrangement from your brothers, and your spirit inactive in carrying out the commandments of God".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:60
verses.text: Now, when the evil thought rises against you, with all these ingenious pretexts and wishes to destroy you, oppose to it in pious reflection your own practical experience, and say, You tell me that the things in the world are good; the reason why I came here is because I judged myself unfit for the good things of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:61
verses.text: With the world's good things are mingled evil things, and the evil things distinctly have the upper hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:62
verses.text: Once when I attended the spiritual assemblies I did with difficulty find one brother, who, so far as I could see, feared God, but he was a victim of the devil, and I heard from him amusing stories and tales made up to deceive those whom he met.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:63
verses.text: After him I fell in with many thieves, plunderers, tyrants.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:64
verses.text: I saw disgraceful drunkards; I saw the blood of the oppressed; I saw women's beauty, which tortured my chastity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:65
verses.text: From actual fornication I fled, but I defiled my virginity by the thoughts of my heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:66
verses.text: I heard many discourses which were good for the soul, but I could not discover in the case of any one of the teachers that his life was worthy of his words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:67
verses.text: After this, again, I heard a great number of plays, which were made attractive by wanton songs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:68
verses.text: Then I heard a lyre sweetly played, the applause of tumblers, the talk of clowns, all kinds of jests and follies and all the noises of a crowd.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:69
verses.text: I saw the tears of the robbed, the agony of the victims of tyranny, the shrieks of the tortured.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:70
verses.text: I looked and lo, there was no spiritual assembly, but only a sea, wind-tossed and agitated, and trying to drown every one at once under its waves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:71
verses.text: Tell me, O evil thought, tell me, daemon of short lived pleasure and vain glory, what is the good of my seeing and hearing all these things, when I am powerless to succour any of those who are thus wronged; when I am allowed neither to defend the helpless nor correct the fallen; when I am perhaps doomed to destroy myself too.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:72
verses.text: For just as a very little fresh water is blown away by a storm of wind and dust, in like manner the good deeds, that we think we do in this life, are overwhelmed by the multitude of evils.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:73
verses.text: Pieces acted for men in this life are driven through joy and merriment, like stakes into their hearts, so that the brightness of their worship is be-dimmed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:74
verses.text: But the wails and lamentations of men wronged by their fellows are introduced to make a show of the patience of the poor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:76
verses.text: What good then do I get except the loss of my soul? For this reason I migrate to the hills like a bird.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:77
verses.text: "I am escaped as a bird out of the snare of the fowlers".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:78
verses.text: I am living, O evil thought, in the desert in which the Lord lived.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:79
verses.text: Here is the oak of Mamre; here is the ladder going up to heaven, and the stronghold of the angels which Jacob saw; here is the wilderness in which the people purified received the law, and so came into the land of promise and saw God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:80
verses.text: Here is Mount Carmel where Elias sojourned and pleased God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:81
verses.text: Here is the plain whither Esdras withdrew, and at God's bidding uttered all the God inspired books.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:82
verses.text: Here is the wilderness in which the blessed John ate locusts and preached repentance to men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:83
verses.text: Here is the Mount of Olives, whither Christ came and prayed, and taught us to pray.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:84
verses.text: Here is Christ the lover of the wilderness, for He says "Where two or three are gathered together in my name there am I in the midst of them".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:85
verses.text: "Here is the strait and narrow way which leadeth unto life".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:86
verses.text: Here are the teachers and prophets "wandering in deserts and in mountains and in dens and caves of the earth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:87
verses.text: Here are apostles and evangelists and solitaries' life remote from cities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:88
verses.text: This I have embraced with all my heart, that I may win what has been promised to Christ's martyrs and all His other saints, and so I may truly say, "Because of the words of thy lips I have kept hard ways".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:89
verses.text: I have heard of Abraham, God's friend, who obeyed the divine voice and went into the wilderness; of Isaac who submitted to authority; of Jacob, the patriarch, who left his home; of Joseph, the chaste, who was sold; of the three children, who learnt how to fast, and fought with the fire; of Daniel thrown twice into the lion's den; of Jeremiah speaking boldly, and thrown into a pit of mud; of Isaiah, who saw unspeakable things, cut asunder with a saw; of Israel led away captive; of John the rebuker of adultery, beheaded; of Christ's martyrs slain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:90
verses.text: But why say more? Here our Saviour Himself was crucified for our sakes that by His death He might give us life, and train and attract us all to endurance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:91
verses.text: To Him I press on, and to the Father and to the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:92
verses.text: I strive to be found true, judging myself unworthy of this world's goods.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:93
verses.text: And yet not I because of the world, but the world because of me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:94
verses.text: Think of all these things in your heart; follow them with zeal; fight, as you have been commanded, for the truth to the death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:95
verses.text: For Christ was made "obedient" even "unto death".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:96
verses.text: The Apostle says, "Take heed lest there be in any of you an evil heart…in departing from the living God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:97
verses.text: But exhort one another…(and edify one another) while it is called to-day".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:98
verses.text: To-day means the whole time of our life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 42:99
verses.text: Thus living, brother, you will save yourself, you will make me glad, and you will glorify God from everlasting to everlasting, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 43:1
verses.text: Letter XLIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 43:2
verses.text: Admonition to the Young.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 43:3
verses.text: O faithful man of solitary life, and practiser of true religion, learn the lessons of the evangelic conversation, of mastery over the body, of a meek spirit, of purity of mind, of destruction of pride.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 43:4
verses.text: Pressed into the service, add to your gifts, for the Lord's sake; robbed, never go to law; hated, love; persecuted, endure; slandered, entreat.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 43:5
verses.text: Be dead to sin; be crucified to God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 43:6
verses.text: Cast all your care upon the Lord, that you may be found where are tens of thousands of angels, assemblies of the first-born, the thrones of prophets, sceptres of patriarchs, crowns of martyrs, praises of righteous men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 43:7
verses.text: Earnestly desire to be numbered with those righteous men in Christ Jesus our Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 43:8
verses.text: To Him be glory for ever, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:1
verses.text: Letter XLIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:2
verses.text: To a lapsed Monk.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:4
verses.text: I do not wish you joy, for there is no joy for the wicked.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:5
verses.text: Even now I cannot believe it; my heart cannot conceive iniquity so great as the crime which you have committed; if, that is, the truth really is what is generally understood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:6
verses.text: I am at a loss to think how wisdom so deep can have been made to disappear; how such exact discipline can have been undone; whence blindness so profound can have been shed round you; how with utter inconsiderateness you have wrought such destruction of souls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:7
verses.text: If this be true, you have given over your own soul to the pit, and have slackened the earnestness of all who have heard of your impiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:8
verses.text: You have set at nought the faith; you have missed the glorious fight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:9
verses.text: I grieve over you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:10
verses.text: What cleric does not lament as he hears? What ecclesiastic does not beat the breast? What layman is not downcast? What ascetic is not sad? Haply, even the sun has grown dark at your fall, and the powers of heaven have been shaken at your destruction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:11
verses.text: Even senseless stones have shed tears at your madness; even your enemies have wept at the greatness of your iniquity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:12
verses.text: Oh hardness of heart! Oh cruelty! You did not fear God; you did not reverence men; you cared nothing for your friends; you made shipwreck of all at once; at once you were stripped of all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:13
verses.text: Once more I grieve over you, unhappy man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:14
verses.text: You were proclaiming to all the power of the kingdom, and you fell from it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:15
verses.text: You were making all stand in fear of your teaching, and there was no fear of God before your eyes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:16
verses.text: You were preaching purity, and you are found polluted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:17
verses.text: You were priding yourself on your poverty, and you are convicted of covetousness; you were demonstrating and explaining the chastisement of God, and you yourself brought chastisement on your own head.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:18
verses.text: How am I to lament you, how grieve for you? How is Lucifer that was rising in the morning fallen and dashed on the ground? Both the ears of every hearer will tingle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:19
verses.text: How is the Nazarite, brighter than gold, become dark above pitch? How has the glorious son of Sion become an unprofitable vessel! Of him, whose memory of the sacred Scriptures was in all men's mouths, the memory to-day has perished with the sound.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:20
verses.text: The man of quick intelligence has quickly perished.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:21
verses.text: The man of manifold wit has wrought manifold iniquity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:22
verses.text: All who profited by your teaching have been injured by your fall.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:23
verses.text: All who came to listen to your conversation have stopped their ears at your fall.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:24
verses.text: I, sorrowful and downcast, weakened in every way, eating ashes for bread and with sackcloth on my wound, am thus recounting your praises; or rather, with none to comfort and none to cure, am making an inscription for a tomb.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:25
verses.text: For comfort is hid from my eyes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:26
verses.text: I have no salve, no oil, no bandage to put on.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:27
verses.text: My wound is sore, how shall I be healed?  2.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:28
verses.text: If you have any hope of salvation; if you have the least thought of God, or any desire for good things to come; if you have any fear of the chastisements reserved for the impenitent, awake without delay, lift up your eyes to heaven, come to your senses, cease from your wickedness, shake off the stupor that enwraps you, make a stand against the foe who has struck you down.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:29
verses.text: Make an effort to rise from the ground.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:30
verses.text: Remember the good Shepherd who will follow and rescue you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:31
verses.text: Though it be but two legs or a lobe of an ear, spring back from the beast that has wounded you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:32
verses.text: Remember the mercies of God and how He cures with oil and wine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:33
verses.text: Do not despair of salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:34
verses.text: Recall your recollection of how it is written in the Scriptures that he who is falling rises and he who turns away returns; the wounded is healed, the prey of beasts escapes; he who owns his sin is not rejected.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:35
verses.text: The Lord willeth not the death of a sinner but rather that he should turn and live.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:36
verses.text: Do not despise, like the wicked in the pit of evil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:37
verses.text: There is a time of endurance, a time of long suffering, a time of healing, a time of correction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:38
verses.text: Have you stumbled? Arise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:39
verses.text: Have you sinned? Cease.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:40
verses.text: Do not stand in the way of sinners, but spring away.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:41
verses.text: When you are converted and groan you shall be saved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:42
verses.text: Out of labour comes health, out of sweat salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:43
verses.text: Beware lest, from your wish to keep certain obligations, you break the obligations to God which you professed before many witnesses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:44
verses.text: Pray do not hesitate to come to me for any earthly considerations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:45
verses.text: When I have recovered my dead I shall lament, I shall tend him, I will weep "because of the spoiling of the daughter of my people".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:46
verses.text: All are ready to welcome you, all will share your efforts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:47
verses.text: Do not sink back.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:48
verses.text: Remember the days of old.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:49
verses.text: There is salvation; there is amendment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:50
verses.text: Be of good cheer; do not despair.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:51
verses.text: It is not a law condemning to death without pity, but mercy remitting punishment and awaiting improvement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:52
verses.text: The doors are not yet shut; the bridegroom hears; sin is not the master.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 44:53
verses.text: Make another effort, do not hesitate, have pity on yourself and on all of us in Jesus Christ our Lord, to Whom be glory and might now and for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:1
verses.text: Letter XLV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:2
verses.text: To a lapsed Monk.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:4
verses.text: I am doubly alarmed to the very bottom of my heart, and you are the cause.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:5
verses.text: I am either the victim of some unkindly prepossession, and so am driven to make an unbrotherly charge; or, with every wish to feel for you, and to deal gently with your troubles, I am forced to take a different and an unfriendly attitude.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:6
verses.text: Wherefore, even as I take my pen to write, I have nerved my unwilling hand by reflection; but my face, downcast as it is, because of my sorrow over you, I have had no power to change.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:7
verses.text: I am so covered with shame, for your sake, that my lips are turned to mourning and my mouth straightway falls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:8
verses.text: Ah me! What am I to write? What shall I think in my perplexity?  If I call to mind your former empty mode of life, when you were rolling in riches and had abundance of petty mundane reputation, I shudder; then you were followed by a mob of flatterers, and had the short enjoyment of luxury, with obvious peril and unfair gain; on the one hand, fear of the magistrates scattered your care for your salvation, on the other the agitations of public affairs disturbed your home, and the continuance of troubles directed your mind to Him Who is able to help you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:9
verses.text: Then, little by little, you took to seeking for the Saviour, Who brings you fears for your good, Who delivers you and protects you, though you mocked Him in your security.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:10
verses.text: Then you began to train yourself for a change to a worthy life, treating all your perilous property as mere dung, and abandoning the care of your household and the society of your wife.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:11
verses.text: All abroad like a stranger and a vagabond, wandering through town and country, you betook yourself to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:12
verses.text: There I myself lived with you, and, for the toil of your ascetic discipline, called you blessed, when fasting for weeks you continued in contemplation before God, shunning the society of your fellows, like a routed runaway.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:13
verses.text: Then you arranged for yourself a quiet and solitary life, and refused all the disquiets of society.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:14
verses.text: You pricked your body with rough sackcloth; you tightened a hard belt round your loins; you bravely put wearing pressure on your bones; you made your sides hang loose from front to back, and all hollow with fasting; you would wear no soft bandage, and drawing in your stomach, like a gourd, made it adhere to the parts about your kidneys.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:15
verses.text: You emptied out all fat from your flesh; all the channels below your belly you dried up; your belly itself you folded up for want of food; your ribs, like the caves of a house, you made to overshadow all the parts about your middle, and, with all your body contracted, you spent the long hours of the night in pouring out confession to God, and made your beard wet with channels of tears.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:16
verses.text: Why particularize? Remember how many mouths of saints you saluted with a kiss, how many bodies you embraced, how many held your hands as undefiled, how many servants God, as though in worship, ran and clasped you by the knees.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:18
verses.text: And what is the end of all this? My ears are wounded by a charge of adultery, flying swifter than an arrow, and piercing my heart with a sharper sting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:19
verses.text: What crafty wiliness of wizard has driven you into so deadly a trap? What many-meshed devil's nets have entangled you and disabled all the powers of your virtue? What has become of the story of your labours? Or must we disbelieve them? How can we avoid giving credit to what has long been hid when we see what is plain? What shall we say of your having by tremendous oaths bound souls which fled for refuge to God, when what is more than yea and nay is carefully attributed to the devil? You have made yourself security for fatal perjury; and, by setting the ascetic character at nought, you have cast blame even upon the Apostles and the very Lord Himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:20
verses.text: You have shamed the boast of purity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:21
verses.text: You have disgraced the promise of chastity; we have been made a tragedy of captives, and our story is made a play of before Jews and Greeks.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:22
verses.text: You have made a split in the solitaries' spirit, driving those of exacter discipline into fear and cowardice, while they still wonder at the power of the devil, and seducing the careless into imitation of your incontinence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:23
verses.text: So far as you have been able, you have destroyed the boast of Christ, Who said, "Be of good cheer I have overcome the world," and its Prince.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:24
verses.text: You have mixed for your country a bowl of ill repute.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:25
verses.text: Verily you have proved the truth of the proverb, "Like a hart stricken through the liver".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:26
verses.text: But what now? The tower of strength has not fallen, my brother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:27
verses.text: The remedies of correction are not mocked; the city of refuge is not shut.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:28
verses.text: Do not abide in the depths of evil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:29
verses.text: Do not deliver yourself to the slayer of souls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:30
verses.text: The Lord knows how to set up them that are dashed down.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:31
verses.text: Do not try to flee afar off, but hasten to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:32
verses.text: Resume once more the labours of your youth, and by a fresh course of good deeds destroy the indulgence that creeps foully along the ground.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:33
verses.text: Look to the end, that has come so near to our life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:34
verses.text: See how now the sons of Jews and Greeks are being driven to the worship of God, and do not altogether deny the Saviour of the World.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 45:35
verses.text: Never let that most awful sentence apply to you, "Depart from me, I never knew you".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:1
verses.text: Letter XLVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:2
verses.text: To a fallen virgin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:4
verses.text: Now is the time to quote the words of the prophet and to say, "Oh that my head were waters, and mine eyes a fountain of tears, that I might weep day and night for the slain of the daughter of my people".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:5
verses.text: Though they are wrapped in profound silence and lie stunned by their misfortune, robbed of all sense of feeling by the fatal blow, I at all events must not let such a fall go unlamented.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:6
verses.text: If, to Jeremiah, it seemed that those whose bodies had been wounded in war, were worthy of innumerable lamentations, what shall be said of such a disaster of souls? "My slain men," it is said, "are not slain with the sword, nor dead in battle".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:7
verses.text: But I am bewailing the sting of the real death, the grievousness of sin and the fiery darts of the wicked one, which have savagely set on fire souls as well as bodies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:8
verses.text: Truly God's laws would groan aloud on seeing so great a pollution on the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:9
verses.text: They have pronounced their prohibition of old "Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's wife"; and through the holy gospels they say that "Whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her, hath committed adultery already with her in his heart".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:10
verses.text: Now they see the bride of the Lord herself, whose head is Christ, boldly committing adultery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:11
verses.text: So too would groan the companies of the Saints.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:12
verses.text: Phinehas, the zealous, because he can now no more take his spear into his hands and avenge the outrage on the bodies; and John the Baptist, because he cannot quit the realms above, as in his life he left the wilderness, to hasten to convict iniquity, and if he must suffer for the deed, rather lose his head than his freedom to speak.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:13
verses.text: But, peradventure, like the blessed Abel, he too though dead yet speaks to us, and now exclaims, more loudly than John of old concerning Herodias, "It is not lawful for thee to have her".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:14
verses.text: For even if the body of John in obedience to the law of nature has received the sentence of God, and his tongue is silent, yet "the word of God is not bound".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:15
verses.text: John, when he saw the wedlock of a fellow servant set at nought, was bold to rebuke even to the death: how would he feel on seeing such an outrage wreaked on the marriage chamber of the Lord?  2.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:16
verses.text: You have flung away the yoke of that divine union; you have fled from the undefiled chamber of the true King; you have shamefully fallen into this disgraceful and impious corruption; and now that you cannot avoid this painful charge, and have no means or device to conceal your trouble, you rush into insolence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:17
verses.text: The wicked man after falling into a pit of iniquity always begins to despise, and you are denying your actual covenant with the true bridegroom; you say that you are not a virgin, and made no promise, although you have undertaken and publicly professed many pledges of virginity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:18
verses.text: Remember the good profession which you witnessed before God, angels, and men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:19
verses.text: Remember the hallowed intercourse, the sacred company of virgins, the assembly of the Lord, the Church of the holy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:20
verses.text: Remember your grandmother, grown old in Christ, still youthful and vigorous in virtue; and your mother vying with her in the Lord, and striving to break with ordinary life in strange and unwonted toils; remember your sister, who copies their doings, nay, endeavours to surpass them, and goes beyond the good deeds of her fathers in her virgin graces, and earnestly challenges by word and deed you her sister, as she thinks, to like efforts, while she earnestly prays that your virginity be preserved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:21
verses.text: All these call to mind, and your holy service of God with them, your life spiritual, though in the flesh; your conversation heavenly, though on earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:22
verses.text: Remember days of calm, nights lighted up, spiritual songs, sweet music of psalms, saintly prayers, a bed pure and undefiled, procession of virgins, and moderate fare.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:23
verses.text: What has become of your grave appearance, your gracious demeanour, your plain dress, meet for a virgin, the beautiful blush of modesty, the comely and bright pallor due to temperance and vigils, shining fairer than any brilliance of complexion? How often have you not prayed, perhaps with tears, that you might preserve your virginity without spot! How often have you not written to the holy men, imploring them to offer up prayers in your behalf, not that it should be your lot to marry, still less to be involved in this shameful corruption, but that you should not fall away from the Lord Jesus? How often have you received gifts from the Bridegroom? Why enumerate the honours given you for His sake by them that are His? Why tell of your fellowship with virgins, your progress with them, your being greeted by them with praises on account of virginity, eulogies of virgins, letters written as to a virgin? Now, nevertheless, at a little blast from the spirit of the air, "that now worketh in the children of disobedience," you have abjured all these; you have changed the honourable treasure, worth fighting for at all costs, for short-lived indulgence which does for the moment gratify the appetite; one day you will find it more bitter than gall.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:25
verses.text: Who would not grieve over such things and say, "How is the faithful city become an harlot?" How would not the Lord Himself say to some of those who are now walking in the spirit of Jeremiah, "Hast thou seen what the virgin of Israel has done to me?" I betrothed her to me in trust, in purity, in righteousness, in judgment, in pity, and in mercy; as I promised her through Hosea the prophet.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:26
verses.text: But she loved strangers, and while I, her husband, was yet alive, she is called adulteress, and is not afraid to belong to another husband.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:27
