verses.text: What then says the conductor of the bride, the divine and blessed Paul, both that one of old, and the later one of to-day under whose mediation and instruction you left your father's house and were united to the Lord? Might not either, in sorrow for such a trouble, say, "The thing which I greatly feared is come upon me, and that which I was afraid of is come unto me".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:28
verses.text: "I have espoused you to one husband that I may present you as a chaste virgin to Christ".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:29
verses.text: I was indeed ever afraid "lest by any means as the serpent beguiled Eve through his subtilty, so your mind should be corrupted;" wherefore by countless counter-charms I strove to control the agitation of your senses, and by countless safeguards to preserve the bride of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:30
verses.text: So I continually set forth the life of the unmarried maid, and described how "the unmarried" alone "careth for the things of the Lord, that she may be holy both in body and spirit".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:31
verses.text: I used to describe the high dignity of virginity, and, addressing you as a temple of God, used as it were to give wings to your zeal as I strove to lift you to Jesus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:32
verses.text: Yet through fear of evil I helped you not to fall by the words "if any man defile the temple of God, him shall God destroy".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:33
verses.text: So by my prayers I tried to make you more secure, if by any means "your body, soul, and spirit might be preserved blameless unto the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:34
verses.text: Yet all my toil on your behalf has been in vain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:35
verses.text: Bitter to me has been the end of those sweet labours.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:36
verses.text: Now I needs must groan again at that over which I ought to have rejoiced.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:37
verses.text: You have been deceived by the serpent more bitterly than Eve; and not only your mind but also your body has been defiled.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:38
verses.text: Even that last horror has come to pass which I shrink from saying, and yet cannot leave unsaid, for it is as a burning and blazing fire in my bones, and I am undone and cannot endure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:39
verses.text: You have taken the members of Christ and made them the members of a harlot.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:40
verses.text: This is an evil with which no other can be matched.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:41
verses.text: This outrage in life is new.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:42
verses.text: "For pass over the Isles of Chittim and see; and send unto Chedar and consider diligently, and see if there be such a thing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:43
verses.text: Hath a nation changed their gods which are yet no gods".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:44
verses.text: But the virgin has changed her glory, and her glory is in her shame.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:45
verses.text: The heavens are astonished at this, and the earth is horribly afraid, saith the Lord, for the virgin has committed two evils; she has forsaken Me, the true and holy Bridegroom of holy souls, and has betaken herself to an impious and lawless destroyer of body and soul alike.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:46
verses.text: She has revolted from God, her Saviour, and yielded her members servants to uncleanness and to iniquity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:47
verses.text: She forgot me and went after her lover from whom she will get no good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:49
verses.text: It were better for him that a mill-stone had been hanged about his neck, and that he had been cast into the sea, than that he should have offended the virgin of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:50
verses.text: What slave ever reached such a pitch of mad audacity as to fling himself upon his master's bed? What robber ever attained such a height of folly as to lay hands upon the very offerings of God, not dead vessels, but bodies living and enshrining a soul made after the image of God? Who was ever known to have the hardihood, in the heart of a city and at high noon, to mark figures of filthy swine upon a royal statue? He who has set at naught a marriage of man, with no mercy shewn him, in the presence of two or three witnesses, dies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:51
verses.text: Of how much sorer punishment, suppose you, shall he be thought worthy who hath trodden under foot the Son of God, and defiled His pledged bride and done despite unto the spirit of virginity? But the woman, he urges, consented, and I did no violence to her against her will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:52
verses.text: So, that unchaste lady of Egypt raged with love for comely Joseph, but the chaste youth's virtue was not overcome by the frenzy of the wicked woman, and, even when she laid her hand upon him, he was not forced into iniquity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:53
verses.text: But still, he urges, this was no new thing in her case; she was no longer a maid; if I had been unwilling, she would have been corrupted by some one else.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:54
verses.text: Yes; and it is written, the Son of Man was ordained to be betrayed, but woe unto that man by whom He was betrayed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:55
verses.text: It must needs be that offences come, but woe to that man by whom they come.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:57
verses.text: In such a state of things as this, "Shall they fall and not arise? Shall he turn away and not return?" Why did the virgin turn shamefully away, though she had heard Christ her bridegroom saying through the mouth of Jeremiah, "And I said, after she had done all these things (committed all these fornications, LXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:58
verses.text: ), turn thou unto me, but she returned not?" "Is there no balm in Gilead; is there no physician there? Why then is not the health of the daughter of my people recovered?" You might indeed find many remedies for evil in Scripture, many medicines to save from destruction and lead to health; the mysteries of death and resurrection, the sentences of terrible judgment and everlasting punishment; the doctrines of repentance and of remission of sins; all the countless illustrations of conversion, the piece of money, the sheep, the son who wasted his substance with harlots, who was lost and was found, who was dead and alive again.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:59
verses.text: Let us not use these remedies for ill; by these means let us heal our soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:60
verses.text: Bethink you of your last day, for you will surely not, unlike all other women, live for ever.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:61
verses.text: The distress, the gasping for breath, the hour of death, the imminent sentence of God, the angels hastening on their way, the soul fearfully dismayed, and lashed to agony by the consciousness of sin, turning itself piteously to things of this life and to the inevitable necessity of that long life to be lived elsewhere.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:62
verses.text: Picture to me, as it rises in your imagination, the conclusion of all human life, when the Son of God shall come in His glory with His angels, "For he shall come and shall not keep silence;" when He shall come to judge the quick and dead, to render to every one according to his work; when that terrible trumpet with its mighty voice shall wake those that have slept through the ages, and they that have done good shall come forth unto the resurrection of life, and they that have done evil unto the resurrection of damnation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:63
verses.text: Remember the vision of Daniel, and how he brings the judgment before us: "I beheld till the thrones were cast down, and the Ancient of days did sit, whose garment was white as snow, and the hair of His head like the pure wool;…and His wheels as burning fire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:64
verses.text: A fiery stream issued and came forth before Him; thousand thousands ministered unto Him, and ten thousand times ten thousand stood before Him: the judgment was set, and the books were opened," clearly disclosing in the hearing of all, angels and men, things good and evil, things done openly and in secret, deeds, words, and thoughts all at once.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:65
verses.text: What then must those men be who have lived wicked lives? Where then shall that soul hide which in the sight of all these spectators shall suddenly be revealed in its fulness of shame? With what kind of body shall it sustain those endless and unbearable pangs in the place of fire unquenched, and of the worm that perishes and never dies, and of depth of Hades, dark and horrible; bitter wailings, loud lamenting, weeping and gnashing of teeth and anguish without end? From all these woes there is no release after death; no device, no means of coming forth from the chastisement of pain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:67
verses.text: We can escape now.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:68
verses.text: While we can, let us lift ourselves from the fall: let us never despair of ourselves, if only we depart from evil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:69
verses.text: Jesus Christ came into the world to save sinners.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:70
verses.text: "O come, let us worship and fall down; let us weep before Him".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:71
verses.text: The Word Who invited us to repentance calls aloud, "Come unto me all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:72
verses.text: There is, then, a way of salvation, if we will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:73
verses.text: "Death in his might has swallowed up, but again the Lord hath wiped away tears from off all faces" of them that repent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:74
verses.text: The Lord is faithful in all His words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:75
verses.text: He does not lie when He says, "Though your sins be scarlet they shall be as white as snow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:76
verses.text: Though they be red like crimson they shall be as wool".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:77
verses.text: The great Physician of souls, Who is the ready liberator, not of you alone, but of all who are enslaved by sin, is ready to heal your sickness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:78
verses.text: From Him come the words, it was His sweet and saving lips that said, "They that be whole need not a physician but they that are sick.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:79
verses.text: …I am not come to call the righteous but sinners to repentance".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:80
verses.text: What excuse have you, what excuse has any one, when He speaks thus? The Lord wishes to cleanse you from the trouble of your sickness and to show you light after darkness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:81
verses.text: The good Shepherd, Who left them that had not wandered away, is seeking after you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:82
verses.text: If you give yourself to Him He will not hold back.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:83
verses.text: He, in His love, will not disdain even to carry you on His own shoulders, rejoicing that He has found His sheep which was lost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:84
verses.text: The Father stands and awaits your return from your wandering.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:85
verses.text: Only come back, and while you are yet afar off, He will run and fall upon your neck, and, now that you are cleansed by repentance, will enwrap you in embraces of love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:86
verses.text: He will clothe with the chief robe the soul that has put off the old man with all his works; He will put a ring on hands that have washed off the blood of death, and will put shoes on feet that have turned from the evil way to the path of the Gospel of peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:87
verses.text: He will announce the day of joy and gladness to them that are His own, both angels and men, and will celebrate your salvation far and wide.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:88
verses.text: For "verily I say unto you," says He, "there is joy in heaven before God over one sinner that repenteth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 46:89
verses.text: If any of those who think they stand find fault because of your quick reception, the good Father will Himself make answer for you in the words, "It was meet that we should make merry and be glad for this" my daughter "was dead and is alive again, was lost and is found".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 47:1
verses.text: Letter XLVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 47:2
verses.text: To Gregory".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 47:3
verses.text: Who will give me wings like a dove? Or how can my old age be so renewed that I can travel to your affection, satisfy my deep longing to see you, tell you all the troubles of my soul, and get from you some comfort in my affliction? For when the blessed bishop Eusebius fell asleep, we were under no small alarm lest plotters against the Church of our Metropolis, wishful to fill it with their heretical tares, should seize the present opportunity, root out by their wicked teaching the true faith sown by much labour in men's souls, and destroy its unity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 47:4
verses.text: This has been the result of their action in many churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 47:5
verses.text: When however I received the letters of the clergy exhorting me not to let their needs be overlooked at such a crisis, as I ranged my eyes in all directions I bethought me of your loving spirit, your right faith, and your unceasing zeal on behalf of the churches of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 47:6
verses.text: I have therefore sent the well beloved Eustathius, the deacon, to invite your reverence, and implore you to add this one more to all your labours on behalf of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 47:7
verses.text: I entreat you also to refresh my old age by a sight of you; and to maintain for the true Church its famous orthodoxy, by uniting with me, if I may be deemed worthy of uniting with you, in the good work, to give it a shepherd in accordance with the will of the Lord, able to guide His people aright.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 47:8
verses.text: I have before my eyes a man not unknown even to yourself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 47:9
verses.text: If only we be found worthy to secure him, I am sure that we shall acquire a confident access to God and confer a very great benefit on the people who have invoked our aid.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 47:10
verses.text: Now once again, aye, many times I call on you, all hesitation put aside, to come to meet me, and to set out before the difficulties of winter intervene.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:1
verses.text: Letter XLVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, Bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:3
verses.text: I have had considerable difficulty in finding a messenger to convey a letter to your reverence, for our men are so afraid of the winter that they can hardly bear even to put their heads outside their houses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:4
verses.text: We have suffered from such a very heavy fall of snow that we have been buried, houses and all, beneath it, and now for two months have been living in dens and caves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:5
verses.text: You know the Cappadocian character and how hard it is to get us to move.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:6
verses.text: Forgive me then for not writing sooner and bringing to the knowledge of your excellency the latest news from Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:7
verses.text: To tell you all this now, when it is probable that you learnt it long ago, is stale and uninteresting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:8
verses.text: But as I do not reckon it any trouble to tell you even what you know, I have sent you the letters conveyed by the reader.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:9
verses.text: On this point I shall say no more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:10
verses.text: Constantinople has now for some time had Demophilus, as the bearers of this letter will themselves tell you, and as has doubtless been reported to your holiness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:11
verses.text: From all who come to us from that city there is unanimously reported about him a certain counterfeit of orthodoxy and sound religion, to such an extent that even the divided portions of the city have been brought to agreement, and some of the neighbouring bishops have accepted the reconciliation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:12
verses.text: Our men here have not turned out better than I expected.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:13
verses.text: They came directly you were gone, said and did many painful things, and at last went home again, after making their separation from me wider.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:14
verses.text: Whether anything better will happen in the future, and whether they will give up their evil ways, is unknown to all but God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:15
verses.text: So much for our present condition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:16
verses.text: The rest of the Church, by God's grace, stands sound, and prays that in the spring we may have you with us again, and be renewed by your good counsel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 48:17
verses.text: My health is no better than it ever is.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 49:1
verses.text: Letter XLIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 49:2
verses.text: To Arcadius the Bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 49:3
verses.text: I thanked the Holy God when I read your letter, most pious brother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 49:4
verses.text: I pray that I may not be unworthy of the expectations you have formed of me, and that you will enjoy a full reward for the honour which you pay me in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 49:5
verses.text: I was exceedingly pleased to hear that you have been occupied in a matter eminently becoming a Christian, have raised a house to the glory of God, and have in practical earnest loved, as it is written, "the beauty of the house of the Lord," and have so provided for yourself that heavenly mansion which is prepared in His rest for them that love the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 49:6
verses.text: If I am able to find any relics of martyrs, I pray that I may take part in your earnest endeavour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 49:7
verses.text: If "the righteous shall be had in everlasting remembrance," I shall without doubt have a share in the good fame which the Holy One will give you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 50:1
verses.text: Letter L.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 50:2
verses.text: To Bishop Innocentius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 50:3
verses.text: Whom, indeed, could it better befit to encourage the timid, and rouse the slumbering, than you, my godly lord, who have shewn your general excellence in this, too, that you have consented to come down among us, your lowly inferiors, like a true disciple of Him Who said, "I am among you," not as a fellow guest, but "as he that serveth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 50:4
verses.text: For you have condescended to minister to us your spiritual gladness, to refresh our souls by your honoured letter, and, as it were, to fling the arms of your greatness round the infancy of children.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 50:5
verses.text: We, therefore, implore your good soul to pray, that we may be worthy to receive aid from the great, such as yourself, and to have a mouth and wisdom wherewith to chime in with the strain of all, who like you are led by the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 50:6
verses.text: Of Him I hear that you are a friend and true worshipper, and I am deeply thankful for your strong and unshaken love to God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 50:7
verses.text: I pray that my lot may be found with the true worshippers, among whom we are sure your excellency is to be ranked, as well as that great and true bishop who has filled all the world with his wonderful work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:1
verses.text: Letter LI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:2
verses.text: To Bishop Bosporius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:3
verses.text: How do you think my heart was pained at hearing of the slanders heaped on me by some of those that feel no fear of the Judge, who "shall destroy them that speak leasing"? I spent nearly the whole night sleepless, thinking of your words of love; so did grief lay hold upon my heart of hearts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:4
verses.text: For verily, in the words of Solomon, slander humbleth a man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:5
verses.text: And no man is so void of feeling as not to be touched at heart, and bowed down to the ground, if he falls in with lips prone to lying.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:6
verses.text: But we must needs put up with all things and endure all things, after committing our vindication to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:7
verses.text: He will not despise us; for "he that oppresseth the poor reproacheth his Maker".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:8
verses.text: They, however, who have patched up this new tragedy of blasphemy seem to have lost all belief in the Lord, Who has declared that we must give account at the day of judgment even for an idle word.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:9
verses.text: And I, tell me, I anathematized the right blessed Dianius? For this is what they have said against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:10
verses.text: Where? When? In whose presence? On what pretext? In mere spoken words, or in writing? Following others, or myself the author and originator of the deed? Alas for the impudence of men who make no difficulty at saying anything! Alas for their contempt of the judgment of God! Unless, indeed, they add this further to their fiction, that they make me out to have been once upon a time so far out of my mind as not to know what I was saying.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:11
verses.text: For so long as I have been in my senses I know that I never did anything of the kind, or had the least wish to do so.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:12
verses.text: What I am, indeed, conscious of is this; that from my earliest childhood I was brought up in love for him, thought as I gazed at him how venerable he looked, how dignified, how truly reverend.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:13
verses.text: Then when I grew older I began to know him by the good qualities of his soul, and took delight in his society, gradually learning to perceive the simplicity, nobility, and liberality of his character, and all his most distinctive qualities, his gentleness of soul, his mingled magnanimity and meekness, the seemliness of his conduct, his control of temper, the beaming cheerfulness and affability which he combined with majesty of demeanour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:14
verses.text: From all this I counted him among men most illustrious for high character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:15
verses.text: However, towards the close of his life (I will not conceal the truth) I, together with many of them that in our country feared the Lord, sorrowed over him with sorrow unendurable, because he signed the creed brought from Constantinople by George.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:16
verses.text: Afterwards, full of kindness and gentleness as he was, and willing out of the fulness of his fatherly heart to give satisfaction to everyone, when he had already fallen sick of the disease of which he died, he sent for me, and, calling the Lord to witness, said that in the simplicity of his heart he had agreed to the document sent from Constantinople, but had had no idea of rejecting the creed put forth by the holy Fathers at Nicaea, nor had had any other disposition of heart than from the beginning he had always had.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:17
verses.text: He prayed, moreover, that he might not be cut off from the lot of those blessed three hundred and eighteen bishops who had announced the pious decree to the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:18
verses.text: In consequence of this satisfactory statement I dismissed all anxiety and doubt, and, as you are aware, communicated with him, and gave over grieving.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:19
verses.text: Such have been my relations with Dianius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 51:20
verses.text: If anyone avers that he is privy to any vile slander on my part against Dianius, do not let him buzz it slave-wise in a corner; let him come boldly out and convict me in the light of day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:1
verses.text: Letter LII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:2
verses.text: To the Canonicae.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:4
verses.text: I have been very much distressed by a painful report which reached my ears; but I have been equally delighted by my brother, beloved of God, bishop Bosporius, who has brought a more satisfactory account of you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:5
verses.text: He avers by God's grace that all those stories spread abroad about you are inventions of men who are not exactly informed as to the truth about you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:6
verses.text: He added, moreover, that he found among you impious calumnies about me, of a kind likely to be uttered by those who do not expect to have to give the Judge in the day of His righteous retribution an account of even an idle word.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:7
verses.text: I thank God, then, both because I am cured of my damaging opinion of you, an opinion which I have derived from the calumnies of men, and because I have heard of your abandonment of those baseless notions about me, on hearing the assurances of my brother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:8
verses.text: He, in all that he has said as coming from himself, has also completely expressed my own feeling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:9
verses.text: For in us both there is one mind about the faith, as being heirs of the same Fathers who once at Nicaea promulgated their great decree concerning the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:10
verses.text: Of this, some portions are universally accepted without cavil, but the homoousion, ill received in certain quarters, is still rejected by some.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:11
verses.text: These objectors we may very properly blame, and yet on the contrary deem them deserving of pardon.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:12
verses.text: To refuse to follow the Fathers, not holding their declaration of more authority than one's own opinion, is conduct worthy of blame, as being brimful of self-sufficiency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:13
verses.text: On the other hand the fact that they view with suspicion a phrase which is misrepresented by an opposite party does seem to a small extent to relieve them from blame.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:14
verses.text: Moreover, as a matter of fact, the members of the synods which met to discuss the case of Paul of Samosata did find fault with the term as an unfortunate one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:15
verses.text: For they maintained that the homoousion set forth the idea both of essence and of what is derived from it, so that the essence, when divided, confers the title of co-essential on the parts into which it is divided.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:16
verses.text: This explanation has some reason in the case of bronze and coins made therefrom, but in the case of God the Father and God the Son there is no question of substance anterior or even underlying both; the mere thought and utterance of such a thing is the last extravagance of impiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:17
verses.text: What can be conceived of as anterior to the Unbegotten? By this blasphemy faith in the Father and the Son is destroyed, for things, constituted out of one, have to one another the relation of brothers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:19
verses.text: Because even at that time there were men who asserted the Son to have been brought into being out of the non-existent, the term homoousion was adopted, to extirpate this impiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:20
verses.text: For the conjunction of the Son with the Father is without time and without interval.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:21
verses.text: The preceding words shew this to have been the intended meaning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:22
verses.text: For after saying that the Son was light of light, and begotten of the substance of the Father, but was not made, they went on to add the homoousion, thereby showing that whatever proportion of light any one would attribute in the case of the Father will obtain also in that of the Son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:23
verses.text: For very light in relation to very light, according to the actual sense of light, will have no variation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:24
verses.text: Since then the Father is light without beginning, and the Son begotten light, but each of Them light and light; they rightly said "of one substance," in order to set forth the equal dignity of the nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:25
verses.text: Things, that have a relation of brotherhood, are not, as some persons have supposed, of one substance; but when both the cause and that which derives its natural existence from the cause are of the same nature, then they are called "of one substance".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:27
verses.text: This term also corrects the error of Sabellius, for it removes the idea of the identity of the hypostases, and introduces in perfection the idea of the Persons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:28
verses.text: For nothing can be of one substance with itself, but one thing is of one substance with another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:29
verses.text: The word has therefore an excellent and orthodox use, defining as it does both the proper character of the hypostases, and setting forth the invariability of the nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:30
verses.text: And when we are taught that the Son is of the substance of the Father, begotten and not made, let us not fall into the material sense of the relations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:31
verses.text: For the substance was not separated from the Father and bestowed on the Son; neither did the substance engender by fluxion, nor yet by shooting forth as plants their fruits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:32
verses.text: The mode of the divine begetting is ineffable and inconceivable by human thought.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:33
verses.text: It is indeed characteristic of poor and carnal intelligence to compare the things that are eternal with the perishing things of time, and to imagine, that as corporeal things beget, so does God in like manner; it is rather our duty to rise to the truth by arguments of the contrary, and to say, that since thus is the mortal, not thus is He who is immortal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:34
verses.text: We must neither then deny the divine generation, nor contaminate our intelligence with corporeal senses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:36
verses.text: The Holy Spirit, too, is numbered with the Father and the Son, because He is above creation, and is ranked as we are taught by the words of the Lord in the Gospel, "Go and baptize in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:37
verses.text: He who, on the contrary, places the Spirit before the Son, or alleges Him to be older than the Father, resists the ordinance of God, and is a stranger to the sound faith, since he fails to preserve the form of doxology which he has received, but adopts some new fangled device in order to be pleasing to men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:38
verses.text: It is written "The Spirit is of God," and if He is of God, how can He be older than that of which He is? And what folly is it not, when there is one Unbegotten, to speak of something else as superior to the Unbegotten? He is not even anterior, for nothing intervenes between Son and Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:39
verses.text: If, however, He is not of God but is through Christ, He does not even exist at all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:40
verses.text: It follows, that this new invention about the order really involves the destruction of the actual existence, and is a denial of the whole faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:41
verses.text: It is equally impious to reduce Him to the level of a creature, and to subordinate Him either to Son or to Father, either in time or in rank.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:42
verses.text: These are the points on which I have heard that you are making enquiry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 52:43
verses.text: If the Lord grant that we meet I may possibly have more to say on these subjects, and may myself, concerning points which I am investigating, receive satisfactory information from you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:1
verses.text: Letter LIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:2
verses.text: To the Chorepiscopi.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:4
verses.text: My soul is deeply pained at the enormity of the matter on which I write, if for this only, that it has caused general suspicion and talk.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:5
verses.text: But so far it has seemed to me incredible.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:6
verses.text: I hope then that what I am writing about it may be taken by the guilty as medicine, by the innocent as a warning, by the indifferent, in which class I trust none of you may be found, as a testimony.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:7
verses.text: And what is it of which I speak? There is a report that some of you take money from candidates for ordination, and excuse it on grounds of religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:8
verses.text: This is indeed worse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:9
verses.text: If any one does evil under the guise of good he deserves double punishment; because he not only does what is in itself not good, but, so to say, makes good an accomplice in the commission of sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:10
verses.text: If the allegation be true, let it be so no more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:11
verses.text: Let a better state of things begin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:12
verses.text: To the recipient of the bribe it must be said, as was said by the Apostles to him who was willing to give money to buy the fellowship of the Holy Ghost, "Thy money perish with thee.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:13
verses.text: It is a lighter sin to wish in ignorance to buy, than it is to sell, the gift of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:14
verses.text: A sale it was; and if you sell what you received as a free gift you will be deprived of the boon, as though you were yourself sold to Satan.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:15
verses.text: You are obtruding the traffic of the huckster into spiritual things and into the Church where we are entrusted with the body and blood of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:16
verses.text: These things must not be.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:17
verses.text: And I will mention wherein lies an ingenious contrivance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:18
verses.text: They think that there is no sin because they take the money not before but after the ordination; but to take is to take at whatever time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:20
verses.text: I exhort you, then, abandon this gain, or, I would rather say, this approach to Hell.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:21
verses.text: Do not, by defiling your hands with such bribes, render yourselves unfit to celebrate holy mysteries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:22
verses.text: But forgive me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:23
verses.text: I began by discrediting; and now I am threatening as though I were convinced.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:24
verses.text: If, after this letter of mine, any one do anything of the kind, he will depart from the altars here and will seek a place where he is able to buy and to sell God's gift.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:25
verses.text: We and the Churches of God have no such custom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:26
verses.text: One word more, and I have done.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:27
verses.text: These things come of covetousness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:28
verses.text: Now covetousness is the root of all evil and is called idolatry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:29
verses.text: Do not then price idols above Christ for the sake of a little money.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:30
verses.text: Do not imitate Judas and once more betray for a bribe Him who was crucified for us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 53:31
verses.text: For alike the lands and the hands of all that make such gain shall be called Aceldama.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:1
verses.text: Letter LIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:2
verses.text: To the Chorepiscopi.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:3
verses.text: I am much distressed that the canons of the Fathers have fallen through, and that the exact discipline of the Church has been banished from among you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:4
verses.text: I am apprehensive lest, as this indifference grows, the affairs of the Church should, little by little, fall into confusion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:5
verses.text: According to the ancient custom observed in the Churches of God, ministers in the Church were received after careful examination; the whole of their life was investigated; an enquiry was made as to their being neither railers nor drunkards, not quick to quarrel, keeping their youth in subjection, so as to be able to maintain "the holiness without which no man shall see the Lord".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:6
verses.text: This examination was made by presbyters and deacons living with them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:7
verses.text: Then they brought them to the Chorepiscopi; and the Chorepiscopi, after receiving the suffrages of the witnesses as to the truth and giving information to the Bishop, so admitted the minister to the sacerdotal order.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:8
verses.text: Now, however, you have quite passed me over; you have not even had the grace to refer to me, and have transferred the whole authority to yourselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:9
verses.text: Furthermore, with complete indifference, you have allowed presbyters and deacons to introduce unworthy persons into the Church, just any one they choose, without any previous examination of life and character, by mere favoritism, on the score of relationship or some other tie.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:10
verses.text: The consequence is, that in every village, there are reckoned many ministers, but not one single man worthy of the service of the altars.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:11
verses.text: Of this you yourselves supply proof from your difficulty in finding suitable candidates for election.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:12
verses.text: As, then, I perceive that the evil is gradually reaching a point at which it would be incurable, and especially at this moment when a large number of persons are presenting themselves for the ministry through fear of the conscription, I am constrained to have recourse to the restitution of the canons of the Fathers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:13
verses.text: I thus order you in writing to send me the roll of the ministers in every village, stating by whom each has been introduced, and what is his mode of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:14
verses.text: You have the roll in your own keeping, so that your version can be compared with the documents which are in mine, and no one can insert his own name when he likes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:15
verses.text: So if any have been introduced by presbyters after the first appointment, let them be rejected, and take their place among the laity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:16
verses.text: Their examination must then be begun by you over again, and, if they prove worthy, let them be received by your decision.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:17
verses.text: Drive out unworthy men from the Church, and so purge it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:18
verses.text: For the future, test by examination those who are worthy, and then receive them; but do not reckon them of the number before you have reported to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 54:19
verses.text: Otherwise, distinctly understand that he who is admitted to the ministry without my authority will remain a layman.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:1
verses.text: Letter LV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:2
verses.text: To Paregorius, the presbyter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:3
verses.text: I have given patient attention to your letter, and I am astonished that when you are perfectly well able to furnish me with a short and easy defence by taking action at once, you should choose to persist in what is my ground of complaint, and endeavour to cure the incurable by writing a long story about it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:4
verses.text: I am not the first, Paregorius, nor the only man, to lay down the law that women are not to live with men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:5
verses.text: Read the canon put forth by our holy Fathers at the Council of Nicaea, which distinctly forbids subintroducts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:6
verses.text: Unmarried life is honourably distinguished by its being cut off from all female society.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:7
verses.text: If, then, any one, who is known by the outward profession, in reality follows the example of those who live with wives, it is obvious that he only affects the distinction of virginity in name, and does not hold aloof from unbecoming indulgence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:8
verses.text: You ought to have been all the more ready to submit yourself without difficulty to my demands, in that you allege that you are free from all bodily appetite.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:9
verses.text: I do not suppose that a man of three score years and ten lives with a woman from any such feelings, and I have not decided, as I have decided, on the ground of any crime having been committed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:10
verses.text: But we have learnt from the Apostle, not to put a stumbling block or an occasion to fall in a brother's way;" and I know that what is done very properly by some, naturally becomes to others an occasion for sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:11
verses.text: I have therefore given my order, in obedience to the injunction of the holy Fathers, that you are to separate from the woman.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:12
verses.text: Why then, do you find fault with the Chorepiscopus? What is the good of mentioning ancient ill-will? Why do you blame me for lending an easy ear to slander? Why do you not rather lay the blame on yourself, for not consenting to break off your connexion with the woman? Expel her from your house, and establish her in a monastery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:13
verses.text: Let her live with virgins, and do you be served by men, that the name of God be not blasphemed in you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:14
verses.text: Till you have so done, the innumerable arguments, which you use in your letters, will not do you the slightest service.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:15
verses.text: You will die useless, and you will have to give an account to God for your uselessness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 55:16
verses.text: If you persist in clinging to your clerical position without correcting your ways, you will be accursed before all the people, and all, who receive you, will be excommunicate throughout the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:1
verses.text: Letter LVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:2
verses.text: To Pergamius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:3
verses.text: I naturally forget very easily, and I have had lately many things to do, and so my natural infirmity is increased.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:4
verses.text: I have no doubt, therefore, that you have written to me, although I have no recollection of having received any letter from your excellency; for I am sure you would not state what is not the case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:5
verses.text: But for there having been no reply, it is not I that am in fault; the guilt lies with him who did not ask for one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:6
verses.text: Now, however, you have this letter, containing my defence for the past and affording ground for a second greeting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:7
verses.text: So, when you write to me, do not suppose that you are taking the initiative in another correspondence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:8
verses.text: You are only discharging your proper obligation in this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:9
verses.text: For really, although this letter of mine is a return for a previous one of yours, as it is more than twice as bulky, it will fulfil a double purpose.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:10
verses.text: You see to what sophisms my idleness drives me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:11
verses.text: But, my dear Sir, do not in a few words bring serious charges, indeed the most serious of all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:12
verses.text: Forgetfulness of one's friends, and neglect of them arising from high place, are faults which involve every kind of wrong.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:13
verses.text: Do we fail to love according to the commandment of the Lord? Then we lose the distinctive mark imprinted on us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:14
verses.text: Are we puffed to repletion with empty pride and arrogance? Then we fall into the inevitable condemnation of the devil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:15
verses.text: If, then, you use these words because you held such sentiments about me, pray that I may flee from the wickedness which you have found in my ways; if, however, your tongue shaped itself to these words, in a kind of inconsiderate conventionality, I shall console myself, and ask you to be good enough to adduce some tangible proof of your allegations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:16
verses.text: Be well assured of this, that my present anxiety is an occasion to me of humility.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:17
verses.text: I shall begin to forget you, when I cease to know myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 56:18
verses.text: Never, then, think that because a man is a very busy man he is a man of faulty character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 57:1
verses.text: Letter LVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 57:2
verses.text: To Meletius, Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 57:3
verses.text: If your holiness only knew the greatness of the happiness you cause me whenever you write to me, I know that you would never have let slip any opportunity of sending me a letter; nay, you would have written me many letters on each occasion, knowing the reward that is kept in store by our loving Lord for the consolation of the afflicted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 57:4
verses.text: Everything here is still in a very painful condition, and the thought of your holiness is the only thing that recalls me from my own troubles; a thought made more distinct to me by my communication with you through that letter of yours which is so full of wisdom and grace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 57:5
verses.text: When, therefore, I take your letter into my hand, first of all, I look at its size, and I love it all the more for being so big; then, as I read it, I rejoice over every word I find in it; as I draw near the end I begin to feel sad; so good is every word that I read, in what you write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 57:6
verses.text: The overflowing of a good heart is good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 57:7
verses.text: Should I, however, be permitted, in answer to your prayers, while I live on this earth, to meet you face to face, and to enjoy the profitable instruction of your living voice, or any aids to help me in the life that now is, or that which is to come, I should count this indeed the best of blessings, a prelude to the mercy of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 57:8
verses.text: I should, ere now, have adhered to this intention, had I not been prevented by true and loving brothers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 57:9
verses.text: I have told my brother Theophrastus to make a detailed report to you of matters, as to which I do not commit my intentions to writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:1
verses.text: Letter LVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:2
verses.text: To Gregory my brother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:3
verses.text: How am I to dispute with you in writing? How can I lay hold of you satisfactorily, with all your simplicity? Tell me; who ever falls a third time into the same nets? Who ever gets a third time into the same snare? Even a brute beast would find it difficult to do so.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:4
verses.text: You forged one letter, and brought it me as though it came from our right reverend uncle the bishop, trying to deceive me, I have no idea why.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:5
verses.text: I received it as a letter written by the bishop and delivered by you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:6
verses.text: Why should I not? I was delighted; I shewed it to many of my friends; I thanked God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:7
verses.text: The forgery was found out, on the bishop's repudiating it in person.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:8
verses.text: I was thoroughly ashamed; covered as I was with the disgrace of cunning trickery and lies, I prayed that the earth might open for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:9
verses.text: Then they gave me a second letter, as sent by the bishop himself by the hands of your servant Asterius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:10
verses.text: Even this second had not really been sent by the bishop, as my very reverend brother Anthimus has told me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:11
verses.text: Now Adamantius has come bringing me a third.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:12
verses.text: How ought I to receive a letter carried by you or yours? I might have prayed to have a heart of stone, so as neither to remember the past, nor to feel the present; so as to bear every blow, like cattle, with bowed head.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:13
verses.text: But what am I to think, now that, after my first and second experience, I can admit nothing without positive proof? Thus I write attacking your simplicity, which I see plainly to be neither what generally becomes a Christian man, nor is appropriate to the present emergency; I write that, at least for the future, you may take care of yourself and spare me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:14
verses.text: I must speak to you with all freedom, and I tell you that you are an unworthy minister of things so great.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:15
verses.text: However, whoever be the writer of the letter, I have answered as is fit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:16
verses.text: Whether, then, you yourself are experimenting on me, or whether really the letter which you have sent is one which you have received from the bishops, you have my answer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:17
verses.text: At such a time as this you ought to have borne in mind that you are my brother, and have not yet forgotten the ties of nature, and do not regard me in the light of an enemy, for I have entered on a life which is wearing out my strength, and is so far beyond my powers that it is injuring even my soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:18
verses.text: Yet for all this, as you have determined to declare war against me, you ought to have come to me and shared my troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:19
verses.text: For it is said, "Brethren and help are against time of trouble".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:20
verses.text: If the right reverend bishops are really willing to meet me, let them make known to me a place and time, and let them invite me by their own men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 58:21
verses.text: I do not refuse to meet my own uncle, but I shall not do so unless the invitation reaches me in due and proper form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:1
verses.text: Letter LIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:2
verses.text: To Gregory, his uncle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:4
verses.text: "I have long time holden my peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:5
verses.text: Am I to hold my peace for ever? Shall I still further endure to enforce against myself the hardest punishment of silence, by neither writing myself, nor receiving any statement from another? By holding fast to this stern determination up to the present time I am able to apply to myself the prophet's words, "I endure patiently like travailing woman".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:6
verses.text: Yet I am ever longing for communication either in person or by letter, and ever, for my own sins' sake, missing it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:7
verses.text: For I cannot imagine any reason for what is happening, other than what I am convinced is the true one, that by being cut off from your love I am expiating old sins; if indeed I am not wrong in using such a phrase as "cut off" in your case, from any one, much less from me, to whom you have always been as a father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:8
verses.text: Now my sin, like some dense cloud overshadowing me, has made me forget all this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:9
verses.text: When I reflect that the only result to me of what is going on is sorrow, how can I attribute it to anything but to my own wickedness? But if events are to be traced to sins, be this the end of my troubles; if there was any intended discipline in it, then your object has been very completely attained, for the punishment has been going on for a long time; so I groan no longer, but am the first to break silence, and beseech you to remember both me and yourself who, to a greater degree than our relationship might have demanded, have shewn me strong affection all my life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:10
verses.text: Now, I implore you, show kindness to the city for my sake.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:11
verses.text: Do not on my account alienate yourself from it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:13
verses.text: If, then, there is any consolation in Christ, any fellowship of the Spirit, any mercy and pity, fulfil my prayer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:14
verses.text: Put a stop to my depression.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:15
verses.text: Let there be a beginning of brighter things for the future.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:16
verses.text: Be yourself a leader to others in the road to all that is best, and follow no one else in the way to what is wrong.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:17
verses.text: Never was any feature so characteristic of any one's body as gentleness and peace are of your soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:18
verses.text: It were well becoming such a one as you are to draw all others to yourself, and to cause all who come near you to be permeated with the goodness of your nature, as with the fragrance of myrrh.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:19
verses.text: For though there be a certain amount of opposition now, nevertheless ere long there will be a recognition of the blessings of peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:20
verses.text: So long, however, as room is found for the calumnies that are bred of dissension, suspicion is sure to grow from worse to worse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:21
verses.text: It is most certainly unbecoming for the rest to take no notice of me, but it is especially unbecoming in your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:22
verses.text: If I am wrong I shall be all the better for being rebuked.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:23
verses.text: This is impossible if we never meet.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:24
verses.text: But, if I am doing no wrong, for what am I disliked? So much I offer in my own defence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:26
verses.text: As to what the Churches might say in their own behalf, perhaps it is better for me to be silent: they reap the result of our disagreement, and it is not to their gain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:27
verses.text: I am not speaking to indulge my grief but to put a stop to it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:28
verses.text: And your intelligence, I am sure, has suffered nothing to escape you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:29
verses.text: You will yourself be better able to discern and to tell to others points of far greater importance than I can conceive.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:30
verses.text: You saw the mischief done to the Churches before I did; and you are grieving more than I am, for you have long learnt from the Lord not to despise even the least.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:31
verses.text: And now the mischief is not confined to one or two, but whole cities and peoples are sharers in my calamities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:32
verses.text: What need to tell what kind of report will spread about me even beyond our borders? It were well for you, large hearted as you are, to leave the love of strife to others; nay rather, if it be possible, to root it from their hearts, while you yourself vanquish what is grievous by endurance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:33
verses.text: Any angry man can defend himself, but to rise above the actual anger belongs only to you, and any one as good as you, if such there be.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:34
verses.text: One thing I will not say, that he who has a grudge against me is letting his anger fall on the innocent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:35
verses.text: Do then comfort my soul by coming to me, or by a letter, or by inviting me to come to you, or by some means or other.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:36
verses.text: My prayer is that your piety may be seen in the Church and that you may heal at once me and the people, both by the sight of you and by the words of your good grace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:37
verses.text: If this be possible it is best; if you determine on any other course I shall willingly accept it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 59:38
verses.text: Only accede to my entreaty that you will give me distinct information as to what your wisdom decides.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:1
verses.text: Letter LX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:2
verses.text: To Gregory his uncle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:3
verses.text: Formerly I was glad to see my brother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:4
verses.text: Why not, since he is my brother and such a brother? Now I have received him on his coming to visit me with the same feelings, and have lost none of my affection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:5
verses.text: God forbid that I should ever so feel as to forget the ties of nature and be at war with those who are near and dear to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:6
verses.text: I have found his presence a comfort in my bodily sickness and the other troubles of my soul, and I have been especially delighted at the letter which he has brought me from your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:7
verses.text: For a long time I have been hoping that it would come, for this only reason, that I need not add to my life any doleful episode of quarrel between kith and kin, sure to give pleasure to foes and sorrow to friends, and to be displeasing to God, Who has laid down perfect love as the distinctive characteristic of His disciples.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:8
verses.text: So I reply, as I am indeed bound, with an earnest request for your prayers for me, and your care for me in all things, as your relative.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:9
verses.text: Since I, from want of information, cannot clearly understand the meaning of what is going on, I have judged it right to accept the truth of the account which you are so good as to give me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:10
verses.text: It is for you of your wisdom to settle the rest, our meeting with one another, the fitting time and a convenient place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:11
verses.text: If your reverence really does not disdain to come down to my lowliness and to have speech with me, whether you wish the interview to take place in the presence of others or in private, I shall make no objection, for I have once for all made up my mind to submit to you in love, and to carry out, without exception, what your reverence enjoins on me for the glory of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 60:12
verses.text: I have not laid my reverend brother under the necessity of reporting anything to you by word of mouth, because on the former occasion what he said was not borne out by facts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 61:1
verses.text: Letter LXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 61:2
verses.text: To Athanasius, Bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 61:3
verses.text: I have read the letter of your holiness, in which you have expressed your distress at the unhappy governor of Libya.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 61:4
verses.text: I am grieved that my own country should have given birth to and nurtured such vices.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 61:5
verses.text: I am grieved too that Libya, a neighbouring country, should suffer from our evils, and should have been delivered to the inhumanity of a man whose life is marked at once by cruelty and crime.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 61:6
verses.text: This however is only in accordance with the wisdom of the Preacher, "Woe to thee O land when thy King is a child;" (a still further touch of trouble) and whose "Princes" do not "eat" after night but revel at mid-day, raging after other men's wives with less understanding than brute beasts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 61:7
verses.text: This man must surely look for the scourges of the righteous Judge, repaid him in exact requital for those which he himself has previously inflicted on the saints.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 61:8
verses.text: Notice has been given to my Church in accordance with the letter of your reverence, and he shall be held by all as abominable, cut off from fire, water and shelter, if indeed in the case of men so possessed there is any use in general and unanimous condemnation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 61:9
verses.text: Notoriety is enough for him, and your own letter, which has been read in all directions, for I shall not fail to show it to all his friends and relatives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 61:10
verses.text: Assuredly, even if retribution does not reach him at once, as it did Pharaoh, certainly it will bring on him hereafter a heavy and hard requital.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 62:1
verses.text: Letter LXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 62:2
verses.text: To the Church of Parnassus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 62:3
verses.text: Following an ancient custom, which has obtained for many years, and at the same time shewing you love in God, which is the fruit of the Spirit, I now, my pious friends, address this letter to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 62:4
verses.text: I feel with you at once in your grief at the event which has befallen you, and in your anxiety at the matter which you have in hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 62:5
verses.text: Concerning all these troubles I can only say, that an occasion is given us to look to the injunctions of the Apostle, and not to sorrow "even as others which have no hope".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 62:6
verses.text: I do not mean that we should be insensible to the loss we have suffered, but that we should not succumb to our sorrow, while we count the Pastor happy in his end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 62:7
verses.text: He has died in a ripe old age, and has found his rest in the great honour given him by his Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 62:8
verses.text: As to the future I have this recommendation to give you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 62:9
verses.text: You must now lay aside all mourning; you must come to yourselves; you must rise to the necessary management of the Church; to the end that the holy God may give heed to His own little flock, and may grant you a shepherd in accordance with His own will, who may wisely feed you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:1
verses.text: Letter LXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:2
verses.text: To the Governor of Neocaesarea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:3
verses.text: The wise man, even if he dwells far away, even if I never set eyes on him, I count a friend.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:4
verses.text: So says the tragedian Euripides.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:5
verses.text: And so, if, though I have never had the pleasure of meeting your excellency in person, I speak of myself as a familiar friend, pray do not set this down to mere empty compliment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:6
verses.text: Common report, which loudly proclaims your universal benevolence, is, in this instance, the promoter of friendship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:7
verses.text: Indeed since I met the highly respectable Elpidius, I have known you as well, and I have been as completely captured by you, as though I had long lived with you and had practical experience of your excellent qualities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:8
verses.text: For he did not cease telling me about you, mentioning one by one your magnanimity, your exalted sentiments, your mild manners, your skill in business, intelligence, dignity tempered by cheerfulness, and eloquence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:9
verses.text: All the other points that he enumerated in his long conversation with me it is impossible for me to write to you, without extending my letter beyond all reasonable bounds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:10
verses.text: How can I fail to love such a man? How could I put such restraint upon myself as not loudly to proclaim what I feel? Accept then, most excellent Sir, the greeting which I send you, for it is inspired by true and unfeigned friendship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:11
verses.text: I abhor all servile compliment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 63:12
verses.text: Pray keep me enrolled in the list of your friends, and, by frequently writing to me, bring yourself before me and comfort me in your absence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 64:1
verses.text: Letter LXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 64:2
verses.text: To Hesychius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 64:3
verses.text: From the beginning I have had many points in common with your excellency, your love of letters, everywhere reported by all who have experienced it, and our old friendship with the admirable Terentius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 64:4
verses.text: But since that most excellent man, who is to me all that friendship could require, my worthy brother Elpidius, has met me, and told me all your good qualities, (and who more capable than he at once to perceive a man's virtue and to describe it?) he has kindled in me such a desire to see you, that I pray that you may one day visit me in my old home, that I may enjoy your good qualities, not merely by hearing of them, but by actual experience.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 65:1
verses.text: Letter LXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 65:2
verses.text: To Atarbius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 65:3
verses.text: If I continue to insist on the privileges to which my superior age entitles me, and wait for you to take the initiative in communication , and if you, my friend, wish to adhere more persistently to your evil counsel of inaction, what end will there be to our silence? However, where friendship is involved, to be defeated is in my opinion to win, and so I am quite ready to gave you precedence, and retire from the contest as to which should maintain his own opinion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 65:4
verses.text: I have been the first to betake myself to writing, because I know that "charity beareth all things…endureth all things…seeketh not her own" and so "never faileth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 65:5
verses.text: He who subjects himself to his neighbour in love can never be humiliated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 65:6
verses.text: I do beg you, then, at all events for the future, show the first and greatest fruit of the Spirit, Love; away with the angry man's sullenness which you are showing me by your silence, and recover joy in your heart, peace with the brothers who are of one mind with you, and zeal and anxiety for the continued safety of the Churches of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 65:7
verses.text: If I were not to make as strenuous efforts on behalf of the Churches as the opponents of sound doctrine make to subvert and utterly destroy them, you may be quite sure that there is nothing to prevent the truth from being swept away and destroyed by its enemies, and my being involved in the condemnation, for not shewing all possible anxiety for the unity of the Churches, with all zeal and eagerness in mutual unanimity and godly agreement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 65:8
verses.text: I exhort you then, drive out of your mind the idea that you need communion with no one else.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 65:9
verses.text: To cut one's self off from connexion with the brethren is not the mark of one who is walking by love, nor yet the fulfilling of the commandment of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 65:10
verses.text: At the same time I do wish you, with all your good intentions, to take into account that the calamities of the war which are now all round about us may one day be at our own doors, and if we too, like all the rest, have our share of outrage, we shall not find any even to sympathise with us, because in the hour of our prosperity we refused to give our share of sympathy to the wronged.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:1
verses.text: Letter LXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:2
verses.text: To Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:3
verses.text: No one, I feel sure, is more distressed at the present condition, or, rather to speak more truly, ill condition of the Churches than your excellency; for you compare the present with the past, and take into account how great a change has come about.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:4
verses.text: You are well aware that if no check is put to the swift deterioration which we are witnessing, there will soon be nothing to prevent the complete transformation of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:5
verses.text: And if the decay of the Churches seems so pitiful to me, what must—so I have often in my lonely musings reflected—be the feelings of one who has known, by experience, the old tranquillity of the Churches of the Lord, and their one mind about the faith? But as your excellency feels most deeply this distress, it seems to me only becoming that your wisdom should be more strongly moved to interest itself in the Church's behalf.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:6
verses.text: I for my part have long been aware, so far as my moderate intelligence has been able to judge of current events, that the one way of safety for the Churches of the East lies in their having the sympathy of the bishops of the West.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:7
verses.text: For if only those bishops liked to show the same energy on behalf of the Christians sojourning in our part of the world which they have shewn in the case of one or two of the men convicted of breaches of orthodoxy in the West, our common interests would probably reap no small benefit, our sovereigns treating the authority of the people with respect, and the laity in all quarters unhesitatingly following them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:8
verses.text: But, to carry out these objects, who has more capacity than yourself, with your intelligence and prudence? Who is keener to see the needful course to be taken? Who has more practical experience in working a profitable policy? Who feels more deeply the troubles of the brethren? What through all the West is more honoured than your venerable gray hairs? O most honoured father, leave behind you some memorial worthy of your life and character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:9
verses.text: By this one act crown your innumerable efforts on behalf of true religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:10
verses.text: Despatch from the holy Church placed under your care men of ability in sound doctrine to the bishops in the West.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:11
verses.text: Recount to them the troubles whereby we are beset.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:12
verses.text: Suggest some mode of relief.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:13
verses.text: Be a Samuel to the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:14
verses.text: Share the grief of the beleaguered people.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:15
verses.text: Offer prayers for peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:16
verses.text: Ask favour from the Lord, that He will send some memorial of peace to the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:17
verses.text: I know how weak letters are to move men in matters of such importance; but you yourself no more need exhortation from others than the noblest athletes need the children's cheers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:18
verses.text: It is not as though I were instructing one in ignorance; I am only giving a new impulse to one whose energies are already roused.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:19
verses.text: For the rest of the affairs of the East perhaps you may need the aid of more, and we must wait for the Westerns.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:20
verses.text: But plainly the discipline of the Church of Antioch depends upon your reverence's being able to control some, to reduce others to silence, and to restore strength to the Church by concord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:21
verses.text: No one knows better than you do, that, like all wise physicians, you ought to begin your treatment in the most vital parts, and what part is more vital to the Churches throughout the world than Antioch? Only let Antioch be restored to harmony, and nothing will stand in the way of her supplying, as a healthy head, soundness to all the body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:22
verses.text: Truly the diseases of that city, which has not only been cut asunder by heretics, but is torn in pieces by men who say that they are of one mind with one another, stand in need of your wisdom and evangelic sympathy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:23
verses.text: To unite the sundered parts again, and bring about the harmony of one body, belongs to Him alone Who by His ineffable power grants even to the dry bones to come back again to sinews and flesh.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:24
verses.text: But the Lord always works His mighty works by means of them that are worthy of Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 66:25
verses.text: Once again, in this case too, we trust that the ministry of matters so important may beseem your excellency, with the result that you will lay the tempest of the people, do away with the party superiorities, and subject all to one another in love, and give back to the Church her ancient strength.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 67:1
verses.text: Letter LXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 67:2
verses.text: To Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 67:3
