verses.text: In my former letter it seemed to me sufficient to point out to your excellency, that all that portion of the people of the holy Church of Antioch who are sound in the faith, ought to be brought to concord and unity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 67:4
verses.text: My object was to make it plain that the sections, now divided into several parts, ought to be united under the God-beloved bishop Meletius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 67:5
verses.text: Now the same beloved deacon, Dorotheus, has requested a more distinct statement on these subjects, and I am therefore constrained to point out that it is the prayer of the whole East, and the earnest desire of one who, like myself, is so wholly united to him, to see him in authority over the Churches of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 67:6
verses.text: He is a man of unimpeachable faith; his manner of life is incomparably excellent, he stands at the head, so to say, of the whole body of the Church, and all else are mere disjointed members.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 67:7
verses.text: On every ground, then, it is necessary as well as advantageous, that the rest should be united with him, just as smaller streams with great ones.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 67:8
verses.text: About the rest, however, a certain amount of management is needed, befitting their position, and likely to pacify the people.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 67:9
verses.text: This is in keeping with your own wisdom, and with your famous readiness and energy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 67:10
verses.text: It has however by no means escaped your intelligence, that this same course of procedure has already recommended itself to the Westerns who are in agreement with you, as I learn from the letters brought to me by the blessed Silvanus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 68:1
verses.text: Letter LXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 68:2
verses.text: To Meletius, bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 68:3
verses.text: I wished to detain the reverend brother Dorotheus, the deacon, so long at my side, with the object of keeping him until the end of the negociations, and so by him acquainting your excellency with every detail.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 68:4
verses.text: But day after day went by; the delay was becoming protracted; now, the moment that some plan, so far as is possible in my difficulties, has occurred to me concerning the course to be taken, I send him to approach your holiness, to make a personal report to you on all the circumstances, and show you my memorandum, to the end that, if what has occurred to me seems to you to be likely to be of service, your excellency may urge on its accomplishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 68:5
verses.text: To be brief, the opinion has prevailed that it is best for this our brother Dorotheus to travel to Rome, to move some of the Italians to undertake a voyage by sea to visit us, that they may avoid all who would put difficulties in their way.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 68:6
verses.text: My reason for this course is that I see that those, who are all powerful with the Emperor, are neither willing nor able to make any suggestion to him about the exiled, but only count it so much to the good that they see no worse thing befalling the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 68:7
verses.text: If, then, my plan seems good also to your prudence, you will be good enough both to indite letters and dictate memoranda as to the points on which he must enlarge, and as to whom he had better address himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 68:8
verses.text: And so that your despatches may have weight and authority, you will add all those who share your sentiments, even though they are not on the spot.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 68:9
verses.text: Here all is uncertain; Euippius has arrived, but so far has made no sign.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 68:10
verses.text: However, he and those who think with him from the Armenian Tetrapolis and Cilicia are threatening a tumultuous meeting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:1
verses.text: Letter LXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:2
verses.text: To Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:4
verses.text: As time moves on, it continually confirms the opinion which I have long held of your holiness; or rather that opinion is strengthened by the daily course of events.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:5
verses.text: Most men are indeed satisfied with observing, each one, what lies especially within his own province; not thus is it with you, but your anxiety for all the Churches is no less than that which you feel for the Church that has been especially entrusted to you by our common Lord; inasmuch as you leave no interval in speaking, exhorting, writing, and despatching emissaries, who from time to time give the best advice in each emergency as it arises.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:6
verses.text: Now, from the sacred ranks of your clergy, you have sent forth the venerable brother Peter, whom I have welcomed with great joy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:7
verses.text: I have also approved of the good object of his journey, which he manifests in accordance with the commands of your excellency, in effecting reconciliation where he finds opposition, and bringing about union instead of division.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:8
verses.text: With the object of offering some contribution to the action which is being taken in this matter, I have thought that I could not make a more fitting beginning than by having recourse to your excellency, as to the head and chief of all, and treating you as alike adviser and commander in the enterprise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:9
verses.text: I have therefore determined to send to your reverence our brother Dorotheus the deacon, of the Church under the right honourable bishop Meletius, being one who at once is an energetic supporter of the orthodox faith, and is earnestly desirous of seeing the peace of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:10
verses.text: The results, I hope, will be, that, following your suggestions (which you are able to make with the less likelihood of failure, both from your age and your experience in affairs, and because you have a greater measure than all others of the aid of the Spirit), he may thus attempt the achievement of our objects.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:11
verses.text: You will welcome him, I am sure, and will look upon him with friendly eyes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:12
verses.text: You will strengthen him by the help of your prayers; you will give him a letter as provision by the way; you will grant him, as companions, some of the good men and true that you have about you; so you will speed him on the road to what is before him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:13
verses.text: It has seemed to me to be desirable to send a letter to the bishop of Rome, begging him to examine our condition, and since there are difficulties in the way of representatives being sent from the West by a general synodical decree, to advise him to exercise his own personal authority in the matter by choosing suitable persons to sustain the labours of a journey,—suitable, too, by gentleness and firmness of character, to correct the unruly among us here; able to speak with proper reserve and appropriateness, and thoroughly well acquainted with all that has been effected after Ariminum to undo the violent measures adopted there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:14
verses.text: I should advise that, without any one knowing anything about it, they should travel hither, attracting as little attention as possible, by the sea, with the object of escaping the notice of the enemies of peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:16
verses.text: A point also that is insisted upon by some of those in these parts, very necessarily, as is plain even to myself, is that they should drive away the heresy of Marcellus, as grievous and injurious and opposed to the sound faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:17
verses.text: For up to this time, in all the letters which they write, they are constant in thoroughly anathematizing the ill-famed Arius and in repudiating him from the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:18
verses.text: But they attach no blame to Marcellus, who propounded a heresy diametrically opposite to that of Arius, and impiously attacked the very existence of the Only begotten Godhead, and erroneously understood the term "Word".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:19
verses.text: He grants indeed that the Only begotten was called "Word," on coming forth at need and in season, but states that He returned again to Him whence He had come forth, and had no existence before His coming forth, nor hypostasis after His return.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:20
verses.text: The books in my possession which contain his unrighteous writings exist as a proof of what I say.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:21
verses.text: Nevertheless they nowhere openly condemned him, and are to this extent culpable that, being from the first in ignorance of the truth, they received him into the communion of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:22
verses.text: The present state of affairs makes it specially necessary that attention should be called to him, so that those who seek for their opportunity, may be prevented from getting it, from the fact of sound men being united to your holiness, and all who are lame in the true faith may be openly known; that so we may know who are on our side, and may not struggle, as in a night battle, without being able to distinguish between friends and foes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:23
verses.text: Only I do beseech you that the deacon, whom I have mentioned, be despatched by the earliest possible packet, that at least some of the ends which we pray for may be accomplished during the ensuing year.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:24
verses.text: One thing, however, even before I mention it, you quite understand and I am sure will give heed to, that, when they come, if God will, they must not let loose schisms among the Churches; and, even though they find some who have personal reasons for mutual differences, they must leave no means untried to unite all who are of the same way of thinking.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:25
verses.text: For we are bound to regard the interests of peace as paramount, and that first of all attention be paid to the Church at Antioch, lest the sound portion of it grow diseased through division on personal grounds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 69:26
verses.text: But you will yourself give more complete attention to all these matters, so soon as, by the blessing of God, you find every one entrusting to you the responsibility of securing the peace of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:1
verses.text: Letter LXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:3
verses.text: To renew laws of ancient love, and once again to restore to vigorous life that heavenly and saving gift of Christ which in course of time has withered away, the peace, I mean, of the Fathers, is a labour necessary indeed and profitable to me, but pleasant too, as I am sure it will seem to your Christ-loving disposition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:4
verses.text: For what could be more delightful than to behold all, who are separated by distances so vast, bound together by the union effected by love into one harmony of members in Christ's body? Nearly all the East (I include under this name all the regions from Illyricum to Egypt) is being agitated, right honourable father, by a terrible storm and tempest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:5
verses.text: The old heresy, sown by Arius the enemy of the truth, has now boldly and unblushingly reappeared.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:6
verses.text: Like some sour root, it is producing its deadly fruit and is prevailing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:7
verses.text: The reason of this is, that in every district the champions of right doctrine have been exiled from their Churches by calumny and outrage, and the control of affairs has been handed over to men who are leading captive the souls of the simpler brethren.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:8
verses.text: I have looked upon the visit of your mercifulness as the only possible solution of our difficulties.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:9
verses.text: Ever in the past I have been consoled by your extraordinary affection; and for a short time my heart was cheered by the gratifying report that we shall be visited by you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:10
verses.text: But, as I was disappointed, I have been constrained to beseech you by letter to be moved to help us, and to send some of those, who are like minded with us, either to conciliate the dissentient and bring back the Churches of God into friendly union, or at all events to make you see more plainly who are responsible for the unsettled state in which we are, that it may be obvious to you for the future with whom it befits you to be in communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:11
verses.text: In this I am by no means making any novel request, but am only asking what has been customary in the case of men who, before our own day, were blessed and dear to God, and conspicuously in your own case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:12
verses.text: For I well remember learning from the answers made by our fathers when asked, and from documents still preserved among us, that the illustrious and blessed bishop Dionysius, conspicuous in your see as well for soundness of faith as for all other virtues, visited by letter my Church of Caesarea, and by letter exhorted our fathers, and sent men to ransom our brethren from captivity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:13
verses.text: But now our condition is yet more painful and gloomy and needs more careful treatment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:14
verses.text: We are lamenting no mere overthrow of earthly buildings, but the capture of Churches; what we see before us is no mere bodily slavery, but a carrying away of souls into captivity, perpetrated day by day by the champions of heresy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 70:15
verses.text: Should you not, even now, be moved to succour us, ere long all will have fallen under the dominion of the heresy, and you will find none left to whom you may hold out your hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:1
verses.text: Letter LXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:2
verses.text: Basil to Gregory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:4
verses.text: I have received the letter of your holiness, by the most reverend brother Helenius, and what you have intimated he has told me in plain terms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:5
verses.text: How I felt on hearing it, you cannot doubt at all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:6
verses.text: However, since I have determined that my affection for you shall outweigh my pain, whatever it is, I have accepted it as I ought to do, and I pray the holy God, that my remaining days or hours may be as carefully conducted in their disposition towards you as they have been in past time, during which, my conscience tells me, I have been wanting to you in nothing small or great.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:7
verses.text: [But that the man who boasts that he is now just beginning to take a look at the life of Christians, and thinks he will get some credit by having something to do with me, should invent what he has not heard, and narrate what he has never experienced, is not at all surprising.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:8
verses.text: What is surprising and extraordinary is that he has got my best friends among the brethren at Nazianzus to listen to him; and not only to listen to him, but as it seems, to take in what he says.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:9
verses.text: On most grounds it might be surprising that the slanderer is of such a character, and that I am the victim, but these troublous times have taught us to bear everything with patience.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:10
verses.text: Slights greater than this have, for my sins, long been things of common occurrence with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:11
verses.text: I have never yet given this man's brethren any evidence of my sentiments about God, and I have no answer to make now.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:12
verses.text: Men who are not convinced by long experience are not likely to be convinced by a short letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:13
verses.text: If the former is enough let the charges of the slanderers be counted as idle tales.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:14
verses.text: But if I give license to unbridled mouths, and uninstructed hearts, to talk about whom they will, all the while keeping my ears ready to listen, I shall not be alone in hearing what is said by other people; they will have to hear what I have to say.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:16
verses.text: I know what has led to all this, and have urged every topic to hinder it; but now I am sick of the subject, and will say no more about it, I mean our little intercourse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:17
verses.text: For had we kept our old promise to each other, and had due regard to the claims which the Churches have on us, we should have been the greater part of the year together; and then there would have been no opening for these calumniators.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:18
verses.text: Pray have nothing to say to them; let me persuade you to come here and assist me in my labours, particularly in my contest with the individual who is now assailing me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:19
verses.text: Your very appearance will have the effect of stopping him; directly you show these disturbers of our home that you will, by God's blessing, place yourself at the head of our party, you will break up their cabal, and you will shut every unjust mouth that speaketh unrighteousness against God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:20
verses.text: And thus facts will show who are your followers in good, and who are the halters and cowardly betrayers of the word of truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:21
verses.text: If, however, the Church be betrayed, why then I shall care little to set men right about myself, by means of words, who account of me as men would naturally account who have not yet learned to measure themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:22
verses.text: Perhaps, in a short time, by God's grace, I shall be able to refute their slanders by very deed, for it seems likely that I shall have soon to suffer somewhat for the truth's sake more than usual; the best I can expect is banishment, or, if this hope fails, after all Christ's judgment-seat is not far distant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:23
verses.text: [If then you ask for a meeting for the Churches' sake, I am ready to betake myself whithersoever you invite me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 71:24
verses.text: But if it is only a question of refuting these slanders, I really have no time to reply to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:1
verses.text: Letter LXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:2
verses.text: To Hesychius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:3
verses.text: I know your affection for me, and your zeal for all that is good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:4
verses.text: I am exceedingly anxious to pacify my very dear son Callisthenes, and I thought that if I could associate you with me in this I might more easily achieve my object.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:5
verses.text: Callisthenes is very much annoyed at the conduct of Eustochius, and he has very good ground for being so.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:6
verses.text: He charges the household of Eustochius with impudence and violence against himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:7
verses.text: I am begging him to be propitiated, satisfied with the fright which he has given the impudent fellows and their master, and to forgive, and end the quarrel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:8
verses.text: Thus two results will follow; he will win the respect of men, and praise with God, if only he will combine forbearance with threats.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:9
verses.text: If you have any friendship and intimacy with him, pray ask this favour of him, and, if you know any in the town likely to be able to move him, get them to act with you, and tell them that it will be specially gratifying to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:10
verses.text: Send back the deacon so soon as his commission is performed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 72:11
verses.text: After men have fled for refuge to me, I should be ashamed not to be able to be of any use to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:1
verses.text: Letter LXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:2
verses.text: To Callisthenes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:4
verses.text: When I had read your letter I thanked God; first, that I been greeted by a man desirous of doing me honour, for truly I highly estimate any intercourse with persons of high merit; secondly, with pleasure at the thought of being remembered.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:5
verses.text: For a letter is a sign of remembrance; and when I had received yours and learnt its contents I was astonished to find how, as all were agreed, it paid me the respect due to a father from a son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:6
verses.text: That a man in the heat of anger and indignation, eager to punish those who had annoyed him, should drop more than half his vehemence and give me authority to decide the matter, caused me to feel such joy as I might over a son in the spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:7
verses.text: In return, what remains for me but to pray for all blessings for you? May you be a delight to your friends, a terror to your foes, an object of respect to all, to the end that any who fall short in their duty to you may, when they learn how gentle you are, only blame themselves for having wronged one of such a character as yourself!  2.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:8
verses.text: I should be very glad to know the object which your goodness has in view, in ordering the servants to be conveyed to the spot where they were guilty of their disorderly conduct.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:9
verses.text: If you come yourself, and exact in person the punishment due for the offence, the slaves shall be there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:10
verses.text: What other course is possible if you have made up your mind? Only that I do not know what further favour I shall have received, if I shall have failed to get the boys off their punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:11
verses.text: But if business detain you on the way, who is to receive the fellows there? Who is to punish them in your stead? But if you have made up your mind to meet them yourself, and this is quite determined on, tell them to halt at Sasima, and there show the extent of your gentleness and magnanimity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:12
verses.text: After having your assailants in your own power, and so showing them that your dignity is not to be lightly esteemed, let them go scot free, as I urged you in my former letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:13
verses.text: So you will confer a favour on me, and will receive the requital of your good deed from God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:15
verses.text: I speak in this way, not because the business ought so to be ended, but as a concession to your agitated feelings, and in fear lest somewhat of your wrath may remain still raw.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:16
verses.text: When a man's eyes are inflamed the softest application seems painful, and I am afraid lest what I say may rather irritate than calm you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:17
verses.text: What would really be most becoming, bringing great credit to you, and no little cause of honour to me with my friends and contemporaries, would be for you to leave the punishment to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:18
verses.text: And although you have sworn to deliver them to execution as the law enjoins, my rebuke is still of no less value as a punishment, nor is the divine law of less account than the laws current in the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:19
verses.text: But it will be possible for them, by being punished here by our laws, wherein too lies your own hope of salvation, both to release you from your oath and to undergo a penalty commensurate with their faults.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:20
verses.text: But once more I am making my letter too long.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:21
verses.text: In the very earnest desire to persuade you I cannot bear to leave unsaid any of the pleas which occur to me, and I am much afraid lest my entreaty should prove ineffectual from my failing to say all that may convey my meaning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:22
verses.text: Now, true and honoured son of the Church, confirm the hopes which I have of you; prove true all the testimony unanimously given to your placability and gentleness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 73:23
verses.text: Give orders to the soldier to leave me without delay; he is now as tiresome and rude as he can well be; he evidently prefers giving no cause of annoyance to you to making all of us here his close friends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:1
verses.text: Letter LXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:2
verses.text: To Martinianus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:4
verses.text: How high do you suppose one to prize the pleasure of our meeting one another once again? How delightful to spend longer time with you so as to enjoy all your good qualities! If powerful proof is given of culture in seeing many men's cities and knowing many men's ways, such I am sure is quickly given in your society.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:5
verses.text: For what is the difference between seeing many men singly or one who has gained experience of all together? I should say that there is an immense superiority in that which gives us the knowledge of good and beautiful things without trouble, and puts within our reach instruction in virtue, pure from all admixture of evil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:6
verses.text: Is there question of noble deed; of words worth handing down; of institutions of men of superhuman excellence? All are treasured in the store house of your mind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:7
verses.text: Not then, would I pray, that I might listen to you, like Alcinous to Ulysses, only for a year, but throughout all my life; and to this end I would pray that my life might be long, even though my state were no easy one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:8
verses.text: Why, then, am I now writing when I ought to be coming to see you? Because my country in her troubles calls me irresistibly to her side.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:9
verses.text: You know, my friend, how she suffers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:10
verses.text: She is torn in pieces like Pentheus by veritable Maenads, daemons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:11
verses.text: They are dividing her, and dividing her again, like bad surgeons who, in their ignorance, make wounds worse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:12
verses.text: Suffering as she is from this dissection, it remains for me to tend her like a sick patient.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:13
verses.text: So the Caesareans have urgently appealed to me by letter, and I must go, not as though I could be of any help, but to avoid any blame of neglect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:14
verses.text: You know how ready men in difficulties are to hope; and ready too, I ween, to find fault, always charging their troubles on what has been left undone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:16
verses.text: Yet for this very reason I ought to have come to see you, and to have told you my mind, or rather to implore you to bethink you of some strong measure worthy of your wisdom; not to turn aside from my country falling on her knees, but to betake yourself to the Court, and, with the boldness which is all your own, not to let them suppose that they own two provinces instead of one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:17
verses.text: They have not imported the second from some other part of the world, but have acted somewhat in the same way in which some owner of horse or ox might act, who should cut it in two, and then think that he had two instead of one, instead of failing to make two and destroying the one he had.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:18
verses.text: Tell the Emperor and his ministers that they are not after this fashion increasing the empire, for power lies not in number but in condition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:19
verses.text: I am sure that now men are neglecting the course of events, some, possibly, from ignorance of the truth, some from their being unwilling to say anything offensive, some because it does not immediately concern them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:20
verses.text: The course likely to be most beneficial, and worthy of your high principles, would be for you, if possible, to approach the Emperor in person.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:21
verses.text: If this is difficult both on account of the season of the year and of your age, of which, as you say, inactivity is the foster brother, at all events you need have no difficulty in writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:22
verses.text: If you thus give our country the aid of a letter, you will first of all have the satisfaction of knowing that you have left nothing undone that was in your power, and further, by showing sympathy, if only in appearance, you will give the patient much comfort.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:23
verses.text: Would only that it were possible for you to come yourself among us and actually see our deplorable condition! Thus, perhaps, stirred by the plain evidence before you, you might have spoken in terms worthy alike of your own magnanimity and of the affliction of Caesarea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:24
verses.text: But do not withhold belief from what I am telling you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:25
verses.text: Verily we want some Simonides, or other like poet, to lament our troubles from actual experience.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:26
verses.text: But why name Simonides? I should rather mention aeschylus, or any other who has set forth a great calamity in words like his, and uttered lamentation with a mighty voice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:28
verses.text: Now we have no more meetings, no more debates, no more gatherings of wise men in the Forum, nothing more of all that made our city famous.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:29
verses.text: In our Forum nowadays it would be stranger for a learned or eloquent man to put in an appearance, than it would for men, shewing a brand of iniquity or unclean hands, to have presented themselves in Athens of old.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:30
verses.text: Instead of them we have the imported boorishness of Massagetae and Scythians.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:31
verses.text: And only one noise is heard of drivers of bargains, and losers of bargains, and of fellows under the lash.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:32
verses.text: On either hand the porticoes resound with doleful echoes, as though they were uttering a natural and proper sound in groaning at what is going on.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:33
verses.text: Our distress prevents our paying any attention to locked gymnasia and nights when no torch is lighted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:34
verses.text: There is no small danger lest, our magistrates being removed, everything crash down together as with fallen props.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:35
verses.text: What words can adequately describe our calamities? Some have fled into exile, a considerable portion of our senate, and that not the least valuable, prefering perpetual banishment to Podandus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:36
verses.text: When I mention Podandus, suppose me to mean the Spartan Ceadas or any natural pit that you may have seen, spots breathing a noxious vapour, to which some have involuntarily given the name Charonian.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:37
verses.text: Picture to yourself that the evils of Podandus are a match for such a place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:38
verses.text: So, of three parts, some have left their homes and are in exile, wives and hearth and all; some are being led away like captives, the majority of the best men in the city, a piteous spectacle to their friends, fulfilling their enemies' prayers; if, that is, any one has ever been found to call down so dire a curse upon our heads.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:39
verses.text: A third division yet remains: these, unable to endure abandonment by their old companions, and at the same time unable to provide for themselves, have to hate their very lives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:40
verses.text: This is what I implore you to make known everywhere with an eloquence all your own, and that righteous boldness of speech which your manner of life gives you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:41
verses.text: One thing distinctly state; that, unless the authorities soon change their counsels, they will find none left on whom to exercise their clemency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:42
verses.text: You will either prove some help to the state, or at least you will have done as Solon did, who, when he was unable to defend his abandoned fellow citizens on the capture of the Acropolis, put on his armour, and sat down before the gates, thus making it plain by this guise that he was no party to what was going on.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 74:43
verses.text: Of one thing I am assured, even though at the present moment there may be some who do not approve of your advice, the day is not far distant when they will give you the greatest credit for benevolence and sagacity, because they see events corresponding with your prediction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 75:1
verses.text: Letter LXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 75:2
verses.text: To Aburgius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 75:3
verses.text: You have many qualities which raise you above the common run of men, but nothing is more distinctly characteristic of you than your zeal for your country.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 75:4
verses.text: Thus you, who have risen to such a height as to become illustrious throughout all the world, pay a righteous recompense to the land that gave you birth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 75:5
verses.text: Yet she, your mother city, who bore you and nursed you, has fallen into the incredible condition of ancient story; and no one visiting Caesarea; not even those most familiar with her, would recognise her as she is; to such complete abandonment has she been suddenly transformed, many of her magistrates having been previously removed, and now nearly all of them transferred to Podandus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 75:6
verses.text: The remainder, torn from these like mutilated extremities, have themselves fallen into complete despair, and have caused such a general weight of despondency, that the population of the city is now but scanty; the place looks like a desert, a piteous spectacle to all who love it, and a cause for delight and encouragement to all who have long been plotting for our fall.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 75:7
verses.text: Who then will reach out a hand to help us? Who will drop a tear of pity over our faith? You have sympathised with a stranger city in like distress; will not your kindly excellency feel for her who gave you birth? If you have any influence, show it in our present need.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 75:8
verses.text: Certainly you have great help from God, Who has never abandoned you, and has given you many proofs of His kindness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 75:9
verses.text: Only be willing to exert yourself in our behalf, and use all the influence you have for the succour of your fellow citizens.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 76:1
verses.text: Letter LXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 76:2
verses.text: To Sophronius the Master.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 76:3
verses.text: The greatness of the calamities, which have befallen our native city, did seem likely to compel me to travel in person to the court, and there to relate, both to your excellency and to all those who are most influential in affairs, the dejected state in which Caesarea is lying.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 76:4
verses.text: But I am kept here alike by ill-health and by the care of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 76:5
verses.text: In the meantime, therefore, I hasten to tell your lordship our troubles by letter, and to acquaint you that never ship, drowned in sea by furious winds, so suddenly disappeared, never city shattered by earthquake or overwhelmed by flood, so swiftly vanished out of sight, as our city, engulfed by this new constitution, has gone utterly to ruin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 76:6
verses.text: Our misfortunes have passed into a tale.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 76:7
verses.text: Our institutions are a thing of the past; and all our men of high civil rank, in despair at what has happened to our magistrates, have left their homes in the city and are wandering about the country.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 76:8
verses.text: There is a break therefore in the necessary conduct of affairs, and the city, which ere now gloried both in men of learning and in others who abound in opulent towns, has become a most unseemly spectacle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 76:9
verses.text: One only consolation have we left in our troubles, and that is to groan over our misfortunes to your excellency and to implore you, if you can, to reach out the helping hand to Caesarea who falls on her knees before you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 76:10
verses.text: How indeed you may be able to aid us I am not myself able to explain; but I am sure that to you, with all your intelligence, it will be easy to discover the means, and not difficult, through the power given you by God, to use them when they are found.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 77:1
verses.text: Letter LXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 77:2
verses.text: Without inscription: about Therasius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 77:3
verses.text: One good thing we have certainly gained from the government of the great Therasius and that is that you have frequently paid us a visit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 77:4
verses.text: Now, alas! we have lost our governor, and we are deprived of this good thing too.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 77:5
verses.text: But since the boons once given us by God remain immovable, and, although we are parted in body, abide fixed by memory in the souls of each of us, let us constantly write, and communicate our needs to one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 77:6
verses.text: And this we may well do at the present moment, when the storm for a brief space has cried a truce.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 77:7
verses.text: I trust that you will not part from the admirable Therasius, for I think that it is very becoming to share his great anxieties, and I am delighted at the opportunity given you both of seeing your friends and of being seen by them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 77:8
verses.text: I have much to say about many things, but I put it off till we meet, for it is, I think, hardly safe to entrust matters of such importance to letters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 78:1
verses.text: Letter LXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 78:2
verses.text: Without inscription, on behalf of Elpidius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 78:3
verses.text: I have not failed to observe the interest you have shown in our venerable friend Elpidius; and how with your usual intelligence you have given the prefect an opportunity of showing his kindness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 78:4
verses.text: What I am now writing to ask you is to make this favour complete and suggest to the prefect that he should by a particular order set over our city the man who is full of all possible care for the public interests.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 78:5
verses.text: You will therefore have many admirable reasons to urge upon the prefect for his ordering Elpidius to remain at Caesarea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 78:6
verses.text: There is at all events no need for you to be taught by me, since you yourself know only too well, what is the position of affairs, and how capable Elpidius in administration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 79:1
verses.text: Letter LXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 79:2
verses.text: To Eustathius bishop of Sebastia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 79:3
verses.text: Even before receiving your letter I knew what trouble you are ready to undergo for every one, and specially for my humble self because I am exposed in this struggle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 79:4
verses.text: So when I received your letter from the reverend Eleusinius, and saw him actually before my face, I praised God for bestowing on me such a champion and comrade, in my struggles on behalf of true religion by the aid of the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 79:5
verses.text: Be it known to your exalted reverence that I have hitherto sustained some attacks from high magistrates, and these no light ones; while both the prefect and the high chamberlain pleaded with sympathy for my opponents.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 79:6
verses.text: But, so far, I have sustained every assault unmoved, by that mercy of God which supplies to me the aid of the Spirit, and strengthens my weakness through Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 80:1
verses.text: Letter LXXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 80:2
verses.text: To Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 80:3
verses.text: The worse the diseases of the Churches grow, the more do we all turn to your excellency, in the belief that your championship is the one consolation left to us in our troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 80:4
verses.text: By the power of your prayers, and your knowledge of what is the best course to suggest in the emergency, you are believed to be able to save us from this terrible tempest by all alike who know your excellency even to a small extent, whether by hearsay or by personal experience.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 80:5
verses.text: Wherefore, cease not, I implore, to pray for our souls and to rouse us by your letters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 80:6
verses.text: Did you but know of what service these are to us you would never have lost a single opportunity of writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 80:7
verses.text: Could I only, by the aid of your prayers, be deemed worthy of seeing you, and of enjoying your good qualities, and of adding to the story of my life a meeting with your truly great and apostolical soul, then I should indeed believe that I had received from God's mercy a consolation equivalent to all the afflictions of my life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:2
verses.text: To Bishop Innocent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:3
verses.text: I was delighted to receive the letter your affection sent me; but I am equally grieved at your having laid on me the load of a responsibility which is more than I can carry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:4
verses.text: How can I, so far removed as I am, undertake so great a charge? As long as the Church possesses you, it rests as it were on its proper buttress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:5
verses.text: Should the Lord be pleased to make some dispensation in the matter of your life, whom, from among us here can I send to take the charge of the brethren, who will be in like esteem with yourself? That is a very wise and proper wish which you express in your letter, that while you are yet alive you may see the successor destined after you to guide the chosen flock of the Lord (like the blessed Moses, who both wished and saw).

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:6
verses.text: As the place is great and famous, and your work has great and wide renown, and the times are difficult, needing no insignificant guide on account of the continuous storms and tempests which are attacking the Church, I have not thought it safe for my own soul to treat the matter perfunctorily, specially when I bear in mind the terms in which you write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:7
verses.text: For you say that, accusing me of disregard of the Churches, you mean to withstand me before the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:8
verses.text: Not then to be at issue with you, but rather to have you on my side in my defence which I make in the presence of Christ I have, after looking round in the assembly of the presbyters of the city, chosen the very honourable vessel, the offspring of the blessed Hermogenes, who wrote the great and invincible creed in the great Synod.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:9
verses.text: He is a presbyter of the Church, of many years standing, of steadfast character, skilled in canons, accurate in the faith, who has lived up to this time in continence and ascetic discipline, although the severity of his austere life has now subdued the flesh; a man of poverty, with no resources in this world, so that he is not even provided with bare bread, but by the labour of his hands gets a living with the brethren who dwell with him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:10
verses.text: It is my intention to send him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:11
verses.text: If, then, this is the kind of man you want, and not some younger man fit only to be sent and to discharge the common duties of this world, be so good as to write to me at the first opportunity, that I may send you this man, who is elect of God, adapted for the present work, respected by all who meet him, and who instructs with meekness all who differ from him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:12
verses.text: I might have sent him at once, but since you yourself had anticipated me in asking for a man of honourable character, and beloved by myself, but far inferior to the one whom I have indicated, I wished my mind in the matter to be made known to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 81:13
verses.text: If therefore this is the kind of man you want, either send one of the brethren to fetch him at the time of the fast, or, if you have no one able to undertake the journey to me, let me know by letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:2
verses.text: To Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:3
verses.text: When I turn my gaze upon the world, and perceive the difficulties by which every effort after good is obstructed, like those of a man walking in fetters, I am brought to despair of myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:4
verses.text: But then I direct my gaze in the direction of your reverence; I remember that our Lord has appointed you to be physician of the diseases in the Churches; and I recover my spirits, and rise from the depression of despair to the hope of better things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:5
verses.text: As your wisdom well knows, the whole Church is undone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:6
verses.text: And you see everything in all directions in your mind's eye like a man looking from some tall watch tower, as when at sea many ships sailing together are all dashed one against the other by the violence of the waves, and shipwreck arises in some cases from the sea being furiously agitated from without, in others from the disorder of the sailors hindering and crowding one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:7
verses.text: It is enough to present this picture, and to say no more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:8
verses.text: Your wisdom requires nothing farther, and the present state of affairs does not allow me freedom of speech.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:9
verses.text: What capable pilot can be found in such a storm? Who is worthy to rouse the Lord to rebuke the wind and the sea? Who but he who from his boyhood fought a good fight on behalf of true religion? Since now truly all that is sound among us is moving in the direction of fellowship and unity with those who are of the same opinion, we have come confidently to implore you to send us a single letter, advising us what is to be done.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:10
verses.text: In this way they wish that they may have a beginning of communication which may promote unity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:11
verses.text: They may, peradventure, be suspected by you, when you remember the past, and therefore, most God-beloved Father, do as follows; send me the letters to the bishops, either by the hand of some one in whom you place trust in Alexandria, or by the hand of our brother Dorotheus the deacon: when I have received these letters I will not deliver them till I have got the bishops' answers; if not, let me "bear the blame for ever".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:12
verses.text: Truly this ought not to have struck more awe into him who first uttered it to his father, than into me who now say it to my spiritual father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 82:13
verses.text: If however you altogether renounce this hope, at least free me from all blame in acting as I have, for I have undertaken this message and mediation in all sincerity and simplicity, from desire for peace and the mutual intercourse of all who think alike about the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:2
verses.text: To a Magistrate.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:3
verses.text: I have had only a short acquaintance and intercourse with your lordship, but I have no small or contemptible knowledge of you from the reports through which I am brought into communication with many men of position and importance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:4
verses.text: You yourself are better able to say whether I, by report, am of any account with you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:5
verses.text: At all events your reputation with me is such as I have said.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:6
verses.text: But since God has called you to an occupation which gives you opportunity of showing kindness, and in the exercise of which it lies in your power to bring about the restoration of my own city, now level with the ground, it is, I think, only my duty to remind your excellency that in the hope of the requital God will give, you should show yourself of such a character as to win a memory that cannot die, and be made an inheritor of everlasting rest, in consequence of your making the afflictions of the distressed hard to bear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:7
verses.text: I have a property at Chamanene, and I beg you to look after its interests as though they were your own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:8
verses.text: And pray do not be surprised at my calling my friend's property my own, for among other virtues I have been taught that of friendship, and I remember the author of the wise saying a friend is another self.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:9
verses.text: I therefore commend to your excellency this property belonging to my friend, as though it were my own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:10
verses.text: I beg you to consider the misfortunes of the house, and both to grant them consolation for the past, and for the future to make the place more comfortable for them; for it is now left and abandoned on account of the weight of the rates imposed upon it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 83:11
verses.text: I will do my best to meet your excellency and converse with you on points of detail.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:2
verses.text: To the President.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:4
verses.text: You will hardly believe what I am about to write, but it must be written for truth's sake.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:5
verses.text: I have been very anxious to communicate as often as possible with your excellency, but when I got this opportunity of writing a letter I did not at once seize the lucky chance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:6
verses.text: I hesitated and hung back.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:7
verses.text: What is astonishing is, that when I got what I had been praying for, I did not take it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:8
verses.text: The reason of this is that I am really ashamed to write to you every time, not out of pure friendship, but with the object of getting something.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:9
verses.text: But then I bethought me (and when you consider it, I do hope you will not think that I communicate with you more for the sake of a bargain than of friendship) that there must be a difference between the way in which one approaches a magistrate and a private man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:10
verses.text: We do not accost a physician as we do any mere nobody; nor a magistrate as we do a private individual.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:11
verses.text: We try to get some advantage from the skill of the one and the position of the other.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:12
verses.text: Walk in the sun, and your shadow will follow you, whether you will or not.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:13
verses.text: Just so intercourse with the great is followed by an inevitable gain, the succour of the distressed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:14
verses.text: The first object of my letter is fulfilled in my being able to greet your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:15
verses.text: Really, if I had no other cause for writing at all, this must be regarded as an excellent topic.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:16
verses.text: Be greeted then, my dear Sir; may you be preserved by all the world while you fill office after office, and succour now some now others by your authority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:17
verses.text: Such greeting I am wont to make; such greeting is only due to you from all who have had the least experience of your goodness in your administration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:19
verses.text: Now, after this prayer, hear my supplication on behalf of the poor old man whom the imperial order had exempted from serving in any public capacity; though really I might say that old age anticipated the Emperor in giving him his discharge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:20
verses.text: You have yourself satisfied the boon conferred on him by the higher authority, at once from respect to natural infirmity, and, I think, from regard to the public interest, lest any harm should come to the state from a man growing imbecile through age.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:21
verses.text: But how, my dear Sir, have you unwittingly dragged him into public life, by ordering his grandson, a child not yet four years old, to be on the roll of the senate? You have done the very same thing as to drag the old man, through his descendant, again into public business.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:22
verses.text: But now, I do implore you, have mercy on both ages, and free both on the ground of what in each case is pitiable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:23
verses.text: The one never saw father or mother, never knew them, but from his very cradle was deprived of both, and has entered into life by the help of strangers: the other has been preserved so long as to have suffered every kind of calamity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:24
verses.text: He saw a son's untimely death; he saw a house without successors; now, unless you devise some remedy commensurate with your kindness, he will see the very consolation of his bereavement made an occasion of innumerable troubles, for, I suppose, the little lad will never act as senator, collect tribute, or pay troops; but once again the old man's white hairs must be shamed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:25
verses.text: Concede a favour in accordance with the law and agreeable to nature; order the boy to be allowed to wait till he come to man's estate, and the old man to await death quietly on his bed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:26
verses.text: Let others, if they will, urge the pretext of press of business and inevitable necessity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 84:27
verses.text: But, even if you are under a press of business, it would not be like you to despise the distressed, to slight the law, or to refuse to yield to the prayers of your friends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:2
verses.text: That the oath ought not to be taken.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:3
verses.text: It is my invariable custom to protest at every synod and to urge privately in conversation, that oaths about the taxes ought not to be imposed on husbandmen by the collectors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:4
verses.text: It remains for me to bear witness, on the same matters, in writing, before God and men, that it behoves you to cease from inflicting death upon men's souls, and to devise some other means of exaction, while you let men keep their souls unwounded.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:5
verses.text: I write thus to you, not as though you needed any spoken exhortation (for you have your own immediate inducements to fear the Lord), but that all your dependents may learn from you not to provoke the Holy One, nor let a forbidden sin become a matter of indifference, through faulty familiarity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:6
verses.text: No possible good can be done them by oaths, with a view to their paying what is exacted from them, and they suffer an undeniable wrong to the soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:7
verses.text: For when men become practised in perjury, they no longer put any pressure on themselves to pay, but they think that they have discovered in the oath a means of trickery and an opportunity for delay.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:8
verses.text: If, then, the Lord brings a sharp retribution on the perjured, when the debtors are destroyed by punishment there will be none to answer when summoned.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:9
verses.text: If on the other hand the Lord endures with long suffering, then, as I said before, those who have tried the patience of the Lord despise His goodness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:10
verses.text: Let them not break the law in vain; let them not whet the wrath of God against them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:11
verses.text: I have said what I ought.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 85:12
verses.text: The disobedient will see.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 86:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 86:2
verses.text: To the Governor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 86:3
verses.text: I know that a first and foremost object of your excellency is in every way to support the right; and after that to benefit your friends, and to exert yourself in behalf of those who have fled to your lordship's protection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 86:4
verses.text: Both these pleas are combined in the matter before us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 86:5
verses.text: The cause is right for which we are pleading; it is dear to me who am numbered among your friends; it is due to those who are invoking the aid of your constancy in their sufferings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 86:6
verses.text: The corn, which was all my very, dear brother Dorotheus had for the necessaries of life, has been carried off by some of the authorities at Berisi, entrusted with the management of affairs, driven to this violence of their own accord or by others' instigation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 86:7
verses.text: Either way it is an indictable offence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 86:8
verses.text: For how does the man whose wickedness is his own do less wrong than he who is the mere minister of other men's wickedness? To the sufferers the loss is the same.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 86:9
verses.text: I implore you, therefore, that Dorotheus may have his corn returned by the men by whom he has been robbed, and that they may not be allowed to lay the guilt of their outrage on other men's shoulders.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 86:10
verses.text: If you grant me my request I shall reckon the value of the boon conferred by your excellency in proportion to the necessity of providing one's self with food.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 87:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 87:2
verses.text: Without address on the same subject.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 87:3
verses.text: I am astonished that, with you to appeal to, so grave an offence should have been committed against the presbyter as that he should have been deprived of his only means of livelihood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 87:4
verses.text: The most serious part of the business is that the perpetrators transfer the guilt of their proceedings to you; while all the while it was your duty not only not to suffer such deeds to be done, but to use all your authority to prevent them in the case of any one, but specially in the case of presbyters, and such presbyters as are in agreement with me, and are walking in the same way of true religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 87:5
verses.text: If then you have any care to give me gratification, see that these matters are set right without delay.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 87:6
verses.text: For, God helping you, you are able to do this, and greater things than this to whom you will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 87:7
verses.text: I have written to the governor of my own country, that, if they refuse to do what is right of their own accord, they may be compelled to do so on pressure from the courts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 88:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 88:2
verses.text: Without address on the subject of the exaction of taxes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 88:3
verses.text: Your excellency knows better than any one else the difficulty of getting together the gold furnished by contribution.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 88:4
verses.text: We have no better witness to our poverty than yourself, for with your great kindness you have felt for us, and, up to the present time, so far as has lain within your power, have borne with us, never departing from your own natural forbearance from any alarm caused by superior authority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 88:5
verses.text: Now of the whole sum there is still something wanting, and that must be got in from the contribution which we have recommended to all the town.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 88:6
verses.text: What I ask is, that you will grant us a little delay, that a reminder may be sent to dwellers in the country, and most of our magistrates are in the country.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 88:7
verses.text: If it is possible for it to be sent in short of as many pounds as those in which we are still behind-hand, I should be glad if you would so arrange, and the amount shall be sent later.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 88:8
verses.text: If, however, it is absolutely necessary that the whole sum should be sent in at once, then I repeat my first request that we may be allowed a longer time of grace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:1
verses.text: Letter LXXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:2
verses.text: To Meletius, bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:4
verses.text: The eagerness of my longing is soothed by the opportunities which the merciful God gives me of saluting your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:5
verses.text: He Himself is witness of the earnest desire which I have to see your face, and to enjoy your good and soul-refreshing instruction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:6
verses.text: Now by my reverend and excellent brother Dorotheus, the deacon, who is setting out, first of all I beg you to pray for me that I be no stumbling block to the people, nor hindrance to your petitions to propitiate the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:7
verses.text: In the second place I would suggest that you would be so good as to make all arrangements through the aforementioned brother; and, if it seems well that a letter should be sent to the Westerns, because it is only right that communication should be made in writing even through our own messenger, that you will dictate the letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:8
verses.text: I have met Sabinus the deacon, sent by them, and have written to the bishops in Illyria, Italy, and Gaul, and to some of those who have written privately to myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:9
verses.text: For it is right that some one should be sent in the common interests of the Synod, conveying a second letter which I beg you to have written.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:11
verses.text: As to what concerns the right reverend bishop Athanasius, your intelligence is already aware of what I will mention, that it is impossible for anything to be advanced by my letters, or for any desirable objects to be carried out, unless by some means or other he receives communion from you, who at that time postponed it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:12
verses.text: He is described as being very anxious to unite with me, and to be willing to contribute all he can, but to be sorry that he was sent away without communion, and that the promise still remains unfulfilled.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:13
verses.text: What is going on in the East cannot have failed to reach your reverence's ears, but the aforementioned brother will give you more accurate information by word of mouth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:14
verses.text: Be so good as to dispatch him directly after Easter, because of his waiting for the answer from Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 89:15
verses.text: Look kindly on his zeal strengthen him by your prayers and so dispatch him on this commission.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:1
verses.text: Letter XC.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:2
verses.text: To the holy brethren the bishops of the West.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:4
verses.text: The good God Who ever mixes consolation with affliction has, even now in the midst of my pangs, granted me a certain amount of comfort in the letters which our right honourable father bishop Athanasius has received from you and sent on to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:5
verses.text: For they contain evidence of sound faith and proof of your inviolable agreement and concord, showing thus that the shepherds are following in the footsteps of the Fathers and feeding the people of the Lord with knowledge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:6
verses.text: All this has so much gladdened my heart as to dispel my despondency and to create something like a smile in my soul in the midst of the distressing state of affairs in which we are now placed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:7
verses.text: The Lord has also extended His consolation to me by means of the reverend deacon Sabinus, my son, who has cheered my soul by giving me an exact narrative of your condition; and from personal experience of his own, will give you clear tidings of ours, that you may, in the first place, aid me in my trouble by earnest and constant prayer to God; and next that you may consent to give such consolation as lies in your power to our afflicted Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:8
verses.text: For here, very honourable brethren, all is in a weak state; the Church has given way before the continuous attacks of her foes, like some bark in mid-ocean buffeted by successive blows of the waves; unless haply there be some quick visitation of the divine mercy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:9
verses.text: As then we reckon your mutual sympathy and unity an important blessing to ourselves, so do we implore you to pity our dissensions; and not, because we are separated by a great extent of country, to part us from you, but to admit us to the concord of one body, because we are united in the fellowship of the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:11
verses.text: Our distresses are notorious, even though we leave them untold, for now their sound has gone out into all the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:12
verses.text: The doctrines of the Fathers are despised; apostolic traditions are set at nought; the devices of innovators are in vogue in the Churches; now men are rather contrivers of cunning systems than theologians; the wisdom of this world wins the highest prizes and has rejected the glory of the cross.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:13
verses.text: Shepherds are banished, and in their places are introduced grievous wolves hurrying the flock of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:14
verses.text: Houses of prayer have none to assemble in them; desert places are full of lamenting crowds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:15
verses.text: The elders lament when they compare the present with the past.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:16
verses.text: The younger are yet more to be compassionated, for they do not know of what they have been deprived.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:17
verses.text: All this is enough to stir the pity of men who have learnt the love of Christ; but, compared with the actual state of things, words fall very far short.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:18
verses.text: If then there be any consolation of love, any fellowship of the Spirit, any bowels of mercy, be stirred to help us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:19
verses.text: Be zealous for true religion, and rescue us from this storm.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:20
verses.text: Ever be spoken among us with boldness that famous dogma of the Fathers, which destroys the ill-famed heresy of Arius, and builds up the Churches in the sound doctrine wherein the Son is confessed to be of one substance with the Father, and the Holy Ghost is ranked and worshipped as of equal honour, to the end that through your prayers and co-operation the Lord may grant to us that same boldness for the truth and glorying in the confession of the divine and saving Trinity which He has given you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:21
verses.text: But the aforenamed deacon will tell you every thing in detail.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 90:22
verses.text: We have welcomed your apostolic zeal for orthodoxy and have agreed to all that has been canonically done by your reverences.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:1
verses.text: Letter XCI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:2
verses.text: To Valerianus, Bishop of Illyricum.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:3
verses.text: Thanks be to the Lord, Who has permitted me to see in your unstained life the fruit of primitive love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:4
verses.text: Far apart as you are in body, you have united yourself to me by writing; you have embraced me with spiritual and holy longing; you have implanted unspeakable affection in my soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:5
verses.text: Now I have realized the force of the proverb, "As cold water is to a thirsty soul so is good news from a far country".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:6
verses.text: Honoured brother, I really hunger for affection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:7
verses.text: The cause is not far to seek, for iniquity is multiplied and the love of many has grown cold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:8
verses.text: For this reason your letter is precious to me, and I am replying by our reverend brother Sabinus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:9
verses.text: By him I make myself known to you, and beseech you to be watchful in prayers on our behalf, that God may one day grant calm and quiet to the Church here, and rebuke this wind and sea, that so we may be freed from the storm and agitation in which we are now every moment expecting to be submerged.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:10
verses.text: But in these our troubles one great boon has God given us in hearing that you are in exact agreement and unity with one another, and that the doctrines of true religion are preached among you without let or hindrance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:11
verses.text: For at some time or other, unless the period of this world is not already concluded, and if there yet remain days of human life, it must needs be that by your means the faith must be renewed in the East and that in due season you recompense her for the blessings which she has given you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:12
verses.text: The sound part among us here, which preserves the true religion of the Fathers, is sore stricken, and the devil in his wiliness has shattered it by many and various subtle assaults.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 91:13
verses.text: But, by the help of the prayers of you who love the Lord, may the wicked and deceitful heresy of the Arian error be quenched; may the good teaching of the Fathers, who met at Nicaea, shine forth; so that the ascription of glory may be rendered to the blessed Trinity in the terms of the baptism of salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:1
verses.text: Letter XCII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:2
verses.text: To the Italians and Gauls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:4
verses.text: To our right godly and holy brethren who are ministering in Italy and Gaul, bishops of like mind with us, we, Meletius, Eusebius, Basil, Bassus, Gregory, Pelagius, Paul, Anthimus, Theodotus, Bithus, Abraamius, Jobinus, Zeno, Theodoretus, Marcianus, Barachus, Abraamius, Libanius, Thalassius, Joseph, Boethus, Iatrius, Theodotus, Eustathius, Barsumas, John, Chosroes, Iosaces, Narses, Maris, Gregory, and Daphnus, send greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:5
verses.text: Souls in anguish find some consolation in sending sigh after sigh from the bottom of the heart, and even a tear shed breaks the force of affliction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:6
verses.text: But sighs and tears give us less consolation than the opportunity of telling our troubles to your love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:7
verses.text: We are moreover cheered by the better hope that, peradventure, if we announce our troubles to you, we may move you to give us that succour which we have long hoped you would give the Churches in the East, but which we have not yet received; God, Who in His wisdom arranges all things, must have ordained according to the hidden judgments of His righteousness, that we should be tried for a longer time in these temptations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:8
verses.text: The fame of our condition has travelled to the ends of the earth, and you are not ignorant of it; nor are you without sympathy with brethren of like mind with yourselves, for you are disciples of the apostle, who teaches us that love for our neighbour is the fulfilling of the law.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:9
verses.text: But, as we have said, the just judgment of God, which has ordained that the affliction due to our sins must be fulfilled, has held you back.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:10
verses.text: But when you have learnt all, specially what has not hitherto reached your ears, from our reverend brother the deacon Sabinus, who will be able to narrate in person what is omitted in our letter, we do beseech you to be roused both to zeal for the truth and sympathy for us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:11
verses.text: We implore you to put on bowels of mercy, to lay aside all hesitation, and to undertake the labour of love, without counting length of way, your own occupations, or any other human interests.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:13
verses.text: It is not only one Church which is in peril, nor yet two or three which have fallen under this terrible storm.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:14
verses.text: The mischief of this heresy spreads almost from the borders of Illyricum to the Thebaid.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:15
verses.text: Its bad seeds were first sown by the infamous Arius; they then took deep root through the labours of many who vigorously cultivated the impiety between his time and ours.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:16
verses.text: Now they have produced their deadly fruit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:17
verses.text: The doctrines of true religion are overthrown.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:18
