verses.text: The laws of the Church are in confusion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:19
verses.text: The ambition of men, who have no fear of God, rushes into high posts, and exalted office is now publicly known as the prize of impiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:20
verses.text: The result is, that the worse a man blasphemes, the fitter the people think him to be a bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:21
verses.text: Clerical dignity is a thing of the past.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:22
verses.text: There is a complete lack of men shepherding the Lord's flock with knowledge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:23
verses.text: Ambitious men are constantly throwing away the provision for the poor on their own enjoyment and the distribution of gifts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:24
verses.text: There is no precise knowledge of canons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:25
verses.text: There is complete immunity in sinning; for when men have been placed in office by the favour of men, they are obliged to return the favour by continually showing indulgence to offenders.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:26
verses.text: Just judgment is a thing of the past; and everyone walks according to his heart's desire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:27
verses.text: Vice knows no bounds; the people know no restraint.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:28
verses.text: Men in authority are afraid to speak, for those who have reached power by human interest are the slaves of those to whom they owe their advancement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:29
verses.text: And now the very vindication of orthodoxy is looked upon in some quarters as an opportunity for mutual attack; and men conceal their private ill-will and pretend that their hostility is all for the sake of the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:30
verses.text: Others, afraid of being convicted of disgraceful crimes, madden the people into fratricidal quarrels, that their own doings may be unnoticed in the general distress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:31
verses.text: Hence the war admits of no truce, for the doers of ill deeds are afraid of a peace, as being likely to lift the veil from their secret infamy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:32
verses.text: All the while unbelievers laugh; men of weak faith are shaken; faith is uncertain; souls are drenched in ignorance, because adulterators of the word imitate the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:33
verses.text: The mouths of true believers are dumb, while every blasphemous tongue wags free; holy things are trodden under foot; the better laity shun the churches as schools of impiety; and lift their hands in the deserts with sighs and tears to their Lord in heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:34
verses.text: Even you must have heard what is going on in most of our cities, how our people with wives and children and even our old men stream out before the walls, and offer their prayers in the open air, putting up with all the inconvenience of the weather with great patience, and waiting for help from the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:36
verses.text: What lamentation can match these woes? What springs of tears are sufficient for them? While, then, some men do seem to stand, while yet a trace of the old state of things is left, before utter shipwreck comes upon the Churches, hasten to us, hasten to us now, true brothers, we implore you; on our knees we implore you, hold out a helping hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:37
verses.text: May your brotherly bowels be moved toward us; may tears of sympathy flow; do not see, unmoved, half the empire swallowed up by error; do not let the light of the faith be put out in the place where it shone first.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:38
verses.text: By what action you can then help matters, and how you are to show sympathy for the afflicted, you do not want to be told by us; the Holy Ghost will suggest to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:39
verses.text: But unquestionably, if the survivors are to be saved, there is need of prompt action, and of the arrival of a considerable number of brethren, that those who visit us may complete the number of the synod, in order that they may have weight in effecting a reform, not merely from the dignity of those whose emissaries they are, but also from their own number: thus they will restore the creed drawn up by our fathers at Nicaea, proscribe the heresy, and, by bringing into agreement all who are of one mind, speak peace to the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:40
verses.text: For the saddest thing about it all is that the sound part is divided against itself, and the troubles we are suffering are like those which once befel Jerusalem when Vespasian was besieging it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:41
verses.text: The Jews of that time were at once beset by foes without and consumed by the internal sedition of their own people.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:42
verses.text: In our case, too, in addition to the open attack of the heretics, the Churches are reduced to utter helplessness by the war raging among those who are supposed to be orthodox.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:43
verses.text: For all these reasons we do indeed desire your help, that, for the future all who confess the apostolic faith may put an end to the schisms which they have unhappily devised, and be reduced for the future to the authority of the Church; that so, once more, the body of Christ may be complete, restored to integrity with all its members.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:44
verses.text: Thus we shall not only praise the blessings of others, which is all we can do now, but see our own Churches once more restored to their pristine boast of orthodoxy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:45
verses.text: For, truly, the boon given you by the Lord is fit subject for the highest congratulation, your power of discernment between the spurious and the genuine and pure, and your preaching the faith of the Fathers without any dissimulation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 92:46
verses.text: That faith we have received; that faith we know is stamped with the marks of the Apostles; to that faith we assent, as well as to all that was canonically and lawfully promulgated in the Synodical Letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:1
verses.text: Letter XCIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:2
verses.text: To the Patrician Caesaria, concerning Communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:3
verses.text: It is good and beneficial to communicate every day, and to partake of the holy body and blood of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:4
verses.text: For He distinctly says, "He that eateth my flesh and drinketh my blood hath eternal life".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:5
verses.text: And who doubts that to share frequently in life, is the same thing as to have manifold life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:6
verses.text: I, indeed, communicate four times a week, on the Lord's day, on Wednesday, on Friday, and on the Sabbath, and on the other days if there is a commemoration of any Saint.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:7
verses.text: It is needless to point out that for anyone in times of persecution to be compelled to take the communion in his own hand without the presence of a priest or minister is not a serious offence, as long custom sanctions this practice from the facts themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:8
verses.text: All the solitaries in the desert, where there is no priest, take the communion themselves, keeping communion at home.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:9
verses.text: And at Alexandria and in Egypt, each one of the laity, for the most part, keeps the communion, at his own house, and participates in it when he likes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:10
verses.text: For when once the priest has completed the offering, and given it, the recipient, participating in it each time as entire, is bound to believe that he properly takes and receives it from the giver.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:11
verses.text: And even in the church, when the priest gives the portion, the recipient takes it with complete power over it, and so lifts it to his lips with his own hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 93:12
verses.text: It has the same validity whether one portion or several portions are received from the priest at the same time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:1
verses.text: Letter XCIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:2
verses.text: To Elias, Governor of the Province.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:3
verses.text: I too have been very anxious to meet your excellency, lest by my failure to do so I might come off worse than my accusers; but bodily sickness has prevented me, attacking me even more seriously than usual, and so I am perforce reduced to address you by letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:4
verses.text: When, not long ago, most excellent sir, I had the pleasure of meeting your excellency, I was anxious to communicate with your wisdom about all my affairs; and I was also anxious to address you on behalf of the Churches, that no ground might be left for future calumnies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:5
verses.text: But I restrained myself, thinking it altogether superfluous and importunate to add troubles outside his own necessary business to a man charged with so many responsibilities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:6
verses.text: At the same time (for the truth shall be told) I did shrink from being driven to wound your soul by our mutual recriminations, when it ought in pure devotion to God to reap the perfect reward of piety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:7
verses.text: For really, if I attract your attention to me, I shall leave you but scant leisure for your public duties; shall act something like a man overloading with additional luggage some boatmen managing a new boat in very rough water, when all the while he ought to lessen the cargo and do his best to lighten the craft.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:8
verses.text: For this very reason, I think, our great Emperor, after seeing how fully occupied I am, leaves me to manage the Churches by myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:9
verses.text: Now I should like those who are besieging your impartial ears to be asked what harm the government suffers from me? What depreciation is suffered by any public interests, be they small or great, by my administration of the Churches? Still, possibly, it might be urged that I have done damage to the government by erecting a magnificently appointed church to God, and round it a dwelling house, one liberally assigned to the bishop, and others underneath, allotted to the officers of the Church in order, the use of both being open to you of the magistracy and your escort.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:10
verses.text: But to whom do we do any harm by building a place of entertainment for strangers, both for those who are on a journey and for those who require medical treatment on account of sickness, and so establishing a means of giving these men the comfort they want, physicians, doctors, means of conveyance, and escort? All these men must learn such occupations as are necessary to life and have been found essential to a respectable career; they must also have buildings suitable for their employments, all of which are an honour to the place, and, as their reputation is credited to our governor, confer glory on him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:11
verses.text: Not indeed that for this reason you were unwillingly induced to accept the responsibility of ruling us, for you alone are sufficient by your high qualities to restore our ruins, to people deserted districts and turn wildernesses into towns.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:12
verses.text: Would it be better to harrass and annoy, or to honour and reverence an associate in the discharge of these duties? Do not think, most excellent sir, that what I say is mere words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:13
verses.text: We have already, in the meanwhile, begun providing material.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:14
verses.text: So much for our defence, before our ruler.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:15
verses.text: As to what is to be said in answer to the charges of our accusers, to a Christian and to a friend who cares for my opinion, I must now say no more; the subject is too long for a letter, and cannot, besides, be safely committed to writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:16
verses.text: But lest, before we have an opportunity of meeting, you are driven by the inducement of some men's calumnies to give up any of your good will towards me, do as Alexander did.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 94:17
verses.text: The story is, as you remember, that, when one of his friends was being calumniated, he left one ear open to the slanderer, and carefully closed the other with his hand, with the object of showing that he whose duty is to judge ought not to be easily and wholly given over to the first occupants of his attention, but should keep half his hearing open for the defence of the absent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 95:1
verses.text: Letter XCV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 95:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 95:3
verses.text: I had written some while since to your reverence about our meeting one another and other subjects, but I was disappointed at my letter not reaching your excellency, for after the blessed deacon Theophrastus had taken charge of the letter, on my setting out on an unavoidable journey, he did not convey it to your reverence, because he was seized by the sickness of which he died.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 95:4
verses.text: Hence it happened that I was so late in writing, that, the time being now so exceedingly short, I did not look for there being much use in this letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 95:5
verses.text: The godly bishop Meletius and Theodotus had strongly urged me to visit them, representing that a meeting would be a proof of affection, and being wishful of remedying the troubles which are at present a cause of anxiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 95:6
verses.text: They had appointed, as a time for our meeting, the middle of the approaching month of June, and for the place, Phargamus, a spot famous for martyr's glory and for the large number of people attending the synod there every year.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 95:7
verses.text: Directly I returned and heard of the death of the blessed deacon, and that my letter was lying useless at home, I felt that I must not be idle, because thirty-three days were still remaining up to the appointed time, and so I hurriedly sent the letter to the very reverend Eustathius, my fellow minister, with the object of its being sent on by him to your reverence and of getting an answer without delay.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 95:8
verses.text: If, then, it is possible and agreeable to you to come, I will come too.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 95:9
verses.text: If not, I, God willing, will pay the debt of meeting due from last year: unless haply some hindrance for my sins comes in the way again, in which case I must put off my meeting with the bishops to another time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:1
verses.text: Letter XCVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:2
verses.text: To Sophronius, the master.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:3
verses.text: Who ever loved his city, honouring with filial love the place which gave him birth and nurture, as you do; praying for the whole city together, and for every one in it individually, and not merely praying but confirming your prayers by your own means? For this you are able to effect by God's help, and long, good man that you are, may you be able so to do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:4
verses.text: Nevertheless in your time our city has enjoyed but a brief dream of prosperity, in being committed to the charge of one the like of whom, according to the students of our oldest annals, never sat in the praefectorial chair.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:5
verses.text: But now the city has suddenly lost his services, through the wickedness of men who have found a ground of attack in his very liberality and impartiality, and, without the knowledge of your excellency, have made up calumnies against him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:6
verses.text: There is therefore universal depression among us at the loss of a governor with unique capacity for raising our dejected community, a true guardian of justice, accessible to the wronged, a terror to law breakers, of like behaviour to rich and poor, and, what is most important, one who has restored the interests of Christians to their old place of honour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:7
verses.text: That he was, of all men that I know, the most incapable of being bribed, and never did any one an unfair favour, I have passed by as a small point in comparison with his other virtues.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:8
verses.text: I am indeed testifying to all this too late, like men who sing dirges to console themselves when they can get no practical relief.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:9
verses.text: Yet, it is not useless that his memory should remain in your generous heart, and that you should be grateful to him as a benefactor of your native place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:10
verses.text: Should any of those who feel a grudge against him, for not sacrificing justice to their interests, attack him, it will be well for you to defend and protect him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:11
verses.text: Thus you will make it clear to all that you count his interests yours, and think it quite a sufficient reason for this your close association with him that his record should be so unimpeachable, and his administration so remarkable in view of the time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:12
verses.text: For what any other man would not be able to affect in many years has been quickly accomplished by him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:13
verses.text: It will be a great favour to me, and a comfort under the circumstances, if you will recommend him to the Emperor, and dispel the calumnious charges brought against him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 96:14
verses.text: Believe me that I am speaking here not for myself alone, but for the whole community, and that it is our unanimous prayer that he may reap some benefit from your excellency's aid.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:1
verses.text: Letter XCVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:2
verses.text: To the Senate of Tyana.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:3
verses.text: The Lord, Who reveals hidden things, and makes manifest the counsels of men's hearts, has given even to the lowly knowledge of devices apparently hard to be understood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:4
verses.text: Nothing has escaped my notice, nor has any single action been unknown.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:5
verses.text: Nevertheless I neither see nor hear anything but the peace of God and all that pertains to it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:6
verses.text: Others may be great and powerful and self-confident, but I am nothing and worth nothing, and so I could never take upon myself so much as to think myself able to manage matters without support.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:7
verses.text: I know perfectly well that I stand more in need of the succour of each of the brethren than one hand does of the other.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:8
verses.text: Truly, from our own bodily constitution, the Lord has taught us the necessity of fellowship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:9
verses.text: When I look to these my limbs and see that no out of them is self-sufficient, how can I reckon myself competent to discharge the duties of life? One foot could not walk securely without the support of the other; one eye could not see well, were it not for the alliance of the other and for its being able to look at objects in conjunction with it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:10
verses.text: Hearing is more exact when sound is received through both channels, and the grasp is made firmer by the fellowship of the fingers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:11
verses.text: In a word, of all that is done by nature and by the will, I see nothing done without the concord of fellow forces.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:12
verses.text: Even prayer, when it is not united prayer, loses its natural strength and the Lord has told us that He will be in the midst where two or three call on Him in concord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:13
verses.text: The Lord Himself undertook the economy, that by the blood of His cross He might make peace between things in earth and things in heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:14
verses.text: For all these reasons then, I pray that I may for my remaining days remain in peace; in peace I ask that it may be my lot to fall asleep.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:15
verses.text: For peace's sake there is no trouble that I will not undertake, no act, no word of humility, that I will shrink from; I will reckon no length of journey, I will undergo any inconvenience, if only I may be rewarded by being able to make peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:16
verses.text: If I am followed by any one in this direction, it is well, and my prayers are answered; but if the result is different I shall not recede from my determination.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 97:17
verses.text: Every one will receive the fruit of his own works in the day of retribution.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:1
verses.text: Letter XCVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:4
verses.text: After receiving the letter of your holiness, in which you said you would not come, I was most anxious to set out for Nicopolis, but I have grown weaker in my wish and have remembered all my infirmity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:5
verses.text: I bethought me, too, of the lack of seriousness in the conduct of those who invited me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:6
verses.text: They gave me a casual invitation by the hands of our reverend brother Hellenius, the surveyor of customs at Nazianzus, but they never took the trouble to send a messenger to remind me, or any one to escort me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:7
verses.text: As, for my sins, I was an object of suspicion to them, I shrank from sullying the brightness of their meeting by my presence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:8
verses.text: In company with your excellency I do not shrink from stripping for even serious trials of strength; but apart from you I feel myself hardly equal even to looking at every day troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:9
verses.text: Since, then, my meeting with them was intended to be about Church affairs, I let the time of the festival go by, and put off the meeting to a period of rest and freedom from distraction, and have decided to go to Nicopolis to discuss the needs of the Churches with the godly bishop Meletius, in case he should decline to go to Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:10
verses.text: If he agrees, I shall hasten to meet him, provided this is made clear to me by both of you, by him in reply to me (for I have written), and by your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:12
verses.text: We were to have met the bishops of Cappadocia Secunda, who, directly they were ranked under another prefecture, suddenly got the idea that they were made foreigners and strangers to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:13
verses.text: They ignored me, as though they had never been under my jurisdiction, and had nothing to do with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:14
verses.text: I was expecting too a second meeting with the reverend bishop Eustathius, which actually took place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:15
verses.text: For on account of the cry raised by many against him that he was injuring the faith, I met him, and found, by God's grace, that he was heartily following all orthodoxy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:16
verses.text: By the fault of the very men who ought to have conveyed my letter, that of the bishop was not transmitted to your excellency, and, harassed as I was by a multitude of cares, it escaped my memory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:17
verses.text: I, too, was anxious that our brother Gregory should have the government of a Church commensurate with his abilities; and that would have been the whole Church under the sun gathered into one place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:18
verses.text: But, as this is impossible, let him be a bishop, not deriving dignity from his see, but conferring dignity on his see by himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:19
verses.text: For it is the part of a really great man not only to be sufficient for great things, but by his own influence to make small things great.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:20
verses.text: But what is to be done to Palmatius, who, after so many exhortations of the brethren, still helps Maximus in his persecutions? Even now they do not hesitate to write to him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:21
verses.text: They are prevented from coming themselves by bodily weakness and their own occupations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 98:22
verses.text: Believe me, very godly Father, our own affairs are much in need of your presence, and yet once more you must put your honourable old age in motion, that you may give your support to Cappadocia, which is now tottering and in danger of falling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:1
verses.text: Letter XCIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:2
verses.text: To Count Terentius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:3
verses.text: I have had every desire and have really done my best to obey, if only in part, the imperial order and the friendly letter of your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:4
verses.text: I am sure that your every word and every thought are full of good intentions and right sentiments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:5
verses.text: But I have not been permitted to show my ready concurrence by practical action.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:6
verses.text: The truest cause is my sins, which always rise before me and always hamper my steps.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:7
verses.text: Then, again, there is the alienation of the bishop who had been appointed to cooperate with me, why, I know not; but my right reverend brother Theodotus, who promised from the beginning to act with me, had cordially invited me from Getasa to Nicopolis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:8
verses.text: When however he saw me in the town, he was so shocked at me, and so afraid of my sins, that he could not bear to take me either to morning or evening prayer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:9
verses.text: In this he acted quite justly so far as my deserts go, and quite as befits my course of life, but not in a manner likely to promote the interests of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:10
verses.text: His alleged reason was that I had admitted the very reverend brother Eustathius to communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:11
verses.text: What I have done is as follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:12
verses.text: When invited to a meeting held by our brother Theodotus, and wishful, for love's sake, to obey the summons, that I might not make the gathering fruitless and vain, I was anxious to hold communication with the aforementioned brother Eustathius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:13
verses.text: I put before him the accusations concerning the faith, advanced against him by our brother Theodotus, and I asked him, if he followed the right faith, to make it plain to me, that I might communicate with him; if he were of another mind he must know plainly that I should be separated from him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:14
verses.text: We had much conversation on the subject, and all that day was spent in its examination; when evening came on we separated without arriving at any definite conclusion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:15
verses.text: On the morrow, we had another sitting in the morning and discussed the same points, with the addition of our brother Poemenius, the presbyter of Sebasteia, who vehemently pressed the argument against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:16
verses.text: Point by point I cleared up the questions on which he seemed to be accusing me, and brought them to agree to my propositions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:17
verses.text: The result was, that, by the grace of the Lord, we were found to be in mutual agreement, even on the most minute particulars.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:18
verses.text: So about the ninth hour, after thanking God for granting us to think and say the same thing, we rose up to go to prayer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:19
verses.text: In addition to this I ought to have got some written statement from him, so that his assent might be made known to his opponents and the proof of his opinion might be sufficient for the rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:20
verses.text: But I was myself anxious, with the desire for great exactitude, to meet my brother Theodotus, to get a written statement of the faith from him, and to propose it to Eustathius; that so both objects might be obtained at once, the confession of the right faith by Eustathius and the complete satisfaction of Theodotus and his friends, and they would have no ground for objection after the acceptance of their own propositions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:21
verses.text: But Theodotus, before learning why we were met and what had been the result of our intercourse, decided not to allow us to take part in the meeting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:22
verses.text: So midway on our journey we set out back again, disappointed that our efforts for the peace of the Churches had been counteracted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:24
verses.text: After this, when I was compelled to undertake a journey into Armenia, knowing the man's character, and with the view both of making my own defence before a competent witness, for what had taken place and of satisfying him, I travelled to Getasa, into the territory of the very godly bishop Meletius, the aforementioned Theodotus being with me; and while there, on being accused by him of my communication with Eustathius, I told him that the result of our intercourse was my finding Eustathius to be in all things in agreement with myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:25
verses.text: Then he persisted that Eustathius, after leaving me, had denied this and asseverated to his own disciples that he had never come to any agreement with me about the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:26
verses.text: I, therefore, combated this statement; and see, O most excellent man, if the answer I made was not most fair and most complete.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:27
verses.text: I am convinced, I said, judging from the character of Eustathius, that he cannot thus lightly be turning from one direction to another, now confessing now denying what he said; that a man, shunning a lie, even in any little matter, as an awful sin, is not likely to choose to run counter to the truth in matters of such vast importance and so generally notorious: but if what is reported among you turns out to be true, he must be confronted with a written statement containing the complete exposition of the right faith; then, if I find him ready to agree in writing, I shall continue in communion with him; but, if I find that he shrinks from the test, I shall renounce all intercourse with him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:28
verses.text: The bishop Meletius agreed to these arguments, and the brother Diodorus the presbyter, who was present, and then the right reverend brother Theodotus, assented, and invited me to go to Nicopolis, both to visit the Church there, and to keep him company as far as Satala.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:29
verses.text: But he left me at Getasa, and, when I reached Nicopolis, forgetting all that he heard from me, and the agreement he had made with me, dismissed me, disgraced by the insults and dishonours which I have mentioned.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:31
verses.text: How, then, right honourable sir, was it possible for me to perform any of the injunctions laid on me, and to provide bishops for Armenia? How could I act, when the sharer of my responsibilities was thus disposed towards me,—the very man by whose aid I was expecting to be able to find suitable persons, because of his having in his district reverend and learned men, skilled in speech, and acquainted with the other peculiarities of the nation? I know their names, but I shall refrain from mentioning them, lest there arise any hindrance to the interests of Armenia being served at some future time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:32
verses.text: Now, after getting as far as Satala in such a state of health, I seemed to settle the rest by the grace of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:33
verses.text: I made peace between the Armenian bishops, and made them a suitable address, urging them to put away their customary indifference, and resume their ancient zeal in the Lord's cause.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:34
verses.text: Moreover, I delivered them rules as to how it behoved them to give heed to iniquities generally practised in Armenia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:35
verses.text: I further accepted a decision of the Church of Satala, asking that a bishop might be given them through me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:36
verses.text: I was also careful to inquire into the calumnies promulgated against our brother Cyril, the Armenian bishop, and by God's grace I have found them to be started by the lying slanders of his enemies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:37
verses.text: This they confessed to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:38
verses.text: And I seemed to some extent to reconcile the people to him, so that they avoid communion with him no more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:39
verses.text: Small achievements these, maybe, and not worth much, but in consequence of the mutual discord caused by the wiles of the devil, it was impossible for me to effect more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:40
verses.text: Even this much I ought not to have said, so as not to seem to be publishing my own disgrace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 99:41
verses.text: But as I could not plead my cause before your excellency in any other way, I was under the necessity of telling you the entire truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 100:1
verses.text: Letter C.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 100:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, Bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 100:3
verses.text: When I saw your affectionate letter, in the country bordering on Armenia, it was like a lighted torch held up at a distance to mariners at sea, especially if the sea happen to be agitated by the wind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 100:4
verses.text: Your reverence's letter was of itself a pleasant one, and full of comfort; but its natural charm was very much enhanced by the time of its arrival, a time so painful to me, that I hardly know how to describe it, after once making up my mind to forget its troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 100:5
verses.text: However, my deacon will give you a full account.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 100:6
verses.text: My bodily strength completely failed me, so that I was not even able to bear the slightest movement without pain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 100:7
verses.text: Nevertheless I do pray that, by the aid of your prayers, my own longing may be fulfilled; although my journey has caused me great difficulties, in consequence of the affairs of my own Church having been neglected through its occupying such a long time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 100:8
verses.text: But if, while I yet live, God grants me to see your reverence in my Church, then truly I shall have good hope, even for the future, that I am not wholly excluded from the gifts of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 100:9
verses.text: If it be possible, I beg that this meeting between us may take place at the Synod which we hold every year, in memory of the blessed martyr Eupsychius, now about to be held on the 7th of September.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 100:10
verses.text: I am compassed with anxieties which demand your help and sympathy, both in the matter of the appointment of bishops and in the consideration of the trouble caused me by the simplicity of Gregory of Nyssa, who is summoning a Synod at Ancyra and leaving nothing undone to counteract me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:1
verses.text: Letter CI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:2
verses.text: Consolatory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:3
verses.text: This is my first letter to you, and I could have prayed that its subject were a brighter one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:4
verses.text: Had it been so, things would have fallen out as I desire, for it is my wish that the life of all those who are purposed to live in true religion should be happily spent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:5
verses.text: But the Lord, Who ordains our course in accordance with His ineffable wisdom, has arranged that all these things should come about for the advantage of our souls, whereby He has, on the one hand, made your life sorrowful, and on the other, roused the sympathy of one who, like myself, is united to you in godly love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:6
verses.text: Therefore on my learning from my brothers what has befallen you it has seemed to me that I could not but give you such comfort as I can.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:7
verses.text: Had it indeed been possible to me to travel to the place in which you are now living I would have made every effort to do so.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:8
verses.text: But my bad health and the present business which occupies me have caused this very journey, which I have undertaken, to be injurious to the interests of my Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:9
verses.text: I have, therefore, determined to address your excellency in writing, to remind you that these afflictions are not sent by the Lord, Who rules us, to the servants of God to no purpose, but as a test of the genuineness of our love to the divine Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:10
verses.text: Just as athletes win crowns by their struggles in the arena, so are Christians brought to perfection by the trial of their temptations, if only we learn to accept what is sent us by the Lord with becoming patience, with all thanksgiving.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:11
verses.text: All things are ordained by the Lord's love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:12
verses.text: We must not accept anything that befalls us as grievous, even if, for the present, it affects our weakness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:13
verses.text: We are ignorant, peradventure, of the reasons why each thing that happens to us is sent to us as a blessing by the Lord but we ought to be convinced that all that happens to us is for our good, either for the reward of our patience, or for the soul which we have received, lest, by lingering too long in this life, it be filled with the wickedness to be found in this world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 101:14
verses.text: If the hope of Christians is limited to this life, it might rightly have been reckoned a bitter lot to be prematurely parted from the body; but if, to them that love God, the sundering of the soul from these bodily fetters is the beginning of our real life, why do we grieve like them which have no hope? Be comforted then, and do not fall under your troubles, but show that you are superior to them and can rise above them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:1
verses.text: Letter CII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:2
verses.text: To the citizens of Satala.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:3
verses.text: Moved by your importunity and that of all your people, I have undertaken the charge of your Church, and have promised before the Lord that I will be wanting to you in nothing which is within my power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:4
verses.text: So I have been compelled, as it is written, to touch as it were the apple of my eye.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:5
verses.text: Thus the high honour in which I hold you has suffered me to remember neither relationship, nor the intimacy which I have had from my boyhood with the person in question, as making a stronger demand on me than your request.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:6
verses.text: I have forgotten all the private considerations which made him near and dear to me, making no account of the sighs which will be heaved by all my people on being deprived of his rule, none of the tears of all his kindred; nor have I taken to heart the affliction of his aged mother, who is supported by his aid alone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:7
verses.text: All these considerations, great and many as they are, I have put aside, keeping only in view the one object of giving your Church the blessing of the rule of such a man, and of aiding her, now distressed as she is, at being so long without a head, and needing great and powerful support to be enabled to rise again.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:8
verses.text: So much for what concerns myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:9
verses.text: Now, on the other hand, I ask you not to fall short of the hope which I have entertained and of the promises which I have made him, that I have sent him to close friends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:10
verses.text: I ask every one of you to try to surpass the rest in love and affection to him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:11
verses.text: I entreat you to show this laudable rivalry, and to comfort his heart by the greatness of your attentions to him, that he may forget his own home, forget his kinsfolk, and forget a people so dependent on his rule, like a child weaned from his mother's breast.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 102:12
verses.text: I have despatched Nicias beforehand to explain everything to your excellencies, and that you may fix a day to keep the feast and give thanks to the Lord, Who has granted the fulfilment of your prayer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 103:1
verses.text: Letter CIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 103:2
verses.text: To the people of Satala.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 103:3
verses.text: The Lord has answered the prayer of His people and has given them, by my humble instrumentality, a shepherd worthy of the name; not one making traffic of the word, as many do, but competent to give full satisfaction to you, who love orthodoxy of doctrine, and have accepted a life agreeable to the Lord's commands, in the name of the Lord, Who has filled him with His own spiritual graces.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:1
verses.text: Letter CIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:2
verses.text: To the prefect Modestus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:3
verses.text: Merely to write to so great a man, even though there be no other reason, must be esteemed a great honour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:4
verses.text: For communication with personages of high distinction confers glory upon all to whom it is permitted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:5
verses.text: My supplication, however, is one which I am driven by necessity to make to your excellency, in my great distress at the condition of my whole country.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:6
verses.text: Bear with me, I beg you, kindly and in accordance with your own characters and reach a helping hand to my country, now beaten to the knee.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:7
verses.text: The immediate object of my entreaty is as follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:8
verses.text: By the old census, the clergy of God, presbyters and deacons, were left exempt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:9
verses.text: The recent registrars, however, without any authority from your lordship, have enrolled them, except that in some cases a few were granted immunity on the score of age.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:10
verses.text: I ask, then, that you will leave us this memorial of your beneficence, to preserve through all coming time your good fame; that in accordance with the old law the clergy be exempt from contribution.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:11
verses.text: I do not ask the remission to be conceded personally and individually to those who are now included, in which case the grace will pass to their successors, who may not always be worthy of the sacred ministry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:12
verses.text: I would suggest that some general concession be made to the clergy, according to the form in the open register, so that the exemption may be given in each place to ministers by the rulers of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:13
verses.text: This boon is sure to bring undying glory to your excellency for your good deeds, and will cause many to pray for the imperial house.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:14
verses.text: It will also really be profitable to the government, if we afford the relief of exemption, not generally to all the clergy, but to those who from time to time are in distress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 104:15
verses.text: This, as any one who chooses may know, is the course we actually pursue when we are at liberty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:1
verses.text: Letter CV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:2
verses.text: To the deaconesses, the daughters of Count Terentius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:3
verses.text: On coming to Samosata I expected to have the pleasure of meeting your excellencies, and when I was disappointed I could not easily bear it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:4
verses.text: When, I said, will it be possible for me to be in your neighbourhood again? When will it be agreeable to you to come into mine? All this, however, must be left to the Lord's will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:5
verses.text: As to the present, when I found that my son Sophronius was setting out to you, I gladly delivered him this letter, to convey you my salutation, and to tell you how, by God's grace, I do not cease to remember you, and to thank the Lord on your behalf, in that you are goodly scions of a goodly stock, fruitful in good works, and verily like lilies among thorns.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:6
verses.text: Surrounded as you are by the terrible perversity of them that are corrupting the word of truth, you do not give in to their wiles; you have not abandoned the apostolic proclamation of faith, you have not gone over to the successful novelty of the day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:7
verses.text: Is not this cause of deep thankfulness to God? Shall not this rightly bring you great renown? You have professed your faith in Father, Son and Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:8
verses.text: Do not abandon this deposit; the Father—origin of all; the Son—Only begotten, begotten of Him, very God, Perfect of Perfect, living image, shewing the whole Father in Himself; the Holy Ghost, having His subsistence of God, the fount of holiness, power that gives life, grace that maketh perfect, through Whom man is adopted, and the mortal made immortal, conjoined with Father and Son in all things in glory and eternity, in power and kingdom, in sovereignty and godhead; as is testified by the tradition of the baptism of salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:9
verses.text: But all who maintain that either Son or Spirit is a creature, or absolutely reduce the Spirit to ministerial and servile rank, are far removed from the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:10
verses.text: Flee their communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:11
verses.text: Turn away from their teaching.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:12
verses.text: They are destructive to souls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 105:13
verses.text: If ever the Lord grant us to meet, I will discourse to you further concerning the faith, to the end that you may perceive at once the power of the truth and the rottenness of heresy by Scriptural proof.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 106:1
verses.text: Letter CVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 106:2
verses.text: To a soldier.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 106:3
verses.text: I have many reasons for thanking God for mercies vouchsafed to me in my journey, but I count no blessing greater than the knowledge of your excellency, which has been permitted me by our good Lord's mercy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 106:4
verses.text: I have learnt to know one who proves that even in a soldier's life it is possible to preserve the perfection of love to God, and that we must mark a Christian not by the style of his dress, but by the disposition of his soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 106:5
verses.text: It was a great delight to me to meet you; and now, whenever I remember you, I feel very glad.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 106:6
verses.text: Play the man; be strong; strive to nourish and multiply love to God, that there may be given you by Him yet greater boons of blessing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 106:7
verses.text: I need no further proof that you remember me; I have evidence in what you have done.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 107:1
verses.text: Letter CVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 107:2
verses.text: To the Widow Julitta.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 107:3
verses.text: I was grieved to find on reading your ladyship's letter that you are involved in the same difficulties.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 107:4
verses.text: What is to be done to men who show such a shifty character, saying now one thing now another and never abiding in the same pledges? If, after the promises made in my presence, and in that of the ex-prefect, he now tries to shorten the time of grace as though nothing had been said, he does seem to have lost, as far as I am concerned, all sense of shame.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 107:5
verses.text: Nevertheless I wrote to him, rebuking him, and reminding him of his promises.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 107:6
verses.text: I wrote also to Helladius, who is of the household of the prefect, that information might be given through him about your affairs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 107:7
verses.text: I hesitated myself to make so free with an officer of such importance, on account of my never having yet written to him about my own private affairs and my fearing some adverse decision from him, great men, as you know, being easily annoyed about such matters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 107:8
verses.text: If, however, any good is to be done in the matter, it will be through Helladius, an excellent man, well disposed towards me, fearing God, and having perfectly free access to the prefect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 107:9
verses.text: The Holy One is able to deliver you from all affliction, if only truly and sincerely we fix all our hope on Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:1
verses.text: Letter CVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:2
verses.text: To the guardian of the heirs of Julitta.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:3
verses.text: I am very much astonished to hear that, after the kind promises which you made and which were only such as might be expected from your generous character, you have now forgotten them and are putting violent and stern pressure on our sister.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:4
verses.text: What to think, under the circumstances, I really do not know.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:5
verses.text: I know from many who have experienced your liberality, and bear testimony to it, how great it is; and I remember the promises which you made before me and the ex-prefect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:6
verses.text: You said that you were naming a shorter time in writing, but that you would grant a longer term of grace, from your wish to meet the necessities of the case, and do a favour to the widow, who is now compelled to pay out of her substance such a large sum of money at once.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:7
verses.text: What is the cause of this change I cannot imagine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:8
verses.text: However, whatever it is, I beg you to be mindful of your own generous character, and to look to the Lord Who requites good deeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:9
verses.text: I beg you to grant the time of remission, which you promised at the outset, that they may be able to sell their property and discharge the debt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:10
verses.text: I perfectly well remember that you promised, if you received the sum agreed on, to restore to the widow all the stipulated documents, as well those which had been executed before the magistrates as the private papers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:11
verses.text: I do beg you then, honour me and win great blessing for yourself from the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:12
verses.text: Remember your own promises, recognizing that you are human and must yourself look for that time when you will need God's help.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 108:13
verses.text: Do not shut yourself off from that help by your present severity; but, by showing all kindness and clemency to the afflicted, attract God's pity to yourself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 109:1
verses.text: Letter CIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 109:2
verses.text: To the Count Helladius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 109:3
verses.text: I shrink from troubling your good nature, on account of the greatness of your influence, for fear of seeming to make an unwarrantable use of your friendship; however, the necessity of the case prevents my holding my peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 109:4
verses.text: Our sister, who is a relative of mine, and now in the sorrowful position of a widow, has to look after the affairs of her orphan boy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 109:5
verses.text: On seeing her above measure oppressed by intolerable responsibilities, I felt great compassion for her, and, feeling deeply on the subject, I have hastened to invoke your aid, in order that you may, if possible, deign to support the messenger whom she has sent, to the end that when she has paid what she promised in person in my presence, she may be freed from any further pressure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 109:6
verses.text: She had agreed that she should be relieved from the interest on payment of the capital.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 109:7
verses.text: Now, however, those who are looking after the affairs of her heirs are trying to exact the payment of the interest as well as that of the capital.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 109:8
verses.text: The Lord, you know, makes the care of widows and orphans His own, and so do you strive to use your best endeavours in this matter, in the hope of the recompense which God Himself will give you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 109:9
verses.text: I cannot help thinking that, when our admirable and kindly prefect has heard of the discharge of the capital, he will feel for this afflicted and unhappy house now stricken to the knee, and no longer able to cope with the injuries inflicted upon it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 109:10
verses.text: Pardon, then, the necessity which compels me to intrude upon you; and give your help in this matter, in proportion to the power which Christ has given you, good and true man as you are, and using your talents for the best.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 110:1
verses.text: Letter CX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 110:2
verses.text: To the prefect Modestus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 110:3
verses.text: In kindly condescending to come down to me you give me great honour and allow me great freedom; and these in like, aye and in greater, measure, I pray that your lordship may receive from our good Master during the whole of your life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 110:4
verses.text: I have long wanted to write to you and to receive honour at your hands, but respect for your great dignity has restrained me, and I have been careful lest I should ever seem to abuse the liberty conceded to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 110:5
verses.text: Now, however, I am forced to take courage, not only by the fact of my having received permission from your incomparable excellency to write, but also by the necessity of the distressed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 110:6
verses.text: If, then, prayers of even the small are of any avail with the great, be moved, most excellent sir, of your good will to grant relief to a rural population now in pitiable case, and give orders that the tax of iron, paid by the inhabitants of iron-producing Taurus, may be made such as it is possible to pay.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 110:7
verses.text: Grant this, lest they be crushed once for all, instead of being of lasting service to the state.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 110:8
verses.text: I am sure that your admirable benevolence will see that this is done.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 111:1
verses.text: Letter CXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 111:2
verses.text: To Modestus, the prefect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 111:3
verses.text: Under any ordinary circumstances I should have lacked courage to intrude upon your excellency, for I know how to gauge my own importance and to recognise dignities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 111:4
verses.text: But now that I have seen a friend in a distressing position at having been summoned before you, I have ventured to give him this letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 111:5
verses.text: I hope that by using it, as a kind of propitiatory symbol, he may meet with merciful consideration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 111:6
verses.text: Truly, although I am of no account, moderation itself may be able to conciliate the most merciful of prefects, and to win pardon for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 111:7
verses.text: Thus if my friend has done no wrong, he may be saved by the mere force of truth; if he has erred, he may be forgiven through my entreaty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 111:8
verses.text: How we are situated here no one knows better than yourself, for you discern the weak parts in each man and rule all with your admirable forethought.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:1
verses.text: Letter CXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:2
verses.text: To Andronicus, a general.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:4
verses.text: Did but my health allow of my being able to undertake a journey without difficulty, and of putting up with the inclemency of the winter, I should, instead of writing, have travelled to your excellency in person, and this for two reasons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:5
verses.text: First to pay my old debt, for I know that I promised to come to Sebastia and to have the pleasure of seeing your excellency; I did indeed come, but I failed to meet you because I arrived a little later than your lordship; secondly, to be my own ambassador, because I have hitherto shrunk from sending, from the idea that I am too insignificant to win such a boon, and at the same time reckoning that no one by merely writing would be so likely to persuade any one of public or private rank, in behalf of any one, as by a personal interview, in which one might clear up some points in the charges, as to others make entreaty, and for others implore pardon; none of which ends can be easily achieved by a letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:6
verses.text: Now against all this I can only set one thing, your most excellent self; and because it will suffice to tell you my mind in the matter, and all that is wanting you will add of yourself, I have ventured to write as I do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:8
verses.text: But you see how from my hesitation, and because I put off explaining the reasons of my pleading, I write in roundabout phrase.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:9
verses.text: This man Domitianus has been an intimate friend of my own and of my parents from the beginning, and is like a brother to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:10
verses.text: Why should I not speak the truth? When I learnt the reasons for his being in his present troubles, I said that he had only got what he deserved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:11
verses.text: For I hoped that no one who has ever committed any offence be it small or great, will escape punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:12
verses.text: But when I saw him living a life of insecurity and disgrace, and felt that his only hope depends on your decision, I thought that he had been punished enough; and so I implore you to be magnanimous and humane in the view you take of his case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:13
verses.text: To have one's opponents under one's power is right and proper for a man of spirit and authority; but to be kind and gentle to the fallen is the mark of the man supereminent in greatness of soul, and in inclemency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:14
verses.text: So, if you will, it is in your power to exhibit your magnanimity in the case of the same man, both in punishing him and in saving him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:15
verses.text: Let the fear Domitian has of what he suspects, and of what he knows he deserves to suffer, be the extent of his chastisement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:16
verses.text: I entreat you to add nothing to his punishment, for consider this: many in former times, of whom no record has reached us, have had those who wronged them in their power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:17
verses.text: But those who surpassed their fellows in philosophy did not persist in their wrath, and of these the memory has been handed down, immortal through all time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:18
verses.text: Let this glory be added to what history will say of you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:19
verses.text: Grant to us, who desire to celebrate your praises, to be able to go beyond the instances of kindnesses sung of in days of old.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:20
verses.text: In this manner Croesus, it is said, ceased from his wrath against the slayer of his son, when he gave himself up for punishment, and the great Cyrus was friendly to this very Croesus after his victory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:21
verses.text: We shall number you with these and shall proclaim this your glory, with all our power, unless we be counted too poor heralds of so great a man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:23
verses.text: Yet another plea that I ought to urge is this, that we do not chastise transgressors for what is past and gone, (for what means can be devised for undoing the past?) but either that they may be reformed for the future, or may be an example of good behaviour to others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:24
verses.text: Now, no one could say that either of these points is lacking in the present case; for Domitian will remember what has happened till the day of his death; and I think that all the rest, with his example before them, are dead with alarm.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:25
verses.text: Under these circumstances any addition which we make to his punishment will only look like a satisfaction of our own anger.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:26
verses.text: This I should say is far from being true in your case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:27
verses.text: I could not indeed be induced to speak of such a thing did I not see that a greater blessing comes to him that gives, than to him that receives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:28
verses.text: Nor will your magnanimity be known only to a few.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:29
verses.text: All Cappadocia is looking to see what is to be done, and I pray that they may be able to number this among the rest of your good deeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:30
verses.text: I shrink from concluding my letter for fear any omission may be to my hurt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:31
verses.text: But one thing I will add.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:32
verses.text: Domitian has letters from many, who plead for him, but he thinks mine the most important of all, because he has learnt, from whom I know not, that I have influence with your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:33
verses.text: Do not let the hopes he has placed in me be blasted; do not let me lose my credit among my people here; be entreated, illustrious sir, and grant my boon.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 112:34
verses.text: You have viewed human life as clearly as ever philosopher viewed it, and you know how goodly is the treasure laid up for all those who give their help to the needy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:1
verses.text: Letter CXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:2
verses.text: To the presbyters of Tarsus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:3
verses.text: On meeting this man, I heartily thanked God that by means of his visit He had comforted me in many afflictions and had through him shewn me clearly your love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:4
verses.text: I seem to see in one man's disposition the zeal of all of you for the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:5
verses.text: He will tell you of our discourses with one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:6
verses.text: What you ought to learn directly from me is as follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:7
verses.text: We live in days when the overthrow of the Churches seems imminent; of this I have long been cognisant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:8
verses.text: There is no edification of the Church; no correction of error; no sympathy for the weak; no single defence of sound brethren; no remedy is found either to heal the disease which has already seized us, or as a preventive against that which we expect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:9
verses.text: Altogether the state of the Church (if I may use a plain figure though it may seem too humble an one) is like an old coat, which is always being torn and can never be restored to its original strength.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:10
verses.text: At such a time, then, there is need of great effort and diligence that the Churches may in some way be benefited.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:11
verses.text: It is an advantage that parts hitherto severed should be united.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:12
verses.text: Union would be effected if we were willing to accommodate ourselves to the weaker, where we can do so without injury to souls; since, then, many mouths are open against the Holy Ghost, and many tongues whetted to blasphemy against Him, we implore you, as far as in you lies, to reduce the blasphemers to a small number, and to receive into communion all who do not assert the Holy Ghost to be a creature, that the blasphemers may be left alone, and may either be ashamed and return to the truth, or, if they abide in their error, may cease to have any importance from the smallness of their numbers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:13
verses.text: Let us then seek no more than this, but propose to all the brethren, who are willing to join us, the Nicene Creed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:14
verses.text: If they assent to that, let us further require that the Holy Ghost ought not to be called a creature, nor any of those who say so be received into communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:15
verses.text: I do not think that we ought to insist upon anything beyond this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 113:16
verses.text: For I am convinced that by longer communication and mutual experience without strife, if anything more requires to be added by way of explanation, the Lord Who worketh all things together for good for them that love Him, will grant it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:1
verses.text: Letter CXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:2
verses.text: To Cyriacus, at Tarsus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:3
verses.text: I need hardly tell the sons of peace how great is the blessing of peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:4
verses.text: But now this blessing, great, marvellous, and worthy as it is of being most strenuously sought by all that love the Lord, is in peril of being reduced to the bare name, because iniquity abounds, and the love of most men has waxed cold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:5
verses.text: I think then that the one great end of all who are really and truly serving the Lord ought to be to bring back to union the Churches now "at sundry times and in divers manners" divided from one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:6
verses.text: In attempting myself to effect this, I cannot fairly be blamed as a busybody, for nothing is so characteristically Christian as the being a peacemaker, and for this reason our Lord has promised us peacemakers a very high reward.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:7
verses.text: When, therefore, I had met the brethren, and learnt how great was their brotherly love, their regard for you, and yet more their love for Christ, and their exactitude and firmness in all that concerns the faith, and moreover their earnestness in compassing two ends, the not being separated from your love, and the not abandoning their sound faith, I approved of their good disposition; and I now write to your reverence beseeching you with all love to retain them in true union, and associated with you in all your anxiety for the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:8
verses.text: I have moreover pledged myself to them for your orthodoxy, and that you too by God's grace are enrolled to fight with all vigour for the truth, whatever you may have to suffer for the true doctrine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:9
verses.text: My own opinion is that the following conditions are such as will not run counter to your own feeling and will be quite sufficient to satisfy the above mentioned brethren; namely, that you should confess the faith put forth by our Fathers once assembled at Nicaea, that you should not omit any one of its propositions, but bear in mind that the three hundred and eighteen who met together without strife did not speak without the operation of the Holy Ghost, and not to add to that creed the statement that the Holy Ghost is a creature, nor hold communion with those who so say, to the end that the Church of God may be pure and without any evil admixture of any tare.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:10
verses.text: If this full assurance is given them by your good feeling, they are prepared to offer proper submission to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 114:11
verses.text: And I myself promise for the brethren that they will offer no opposition, but will show themselves entirely subordinate, if only your excellency shall have readily granted this one thing which they ask for.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:1
verses.text: Letter CXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:2
verses.text: To the heretic Simplicia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:3
verses.text: We often ill advisedly hate our superiors and love our inferiors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:4
verses.text: So I, for my part, hold my tongue, and keep silence about the disgrace of the insults offered me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:5
verses.text: I wait for the Judge above, Who knows how to punish all wickedness in the end, even though a man pour out gold like sand; let him trample on the right, he does but hurt his own soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:6
verses.text: God always asks for sacrifice, not, I think, because He needs it, but because He accepts a pious and right mind as a precious sacrifice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:7
verses.text: But when a man by his transgressions tramples on himself God reckons his prayers impure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:8
verses.text: Bethink thyself, then, of the last day, and pray do not try to teach me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:9
verses.text: I know more than you do, and am not so choked with thorns within.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:10
verses.text: I do not mind tenfold wickedness with a few good qualities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:11
verses.text: You have stirred up against me lizards and toads, beasts, it is true, of Spring time, but nevertheless unclean.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:12
verses.text: But a bird will come from above who will devour them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:13
verses.text: The account I have to render is not according to your ideas, but as God thinks fit to judge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:14
verses.text: If witnesses are wanted, there will not stand before the Judge slaves; nor yet a disgraceful and detestable set of eunuchs; neither woman nor man, lustful, envious, ill-bribed, passionate, effeminate, slaves of the belly, mad for gold, ruthless, grumbling about their dinner, inconstant, stingy, greedy, insatiable, savage, jealous.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:15
verses.text: What more need I say? At their very birth they were condemned to the knife.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:16
verses.text: How can their mind be right when their feet are awry? They are chaste because of the knife, and it is no credit to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:17
verses.text: They are lecherous to no purpose, of their own natural vileness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 115:18
verses.text: These are not the witnesses who shall stand in the judgment, but rather the eyes of the just and the eyesight of the perfect, of all who are then to see with their eyes what they now see with their understanding.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:1
verses.text: Letter CXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:2
verses.text: To Firminius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:3
verses.text: You write seldom, and your letters are short, either because you shrink from writing or from avoiding the satiety that comes from excess; or perhaps to train yourself to curt speech.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:4
verses.text: I, indeed, am never satisfied and however abundant be your communication, it is less than my desire, because I wish to know every detail about you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:5
verses.text: How are you as to health? How as to ascetic discipline? Do you persevere in your original purpose? Or have you formed some new plan, changing your mind according to circumstances? Had you remained the same, I should not have wanted a great number of letters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:6
verses.text: I should have been quite satisfied with "I am quite well and I hope you are quite well".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:7
verses.text: But I hear what I am ashamed to say, that you have deserted the ranks of your blessed forefathers, and deserted to your paternal grandfather, and are anxious to be rather a Brettanius than a Firminius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:8
verses.text: I am very anxious to hear about this, and to learn the reasons which have induced you to take to this kind of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:9
verses.text: You have yourself been silent; ashamed, I suppose, of your intentions, and therefore I must implore you not to entertain any project, which can be associated with shame.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:10
verses.text: If any such idea has entered into your mind, put it from you, come to yourself again, bid a long farewell to soldiering and arms and the toils of the camp.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:11
verses.text: Return home thinking it, as your forefathers thought before you, quite enough for ease of life and all possible distinction to hold a high place in your city.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:12
verses.text: This, I am sure, you will be able to achieve without difficulty, when I consider your natural gifts and the small number of your rivals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:13
verses.text: If, then, this was not your original intention, or if after forming it you have rejected it, let me know at once.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:14
verses.text: If, on the other hand, which God forbid, you remain in the same mind, let the trouble come self announced.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 116:15
verses.text: I do not want a letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:1
verses.text: Letter CXVII.
