verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:3
verses.text: For many reasons I know that I am a debtor to your reverence, and now the anxiety in which I find myself necessarily puts me in the way of services of this kind, although my advisers are mere chance comers, and not like yourself joined to me by many and different ties.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:4
verses.text: There is no need to bring the past under review.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:5
verses.text: I may say that I was the cause of my own difficulties, by determining to leave that good discipline which alone leads to salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:6
verses.text: The result was that in this trouble I soon fell into temptation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:7
verses.text: What happened has seemed worthy of mention, so that I may not again fall into similar distress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:8
verses.text: As to the future, I wish to give full assurance to your reverence, that, by God's grace, all will go well, since the proceeding is lawful, and there is no difficulty about it, as many of my friends about the court are ready to help me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:9
verses.text: I shall therefore have a petition drawn up, similar to the form presented to the Vicar; and, if no delay intervene, I shall promptly get my discharge, and shall be sure to give you relief by sending you the formal document.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:10
verses.text: I feel sure that in this my own convictions have more force than the imperial orders.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:11
verses.text: If I shew this fixed and firm in the highest life, by God's aid the keeping of my chastity will be inviolable and sure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:12
verses.text: I have been pleased to see the brother entrusted to me by you, and hold him among my intimate friends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 117:13
verses.text: I trust he may prove worthy of God and of your good word.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 118:1
verses.text: Letter CXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 118:2
verses.text: To Jovinus, Bishop of Perrha.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 118:3
verses.text: You owe me a good turn.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 118:4
verses.text: For I lent you a kindness, which I ought to get back with interest;—a kind of interest, this, which our Lord does not refuse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 118:5
verses.text: Pay me, then, my friend, by paying me a visit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 118:6
verses.text: So much for the capital; what of the increment? It is the fact of the visit being paid by you, who are a man as much superior to me, as fathers are better than children.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:1
verses.text: Letter CXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:2
verses.text: To Eustathius, Bishop of Sebasteia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:3
verses.text: I address you by the very honourable and reverend brother Petrus, beseeching you now and ever to pray for me, that I may be changed from ways dangerous and to be shunned, and may be made one day worthy of the name of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:4
verses.text: Though I say nothing, you will converse together about my affairs, and he will give you an exact account of what has taken place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:5
verses.text: But you admit without due examination, the vile suspicions against me which will probably be raised by men who have insulted me, in violation of the fear of God and the regard of men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:6
verses.text: I am ashamed to tell you what treatment I have received from the illustrious Basilius, whom I had accepted at the hands of your reverence as a protection for my life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:7
verses.text: But, when you have heard what our brother has to say, you will know every detail.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:8
verses.text: I do not thus speak to avenge myself upon him, for I pray that it may not be put to his account by the Lord, but in order that your affection to me may remain firm, and because I am afraid lest it be shaken by the monstrous slanders which these men are pretty sure to make up in defence of their fall.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:9
verses.text: Whatever be the charges they adduce, I hope your intelligence will put these enquiries to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:10
verses.text: Have they formally accused me? Have they sought for any correction of the error which they bring against me? Have they made their grievance against me plain? As matters are, by their ignoble flight they have made it evident that under the cheerfulness of their countenance, and their counterfeit expressions of affection, they are all the while hiding in their heart an immense depth of guile and of gall.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:11
verses.text: In all this, whether I narrate it or not, your intelligence knows perfectly well what sorrow they have caused me, and what laughter to those who, always expressing their abomination for the pious life in this wretched city, affirm that the pretence of virtue is practised as a mere trick to get credit, a mere assumption to deceive.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:12
verses.text: So in these days no mode of life is now so suspected of vice by people here as the profession of asceticism.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:13
verses.text: Your intelligence will consider what is the best cure for all this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:14
verses.text: As to the charges patched up against me by Sophronius, far from being a prelude of blessings, they are a beginning of division and separation, and are likely to lead to even my love growing cold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 119:15
verses.text: I implore that by your merciful kindness he may be withheld from his injurious efforts, and that your affection may strive rather to tighten the bonds of what is falling asunder, and not to increase separation by joining with those who are eager for dissent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:1
verses.text: Letter CXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:2
verses.text: To Meletius, bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:3
verses.text: I have received a letter from the very God-beloved bishop Eusebius, in which he enjoins that a second letter be written to the Westerns about certain Church matters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:4
verses.text: He has expressed a wish that the letter should be drawn up by me, and signed by all those who are in communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:5
verses.text: Having no means of writing a letter about these wishes of his, I have sent on his minute to your holiness, in order that, when you have read it and can give heed to the information given by the very dear brother Sanctissimus, our fellow presbyter, you may yourself be so good as to indite a letter on these points as seems best to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:6
verses.text: We are prepared to agree to it and to lose no time in having it conveyed to those in communion with us, so that, when all have signed it may be carried by the messenger, who is on the point of starting on his journey to visit the bishops of the West.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:7
verses.text: Give orders for the decision of your holiness to be communicated to me as quickly as possible, that I may not be ignorant of your intentions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:8
verses.text: As to the intrigue which is now being devised, or has already been devised against me, in Antioch, the same brother will convey intimation to your holiness, unless indeed the report of what has been done does not anticipate him and make the position clear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:9
verses.text: There is ground for hope that the threats are coming to an end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:10
verses.text: I wish your reverence to know that our brother Anthimus has ordained Faustus, who is living with the pope as bishop, without having received the votes, and in place of our right reverend brother Cyril.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:11
verses.text: Thus he has filled Armenia with schisms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:12
verses.text: I have thought it right to tell your reverence this, lest they should lie against me, and I be responsible for these disorderly proceedings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:13
verses.text: You will of course deem it right to make this known to the rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 120:14
verses.text: I think such irregularity will distress many.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 121:1
verses.text: Letter CXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 121:2
verses.text: To Theodotus, bishop of Nicopolis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 121:3
verses.text: The winter is severe and protracted, so that it is difficult for me even to have the solace of letters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 121:4
verses.text: For this reason I have written seldom to your reverence and seldom heard from you, but now my beloved brother Sanctissimus, the co-presbyter, has undertaken a journey as far as your city.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 121:5
verses.text: By him I salute your lordship, and ask you to pray for me, and to give ear to Sanctissimus, that from him you may learn in what situation the Churches are placed, and may give all possible heed to the points put before you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 121:6
verses.text: You must know that Faustus came with letters for me, from the pope, requesting that he might be ordained bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 121:7
verses.text: When however I asked him for some testimonial from yourself, and the rest of the bishops, he made light of me and betook himself to Anthimus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 121:8
verses.text: He came back, ordained by Anthimus, without any communication having been made to me on the subject.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 122:1
verses.text: Letter CXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 122:2
verses.text: To Poemenius, bishop of Satala.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 122:3
verses.text: When the Armenians returned by your way you no doubt asked for a letter from them, and you learnt why I had not given the letter to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 122:4
verses.text: If they spoke as truth lovers should, you forgave me on the spot; if they kept anything back (which I do not suppose), at all events hear it from me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 122:5
verses.text: The most illustrious Anthimus, who long ago made peace with me, when he found an opportunity of satisfying his own vain gloriousness, and of causing me some vexation, consecrated Faustus, by his own authority and with his own hand, without waiting for any election from you, and ridiculing my punctiliousness in such matters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 122:6
verses.text: Inasmuch, then, as he has confounded ancient order and has made light of you, for whose election I was waiting, and has acted in a manner, as I view it, displeasing to God, for these reasons I felt pained with them, and gave no letter for any of the Armenians, not even for your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 122:7
verses.text: Faustus I would not even receive into communion, thereby plainly testifying that, unless he brought me a letter from you, I should be permanently alienated from him, and should influence those of the same mind with me to treat him in the same manner.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 122:8
verses.text: If there is any remedy for these things, be sure to write to me yourself, giving your testimony to him, if you see that his life is good; and exhort the rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 122:9
verses.text: If on the other hand the mischief is incurable, let me perfectly understand it to be so, that I may no longer take them into account; although really, as they have proved, they have agreed, for the future, to transfer their communion to Anthimus, in contempt of me and of my Church, as though my friendship were no longer worth having.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 123:1
verses.text: Letter CXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 123:2
verses.text: To Urbicius, the monk.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 123:3
verses.text: You were to have come to see me (and the blessing was drawing near) to cool me, aflame in my temptations, with the tip of your finger.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 123:4
verses.text: What then? My sins stood in the way and hindered your start, so that I am sick without a remedy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 123:5
verses.text: Just as when the waves are round us, one sinks and another rises, and another looms black and dreadful, so of my troubles: some have ceased, some are with me, some are before me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 123:6
verses.text: As is generally the case, the one remedy for these troubles is to yield to the crisis and withdraw from my persecutors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 123:7
verses.text: Yet come to me, to console, to advise, or even to travel with me; in any case you will make me better for the mere sight of you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 123:8
verses.text: Above all, pray, and pray again, that my reason be not whelmed by the waves of my troubles; pray that all through I may keep a heart pleasing to God, that I be not numbered with the wicked servants, who thank a master when he gives them good, and refuse to submit when he chastises them by adversity; but let me reap benefit from my very trials, trusting most in God when I need Him most.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:1
verses.text: Letter CXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:2
verses.text: To Theodorus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:3
verses.text: It is sometimes said that slaves to the passion of love, when by some inevitable necessity they are separated from the object of their desire, are able to stay the violence of their passion by indulging the sense of sight, if haply they can look at the picture of the beloved object.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:4
verses.text: Whether this be true or not I cannot say; but what has befallen me in your case, my friend, is not very different.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:5
verses.text: I have felt a disposition towards your godly and guileless soul, somewhat, if I may so say, of the nature of love; but the gratification of my desire, like that of all other blessings, is made difficult to me by the opposition of my sins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:6
verses.text: However, I have seemed to see a very good likeness of you in the presence of my very reverend brothers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:7
verses.text: And if it had been my lot to fall in with you when far away from them, I should have fancied that I saw them in you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:8
verses.text: For the measure of love in each of you is so great, that in both of you there is a plain contest for the superiority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:9
verses.text: I have thanked God for this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:10
verses.text: If any longer life be left me, I pray that my life may be made sweet through you, just as now I look on life as a wretched thing to be avoided, because I am separated from the companionship of those I love best.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 124:11
verses.text: For, in my judgment, there is nothing in which one can be cheerful when cut off from those who truly love us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:1
verses.text: Letter CXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:2
verses.text: A transcript of the faith as dictated by Saint Basil, and subscribed by Eustathius, bishop of Sebasteia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:4
verses.text: Both men whose minds have been preoccupied by a heterodox creed and now wish to change over to the congregation of the orthodox, and also those who are now for the first time desirous of being instructed in the doctrine of truth, must be taught the creed drawn up by the blessed fathers in the Council which met at Nicaea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:5
verses.text: The same training would also be exceedingly useful in the case of all who are under suspicion of being in a state of hostility to sound doctrine, and who by ingenious and plausible excuses keep the depravity of their sentiments out of view.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:6
verses.text: For these too this creed is all that is needed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:7
verses.text: They will either get cured of their concealed unsoundness, or, by continuing to keep it concealed, will themselves bear the load of the sentence due to their dishonesty, and will provide us with an easy defence in the day of judgment, when the Lord will lift the cover from the hidden things of darkness, and "make manifest the counsels of the hearts".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:8
verses.text: It is therefore desirable to receive them with the confession not only that they believe in the words put forth by our fathers at Nicaea, but also according to the sound meaning expressed by those words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:9
verses.text: For there are men who even in this creed pervert the word of truth, and wrest the meaning of the words in it to suit their own notions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:10
verses.text: So Marcellus, when expressing impious sentiments concerning the hypostasis of our Lord Jesus Christ, and describing Him as being Logos and nothing more, had the hardihood to profess to find a pretext for his principles in that creed by affixing an improper sense upon the Homoousion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:11
verses.text: Some, moreover, of the impious following of the Libyan Sabellius, who understand hypostasis and substance to be identical, derive ground for the establishment of their blasphemy from the same source, because of its having been written in the creed "if any one says that the Son is of a different substance or hypostasis, the Catholic and Apostolic Church anathematizes him".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:12
verses.text: But they did not there state hypostasis and substance to be identical.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:13
verses.text: Had the words expressed one and the same meaning, what need of both? It is on the contrary clear that while by some it was denied that the Son was of the same substance with the Father, and some asserted that He was not of the substance and was of some other hypostasis, they thus condemned both opinions as outside that held by the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:14
verses.text: When they set forth their own view, they declared the Son to be of the substance of the Father, but they did not add the words "of the hypostasis".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:15
verses.text: The former clause stands for the condemnation of the faulty view; the latter plainly states the dogma of salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:16
verses.text: We are therefore bound to confess the Son to be of one substance with the Father, as it is written; but the Father to exist in His own proper hypostasis, the Son in His, and the Holy Ghost in His, as they themselves have clearly delivered the doctrine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:17
verses.text: They indeed clearly and satisfactorily declared in the words Light of Light, that the Light which begat and the Light which was begotten, are distinct, and yet Light and Light; so that the definition of the Substance is one and the same.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:18
verses.text: I will now subjoin the actual creed as it was drawn up at Nicaea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:20
verses.text: πιστεύομεν εἰς ἕνα Θεὸν Πατέρα παντοκράτορα, πάντων ὁρατῶν τε καὶ ἀοράτων ποιητήν· [ποιητὴν οὐρανοῦ καὶ γῆς ὁρατῶν τε πάντων καὶ ἀοράτων·]  καὶ εἰς ἕνα Κύριον Ιησοῦν Χριστόν, τὸν υἱ& 232·ν τοῦ Θεοῦ [τὸν μονογενῆ] γεννηθέντα ἐκ τοῦ Πατρὸς μονογενῆ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:21
verses.text: [τὸν ἐκ τοῦ Πατρὸς γεννηθέντα πρὸ πάντων τών αἰ& 240·νων.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:22
verses.text: ]  τουτέστιν ἐκ τῆς οὐσίας τοῦ Πατρός, Θεὸν ἐκ Θεοῦ [omit], Φῶς ἐκ Φῶτος, Θεὸν ἀληθινὸν ἐκ Θεοῦ ἀληθινοῦ, γεννηθέντα οὐ ποιηθέντα, ὁμοούσιον τῷ Πατρι, δι᾽ οἷ τὰ πάντα ἐγένετο, τά τε ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ καὶ τὰ ἐν τῇ γῇ [omit].

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:23
verses.text: τὸν δι᾽ ἡμᾶς τοὺς ἀνθρωποὺς καὶ διὰ τὴν ἡμέτεραν σωτηρίαν, κατελθόντα [ἐκ τῶν οὐρανῶν] καὶ σαρκωθέντα.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:24
verses.text: [ἑκ πνεύματος ἁγίου καὶ Μαρίας τῆς παρθένου.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:25
verses.text: ]  καὶ ἐνανθρωπήσαντα [σταυρωθέντα τε ὑπὲρ ημῶν ἐπὶ Ποντίου Πιλάτου, καὶ], παθόντα [καὶ ταφέντα], καί ἀναστάντα τῇ τρίτῃ ἡμέρα [κατὰ τὰς γραφὰς καὶ], ἀνελθόντα εἰς τοὺς οὐρανοὺς.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:26
verses.text: [καὶ καθεζόμενον ἐκ δεξιῶν τοῦ Πατρός.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:27
verses.text: ]  καί πάλιν ἐρχόμενον [μετὰ δόξης] κρῖναι ζῶντας καὶ νεκρούς· [οὗ τῆς βασιλείας οὐκ ἔσται τέλος·]  καί εἰς τὸ Πνεῦμα τὸ ἅγιον.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:28
verses.text: [τὸ Κύριον καὶ τὸ ζωοποιὸν τὸ ἐκ τοῦ Πατρὸς ἐκπορευόμενον, τὸ σὺν Πατρὶ καὶ Υἱ& 254· συμπροσκυνούμενον καὶ συνδοξαζόμενον, τὸ λαλῆσαν διὰ τῶν προφητῶν· εἰς μίαν ἁγίαν καθολικὴν καὶ ἀποστολικὴν ἐκκλησίαν, ὁμολογοῦμεν ἓν βάπτισμα εἰς ἄφεσιν ἁμαρτιῶν, προσδοκῶμεν ἀνάστασιν νεκρῶν, καὶ ζωὴν τοῦ μέλλοντος αἰ& 242·νος.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:29
verses.text: ᾽Αμὴν.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:30
verses.text: ]  τοῦς δὲ λέγοντας, ἦν ποτε ὅτε οὐκ ἦν, καὶ πρὶν γεννηθῆναι οὐκ ἦν, καὶ ὅτι ἐξ οὐκ ὄντων ἐγένετο, ἢ ἐξ ἑτέρας ὑποστάσεως ἢ οὐσίας φάσκοντας εἶναι, ἢ κτιστὸν ἢ τρεπτὸν ἢ ἀλλοιωτὸν τὸν Υἱ& 232·ν τοῦ Θεοῦ, τουτοὺς ἀναθεματίζει ἡ καθολικὴ καὶ ἀποστολικὴ ἐκκλησια.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:31
verses.text: [Omit all the Anathemas.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:33
verses.text: Here then all points but one are satisfactorily and exactly defined, some for the correction of what had been corrupted, some as a precaution against errors expected to arise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:34
verses.text: The doctrine of the Spirit, however, is merely mentioned, as needing no elaboration, because at the time of the Council no question was mooted, and the opinion on this subject in the hearts of the faithful was exposed to no attack.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:35
verses.text: Little by little, however, the growing poison-germs of impiety, first sown by Arius, the champion of the heresy, and then by those who succeeded to his inheritance of mischief, were nurtured to the plague of the Church, and the regular development of the impiety issued in blasphemy against the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:36
verses.text: Under these circumstances we are under the necessity of putting before the men who have no pity for themselves, and shut their eyes to the inevitable threat directed by our Lord against blasphemers of the Holy Ghost, their bounden duty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:37
verses.text: They must anathematize all who call the Holy Ghost a creature, and all who so think; all who do not confess that He is holy by nature, as the Father is holy by nature, and the Son is holy by nature, and refuse Him His place in the blessed divine nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:38
verses.text: Our not separating Him from Father and Son is a proof of our right mind, for we are bound to be baptized in the terms we have received and to profess belief in the terms in which we are baptized, and as we have professed belief in, so to give glory to Father, Son, and Holy Ghost; and to hold aloof from the communion of all who call Him creature, as from open blasphemers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:39
verses.text: One point must be regarded as settled; and the remark is necessary because of our slanderers; we do not speak of the Holy Ghost as unbegotten, for we recognise one Unbegotten and one Origin of all things, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ: nor do we speak of the Holy Ghost as begotten, for by the tradition of the faith we have been taught one Only-begotten: the Spirit of truth we have been taught to proceed from the Father, and we confess Him to be of God without creation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:40
verses.text: We are also bound to anathematize all who speak of the Holy Ghost as ministerial, inasmuch as by this term they degrade Him to the rank of a creature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:41
verses.text: For that the ministering spirits are creatures we are told by Scripture in the words "they are all ministering spirits sent forth to minister".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:42
verses.text: But because of men who make universal confusion, and do not keep the doctrine of the Gospels, it is necessary to add yet this further, that they are to be shunned, as plainly hostile to true religion, who invert the order left us by the Lord, and put the Son before the Father, and the Holy Spirit before the Son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:43
verses.text: For we must keep unaltered and inviolable that order which we have received from the very words of the Lord, "Go ye therefore and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:44
verses.text: I, Eustathius, bishop, have read to thee, Basil, and understood; and I assent to what is written above.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 125:45
verses.text: I have signed in the presence of our Fronto, Severus, the chorepiscopus, and several other clerics.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 126:1
verses.text: Letter CXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 126:2
verses.text: To Atarbius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 126:3
verses.text: On arriving at Nicopolis in the double hope of settling the disturbances which had arisen, and applying a remedy, as far as possible, to measures taken in a disorderly manner and in violation of the law of the Church, I was exceedingly disappointed at failing to meet you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 126:4
verses.text: I heard that you had hurriedly withdrawn, and actually from the very synod which was being held by you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 126:5
verses.text: I am, therefore, under the necessity of having recourse to writing, and by this letter I bid you present yourself before me, that you may in person apply some remedy to the pain which I felt, even unto death, on hearing that you had ventured on action, in the very middle of the church, of the like of which I hitherto have never heard.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 126:6
verses.text: All this, although painful and serious, is endurable, as having happened to a man who has committed the punishment due for his sufferings to God, and is wholly devoted to peace and to preventing harm falling from any fault of his on God's people.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 126:7
verses.text: Since, however, some honourable brethren, worthy of all credit, have told me that you have introduced certain innovations into the faith, and have spoken against sound doctrine, I am under the circumstances the more agitated, and above measure anxious, lest, in addition to the countless wounds which have been inflicted on the Church by traitors to the truth of the Gospel, yet a further calamity should spring up in the renewal of the ancient heresy of Sabellius, the enemy of the Church; for to this the brethren have reported your utterances to be akin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 126:8
verses.text: I have, therefore, written to charge you not to shrink from undertaking a short journey to come to me, and, by giving me full assurance in the matter, at once to alleviate my pangs, and to solace the Churches of God, which are now pained to a grave, nay an unendurable extent, at your actions and your reported words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 127:1
verses.text: Letter CXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 127:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 127:3
verses.text: Our merciful God, Who makes comfort match trouble, and consoles the lowly, lest they be drowned unawares in exceeding grief, has sent a consolation, equivalent to the troubles I have suffered in Nicopolis, in seasonably bringing me the God-beloved bishop Jobinus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 127:4
verses.text: He must tell you himself how very opportune his visit was.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 127:5
verses.text: I shrink from a long letter, and will hold my peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 127:6
verses.text: And I am the more inclined to silence, lest I seem as it were to put a mark on men, who have turned round and begun to show regard to me, by mentioning their fall.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 127:7
verses.text: God grant that you may come to see me in my own home, so that I may embrace your reverence and tell you everything in detail.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 127:8
verses.text: For we often find some comfort in telling what is painful in actual experience.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 127:9
verses.text: However, for all that the very godly bishop has done, fully as far as regards his affection for me, and preeminently and stoutly as regards the exact observance of the canons, commend him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 127:10
verses.text: Moreover, thank God that your pupils everywhere exhibit your reverence's character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:1
verses.text: Letter CXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:4
verses.text: Hitherto I have been unable to give any adequate and practical proof of my earnest desire to pacify the Churches of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:5
verses.text: But in my heart I affirm that I have so great a longing, that I would gladly give up even my life, if thereby the flame of hatred, kindled by the evil one, could be put out.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:6
verses.text: If it was not for the sake of this longing for peace that I consented to come to Colonia, may my life be unblessed by peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:7
verses.text: The peace I seek is the true peace, left us by the Lord Himself; and what I have asked that I may have for my assurance belongs to one who desires nothing but the true peace, although some perversely interpret the truth into another sense.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:8
verses.text: Let them use their tongues as they will, but assuredly they will one day be sorry for their words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:10
verses.text: Now I beseech your holiness to remember the original propositions, and not to be led away by receiving answers that do not fit the questions, nor yet to give practical weight to the quibbles of men who, without any power of argument, very cleverly pervert the truth, from their own ideas alone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:11
verses.text: I set out propositions which were perfectly simple, clear and easy to remember; do we decline to receive into communion those who refuse to accept the Nicene Creed? Do we refuse to have part or lot with those who have the hardihood to assert that the Holy Ghost is a creature? He, however, instead of answering my questions word for word, has concocted the statement which you have sent me:—and this not from simplemindedness, as might be imagined, nor yet from his inability to see the consequences.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:12
verses.text: What he reckons is that, by repudiating my proposition, he will expose his true character to the people; while, if he agrees to it, he will depart from that via media which has hitherto seemed to him preferable to any other position.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:13
verses.text: Let him not try to beguile me, nor, with the rest, deceive your intelligence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:14
verses.text: Let him send a concise answer to my question, whether he accepts or repudiates communion with the enemies of the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:15
verses.text: If you get him to do this and send me such a distinct answer as I pray for, I own myself in error in all that has gone before; I take all the blame upon myself; then ask from me a proof of humility.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:16
verses.text: But, if nothing of the kind come to pass, pardon me, most God-beloved father, in my inability to approach God's altar with hypocrisy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:17
verses.text: Were it not for this dread, why should I separate myself from Euippius, so learned a man, so advanced in age, and bound to me by so many ties of affection? If, however, in this case I acted rightly, it would, I am sure, be absurd to appear united with those who maintain the same views as Euippius, through the mediation of these amiable and charming persons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:19
verses.text: Not that I think it is absolutely our duty to cut ourselves off from those who do not receive the faith, but rather to have regard to them in accordance with the old law of love, and to write to them with one consent, giving them all exhortation with pity, and to propose to them the faith of the fathers, and invite them to union.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:20
verses.text: If we succeed we should be united in communion with them; if we fail we must be content with one another and purge our conduct of this uncertain spirit, restoring the evangelical and simple conversation followed by those who accepted the Word from the beginning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:21
verses.text: "They," it is said, "were of one heart and of one soul".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 128:22
verses.text: If they obey you, this will be best; if not, recognise the real authors of the war, and, for the future do not write me any more letters about reconciliation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:1
verses.text: Letter CXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:2
verses.text: To Meletius Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:4
verses.text: I knew that the charge which had lately sprung up against the loquacious Apollinarius would sound strange in the ears of your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:5
verses.text: I did not know myself, till now, that he was accused; at the present time, however, the Sebastenes, after search in some quarter or another, have brought these things forward, and they are carrying about a document for which they are specially trying to condemn me on the ground that I hold the same sentiments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:6
verses.text: It contains the following phrases.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:7
verses.text: "Wherefore it is everywhere necessary to understand the first identity in conjunction with, or rather in union with, the second, and to say that the second and the third are the same.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:8
verses.text: For what the Father is firstly, the Son is secondly, and the Spirit thirdly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:9
verses.text: And, again, what the Spirit is firstly, the Son is secondly, in so far as the Spirit is the Lord; and the Father thirdly, in so far as the Spirit is God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:10
verses.text: And, to express the ineffable with greatest force, the Father is Son in a paternal sense, and the Son Father in a filial sense, and so in the case of the Spirit, in so far as the Trinity is one God".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:11
verses.text: This is what is being bruited about.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:12
verses.text: I never can believe it to have been invented by those through whom it has been published, although, after their slanders against me, I can regard nothing as beyond their audacity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:13
verses.text: For writing to some of their party, they advanced their false accusation against me, and then added the words I have quoted, describing them as the work of heretics, but saying nothing as to the author of the document, in order that it might vulgarly be supposed to have come from my pen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:14
verses.text: Nevertheless, in my opinion, their intelligence would not have gone far enough in putting the phrases together.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:15
verses.text: On this account, in order to repudiate the growing blasphemy against myself, and shew to all the world that I have nothing in common with those who make such statements, I have been compelled to mention Apollinarius as approximating to the impiety of Sabellius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:16
verses.text: Of this subject I will say no more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:18
verses.text: I have received a message from the court that, after the first impulse of the Emperor, to which he was impelled by my calumniators, a second decree has been passed, that I am not to be delivered to my accusers, nor given over to their will, as was ordered at the beginning; but that there has been in the meanwhile some delay.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:19
verses.text: If then this obtains, or any gentler measure is determined on, I will let you know.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:20
verses.text: If the former prevails, it shall not be so, without your knowledge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:22
verses.text: Our brother Sanctissimus has certainly been with you a long time, and you have learnt the objects he has in view.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:23
verses.text: If, then, the letter to the Westerns seems to you to contain at all what is requisite, be so good as to have it written out and conveyed to me, that I may get it signed by those who think with us, and may keep the subscription ready, and written out on a separate paper, which we can fasten on to the letter which is being carried about by our brother and fellow presbyter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:24
verses.text: As I did not find in the minute anything conclusive, I was in a difficulty on what point to write to the Westerns.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:25
verses.text: Necessary points are anticipated, and it is useless to write what is superfluous, and on such points would it not be ridiculous to show feeling? One subject, however, did appear to me to be hitherto untouched, and to suggest a reason for writing, and that was an exhortation to them not indiscriminately to accept the communion of men coming from the East; but, after once choosing one side, to receive the rest on the testimony of their fellows, and not to assent to every one writing a form of creed on the pretext of orthodoxy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:26
verses.text: If they do so, they will be found in communion with men at war with one another, who often put forward the same formulae, and yet battle vehemently against one another, as those who are most widely separated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 129:27
verses.text: To the end, then, that the heresy may not be the more widely kindled, while those who are at variance with one another mutually object to their own formulae, they ought to be exhorted to make a distinction between the acts of communion which are brought them by chance comers, and those which are duly drawn up according to the rule of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:1
verses.text: Letter CXXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:2
verses.text: To Theodotus bishop of Nicopolis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:4
verses.text: You have very rightly and properly blamed me, right honourable and well beloved brother, in that ever since I departed from your reverence, conveying to Eustathius those propositions about the faith, I have told you neither much nor little about his business.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:5
verses.text: This neglect is really not due to any contempt on my part for the way in which he has treated me, but simply to the fact that the story is now published abroad in all men's ears, and nobody needs any instructions from me in order to learn what his intentions are.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:6
verses.text: For this he has had good heed, as though he were really afraid that he would have few witnesses of his opinion, and has sent to the ends of the earth the letter which he has written against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:7
verses.text: He has therefore severed himself from communion with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:8
verses.text: He did not consent to meet me at the appointed spot, and did not bring his disciples, as he had promised.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:9
verses.text: On the contrary, he publicly stigmatized me in the public synods, with the Cilician Theophilus, by the open and undisguised slander of sowing in the souls of the people doctrines at variance with his own teaching.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:10
verses.text: This was quite enough to break up all union between us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:11
verses.text: Afterwards he came to Cilicia, and, on meeting with a certain Gelasius, showed him the creed which only an Arian, or a thorough disciple of Arius, could subscribe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:12
verses.text: Then, indeed, I was yet more confirmed in my alienation from him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:13
verses.text: I felt that the Ethiopian will never change his skin, nor the leopard his spots, nor a man nurtured in doctrines of perversity ever be able to rub off the stain of his heresy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:15
verses.text: In addition to all this he has had the impudence to write against me, or rather to compose long discourses full of all kinds of abuse and calumny.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:16
verses.text: To these, up to this time, I have answered nothing, taught as we are by the Apostle, not to avenge ourselves, but to give place unto wrath.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:17
verses.text: Moreover, at the thought of the depth of the hypocrisy with which he has all along approached me, I have, in a way, become speechless with amazement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:18
verses.text: But, if all this had never happened, who would not feel horror and detestation of the fellow at this fresh piece of audacity? Now, as I hear, if the report is really true and not a slanderous invention, he has ventured to re-ordain certain men; a proceeding on which so far no heretic has ventured.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:19
verses.text: How then can I quietly endure such treatment? How can I look upon the errors of the man as curable? Beware, then, of being led away by lies; do not be moved by the suspicions of men who are prone to look at everything in a bad light, as though I were making little of such things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:20
verses.text: For, be sure, my very dear and honourable friend, that I have never at any time been so grieved as I am now, on hearing of this confusion of the laws of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:21
verses.text: Pray only that the Lord grant me to take no step in anger, but to maintain charity, which behaveth itself not unseemly and is not puffed up.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 130:22
verses.text: Only look how men without charity have been lifted up beyond all human bounds and conduct themselves in an unseemly manner, daring deeds which have no precedent in all the past.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:2
verses.text: To Olympius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:4
verses.text: Truly unexpected tidings make both ears tingle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:5
verses.text: This is my case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:6
verses.text: These compositions against me, which are being carried about, have fallen upon ears by this time pretty well seasoned, on account of my having formerly received the letter, appropriate enough to my sins, but which I should never have expected to be written by those who sent it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:7
verses.text: Nevertheless what followed did seem to me so extraordinarily cruel as to blot out all that had gone before.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:8
verses.text: How could I fail to be driven almost out of my senses when I read the letter addressed to the reverend brother Dazinas, full of outrageous insults and calumnies and of attacks against me, as though I had been convicted of much pernicious designs against the Church? Moreover proofs were forthwith offered of the truth of the calumnies against me, from the document of whose authorship I am ignorant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:9
verses.text: Parts I recognise, I own, as having been written by Apollinarius of Laodicea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:10
verses.text: These I had purposely not even ever read, but I had heard of them from the report of others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:11
verses.text: Other portions I found included, which I had never either read or heard of from any one else; of the truth of this there is a faithful witness in heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:12
verses.text: How then can men who shun lies, who have learnt that love is the fulfilling of the law, who profess to bear the burdens of the weak, have consented to bring these calumnies against me and to condemn me out of other men's writings? I have often asked myself this question, but I cannot imagine the reason, unless it be, as I have said from the beginning, that my pain in all this is a part of the punishment which is due to my sins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:14
verses.text: First of all I sorrowed in soul that truths were lessened by the sons of men; in the second place I feared for my own self, lest in addition to my other sins, I should become a misanthrope, believing no truth and honour to be left in any man; if indeed those whom I have most greatly trusted are proved to be so disposed both to me and to the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:15
verses.text: Be sure then, my brother, and every one who is a friend of the truth, that the composition is not mine; I do not approve of it, for it is not drawn up according to my views.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:16
verses.text: Even if I did write, a good many years ago, to Apollinarius or to any one else, I ought not to be blamed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:17
verses.text: I find no fault myself if any member of any society has been cut off into heresy (and you know perfectly well whom I mean though I mention nobody by name), because each man will die in his own sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:18
verses.text: This is my reply to the document sent me, that you may know the truth, and make it plain to all who wish not to hold the truth in unrighteousness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:19
verses.text: If it prove necessary to defend myself more at length on each separate count, I will do so, God being my helper.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 131:20
verses.text: I, brother Olympius, neither maintain three Gods, nor communicate with Apollinarius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 132:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 132:2
verses.text: To Abramius, bishop of Batnae.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 132:3
verses.text: Ever since the autumn I have been quite ignorant of the whereabouts of your reverence; for I kept hearing uncertain rumours, some saying that you were stopping at Samosata, and some in the country, while others maintained that they had seen you at Batnae.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 132:4
verses.text: This is the reason of my not writing frequently.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 132:5
verses.text: Now, on hearing that you are staying at Antioch, in the house of the honourable Count Saturninus, I have been glad to give this letter to our beloved and reverend brother Sanctissimus, our fellow presbyter, by whom I salute you, and exhort you, whereever you be, to remember firstly God, and secondly myself, whom you determined from the beginning to love and to reckon among your most intimate friends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 133:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 133:2
verses.text: To Peter, bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 133:3
verses.text: The sight of the eyes brings about bodily friendship, and long companionship strengthens it, but genuine regard is the gift of the Spirit, Who unites what is separated by long distances, and makes friends known to one another, not by bodily qualities, but by the characteristics of the soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 133:4
verses.text: The grace of the Lord has granted me this favour, by permitting me to see you with the soul's eye, and to embrace you with genuine affection, and as it were, to be drawn very near to you, and to come into close union with you in the communion of faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 133:5
verses.text: I am sure that you, disciple as you are of so great a man, and long associated with him, will walk in the same spirit and follow the same doctrines of true religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 133:6
verses.text: Under these circumstances I address your excellency, and beseech you that among the other things in which you have succeeded that great man, you will succeed him in love to me, that you will frequently write me news of you, and will give heed to the brotherhood all over the world with the same affection and the same zeal which that most blessed man always showed to all that love God in truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:2
verses.text: To the presbyter Poeonius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:3
verses.text: You may conjecture from what it contains, what pleasure you have given me by your letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:4
verses.text: The pureness of heart, from which such expressions sprang, was plainly signified by what you wrote.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:5
verses.text: A streamlet tells of its own spring, and so the manner of speech marks the heart from which it came.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:6
verses.text: I must confess that an extraordinary and improbable thing has happened to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:7
verses.text: For deeply anxious as I always was to receive a letter from your excellency, when I had taken your letter into my hand and had read it, I was not so much pleased at what you had written, as annoyed at reckoning up the loss I had suffered in your long silence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:8
verses.text: Now that you have begun to write, pray do not leave off.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:9
verses.text: You will give me greater pleasure than men can give by sending much money to misers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:10
verses.text: I have had no writer with me, neither caligraphist, nor short-hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 134:11
verses.text: Of all those whom I happen to employ, some have returned to their former mode of life, and others are unfit for work from long sickness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:2
verses.text: To Diodorus, presbyter of Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:4
verses.text: I have read the books sent me by your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:5
verses.text: With the second I was delighted, not only with its brevity, as was likely to be the case with a reader out of health and inclined to indolence, but, because it is at once full of thought, and so arranged that the objections of opponents, and the answers to them, stand out distinctly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:6
verses.text: Its simple and natural style seems to me to befit the profession of a Christian who writes less for self-advertisement than for the general good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:7
verses.text: The former work, which has practically the same force, but is much more elaborately adorned with rich diction, many figures, and niceties of dialogue, seems to me to require considerable time to read, and much mental labour, both to gather its meaning and retain it in the memory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:8
verses.text: The abuse of our opponents and the support of our own side, which are thrown in, although they may seem to add some charms of dialectic to the treatise, do yet break the continuity of the thought and weaken the strength of the argument, by causing interruption and delay.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:9
verses.text: I know that your intelligence is perfectly well aware that the heathen philosophers who wrote dialogues, Aristotle and Theophrastus, went straight to the point, because they were aware of their not being gifted with the graces of Plato.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:10
verses.text: Plato, on the other hand, with his great power of writing, at the same time attacks opinions and incidentally makes fun of his characters, assailing now the rashness and recklessness of a Thrasymachus, the levity and frivolity of a Hippias, and the arrogance and pomposity of a Protagoras.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:11
verses.text: When, however, he introduces unmarked characters into his dialogues, he uses the interlocutors for making the point clear, but does not admit anything more belonging to the characters into his argument.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:12
verses.text: An instance of this is in the Laws.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:14
verses.text: It is well for us too, who betake ourselves to writing, not from any vain ambition, but from the design of bequeathing counsels of sound doctrine to the brethren, if we introduce some character well known to all the world for presumption of manners, to interweave into the argument some points in accordance with the quality of the character, unless indeed we have no right at all to leave our work and to accuse men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:15
verses.text: But if the subject of the dialogue be wide and general, digressions against persons interrupt its continuity and tend to no good end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:16
verses.text: So much I have written to prove that you did not send your work to a flatterer, but have shared your toil with a real brother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:17
verses.text: And I have spoken not for the correction of what is finished, but as a precaution for the future; for assuredly one who is so accustomed to write, and so diligent in writing, will not hesitate to do so; and the more so that there is no falling off in the number of those who give him subjects.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:18
verses.text: Enough for me to read your books.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:19
verses.text: I am as far from being able to write anything as, I had very nearly said, I am from being well, or from having the least leisure from my work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:20
verses.text: I have however now sent back the larger and earlier of the two volumes, after perusing it as far as I have been able.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:21
verses.text: The second I have retained, with the wish to transcribe it, but, hitherto, without finding any quick writer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 135:22
verses.text: To such a pitch of poverty has come the enviable condition of the Cappadocians!.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:4
verses.text: In what state the good Isaaces has found me, he himself will best explain to you; though his tongue cannot be tragic enough to describe my sufferings, so great was my illness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:5
verses.text: However, any one who knows me ever so little, will be able to conjecture what it was.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:6
verses.text: For, if when I am called well, I am weaker even than persons who are given over, you may fancy what I was when thus ill.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:7
verses.text: Yet, since disease is my natural state, it would follow (let a fever have its jest) that in this change of habit, my health became especially flourishing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:8
verses.text: But it is the scourge of the Lord which goes on increasing my pain according to my deserts; therefore I have received illness upon illness, so that now even a child may see that this shell of mine must for certain fail, unless perchance, God's mercy vouchsafe to me, in His long suffering, time for repentance, and now, as often before, extricate me from evils beyond human cure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:9
verses.text: This shall be, as it is pleasing to Him and good for myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:11
verses.text: I need hardly tell you how deplorable and hopeless is the condition of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:12
verses.text: Now, for the sake of our own safety, we neglect our neighbour's, and do not even seem able to see that general disaster involves individual ruin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:13
verses.text: Least of all need I say this to one who, like yourself, foresaw the future from afar, and has foretold and proclaimed it and has been among the first to be roused, and to rouse the rest, writing letters, coming yourself in person, leaving no deed undone, no word unspoken.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:14
verses.text: I remember this in every instance, but yet we are none the better off.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:15
verses.text: Now, indeed, were not my sins in the way, (first of all, my dear brother the reverend deacon Eustathius fell seriously ill and detained me two whole months, looking day by day for his restoration to health; and then all about me fell sick; brother Isaaces will tell you the rest; then last of all I myself was attacked by this complaint) I should long ago have been to see your excellency, not indeed thereby to try to improve the general state of affairs, but to get some good for myself from your society.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:16
verses.text: I had made up my mind to get out of the reach of the ecclesiastical artillery, because I am quite unprepared to meet my enemies' attacks.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 136:17
verses.text: May God's mighty hand preserve you for all of us, as a noble guardian of the faith, and a vigilant champion of the Churches; and grant me, before I die, to meet you for the comfort of my soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 137:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 137:2
verses.text: To Antipater, on his assuming the governorship of Cappadocia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 137:3
verses.text: I do now really feel the loss which I suffer from being ill; so that, when such a man succeeds to the government of my country, my having to nurse myself compels me to be absent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 137:4
verses.text: For a whole month I have been undergoing the treatment of natural hot springs, in the hope of drawing some benefit from them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 137:5
verses.text: But I seem to be troubling myself to no purpose in my solitude, or indeed to be deservedly a laughing stock to mankind, for not heeding the proverb which says "warmth is no good to the dead".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 137:6
verses.text: Even situated as I am, I am very anxious to put aside everything else, and betake myself to your excellency, that I may enjoy the benefit of all your high qualities, and through your goodness settle all my home affairs here in a proper manner.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 137:7
verses.text: The house of our reverend mother Palladia is my own, for I am not only nearly related to her, but regard her as a mother on account of her character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 137:8
verses.text: Now, as some disturbance has been raised about her house, I ask your excellency to postpone the enquiry for a little while, and to wait till I come; not at all that justice may not be done, for I had rather die ten thousand times than ask a favour of that kind from a judge who is a friend of law and right, but that you may learn from me by word of mouth matters which it would be unbecoming for me to write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 137:9
verses.text: If you do so you will in no wise fail in fealty to the truth, and we shall suffer no harm.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 137:10
verses.text: I beg you then to keep the individual in question in safe custody under the charge of the troops, and not refuse to grant me this harmless favour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:4
verses.text: What was my state of mind, think you, when I received your piety's letter? When I thought of the feelings which its language expressed, I was eager to fly straight to Syria; but when I thought of the bodily illness, under which I lay bound, I saw myself unequal, not only to flying, but even to turning on my bed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:5
verses.text: This day, on which our beloved and excellent brother and deacon, Elpidius, has arrived, is the fiftieth of my illness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:6
verses.text: I am much reduced by the fever.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:7
verses.text: For lack of what it might feed on, it lingers in this dry flesh as in an expiring wick, and so has brought on a wasting and tedious illness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:8
verses.text: Next my old plague, the liver, coming upon it, has kept me from taking nourishment, prevented sleep, and held me on the confines of life and death, granting just life enough to feel its inflictions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:9
verses.text: In consequence I have had recourse to the hot springs, and have availed myself of help from medical men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:10
verses.text: But for all these the mischief has proved too strong.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:11
verses.text: Perhaps another man might endure it, but, coming as it did unexpectedly, no one is so stout as to bear it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:12
verses.text: Long troubled by it as I have been, I have never been so distressed as now at being prevented by it from meeting you and enjoying your true friendship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:13
verses.text: I know of how much pleasure I am deprived, although last year I did touch with the tip of my finger the sweet honey of your Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:15
verses.text: For many urgent reasons I felt bound to meet your reverence, both to discuss many things with you and to learn many things from you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:16
verses.text: Here it is not possible even to find genuine affection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:17
verses.text: And, could one even find a true friend, none can give counsel to me in the present emergency with anything like the wisdom and experience which you have acquired in your many labours on the Church's behalf.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:18
verses.text: The rest I must not write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:19
verses.text: I may, however, safely say what follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:20
verses.text: The presbyter Evagrius, son of Pompeianus of Antioch, who set out some time ago to the West with the blessed Eusebius, has now returned from Rome.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:21
verses.text: He demands from me a letter couched in the precise terms dictated by the Westerns.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:22
verses.text: My own he has brought back again to me, and reports that it did not give satisfaction to the more precise authorities there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:23
verses.text: He also asks that a commission of men of repute may be promptly sent, that they may have a reasonable pretext for visiting me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:24
verses.text: My sympathisers in Sebasteia have stripped the covering from the secret sore of the unorthodoxy of Eustathius, and demand my ecclesiastical care.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:25
verses.text: Iconium is a city of Pisidia, anciently the first after the greatest, and now it is capital of a part, consisting of an union of different portions, and allowed the government of a distinct province.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:26
verses.text: Iconium too calls me to visit her and to give her a bishop; for Faustinus is dead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:27
verses.text: Whether I ought to shrink from consecrations over the border; what answer I ought to give to the Sebastenes; what attitude I should show to the propositions of Evagrius; all these are questions to which I was anxious to get answers in a personal interview with you, for here in my present weakness I am cut off from everything.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:28
verses.text: If, then, you can find any one soon coming this way, be so good as to give me your answer on them all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:29
verses.text: If not, pray that what is pleasing to the Lord may come into my mind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 138:30
verses.text: In your synod also bid mention to be made of me, and pray for me yourself, and join your people with you in the prayer that it may be permitted me to continue my service through the remaining days or hours of my sojourning here in a manner pleasing to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:1
verses.text: Letter CXXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:2
verses.text: To the Alexandrians.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:4
verses.text: I have already heard of the persecution in Alexandria and the rest of Egypt, and, as might be expected, I am deeply affected.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:5
verses.text: I have observed the ingenuity of the devil's mode of warfare.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:6
verses.text: When he saw that the Church increased under the persecution of enemies and flourished all the more, he changed his plan.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:7
verses.text: He no longer carries on an open warfare, but lays secret snares against us, hiding his hostility under the name which they bear, in order that we may both suffer like our fathers, and, at the same time, seem not to suffer for Christ's sake, because our persecutors too bear the name of Christians.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:8
verses.text: With these thoughts for a long time we sat still, dazed at the news of what had happened, for, in sober earnest, both our ears tingled on hearing of the shameless and inhuman heresy of your persecutors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:9
verses.text: They have reverenced neither age, nor services to society, nor people's affection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:10
verses.text: They inflicted torture, ignominy, and exile; they plundered all the property they could find; they were careless alike of human condemnation and of the awful retribution to come at the hands of the righteous Judge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:11
verses.text: All this has amazed me and all but driven me out of my senses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:12
verses.text: To my reflections has been added this thought too; can the Lord have wholly abandoned His Churches? Has the last hour come, and is "the falling away" thus coming upon us, that now the lawless one "may be revealed, the son of perdition who opposeth and exalteth himself above all that is called God and is worshipped"? But if the temptation is for a season, bear it, ye noble athletes of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:13
verses.text: If the world is being delivered to complete, and final destruction, let us not lose heart for the present, but let us await the revelation from heaven, and the manifestation of our great God and Saviour Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:14
verses.text: If all creation is to be dissolved, and the fashion of this world transformed, why should we be surprised that we, who are apart of creation, should feel the general woe, and be delivered to afflictions which our just God inflicts on us according to the measure of our strength, not letting us "be tempted above that we are able, but with the temptation giving us a way to escape that we may be able to bear it"? Brothers, martyrs' crowns await you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:15
verses.text: The companies of the confessors are ready to reach out their hands to you and to welcome you into their own ranks.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:16
verses.text: Remember how none of the saints of old won their crowns of patient endurance by living luxuriously and being courted; but all were tested by being put through the fire of great afflictions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:17
verses.text: "For some had trial of cruel mockings and scourgings, and others were sawn asunder and were slain with the sword".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:18
verses.text: These are the glories of saints.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:19
verses.text: Blessed is he who is deemed worthy to suffer for Christ; more blessed is he whose sufferings are greater, since "the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory that shall be revealed in us".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:21
verses.text: Had it but been possible for me to travel to you I should have liked nothing better than to meet you, that I might see and embrace Christ's athletes, and share your prayers and spiritual graces.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:22
verses.text: But now my body is wasted by long sickness, so that I can scarcely even leave my bed, and there are many who are lying in wait for me, like ravening wolves, watching the moment when they may be able to rend Christ's sheep.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:23
verses.text: I have therefore been compelled to visit you by letter; and I exhort you first of all most earnestly to pray for me, that for the rest of my remaining days or hours I may be enabled to serve the Lord, in accordance with the gospel of His kingdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:24
verses.text: Next I beg you to pardon me for my absence and for my delay in writing to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:25
verses.text: I have only with great difficulty found a man able to carry out my wishes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 139:26
verses.text: I speak of my son, the monk Eugenius, by whom I beseech you to pray for me and for the whole Church, and to write back news of you so that, when I hear, I may be more cheerful.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:1
verses.text: Letter CXL.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:2
verses.text: To the Church of Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:4
verses.text: "Oh that I had wings like a dove for then would I fly away" to you, and satisfy my longing to meet you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:5
verses.text: But now it is not only wings that I want, but a whole body, for mine has suffered from long sickness, and now is quite worn away with continuous affliction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:6
verses.text: For no one can be so hard of heart, so wholly destitute of sympathy and kindness, as to hear the sigh that strikes my ear from every quarter, as though from some sad choir chanting a symphony of lamentation, without being grieved at heart, being bent to the ground, and wasting away with these irremediable troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:7
verses.text: But the holy God is able to provide a remedy for the irremediable, and to grant you a respite from your long toils.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:8
verses.text: I should like you to feel this comfort and, rejoicing in the hope of consolation, to submit to the present pain of your afflictions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:9
verses.text: Are we paying the penalty of our sins? Then our plagues are such as to save us for the future from the wrath of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:10
verses.text: Are we called upon through these temptations to fight for the truth? Then the righteous Giver of the prizes will not suffer us to be tried above that which we are able to bear, but, in return for our previous struggles, will give us the crown of patience and of hope in Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:11
verses.text: Let us, therefore, not flinch from fighting a good fight on behalf of the truth, nor, in despair, fling away the labours we have already achieved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:12
verses.text: For the strength of the soul is not shewn by one brave deed, nor yet by effort only for a short time; but He Who tests our hearts wishes us to win crowns of righteousness after long and protracted trial.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:13
verses.text: Only let our spirit be kept unbroken, the firmness of our faith in Christ be maintained unshaken, and ere long our Champion will appear; He will come and will not tarry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:14
verses.text: Expect tribulation after tribulation, hope upon hope; yet a little while; yet a little while.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:15
verses.text: Thus the Holy Ghost knows how to comfort His nurslings by a promise of the future.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:16
verses.text: After tribulations comes hope, and what we are hoping for is not far off, for let a man name the whole of human life, it is but a tiny interval compared with the endless age which is laid up in our hopes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:18
verses.text: Now I accept no newer creed written for me by other men, nor do I venture to propound the outcome of my own intelligence, lest I make the words of true religion merely human words; but what I have been taught by the holy Fathers, that I announce to all who question me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:19
verses.text: In my Church the creed written by the holy Fathers in synod at Nicaea is in use.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:20
verses.text: I believe that it is also repeated among you; but I do not refuse to write its exact terms in my letter, lest I be accused of taking too little trouble.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:21
verses.text: It is as follows: This is our faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:22
verses.text: But no definition was given about the Holy Ghost, the Pneumatomachi not having at that date appeared.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:23
verses.text: No mention was therefore made of the need of anathematizing those who say that the Holy Ghost is of a created and ministerial nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 140:24
verses.text: For nothing in the divine and blessed Trinity is created.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:1
verses.text: Letter CXLI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:4
verses.text: I have now received two letters from your divine and most excellent wisdom, whereof the one told me clearly how I had been expected by the laity under the jurisdiction of your holiness, and what disappointment I had caused by failing to attend the sacred synod.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:5
verses.text: The other, which from the writing I conjecture to be of the earlier date, though it was delivered later, gave me advice, at once honourable to yourself and necessary to me, not to neglect the interests of God's Churches, nor little by little to allow the guidance of affairs to pass to our opponents, whereby their interests must win, and ours lose.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:6
verses.text: I think that I answered both.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:7
verses.text: But, as I am uncertain whether my replies were preserved by those who were entrusted with the duty of conveying them, I will make my defence over again.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:8
verses.text: As to my absence, I can put in an unimpeachable plea, as to which I think intelligence must have reached your holiness, that I have been detained by illness which has brought me to the very gates of death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:9
verses.text: Even now as I write about it, the remains of sickness are still upon me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:10
verses.text: And they are such as to another man might be unendurable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:12
