verses.text: As to the fact of its not being owing to my neglect that the interests of the Churches have been betrayed to our opponents, I wish your reverence to know that the bishops in communion with me, from lack of earnestness, or because they suspect me and are not open with me, or because the devil is always at hand to oppose good works, are unwilling to cooperate with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:13
verses.text: Formerly, indeed, the majority of us were united with one another, including the excellent Bosporius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:14
verses.text: In reality they give me no aid in what is most essential.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:15
verses.text: The consequence of all this is, that to a great extent my recovery is hindered by my distress, and the sorrow I feel brings back my worst symptoms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:16
verses.text: What, however, can I do alone and unaided, when the canons, as you yourself know, do not allow points of this kind to be settled by one man? And yet what remedy have I not tried? Of what decision have I failed to remind them, some by letter and some in person? They even came to the city, when they heard a report of my death; when, by God's will, they found me yet alive I made them such a speech as was proper to the occasion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:17
verses.text: In my presence they respect me, and promise all that is fit, but no sooner have they got back again than they return to their own opinion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:18
verses.text: In all this I am a sufferer, like the rest, for the Lord has clearly abandoned us, whose love has grown cold because iniquity abounds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:19
verses.text: For all this may your great and powerful intercession with God be sufficient for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 141:20
verses.text: Perhaps we shall either become of some use, or, even if we fail in our object, we may escape condemnation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 142:1
verses.text: Letter CXLII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 142:2
verses.text: To the prefects' accountant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 142:3
verses.text: I assembled all my brethren the chorepiscopi at the synod of the blessed martyr Eupsychius to introduce them to your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 142:4
verses.text: On account of your absence they must be brought before you by letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 142:5
verses.text: Know, therefore, this brother as being worthy to be trusted by your intelligence, because he fears the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 142:6
verses.text: As to the matters on behalf of the poor, which he refers to your good-will, deign to believe him as one worthy of credit, and to give the afflicted all the aid in your power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 142:7
verses.text: I am sure you will consent to look favourably upon the hospital of the poor which is in his district, and exempt it altogether from taxation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 142:8
verses.text: It has already seemed good to your colleague to make the little property of the poor not liable to be rated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 143:1
verses.text: Letter CXLIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 143:2
verses.text: To another accountant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 143:3
verses.text: Had it been possible for me to meet your excellency I would have in person brought before you the points about which I am anxious, and would have pleaded the cause of the afflicted, but I am prevented by illness and by press of business.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 143:4
verses.text: I have therefore sent to you in my stead this chorepiscopus, my brother, begging you to give him your aid and use him and to take him into counsel, for his truthfulness and sagacity qualify him to advise in such matters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 143:5
verses.text: If you are so good as to inspect the hospital for the poor, which is managed by him, (I am sure you will not pass it without a visit, experienced as you are in the work; for I have been told that you support one of the hospitals at Amasea out of the substance wherewith the Lord has blessed you), I am confident that, after seeing it, you will give him all he asks.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 143:6
verses.text: Your colleague has already promised me some help towards the hospitals.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 143:7
verses.text: I tell you this, not that you may imitate him, for you are likely to be a leader of others in good works, but that you may know that others have shown regard for me in this matter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 144:1
verses.text: Letter CXLIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 144:2
verses.text: To the prefects' officer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 144:3
verses.text: You know the bearer from meeting him in the town.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 144:4
verses.text: Nevertheless I write to commend him to you, that he may be useful to you in many matters in which you are interested, from his being able to give pious and sensible advice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 144:5
verses.text: Now is the time to carry out what you have said to me in private; I mean when this my brother has told you the state of the poor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:1
verses.text: Letter CXLV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:3
verses.text: I know the countless labours which you have undergone for the Churches of God; I know your press of occupation, while you discharge your responsibilities, not as though they were of mere secondary importance, but in accordance with God's will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:4
verses.text: I know the man who is, as it were, laying close siege to you and by whom you are forced, like birds crouching in cover under an eagle, not to go far from your shelter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:5
verses.text: I know all this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:6
verses.text: But longing is strong, both in hoping for the impracticable and attempting the impossible.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:7
verses.text: Rather I should say, hope in God is the strongest of all things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:8
verses.text: For it is not from unreasonable desire, but from strength of faith, that I expect a way out, even from the greatest difficulties, and that you will find a way to get over all hindrances, and to come to see the Church that loves you best of all, and to be seen by her.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:9
verses.text: What she values most of all good things is to behold your face and to hear your voice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:10
verses.text: Beware then of making her hopes vain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:11
verses.text: When last year, on my return from Syria, I reported the promise which you had given me, you cannot think how elated with her hopes I made her.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:12
verses.text: Do not, my friend, postpone your coming to another time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 145:13
verses.text: Even if it may be possible for you to see her one day, you may not see her and me too, for sickness is hurrying me on to quit this painful life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 146:1
verses.text: Letter CXLVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 146:2
verses.text: To Antiochus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 146:3
verses.text: I cannot accuse you of carelessness and inattention, because, when an opportunity of writing occurred, you said nothing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 146:4
verses.text: For I count the greeting which you have sent me in your own honoured hand worth many letters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 146:5
verses.text: In return I salute you, and beg you earnestly to give heed to the salvation of your soul, disciplining all the lusts of the flesh by reason, and ever keeping the thought of God built up in your soul, as in a very holy temple.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 146:6
verses.text: In every deed and every word hold before your eyes the judgment of Christ, so that every individual action, being referred to that exact and awful examination may bring you glory in the day of retribution, when you win praise from all creation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 146:7
verses.text: If that great man should be able to pay me a visit, it would be a pleasure to me to see you here with him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:1
verses.text: Letter CXLVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:2
verses.text: To Aburgius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:3
verses.text: Up to this time I used to think Homer a fable, when I read the second part of his poem, in which he narrates the adventures of Ulysses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:4
verses.text: But the calamity which has befallen the most excellent Maximus has led me to look on what I used to think fabulous and incredible, as exceedingly probable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:5
verses.text: Maximus was governor of no insignificant people, just as Ulysses was chief of the Cephallenians.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:6
verses.text: Ulysses had great wealth, and returned stripped of everything.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:7
verses.text: To such straits has calamity reduced Maximus, that he may have to present himself at home in borrowed rags.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:8
verses.text: And perhaps he has suffered all this because he has irritated some Laestrygones against him, and has fallen in with some Scylla, hiding a dog's fierceness and fury under a woman's form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:9
verses.text: Since then he has barely been able to swim out of this inextricable whirlpool.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:10
verses.text: He supplicates you by my means for humanity's sake to grieve for his undeserved misfortunes and not be silent about his needs, but make them known to the authorities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:11
verses.text: He hopes thus that he may find some aid against the slanders which have been got up against him: and if not, that at all events the intention of the enemy who has shewn such an intoxication of hostility against him may be made public.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 147:12
verses.text: When a man has been wronged it is a considerable comfort to him if the wickedness of his enemies can be made plain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:1
verses.text: Letter CXLVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:2
verses.text: To Trajan.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:3
verses.text: Even the ability to bewail their own calamities brings much comfort to the distressed; and this is specially the case when they meet with others capable, from their lofty character, of sympathizing with their sorrows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:4
verses.text: So my right honourable brother Maximus, after being prefect of my country, and then suffering what no other man ever yet suffered, stripped of all his belongings both inherited from his forefathers and collected by his own labours, afflicted in body in many and various ways, by his wanderings up and down the world, and not having been able to keep even his civil status free from attack, to preserve which freemen are wont to leave no labour undone, has made many complaints to me about all that has happened to him, and has begged me to give you a short description of the Iliad of woes in which he is involved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:5
verses.text: And I, being quite unable to relieve him in any other way in his troubles, have readily done him the favour shortly to relate to your excellency a part of what I have heard from him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:6
verses.text: He, indeed, seemed to me to blush at the idea of making a plain tale of his own calamity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:7
verses.text: If what has happened shews that the inflicter of the wrong is a villain, at all events it proves the sufferer to be deserving of great pity; since the very fact of having fallen into troubles inflicted by Divine Providence, seems in a manner to shew that a man has been devoted to suffering.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:8
verses.text: But it would be a sufficient comfort to him if you will only look at him kindly, and extend also to him that abundant favour which all the recipients of it cannot exhaust,—I mean your clemency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:9
verses.text: We are all of us convinced that before the tribunal your protection will be an immense step towards victory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:10
verses.text: He who has asked for my letter as likely to be of service is of all men most upright.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 148:11
verses.text: May it be granted me to see him, with the rest, proclaiming aloud the praises of your lordship with all his power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 149:1
verses.text: Letter CXLIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 149:2
verses.text: To Trajan.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 149:3
verses.text: You yourself have seen with your own eyes the distressing condition of Maximus, once a man of high reputation, but now most of all to be pitied, formerly prefect of my country.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 149:4
verses.text: Would that he had never been so! Many, I think, would be likely to shun provincial governorships, if their dignities are likely to issue in such an end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 149:5
verses.text: To a man, then, from the quickness of his intelligence, able from a few circumstances to conjecture the rest, I need hardly narrate in detail all that I have seen and all that I have heard.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 149:6
verses.text: Perhaps, however, I shall not seem to be telling a superfluous story if I mention that, though many and terrible things were audaciously done against him before your coming, what went on afterwards was such as to cause the former proceedings to be reckoned as kindness; to such an excess of outrage and injury and actually of personal cruelty did the proceedings go which were afterwards taken against him by the person in authority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 149:7
verses.text: Now he is here with an escort to fill up the measure of his evil deeds unless you are willing to stretch out your strong hand to protect the sufferer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 149:8
verses.text: In urging your goodness to an act of kindness I feel that I am undertaking an unnecessary task.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 149:9
verses.text: Yet since I desire to be serviceable to Maximus I do beg your lordship to add something for my sake to your natural zeal for what is right, to the end that he may clearly perceive that my intervention on his behalf has been of service to him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:1
verses.text: Letter CL.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius in the name of Heraclidas.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:4
verses.text: I remember our old conversations with one another, and am forgetful neither of what I said, nor of what you said.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:5
verses.text: And now public life has no hold upon me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:6
verses.text: For although I am the same in heart and have not yet put off the old man, nevertheless, outwardly and by withdrawing myself far from worldly life, I seem already to have begun to tread the way of Christian conversation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:7
verses.text: I sit apart, like men who are on the point of embarking on the deep, looking out at what is before me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:8
verses.text: Mariners, indeed, need winds to make their voyage prosperous; I on the other hand want a guide to take me by the hand and conduct me safely through life's bitter waves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:9
verses.text: I feel that I need first a curb for my young manhood, and then pricks to drive me to the course of piety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:10
verses.text: Both these seem to be provided by reason, which at one time disciplines my unruliness of soul, and at another time my sluggishness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:11
verses.text: Again I want other remedies that I may wash off the impurity of habit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:12
verses.text: You know how, long accustomed as I was to the Forum, I am lavish of words, and do not guard myself against the thoughts put into my mind by the evil one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:13
verses.text: I am the servant too of honour, and cannot easily give up thinking great things of myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:14
verses.text: Against all this I feel that I need a great instructor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:15
verses.text: Then, further, I conclude that it is of no small importance, nor of benefit only for a little while, that the soul's eye should be so purged that, after being freed from all the darkness of ignorance, as though from some blinding humour, one can gaze intently on the beauty of the glory of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:16
verses.text: All this I know very well that your wisdom is aware of; I know that you would wish that I might have some one to give me such help, and if ever God grant me to meet you I am sure that I shall learn more about what I ought to heed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:17
verses.text: For now, in my great ignorance, I can hardly even form a judgment as to what I lack.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:18
verses.text: Yet I do not repent of my first impulse; my soul does not hang back from the purpose of a godly life as you have feared for me, nobly and becomingly doing everything in your power, lest, like the woman of whom I have heard the story, I should turn back and become a pillar of salt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:19
verses.text: I am still, however, under the restraint of external authority; for the magistrates are seeking me like a deserter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:20
verses.text: But I am chiefly influenced by my own heart, which testifies to itself of all that I have told you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:22
verses.text: Since you have mentioned our bond, and have announced that you mean to prosecute, you have made me laugh in this my dejection, because you are still an advocate and do not give up your shrewdness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:23
verses.text: I hold, unless, indeed, like an ignorant man, I am quite missing the truth, that there is only one way to the Lord, and that all who are journeying to Him are travelling together and walking in accordance with one "bond" of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:24
verses.text: If this be so, wherever I go how can I be separated from you? How can I cease to live with you, and with you serve God, to Whom we have both fled for refuge? Our bodies may be separated by distance, but God's eye still doubtless looks upon us both; if indeed a life like mine is fit to be beheld by the divine eyes; for I have read somewhere in the Psalms that the eyes of the Lord are upon the righteous.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:25
verses.text: I do indeed pray that with you and with all that are like minded with you, I may be associated, even in body, and that night and day with you and with any other true worshipper of God I may bow my knees to our Father which is in heaven; for I know that communion in prayer brings great gain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:26
verses.text: If, as often as it is my lot to lie and groan in a different corner, I am always to be accused of lying, I cannot contend against your argument, and already condemn myself as a liar, if with my own carelessness I have said anything which brings me under such a charge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:28
verses.text: I was lately at Caesarea, in order to learn what was going on there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:29
verses.text: I was unwilling to remain in the city itself, and betook myself to the neighbouring hospital, that I might get there what information I wanted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:30
verses.text: According to his custom the very godly bishop visited it, and I consulted him as to the points which you had urged upon me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:31
verses.text: It is not possible for me to remember all that he said in reply; it went far beyond the limits of a letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:32
verses.text: In sum, however, what he said about poverty was this, that the rule ought to be that every one should limit his possessions to one garment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:33
verses.text: For one proof of this he quoted the words of John the Baptist "he that hath two coats let him impart to him that hath none;" and for another our Lord's prohibition to His disciples to have two coats.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:34
verses.text: He further added "If thou wilt be perfect go and sell that thou hast and give to the poor".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:35
verses.text: He said too that the parable of the pearl bore on this point, because the merchant, who had found the pearl of great price, went away and sold all that he had and bought it; and he added too that no one ought even to permit himself the distribution of his own property, but should leave it in the hands of the person entrusted with the duty of managing the affairs of the poor; and he proved the point from the acts of the apostles, because they sold their property and brought and laid it at the feet of the apostles, and by them it was distributed to each as every man had need.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:36
verses.text: For he said that experience was needed in order to distinguish between cases of genuine need and of mere greedy begging.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:37
verses.text: For whoever gives to the afflicted gives to the Lord, and from the Lord shall have his reward; but he who gives to every vagabond casts to a dog, a nuisance indeed from his importunity, but deserving no pity on the ground of want.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:39
verses.text: He was moreover the first to speak shortly, as befits the importance of the subject, about some of the daily duties of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:40
verses.text: As to this I should wish you to hear from himself, for it would not be right for me to weaken the force of his lessons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:41
verses.text: I would pray that we might visit him together, that so you might both accurately preserve in your memory what he said, and supply any omissions by your own intelligence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:42
verses.text: One thing that I do remember, out of the many which I heard, is this; that instruction how to lead the Christian life depends less on words, than on daily example.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:43
verses.text: I know that, if you had not been detained by the duty of succouring your aged father, there is nothing that you would have more greatly esteemed than a meeting with the bishop, and that you would not have advised me to leave him in order to wander in deserts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:44
verses.text: Caves and rocks are always ready for us, but the help we get from our fellow man is not always at hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 150:45
verses.text: If, then, you will put up with my giving you advice, you will impress on your father the desirability of his allowing you to leave him for a little while in order to meet a man who, alike from his experience of others and from his own wisdom, knows much, and is able to impart it to all who approach him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:1
verses.text: Letter CLI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:2
verses.text: To Eustathius the Physician.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:3
verses.text: If my letters are of any good, lose no time in writing to me and in rousing me to write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:4
verses.text: We are unquestionably made more cheerful when we read the letters of wise men who love the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:5
verses.text: It is for you to say, who read it, whether you find anything worth attention in what I write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:6
verses.text: Were it not for the multitude of my engagements, I should not debar myself from the pleasure of writing frequently.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:7
verses.text: Pray do you, whose cares are fewer, soothe me by your letters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:8
verses.text: Wells, it is said, are the better for being used.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:9
verses.text: The exhortations which you derive from your profession are apparently beside the point, for it is not I who am applying the knife; it is men whose day is done, who are falling upon themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:10
verses.text: The phrase of the Stoics runs, "since things do not happen as we like, we like what happens;" but I cannot make my mind fall in with what is happening.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:11
verses.text: That some men should do what they do not like because they cannot help it, I have no objection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:12
verses.text: You doctors do not cauterise a sick man, or make him suffer pain in some other way, because you like it; but you often adopt this treatment in obedience to the necessity of the case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:13
verses.text: Mariners do not willingly throw their cargo overboard; but in order to escape shipwreck they put up with the loss, preferring a life of penury to death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:14
verses.text: Be sure that I look with sorrow and with many groans upon the separation of those who are holding themselves aloof.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:15
verses.text: But yet I endure it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 151:16
verses.text: To lovers of the truth nothing can be put before God and hope in Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 152:1
verses.text: Letter CLII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 152:2
verses.text: To Victor, the Commander.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 152:3
verses.text: If I were to fail to write to any one else I might possibly with justice incur the charge of carelessness or forgetfulness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 152:4
verses.text: But it is not possible to forget you, when your name is in all men's mouths.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 152:5
verses.text: But I cannot be careless about one who is perhaps more distinguished than any one else in the empire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 152:6
verses.text: The cause of my silence is evident.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 152:7
verses.text: I am afraid of troubling so great a man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 152:8
verses.text: If, however, to all your other virtues you add that of not only receiving what I send, but of actually asking after what is missing, lo! here I am writing to you with joyous heart, and I shall go on writing for the future, with prayers to God that you may be requited for the honour you pay me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 152:9
verses.text: For the Church, you have anticipated my supplications, by doing everything which I should have asked.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 152:10
verses.text: And you act to please not man but God, Who has honoured you; Who has given you some good things in this life, and will give you others in the life to come, because you have walked with truth in His way, and, from the beginning to the end, have kept your heart fixed in the right faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 153:1
verses.text: Letter CLIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 153:2
verses.text: To Victor the Ex-Consul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 153:3
verses.text: As often as it falls to my lot to read your lordship's letters, so often do I thank God that you continue to remember me, and that you are not moved by any calumny to lessen the love which once you consented to entertain for me, either from your wise judgment or your kindly intercourse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 153:4
verses.text: I pray then the holy God that you may remain in this mind towards me, and that I may be worthy of the honour which you give me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:1
verses.text: Letter CLIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:2
verses.text: To Ascholius, bishop of Thessalonica.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:3
verses.text: You have done well, and in accordance with the law of spiritual love, in writing to me first, and by your good example challenging me to like energy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:4
verses.text: The friendship of the world, indeed, stands in need of actual sight and intercourse, that thence intimacy may begin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:5
verses.text: All, however, who know how to love in the spirit do not need the flesh to promote affection, but are led to spiritual communion in the fellowship of the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:6
verses.text: Thanks, then, to the Lord Who has comforted my heart by showing me that love has not grown cold in all, but that there are yet in the world men who show the evidence of the discipleship of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:7
verses.text: The state of affairs with you seems to be something like that of the stars by night, shining some in one part of the sky and some in another, whereof the brightness is charming, and the more charming because it is unexpected.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:8
verses.text: Such are you, luminaries of the Churches, a few at most and easily counted in this gloomy state of things, shining as in a moonless night, and, besides being welcome for your virtue, being all the more longed for because of its being so seldom that you are found.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:9
verses.text: Your letter has made your disposition quite plain to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:10
verses.text: Although small, as far as regards the number of its syllables, in the correctness of its sentiments it was quite enough to give me proof of your mind and purpose.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:11
verses.text: Your zeal for the cause of the blessed Athanasius is plain proof of your being sound as to the most important matters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:12
verses.text: In return for my joy at your letter I am exceedingly grateful to my honourable son Euphemius, to whom I pray that all help may be given by the Holy One, and I beg you to join in my prayers that we may soon receive him back with his very honourable wife, my daughter in the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:13
verses.text: As to yourself, I beg that you will not stay our joy at its beginning, but that you will write on every possible opportunity, and increase your good feeling towards me by constant communication.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:14
verses.text: Give me news, I beg you, about your Churches and how they are situated as regards union.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 154:15
verses.text: Pray for us here that our Lord may rebuke the winds and the sea, and that with us there may be a great, calm.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:1
verses.text: Letter CLV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:3
verses.text: In the case of a trainer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:4
verses.text: I am at a loss how to defend myself against all the complaints contained in the first and only letter which your lordship has been so good as to send me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:5
verses.text: It is not that there is any lack of right on my side, but because among so many charges it is hard to select the most vital, and fix on the point at which I ought to begin to apply a remedy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:6
verses.text: Perhaps, if I follow the order of your letter, I shall come upon each in turn.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:7
verses.text: Up to to-day I knew nothing about those who are setting out for Scythia; nor had any one told me even of those who came from your house, so that I might greet you by them, although I am anxious to seize every opportunity of greeting your lordship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:8
verses.text: To forget you in my prayers is impossible, unless first I forget the work to which God has called me, for assuredly, faithful as by God's grace you are, you remember all the prayers of the Church; how we pray also for our brethren when on a journey and offer prayer in the holy church for those who are in the army, and for those who speak for the sake of the Lord's name, and for those who show the fruits of the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:9
verses.text: In most, or all of these, I reckon your lordship to be included.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:10
verses.text: How could I ever forget you, as far as I am individually concerned, when I have so many reasons to stir me to recollection, such a sister, such nephews, such kinsfolk, so good, so fond of me, house, household, and friends? By all these, even against my will, I am perforce reminded of your good disposition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:11
verses.text: As to this, however, our brother has brought me no unpleasant news, nor has any decision been come to by me which could do him any injury.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:12
verses.text: Free, then, the chorepiscopus and myself from all blame, and grieve rather over those who have made false reports.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:13
verses.text: If our learned friend wishes to bring an action against me, he has law courts and laws.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:14
verses.text: In this I beg you not to blame me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:15
verses.text: In all the good deeds that you do, you are laying up treasure for yourself; you are preparing for yourself in the day of retribution the same refreshment which you are providing for those who are persecuted for the sake of the name of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 155:16
verses.text: If you send the relics of the martyrs home you will do well; as you write that the persecution there is, even now, causing martyrs to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:1
verses.text: Letter CLVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:2
verses.text: To the Presbyter Evagrius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:4
verses.text: So far from being impatient at the length of your letter, I assure you I thought it even short, from the pleasure it gave me when reading it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:5
verses.text: For is there anything more pleasing than the idea of peace? Is anything more suitable to the sacred office, or more acceptable to the Lord, than to take measures for effecting it? May you have the reward of the peace-maker, since so blessed an office has been the object of your good desires and earnest efforts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:6
verses.text: At the same time, believe me, my revered friend, I will yield to none in my earnest wish and prayer to see the day when those who are one in sentiment shall all fill the same assembly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:7
verses.text: Indeed it would be monstrous to feel pleasure in the schisms and divisions of the Churches, and not to consider that the greatest of goods consists in the knitting together of the members of Christ's body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:8
verses.text: But, alas! my inability is as real as my desire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:9
verses.text: No one knows better than yourself, that time alone is the remedy of ills that time has matured.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:10
verses.text: Besides, a strong and vigorous treatment is necessary to get at the root of the complaint.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:11
verses.text: You will understand this hint, though there is no reason why I should not speak out.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:13
verses.text: Self-importance, when rooted by habit in the mind, cannot be destroyed by one man, by one single letter, or in a short time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:14
verses.text: Unless there be some arbiter in whom all parties have confidence, suspicions and collisions will never altogether cease.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:15
verses.text: If, indeed, the influence of Divine grace were shed upon me, and I were given power in word and deed and spiritual gifts to prevail with these rival parties, then this daring experiment might be demanded of me; though, perhaps, even then, you would not advise me to attempt this adjustment of things by myself, without the co-operation of the bishop, on whom principally falls the care of the church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:16
verses.text: But he cannot come hither, nor can I easily undertake a long journey while the winter lasts, or rather I cannot anyhow, for the Armenian mountains will be soon impassable, even to the young and vigorous, to say nothing of my continued bodily ailments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:17
verses.text: I have no objection to write to tell him of all this; but I have no expectation that writing will lead to anything, for I know his cautious character, and after all written words have little power to convince the mind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:18
verses.text: There are so many things to urge, and to bear, and to reply to, and to object, that a letter has no soul, and is in fact but waste paper.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:19
verses.text: However, as I have said, I will write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:20
verses.text: Only give me credit, most religious and dear brother, for having no private feeling in the matter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:21
verses.text: Thank God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:22
verses.text: I have no such feeling towards any one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:23
verses.text: I have not busied myself in the investigation of the supposed or real complaints which are brought against this or that man; so my opinion has a claim on your attention as that of one who really cannot act from partiality or prejudice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:24
verses.text: I only desire, through the Lord's good will, that all things may be done with ecclesiastical propriety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:26
verses.text: I was vexed to find from my dear son Dorotheus, our associate in the ministry, that you had been unwilling to communicate with him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:27
verses.text: This was not the kind of conversation which you had with me, as well as I recollect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:28
verses.text: As to my sending to the West it is quite out of the question.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:29
verses.text: I have no one fit for the service.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:30
verses.text: Indeed, when I look round, I seem to have no one on my side.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:31
verses.text: I can but pray I may be found in the number of those seven thousand who have not bowed the knee to Baal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 156:32
verses.text: I know the present persecutors of us all seek my life; yet that shall not diminish ought of the zeal which I owe to the Churches of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 157:1
verses.text: Letter CLVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 157:2
verses.text: To Amiochus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 157:3
verses.text: You may well imagine how disappointed I was not to meet you in the summer; not that our meeting in former years was enough to satisfy me, but even to see loved objects in a dream brings those who love some comfort.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 157:4
verses.text: But you do not even write, so sluggish are you, and I think your absence can be referred to no other cause than that you are slow to undertake journeys for affection's sake.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 157:5
verses.text: On this point I will say no more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 157:6
verses.text: Pray for me, and ask the Lord not to desert me, but as He has brought me out of bygone temptations so also to deliver me from those that I await, for the glory of the name of Him in Whom I put my trust.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 158:1
verses.text: Letter CLVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 158:2
verses.text: To Antiochus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 158:3
verses.text: My sins have prevented me from carrying out the wish to meet you, which I have long entertained.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 158:4
verses.text: Let me apologise by letter for my absence, and beseech you not to omit to remember me in your prayers, that, if I live, I may be permitted to enjoy your society.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 158:5
verses.text: If not, by the aid of your prayers may I quit this world with good hope.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 158:6
verses.text: I commend to you our brother the camel-master.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:1
verses.text: Letter CLIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:2
verses.text: To Eupaterius and his daughter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:4
verses.text: You may well imagine what pleasure the letter of your excellencies gave me, if only from its very contents.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:5
verses.text: What, indeed, could give greater gratification to one who prays ever to be in communication with them who fear the Lord, and to share their blessings, than a letter of this kind, wherein questions are asked about the knowledge of God? For if, to me, "to live is Christ,"truly my words ought to be about Christ, my every thought and deed ought to depend upon His commandments, and my soul to be fashioned after His.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:6
verses.text: I rejoice, therefore, at being asked about such things, and congratulate the askers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:7
verses.text: By me, to speak shortly, the faith of the Fathers assembled at Nicaea is honoured before all later inventions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:8
verses.text: In it the Son is confessed to be con-substantial with the Father and to be naturally of the same nature with Him who begat Him, for He was confessed to be Light of Light, God of God, and Good of Good, and the like.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:9
verses.text: Both by those holy men the same doctrine was declared, and by me now who pray that I may walk in their footsteps.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:11
verses.text: But since the question now raised by those who are always endeavouring to introduce novelties, but passed over in silence by the men of old, because the doctrine was never gainsaid, has remained without full explanation (I mean that which concerns the Holy Ghost) I will add a statement on this subject in conformity with the sense of Scripture.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:12
verses.text: As we were baptized, so we profess our belief.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:13
verses.text: As we profess our belief, so also we offer praise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:14
verses.text: As then baptism has been given us by the Saviour, in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost, so, in accordance with our baptism, we make the confession of the creed, and our doxology in accordance with our creed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:15
verses.text: We glorify the Holy Ghost together with the Father and the Son, from the conviction that He is not separated from the Divine Nature; for that which is foreign by nature does not share in the same honors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:16
verses.text: All who call the Holy Ghost a creature we pity, on the ground that, by this utterance, they are falling into the unpardonable sin of blasphemy against Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:17
verses.text: I need use no argument to prove to those who are even slightly trained in Scripture, that the creature is separated from the Godhead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:18
verses.text: The creature is a slave; but the Spirit sets free.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:19
verses.text: The creature needs life; the Spirit is the Giver of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:20
verses.text: The creature requires teaching.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:21
verses.text: It is the Spirit that teaches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:22
verses.text: The creature is sanctified; it is the Spirit that sanctifies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:23
verses.text: Whether you name angels, archangels, or all the heavenly powers, they receive their sanctification through the Spirit, but the Spirit Himself has His holiness by nature, not received by favour, but essentially His; whence He has received the distinctive name of Holy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:24
verses.text: What then is by nature holy, as the Father is by nature holy, and the Son by nature holy, we do not ourselves allow to be separated and severed from the divine and blessed Trinity, nor accept those who rashly reckon it as part of creation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:25
verses.text: Let this short summary be sufficient for you, my pious friends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:26
verses.text: From little seeds, with the co-operation of the Holy Ghost, you will reap the fuller crop of piety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:27
verses.text: "Give instruction to a wise man and he will be yet wiser".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:28
verses.text: I will put off fuller demonstration till we meet.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:29
verses.text: When we do, it will be possible for me to answer objections, to give you fuller proofs from Scripture, and to confirm all the sound rule of faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:30
verses.text: For the present pardon my brevity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 159:31
verses.text: I should not have written at all had I not thought it a greater injury to you to refuse your request altogether than to grant it in part.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:1
verses.text: Letter CLX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:2
verses.text: To Diodorus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:4
verses.text: I have received the letter which has reached me under the name of Diodorus, but in what it contains creditable to any one rather than to Diodorus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:5
verses.text: Some ingenious person seems to have assumed your name, with the intention of getting credit with his hearers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:6
verses.text: It appears that he was asked by some one if it was lawful to contract marriage with his deceased wife's sister; and, instead of shuddering at such a question, he heard it unmoved, and quite boldly and bravely supported the unseemly desire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:7
verses.text: Had I his letter by me I would have sent it you, and you would have been able to defend both yourself and the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:8
verses.text: But the person who showed it me took it away again, and carried it about as a kind of trophy of triumph against me who had forbidden it from the beginning, declaring that he had permission in writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:9
verses.text: Now I have written to you that I may attack that spurious document with double strength, and leave it no force whereby it may injure its readers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:11
verses.text: First of all I have to urge, what is of most importance in such matters, our own custom, which has the force of law, because the rules have been handed down to us by holy men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:12
verses.text: It is as follows: if any one, overcome by impurity, falls into unlawful intercourse with two sisters, this is not to be looked upon as marriage, nor are they to be admitted at all into the Church until they have separated from one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:13
verses.text: Wherefore, although it were possible to say nothing further, the custom would be quite enough to safeguard what is right.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:14
verses.text: But, since the writer of the letter has endeavoured to introduce this mischief into our practice by a false argument, I am under the necessity of not omitting the aid of reasoning; although in matters which are perfectly plain every man's instinctive sentiment is stronger than argument.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:16
verses.text: It is written, he says, in Leviticus "Neither shalt thou take a wife to her sister, to vex her, to uncover her nakedness, beside the other in her life time".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:17
verses.text: From this it is plain, he argues, that it is lawful to take her when the wife is dead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:18
verses.text: To this my first answer shall be, that whatever the law says, it says to those who are under the law; otherwise we shall be subject to circumcision, the sabbath, abstinence from meats.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:19
verses.text: For we certainly must not, when we find anything which falls in with our pleasures, subject ourselves to the yoke of slavery to the law; and then, if anything in the law seems hard, have recourse to the freedom which is in Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:20
verses.text: We have been asked if it is written that one may be taken to wife after her sister.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:21
verses.text: Let us say what is safe and true, that it is not written.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:22
verses.text: But to deduce by sequence of argument what is passed over in silence is the part of a legislator, not of one who quotes the articles of the law.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:23
verses.text: Indeed, on these terms, any one who likes will be at liberty to take the sister, even in the lifetime of the wife.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:24
verses.text: The same sophism fits in this case also.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:25
verses.text: It is written, he says, "Thou shalt not take a wife to vex her:" so that, apart from vexation, there is no prohibition to take her.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:26
verses.text: The man who wants to indulge his desire will maintain that the relationship of sisters is such that they cannot vex one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:27
verses.text: Take away the reason given for the prohibition to live with both, and what is there to prevent a man's taking both sisters? This is not written, we shall say.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:28
verses.text: Neither is the former distinctly stated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:29
verses.text: The deduction from the argument allows liberty in both cases.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:30
verses.text: But a solution of the difficulty might be found by going a little back to what is behind the enactment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:31
verses.text: It appears that the legislator does not include every kind of sin, but particularly prohibits those of the Egyptians, from among whom Israel had gone forth, and of the Canaanites among whom they were going.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:32
verses.text: The words are as follows, "After the doings of the land of Egypt, wherein ye dwelt, shall ye not do; and after the doings of the land of Canaan, whither I bring you, shall ye not do: neither shall ye walk in their ordinances".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:33
verses.text: It is probable that this kind of sin was not practised at that time among the Gentiles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:34
verses.text: Under these circumstances the lawgiver was, it may be supposed, under no necessity of guarding against it; the unwritten custom sufficed to condemn the crime.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:35
verses.text: How then is it that while forbidding the greater he was silent about the less? Because the example of the patriarch seemed injurious to many who indulged their flesh so far as to live with sisters in their life time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:36
verses.text: What ought to be my course? To quote the Scriptures, or to work out what they leave unsaid? In these laws it is not written that a father and son ought not to have the same concubine, but, in the prophet, it is thought deserving of the most extreme condemnation, "A man and his father" it is said "will go in unto the same maid".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:37
verses.text: And how many other forms of unclean lust have been found out in the devils' school, while divine scripture is silent about them, not choosing to befoul its dignity with the names of filthy things and condemning their uncleanness in general terms! As the apostle Paul says, "Fornication and all uncleanness…let it not be once named among you as becometh saints," thus including the unspeakable doings of both males and females under the name of uncleanness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:38
verses.text: It follows that silence certainly does not give license to voluptuaries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:40
verses.text: I, however, maintain that this point has not been left in silence, but that the lawgiver has made a distinct prohibition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:41
verses.text: The words "None of you shall approach to any one that is near of kin to him, to uncover their nakedness," embraces also this form of kinsmanship, for what could be more akin to a man than his own wife, or rather than his own flesh? "For they are no more twain but one flesh".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:42
verses.text: So, through the wife, the sister is made akin to the husband.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:43
verses.text: For as he shall not take his wife's mother, nor yet his wife's daughter, because he may not take his own mother nor his own daughter, so he may not take his wife's sister, because he may not take his own sister.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:44
verses.text: And, on the other hand, it will not be lawful for the wife to be joined with the husband's kin, for the rights of relationship hold good on both sides.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:45
verses.text: But, for my part, to every one who is thinking about marriage I testify that, "the fashion of this world passeth away," and the time is short: "it remaineth that both they that have wives be as though they had none".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:46
verses.text: If he improperly quotes the charge "Increase and multiply," I laugh at him, for not discerning the signs of the times.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:47
verses.text: Second marriage is a remedy against fornication, not a means of lasciviousness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:48
verses.text: "If they cannot contain," it is said "let them marry;" but if they marry they must not break the law.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:50
verses.text: But they whose souls are blinded by dishonourable lust do not regard even nature, which from old time distinguished the names of the family.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:51
verses.text: For under what relationship will those who contract these unions name their sons? Will they call them brothers or cousins of one another? For, on account of the confusion, both names will apply.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:52
verses.text: O man, do not make the aunt the little one's stepmother; do not arm with implacable jealousy her who ought to cherish them with a mother's love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:53
verses.text: It is only stepmothers who extend their hatred even beyond death; other enemies make a truce with the dead; stepmothers begin their hatred after death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:54
verses.text: The sum of what I say is this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:55
verses.text: If any one wants to contract a lawful marriage, the whole world is open to him: if he is only impelled by lust, let him be the more restricted, "that he may know how to possess his vessel in sanctification and honour, not in the lust of concupiscence".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:56
verses.text: I should like to say more, but the limits of my letter leave me no further room.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:57
verses.text: I pray that my exhortation may prove stronger than lust, or at least that this pollution may not be found in my own province.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 160:58
verses.text: Where it has been ventured on there let it abide.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:1
verses.text: Letter CLXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius on his consecration as Bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:4
verses.text: Blessed be God Who from age to age chooses them that please Him, distinguishes vessels of election, and uses them for the ministry of the Saints.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:5
verses.text: Though you were trying to flee, as you confess, not from me, but from the calling you expected through me, He has netted you in the sure meshes of grace, and has brought you into the midst of Pisidia to catch men for the Lord, and draw the devil's prey from the deep into the light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:6
verses.text: You, too, may say as the blessed David said, "Whither shall I go from thy Spirit? or whither shall I flee from thy presence".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:7
verses.text: Such is the wonderful work of our loving Master.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:8
verses.text: "Asses are lost" that there may be a king of Israel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:9
verses.text: David, however, being an Israelite was granted to Israel; but the land which has nursed you and brought you to such a height of virtue, possesses you no longer, and sees her neighbour beautified by her own adornment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:10
verses.text: But all believers in Christ are one people; all Christ's people, although He is hailed from many regions, are one Church; and so our country is glad and rejoices at the dispensation of the Lord, and instead of thinking that she is one man the poorer, considers that through one man she has become possessed of whole Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:11
verses.text: Only may the Lord grant me both to see you in person, and, so long as I am parted from you, to hear of your progress in the gospel, and of the good order of your Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:13
verses.text: Play the man, then, and be strong, and walk before the people whom the Most High has entrusted to your hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:14
verses.text: Like a skilful pilot, rise in mind above every wave lifted by heretical blasts; keep the boat from being whelmed by the salt and bitter billows of false doctrine; and wait for the calm to be made by the Lord so soon as there shall have been found a voice worthy of rousing Him to rebuke the winds and the sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:15
verses.text: If you wish to visit me, now hurried by long sickness towards the inevitable end, do not wait for an opportunity, or for the word from me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:16
verses.text: You know that to a father's heart every time is suitable to embrace a well-loved son, and that affection is stronger than words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:17
verses.text: Do not lament over a responsibility transcending your strength.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:18
verses.text: If you had been destined to bear the burden unaided, it would have been not merely heavy; it would have been intolerable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:19
verses.text: But if the Lord shares the load with you, "cast all your care upon the Lord" and He will Himself act.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:20
verses.text: Only be exhorted ever to give heed lest you be carried away by wicked customs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:21
verses.text: Rather change all previous evil ways into good by the help of the wisdom given you by God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:22
verses.text: For Christ has sent you not to follow others, but yourself to take the lead of all who are being saved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:23
verses.text: I charge you to pray for me, that, if I am still in this life, I may be permitted to see you with your Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:24
verses.text: If, however, it is ordained that I now depart, may I see all of you hereafter with the Lord, your Church blooming like a vine with good works, and yourself like a wise husbandman and good servant giving meat in due season to his fellow-servants and receiving the reward of a wise and trusty steward.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:25
verses.text: All who are with me salute your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:26
verses.text: May you be strong and joyful in the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 161:27
verses.text: May you be preserved glorious in the graces of the Spirit and of wisdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:1
verses.text: Letter CLXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:3
verses.text: The same cause seems to make me hesitate to write, and to prove that I must write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:4
verses.text: When I think of the visit which I owe, and reckon up the gain at meeting you, I cannot help despising letters, as being not even shadows in comparison with the reality.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:5
verses.text: Then, again, when I reckon that my only consolation, deprived as I am of all that is best and most important, is to salute such a man and beg him, as I am wont, not to forget me in his prayers, I bethink me that letters are of no small value.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:6
verses.text: I do not, myself, wish to give up all hope of my visit, nor to despair of seeing you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:7
verses.text: I should be ashamed not to seem to put so much confidence in your prayers as even to expect to be turned from an old man into a young one, if such a need were to arise, and not merely from a sick and emaciated one, as I am now, into one a little bit stronger.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:8
verses.text: It is not easy to express in words the reason of my not being with you already, because I am not only prevented by actual illness, but have not even force of speech enough at any time to give you an account of such manifold and complex disease.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:9
verses.text: I can only say that, ever since Easter up to now, fever, diarrhoea, and intestinal disturbance, drowning me like waves, do not suffer me to lift my head above them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:10
verses.text: Brother Barachus may be able to tell you the character of my symptoms, if not as their severity deserves, at least clearly enough to make you understand the reason of my delay.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 162:11
verses.text: If you join cordially in my prayers, I have no doubt that my troubles will easily pass away.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 163:1
verses.text: Letter CLXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 163:2
verses.text: To Count Jovinus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 163:3
verses.text: One can see your soul in your letter, for in reality no painter can so exactly catch an outward likeness, as uttered thoughts can image the secrets of the soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 163:4
verses.text: As I read your letter, your words exactly characterized your steadfastness, your real dignity, your unfailing sincerity; in all those things it comforted me greatly though I could not see you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 163:5
verses.text: Never fail, then, to seize every opportunity of writing to me, and to give me the pleasure of conversing with you at a distance; for to see you face to face I am now forbidden by the distressing state of my health.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 163:6
verses.text: How serious this is you will learn from the God-beloved bishop Amphilochius, who is both able to report to you from his having been constantly with me, and fully competent to tell you what he has seen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 163:7
verses.text: But the only reason why I wish you to know of my sufferings is, that you will forgive me for the future, and acquit me of lack of energy, if I fail to come and see you, though in truth my loss does not so much need defence from me as comfort from you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 163:8
verses.text: Had it been possible for me to come to you, I should have very much preferred a sight of your excellency to all the ends that other men count worth an effort.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:1
verses.text: Letter CLXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:2
verses.text: To Ascholius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:4
verses.text: It would not be easy for me to say how very much delighted I am with your holiness's letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:5
verses.text: My words are too weak to express all that I feel; you, however, ought to be able to conjecture it, from the beauty of what you have written.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:6
verses.text: For what did not your letter contain? It contained love to God; the marvellous description of the martyrs, which put the manner of their good fight so plainly before me that I seemed actually to see it; love and kindness to myself; words of surpassing beauty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:7
verses.text: So when I had taken it into my hands, and read it many times, and perceived how abundantly full it was of the grace of the Spirit, I thought that I had gone back to the good old times, when God's Churches flourished, rooted in faith, united in love, all the members being in harmony, as though in one body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:8
verses.text: Then the persecutors were manifest, and manifest too the persecuted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:9
verses.text: Then the people grew more numerous by being attacked.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:10
verses.text: Then the blood of the martyrs, watering the Churches, nourished many more champions of true religion, each generation stripping for the struggle with the zeal of those that had gone before.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:11
verses.text: Then we Christians were in peace with one another, the peace which the Lord bequeathed us, of which, so cruelly have we driven it from among us, not a single trace is now left us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:12
verses.text: Yet my soul did go back to that blessedness of old, when a letter came from a long distance, bright with the beauty of love, and a martyr travelled to me from wild regions beyond the Danube, preaching in his own person the exactitude of the faith which is there observed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:13
verses.text: Who could tell the delight of my soul at all this? What power of speech could be devised competent to describe all that I felt in the bottom of my heart? However, when I saw the athlete, I blessed his trainer: he, too, before the just Judge, after strengthening many for the conflict on behalf of true religion, shall receive the crown of righteousness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:15
verses.text: By bringing the blessed Eutyches to my recollection, and honouring my country for having sown the seeds of true religion, you have at once delighted me by your reminder of the past, and distressed me by your conviction of the present.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:16
verses.text: None of us now comes near Eutyches in goodness: so far are we from bringing barbarians under the softening power of the Spirit, and the operation of His graces, that by the greatness of our sins we turn gentle hearted men into barbarians, for to ourselves and to our sins I attribute it that the influence of the heretics is so widely diffused.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:17
verses.text: Peradventure no part of the world has escaped the conflagration of heresy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:18
verses.text: You tell me of struggles of athletes, bodies lacerated for the truth's sake, savage fury despised by men of fearless heart, various tortures of persecutors, and constancy of the wrestlers through them all, the block and the water whereby the martyrs died.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:19
verses.text: And what is our condition? Love is grown cold; the teaching of the Fathers is being laid waste; everywhere is shipwreck of the Faith; the mouths of the Faithful are silent; the people, driven from the houses of prayer, lift up their hands in the open air to their Lord which is in heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:20
verses.text: Our afflictions are heavy, martyrdom is nowhere to be seen, because those who evilly entreat us are called by the same name as ourselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 164:21
verses.text: Wherefore pray to the Lord yourself, and join all Christ's noble athletes with you in prayer for the Churches, to the end that, if any further time remains for this world, and all things are not being driven to destruction, God may be reconciled to his own Churches and restore them to their ancient peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:1
verses.text: Letter CLXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:2
verses.text: To Ascholius, bishop of Thessalonica.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:3
verses.text: God has fulfilled my old prayer in deigning to allow me to receive the letter of your veritable holiness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:4
verses.text: What I most of all desire is to see you and to be seen by you, and to enjoy in actual intercourse all the graces of the Spirit with which you are endowed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:5
verses.text: This, however, is impossible, both on account of the distance which separates us, and the engrossing occupations of each of us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:6
verses.text: I therefore pray, in the second place, that my soul may be fed by frequent letters from your love in Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:7
verses.text: This has now been granted me on taking your epistle into my hands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:8
verses.text: I have been doubly delighted at the enjoyment of your communication.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:9
verses.text: I felt as though I could really see your very soul shining in your words as in some mirror; and I was moved to exceeding joy, not only at your proving to be what all testimony says of you, but that your noble qualities are the ornament of my country.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:10
verses.text: You have filled the country beyond our borders with spiritual fruits, like some vigorous branch sprung from a glorious root.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:11
verses.text: Rightly, then, does our country rejoice in her own offshoots.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:12
verses.text: When you were engaging in conflicts for the Faith she heard that the goodly heritage of the Fathers was preserved in you, and she glorified God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:13
verses.text: And now what are you about? You have honoured the land that gave you birth by sending her a martyr who has just fought a good fight in the barbarian country on your borders, just as a grateful gardener might send his first fruits to those who had given him the seeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:14
verses.text: Verily the gift is worthy of Christ's athlete, a martyr of the truth just crowned with the crown of righteousness, whom we have gladly welcomed, glorifying God who has now fulfilled the gospel of His Christ in all the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 165:15
verses.text: Let me ask you to remember in your prayers me who love you, and for my soul's sake earnestly to beseech the Lord that one day I, too, may be deemed worthy to begin to serve God, according to the way of His commandments which He has given us to salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 166:1
verses.text: Letter CLXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 166:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 167:1
verses.text: Letter CLXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 167:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 167:3
verses.text: I am delighted at your remembering me and writing, and, what is yet more important, at your sending me your blessing in your letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 167:4
verses.text: Had I been but worthy of your labours and of your struggles in Christ's cause, I should have been permitted to come to you and embrace you, and to take you as a model of patience.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 167:5
verses.text: But since I am not worthy of this, and am detained by many afflictions and much occupation, I do what is next best.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 167:6
verses.text: I salute your excellency, and beseech you not to grow weary of remembering me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 167:7
verses.text: For the honour and pleasure of receiving your letters is not only an advantage to me, but it is a ground of boasting and pride before the world that I should be held in honour by one whose virtue is so great, and who is in such close communion with God as to be able, alike by his teaching and example, to unite others with him in it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 168:1
verses.text: Letter CLXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 168:2
verses.text: To Antiochus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 168:3
verses.text: I mourn for the Church that is deprived of the guidance of such a shepherd.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 168:4
verses.text: But I have so much the more ground for congratulating you on being worthy of the privilege of enjoying, at such a moment, the society of one who is fighting such a good fight in the cause of the truth, and I am sure that you, who nobly support and stimulate his zeal, will be thought worthy by the Lord of a lot like his.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 168:5
verses.text: What a blessing, to enjoy in unbroken quiet the society of the man so rich in learning and experienced in life! Now, at least, you must, I am sure, know how wise he is.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 168:6
verses.text: In days gone by his mind was necessarily given to many divided cares, and you were too busy a man to give your sole heed to the spiritual fountain which springs from his pure heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 168:7
verses.text: God grant that you may be a comfort to him, and never yourself want consolation from others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 168:8
verses.text: I am sure of the disposition of your heart, alike from the experience which I, for a short time, have had of you, and from the exalted teaching your illustrious instructor, with whom to pass one single day is a sufficient provision for the journey to salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:1
verses.text: Letter CLXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:2
verses.text: Basil to Gregory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:3
verses.text: You have undertaken a kindly and charitable task in getting together the captive troop of the insolent Glycerius (at present I must so write), and, so far as in you lay, covering our common shame.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:4
verses.text: It is only right that your reverence should undo this dishonour with a full knowledge of the facts about him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:5
verses.text: This grave and venerable Glycerius of yours was ordained by me deacon of the church of Venesa to serve the presbyter, and look after the work of the Church, for, though the fellow is in other respects intractable, he is naturally clever at manual labour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:6
verses.text: No sooner was he appointed than he neglected his work, as though there had been absolutely nothing to do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:7
verses.text: But, of his own private power and authority, he got together some wretched virgins, some of whom came to him of their own accord (you know how young people are prone to anything of this kind), and others were unwillingly forced to accept him as leader of their company.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:8
verses.text: Then he assumed the style and title of patriarch, and began all of a sudden to play the man of dignity.
