verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:9
verses.text: He had not attained to this on any reasonable or pious ground; his only object was to get a means of livelihood, just as some men start one trade and some another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:10
verses.text: He has all but upset the whole Church, scorning his own presbyter, a man venerable both by character and age; scorning his chorepiscopus, and myself, as of no account at all, continually filling the town and all the clergy with disorder and disturbance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:11
verses.text: And now, on being mildly rebuked by me and his chorepiscopus, that he may not treat us with contempt (for he was trying to stir the younger men to like insubordination), he is meditating conduct most audacious and inhuman.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:12
verses.text: After robbing as many of the virgins as he could, he has made off by night.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:13
verses.text: I am sure all this will have seemed very sad to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:14
verses.text: Think of the time too.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:15
verses.text: The feast was being held there, and, as was natural, large numbers of people were gathered together.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:16
verses.text: He, however, on his side, brought out his own troop, who followed young men and danced round them, causing all well-disposed persons to be most distressed, while loose chatterers laughed aloud.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:17
verses.text: And even this was not enough, enormous as was the scandal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:18
verses.text: I am told that even the parents of the virgins, finding their bereavement unendurable, wishful to bring home the scattered company, and falling with not unnatural sighs and tears at their daughters' feet, have been insulted and outraged by this excellent young man and his troop of bandits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:19
verses.text: I am sure your reverence will think all this intolerable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:20
verses.text: The ridicule of it attaches to us all alike.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:21
verses.text: First of all, order him to come back with the virgins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:22
verses.text: He might find some mercy, if he were to come back with a letter from you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:23
verses.text: If you do not adopt this course, at least send the virgins back to their mother the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:24
verses.text: If this cannot be done, at all events do not allow any violence to be done to those that are willing to return, but get them to return to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:25
verses.text: Otherwise I call God and man to witness that all this is ill done, and a breach of the law of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 169:26
verses.text: The best course would be for Glycerius to come back with a letter, and in a becoming and proper frame of mind; if not, let him be deprived of his ministry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 170:1
verses.text: Letter CLXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 170:2
verses.text: To Glycerius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 170:3
verses.text: How far will your mad folly go? How long will you counsel mischief against yourself? How long will you go on rousing me to wrath, and bringing shame on the common order of solitaries? Return.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 170:4
verses.text: Put confidence in God, and in me, who imitate God's loving-kindness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 170:5
verses.text: If I rebuked you like a father, like a father I will forgive you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 170:6
verses.text: This is the treatment you shall receive from me, for many others are making supplication in your behalf, and before all the rest your own presbyter, for whose grey hairs and compassionate disposition I feel much respect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 170:7
verses.text: Continue longer to hold aloof from me and you have quite fallen from your degree.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 170:8
verses.text: You will also fall away from God, for with your songs and your garb you are leading the young women not to God, but to the pit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 171:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 171:2
verses.text: To Gregory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 171:3
verses.text: I wrote to you, not long ago, about Glycerius and the virgins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 171:4
verses.text: Even now they have not returned, but are still hesitating, how and why I know not.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 171:5
verses.text: I should be sorry to charge this against you, as though you were acting thus to bring discredit on me, either because you have some ground of complaint against me, or to gratify others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 171:6
verses.text: Let them then come, fearing nothing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 171:7
verses.text: Do you be surety for their doing this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 171:8
verses.text: For it pains me to have my members cut off, although they have been rightly cut off.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 171:9
verses.text: If they hold out the burden will rest on others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 171:10
verses.text: I wash my hands of it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 172:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 172:2
verses.text: To Sophronius, the bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 172:3
verses.text: There is no need for me to say how much I was delighted by your letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 172:4
verses.text: Your own words will enable you to conjecture what I felt on receiving it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 172:5
verses.text: You have exhibited to me in your letter, the first fruits of the Spirit, love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 172:6
verses.text: Than this what can be more precious to me in the present state of affairs, when, because iniquity abounds, the love of many has waxed cold? Nothing is rarer now than spiritual intercourse with a brother, a word of peace, and such spiritual communion as I have found in you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 172:7
verses.text: For this I thank the Lord, beseeching Him that I may have part in the perfect joy that is found in you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 172:8
verses.text: If such be your letter, what must it be to meet you in person? If when you are far away you so affect me, what will you be to me when you are seen face to face? Be sure that if I had not been detained by innumerable occupations, and all the unavoidable anxieties which tie me down, I should have hurried to see your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 172:9
verses.text: Although that old complaint of mine is a great hindrance to my moving about, nevertheless in view of the good I expect, I would not have allowed this to stand in my way.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 172:10
verses.text: To be permitted to meet a man holding the same views and reverencing the faith of the Fathers, as you are said to do by our honourable brethren and fellow presbyters, is in truth to go back to the ancient blessedness of the Churches, when the sufferers from unsound disputation were few, and all lived in peace, "workmen" obeying the commandments and not "needing to be ashamed," serving the Lord with simple and clear confession, and keeping plain and inviolate their faith in Father, Son and Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:2
verses.text: To Theodora the Canoness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:3
verses.text: I should be more diligent in writing to you but for my belief that my letters do not always, my friend, reach your own hands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:4
verses.text: I am afraid that through the naughtiness of those on whose service I depend, especially at a time like this when the whole world is in a state of confusion, a great many other people get hold of them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:5
verses.text: So I wait to be found fault with, and to be eagerly asked for my letters, that so I may have this proof of their delivery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:6
verses.text: Yet, whether I write or not, one thing I do without failing, and that is to keep in my heart the memory of your excellency, and to pray the Lord to grant that you may complete the course of good living which you have chosen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:7
verses.text: For in truth it is no light thing for one, who makes a profession, to follow up all that the promise entails.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:8
verses.text: Any one may embrace the gospel life, but only a very few of those who have come within my knowledge have completely carried out their duty in its minutest details, and have overlooked nothing that is contained therein.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:9
verses.text: Only a very few have been consistent in keeping the tongue in check and the eye under guidance, as the Gospel would have it; in working with the hands according to the mark of doing what is pleasing to God; in moving the feet, and using every member, as the Creator ordained from the beginning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:10
verses.text: Propriety in dress, watchfulness in the society of men, moderation in eating and drinking, the avoidance of superfluity in the acquisition of necessities; all these things seem small enough when they are thus merely mentioned, but, as I have found by experience, their consistent observance requires no light struggle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:11
verses.text: Further, such a perfection of humility as not even to remember nobility of family, nor to be elevated by any natural advantage of body or mind which we may have, nor to allow other people's opinion of us to be a ground of pride and exaltation, all this belongs to the evangelic life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:12
verses.text: There is also sustained self-control, industry in prayer, sympathy in brotherly love, generosity to the poor, lowliness of temper, contrition of heart, soundness of faith, calmness in depression, while we never forget the terrible and inevitable tribunal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 173:13
verses.text: To that judgment we are all hastening, but those who remember it, and are anxious about what is to follow after it, are very few.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:2
verses.text: To a Widow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:3
verses.text: I have been most wishful to write constantly to your excellency, but I have from time to time denied myself, for fear of causing any temptation to beset you, because of those who are ill disposed toward me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:4
verses.text: As I am told, their hatred has even gone so far that they make a fuss if any one happens to receive a letter from me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:5
verses.text: But now that you have begun to write yourself, and very good it is of you to do so, sending me needful information about all that is in your mind, I am stirred to write back to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:6
verses.text: Let me then set right what has been omitted in the past, and at the same time reply to what your excellency has written.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:7
verses.text: Truly blessed is the soul, which by night and by day has no other anxiety than how, when the great day comes wherein all creation shall stand before the Judge and shall give an account for its deeds, she too may be able easily to get quit of the reckoning of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:8
verses.text: For he who keeps that day and that hour ever before him, and is ever meditating upon the defence to be made before the tribunal where no excuses will avail, will sin not at all, or not seriously, for we begin to sin when there is a lack of the fear of God in us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:9
verses.text: When men have a clear apprehension of what is threatened them, the awe inherent in them will never allow them to fall into inconsiderate action or thought.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:10
verses.text: Be mindful therefore of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:11
verses.text: Keep the fear of Him in your heart, and enlist all men to join with you in your prayers, for great is the aid of them that are able to move God by their importunity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:12
verses.text: Never cease to do this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:13
verses.text: Even while we are living this life in the flesh, prayer will be a mighty helper to us, and when we are departing hence it will be a sufficient provision for us on the journey to the world to come.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:14
verses.text: Anxiety is a good thing; but, on the other hand, despondency, dejection, and despair of our salvation, are injurious to the soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 174:15
verses.text: Trust therefore in the goodness of God, and look for His succour, knowing that if we turn to Him rightly and sincerely, not only will He not cast us off forever, but will say to us, even while we are in the act of uttering the words of our prayer, "Lo! I am with you".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 175:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 175:2
verses.text: To Count Magnenianus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 175:3
verses.text: Your excellency lately wrote to me, plainly charging me, besides other matters, to write concerning the Faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 175:4
verses.text: I admire your zeal in the matter, and I pray God that your choice of good things may be persistent, and that, advancing in knowledge and good works, you may be made perfect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 175:5
verses.text: But I have no wish to leave behind me a treatise on the Faith, or to write various creeds, and so I have declined to send what you asked.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 175:6
verses.text: You seem to me to be surrounded by the din of your men there, idle fellows, who say certain things to calumniate me, with the idea that they will improve their own position by lying disgracefully against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 175:7
verses.text: The past shews what they are, and future experience will shew them in still plainer colours.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 175:8
verses.text: I, however, call on all who trust in Christ not to busy themselves in opposition to the ancient faith, but, as we believe, so to be baptized, and, as we are baptized, so to offer the doxology.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 175:9
verses.text: It is enough for us to confess those names which we have received from Holy Scripture, and to shun all innovation about them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 175:10
verses.text: Our salvation does not lie in the invention of modes of address, but in the sound confession of the Godhead in which we have professed our faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 176:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 176:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, Bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 176:3
verses.text: God grant that when this letter is put into your hands, it may find you in good health, quite at leisure, and as you would wish to be.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 176:4
verses.text: For then it will not be in vain that I send you this invitation to be present at our city, to add greater dignity to the annual festival which it is the custom of our Church to hold in honour of the martyrs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 176:5
verses.text: For be sure my most honoured and dear friend, that our people here, though they have had experience of many, desire no one's presence so eagerly as they do yours; so affectionate an impression has your short intercourse with them left behind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 176:6
verses.text: So, then, that the Lord may be glorified, the people delighted, the martyrs honoured, and that I in my old age may receive the attention due to me from my true son, do not refuse to travel to me with all speed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 176:7
verses.text: I will beg you too to anticipate the day of assembly, that so we may converse at leisure and may comfort one another by the interchange of spiritual gifts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 176:8
verses.text: The day is the fifth of September.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 176:9
verses.text: Come then three days beforehand in order that you may also honour with your presence the Church of the Hospital.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 176:10
verses.text: May you by the grace of the Lord be kept in good health and spirits in the Lord, praying for me and for the Church of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 177:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 177:2
verses.text: To Saphronius the Master.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 177:3
verses.text: To reckon up all those who have received kindness at your excellency's hand, for my sake, is no easy task; so many are there whom I feel that I have benefited through your kind aid, a boon which the Lord has given me to help me in these very serious times.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 177:4
verses.text: Worthiest of all is he who is now introduced to you by my letter, the reverend brother Eusebius, attacked by a ridiculous calumny which it depends upon you alone in your uprightness, to destroy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 177:5
verses.text: I beseech you, therefore, both as respecting the right and as being humanely disposed, to grant me your accustomed favours, by adopting the cause of Eusebius as your own, and championing him, and, at the same time, truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 177:6
verses.text: It is no small thing that he has the right on his side; and this, if he be not stricken down by the present crisis, he will have no difficulty in proving plainly and without possibility of contradiction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 178:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 178:2
verses.text: To Aburgius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 178:3
verses.text: I know that I have often recommended many persons to your excellency, and so in serious emergencies have been very useful to friends in distress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 178:4
verses.text: But I do not think that I have ever sent to you one whom I regard with greater respect, or one engaged in contests of greater importance, than my very dear son Eusebius, who now places this letter in your hands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 178:5
verses.text: He will himself inform your excellency, if the opportunity is permitted him, in what difficulties he is involved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 178:6
verses.text: I ought to say, at least, as much as this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 178:7
verses.text: The man ought not to be misjudged, nor, because many have been convicted of disgraceful doings, ought he to come under common suspicion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 178:8
verses.text: He ought to have a fair trial, and his life must be enquired into.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 178:9
verses.text: In this way the untruth of the charges against him will be made plain, and he, after enjoying your righteous protection, will ever proclaim what he owes to your kindness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 179:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 179:2
verses.text: To Arinthaeus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 179:3
verses.text: Your natural nobility of character and your general accessibility have taught me to regard you as a friend of freedom and of men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 179:4
verses.text: I have, therefore, no hesitation in approaching you in behalf of one who is rendered illustrious by a long line of ancestry, but is worthy of greater esteem and honour on his own account, because of his innate goodness of disposition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 179:5
verses.text: I beg you, on my entreaty, to give him your support under a legal charge, in reality, indeed, ridiculous, but difficult to meet on account of the seriousness of the accusation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 179:6
verses.text: It would be of great importance to his success if you would deign to say a kind word in his behalf.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 179:7
verses.text: You would, in the first place, be helping the right; but you would further be showing in this your wonted respect and kindness to myself, who am your friend.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 180:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 180:2
verses.text: To the Master Sophronius, on behalf of Eunathius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 180:3
verses.text: I have been much distressed on meeting a worthy man involved in very great trouble.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 180:4
verses.text: Being human, how could I fail to sympathise with a man of high character afflicted beyond his deserts? On thinking in what way I could be useful to him, I did find one means of helping him out of his difficulties, and that is by making him known to your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 180:5
verses.text: It is now for you to extend also to him the same good offices which, as I can testify, you have shown to many.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 180:6
verses.text: You will learn all the facts of the case from the petition presented by him to the emperors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 180:7
verses.text: This document I beg you to take into your hands, and implore you to help him to the utmost of your power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 180:8
verses.text: You will be helping a Christian, a gentleman, and one whose deep learning ought to win respect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 180:9
verses.text: If I add that in helping him you will confer a great kindness upon me, though, indeed, my interests are matters of small moment, yet, since you are always so good as to make them of importance, your boon to me will be no small one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 181:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 181:2
verses.text: To Otreius, bishop of Melitene.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 181:3
verses.text: Your reverence is, I know, no less distressed than myself at the removal of the very God-beloved bishop Eusebius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 181:4
verses.text: We both of us need comfort.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 181:5
verses.text: Let us try to give it to one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 181:6
verses.text: Do you write to me what you hear from Samosata, and I will report to you anything that I may learn from Thrace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 181:7
verses.text: It is to me no slight alleviation of our present distress to know the constancy of the people.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 181:8
verses.text: It will be the same to you to have news of our common father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 181:9
verses.text: Of course I cannot now tell you this by letter, but I commend to you one who is fully informed, and will report to you in what condition he left him, and how he bears his troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 181:10
verses.text: Pray, then, for him and for me that the Lord will grant him speedy release from his distress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 182:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 182:2
verses.text: To the presbyters of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 182:3
verses.text: Grieved as I am at the desolation of the Church, I none the less congratulate you on having been brought so soon to this extreme limit of your hard struggle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 182:4
verses.text: God grant that you may pass through it with patience, to the end that in return for your faithful stewardship, and the noble constancy which you have shewn in Christ's cause, you may receive the great reward.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 183:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 183:2
verses.text: To the Senate of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 183:3
verses.text: Seeing, as I do, that temptation is now spread all over the world, and that the greater cities of Syria have been tried by the same sufferings as yourselves, (though, indeed, nowhere is the Senate so approved and renowned for good works, as your own, noted as you are for your righteous zeal,) I all but thank the troubles which have befallen you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 183:4
verses.text: For had not this affliction come to pass, your proof under trial would never have been known.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 183:5
verses.text: To all that earnestly strive for any good, the affliction they endure for the sake of their hope in God is like a furnace to gold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 183:6
verses.text: Rouse ye, then, most excellent sirs, that the labours you are about to undertake may not be unworthy of those which you have already sustained, and that on a firm foundation you may be seen putting a yet worthier finish.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 183:7
verses.text: Rouse ye, that ye may stand round about the shepherd of the Church, when the Lord grants him to be seen on his own throne, telling each of you in his turn.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 183:8
verses.text: some good deed done for the sake of the Church of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 183:9
verses.text: On the great day of the Lord, each, according to the proportion of his labours, shall receive his recompense from the munificent Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 183:10
verses.text: By remembering me and writing to me as often as you can, you will be doing justice in sending me a reply, and will moreover give me very great pleasure, by sending me in writing a plain token of a voice which it is delightful to me to hear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 184:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 184:2
verses.text: To Eustathius, bishop of Himmeria.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 184:3
verses.text: Orphanhood is, I know, very dismal, and entails a great deal of work, because it deprives us of those who are set over us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 184:4
verses.text: Whence I conclude that you do not write to me, because you are depressed at what has happened to you, and at the same time are now very much occupied in visiting the folds of Christ, because they are attacked on every side by foes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 184:5
verses.text: But every grief finds consolation in communication with sympathising friends.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 184:6
verses.text: Do then, I beg you, as often as you can, write to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 184:7
verses.text: You will both refresh yourself by speaking to me, and you will comfort me by letting me hear from you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 184:8
verses.text: I shall endeavour to do the same to you, as often as my work lets me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 184:9
verses.text: Pray yourself, and entreat all the brotherhood earnestly to importune the Lord, to grant us one day release from the present distress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 185:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 185:2
verses.text: To Theodotus, bishop of Beraea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 185:3
verses.text: Although you do not write to me, I know that there is recollection of me in your heart; and this I infer, not because I am worthy of any favourable recollection, but because your soul is rich in abundance of love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 185:4
verses.text: Yet, as far as in you lies, use whatever opportunities you have of writing to me, to the end that I may both be cheered by hearing news of you, and have occasion to send you tidings of myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 185:5
verses.text: This is the only mode of communication for those who live far apart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 185:6
verses.text: Do not let us deprive one another of it, so far as our labours will permit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 185:7
verses.text: But I pray God that we may meet in person, that our love may be increased, and that we may multiply gratitude to our Master for His greater boons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 186:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 186:2
verses.text: To Antipater, the governor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 186:3
verses.text: Philosophy is an excellent thing, if only for this, that it even heals its disciples at small cost; for, in philosophy, the same thing is both dainty and healthy fare.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 186:4
verses.text: I am told that you have recovered your failing appetite by pickled cabbage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 186:5
verses.text: Formerly I used to dislike it, both on account of the proverb, and because it reminded me of the poverty that went with it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 186:6
verses.text: Now, however, I am driven to change my mind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 186:7
verses.text: I laugh at the proverb when I see that cabbage is such a "good nursing mother of men," and has restored our governor to the vigour of youth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 186:8
verses.text: For the future I shall think nothing like cabbage, not even Homer's lotus, not even that ambrosia, whatever it was, which fed the Olympians.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 187:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 187:2
verses.text: Antipater to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 187:3
verses.text: "Twice cabbage is death," says the unkind proverb.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 187:4
verses.text: I, however, though I have called for it often, shall die once.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 187:5
verses.text: Yes: even though I had never called for it at all! If you do die anyhow, don't fear to eat a delicious relish, unjustly reviled by the proverb!.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:2
verses.text: (Canonica Prima.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:3
verses.text: )  To Amphilochius, concerning the Canons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:4
verses.text: "Even afool," it is said, "when he asks questions," is counted wise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:5
verses.text: But when a wise man asks questions, he makes even a fool wise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:6
verses.text: And this, thank God, is my case, as often as I receive a letter from your industrious self.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:7
verses.text: For we become more learned and wiser than we were before, merely by asking questions, because we are taught many things which we did not know; and our anxiety to answer them acts as a teacher to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:8
verses.text: Assuredly at the present time, though I have never before paid attention to the points you raise, I have been forced to make accurate enquiry, and to turn over in my mind both whatever I have heard from the elders, and all that I have been taught in conformity with their lessons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:9
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:10
verses.text: As to your enquiry about the Cathari, a statement has already been made, and you have properly reminded me that it is right to follow the custom obtaining in each region, because those, who at the time gave decision on these points, held different opinions concerning their baptism.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:11
verses.text: But the baptism of the Pepuzeni seems to me to have no authority; and I am astonished how this can have escaped Dionysius, acquainted as he was with the canons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:12
verses.text: The old authorities decided to accept that baptism which in nowise errs from the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:13
verses.text: Thus they used the names of heresies, of schisms, and of unlawful congregations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:14
verses.text: By heresies they meant men who were altogether broken off and alienated in matters relating to the actual faith; by schisms men who had separated for some ecclesiastical reasons and questions capable of mutual solution; by unlawful congregations gatherings held by disorderly presbyters or bishops or by uninstructed laymen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:15
verses.text: As, for instance, if a man be convicted of crime, and prohibited from discharging ministerial functions, and then refuses to submit to the canons, but arrogates to himself episcopal and ministerial rights, and persons leave the Catholic Church and join him, this is unlawful assembly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:16
verses.text: To disagree with members of the Church about repentance, is schism.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:17
verses.text: Instances of heresy are those of the Manichaeans, of the Valentinians, of the Marcionites, and of these Pepuzenes; for with them there comes in at once their disagreement concerning the actual faith in God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:18
verses.text: So it seemed good to the ancient authorities to reject the baptism of heretics altogether, but to admit that of schismatics, on the ground that they still belonged to the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:19
verses.text: As to those who assembled in unlawful congregations, their decision was to join them again to the Church, after they had been brought to a better state by proper repentance and rebuke, and so, in many cases, when men in orders had rebelled with the disorderly, to receive them on their repentance, into the same rank.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:20
verses.text: Now the Pepuzeni are plainly heretical, for, by unlawfully and shamefully applying to Montanus and Priscilla the title of the Paraclete, they have blasphemed against the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:21
verses.text: They are, therefore, to be condemned for ascribing divinity to men; and for outraging the Holy Ghost by comparing Him to men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:22
verses.text: They are thus also liable to eternal damnation, inasmuch as blasphemy against the Holy Ghost admits of no forgiveness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:23
verses.text: What ground is there, then, for the acceptance of the baptism of men who baptize into the Father and the Son and Montanus or Priscilla? For those who have not been baptized into the names delivered to us have not been baptized at all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:24
verses.text: So that, although this escaped the vigilance of the great Dionysius, we must by no means imitate his error.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:25
verses.text: The absurdity of the position is obvious in a moment, and evident to all who are gifted with even a small share of reasoning capacity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:26
verses.text: The Cathari are schismatics; but it seemed good to the ancient authorities, I mean Cyprian and our own Firmilianus, to reject all these, Cathari, Encratites, and Hydroparastatae, by one common condemnation, because the origin of separation arose through schism, and those who had apostatized from the Church had no longer on them the grace of the Holy Spirit, for it ceased to be imparted when the continuity was broken.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:27
verses.text: The first separatists had received their ordination from the Fathers, and possessed the spiritual gift by the laying on of their hands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:28
verses.text: But they who were broken off had become laymen, and, because they are no longer able to confer on others that grace of the Holy Spirit from which they themselves are fallen away, they had no authority either to baptize or to ordain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:29
verses.text: And therefore those who were from time to time baptized by them, were ordered, as though baptized by laymen, to come to the church to be purified by the Church's true baptism.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:30
verses.text: Nevertheless, since it has seemed to some of those of Asia that, for the sake of management of the majority, their baptism should be accepted, let it be accepted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:31
verses.text: We must, however, perceive the iniquitous action of the Encratites; who, in order to shut themselves out from being received back by the Church have endeavoured for the future to anticipate readmission by a peculiar baptism of their own, violating, in this manner even their own special practice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:32
verses.text: My opinion, therefore, is that nothing being distinctly laid down concerning them, it is our duty to reject their baptism, and that in the case of any one who has received baptism from them, we should, on his coming to the church, baptize him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:33
verses.text: If, however, there is any likelihood of this being detrimental to general discipline, we must fall back upon custom, and follow the fathers who have ordered what course we are to pursue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:34
verses.text: For I am under some apprehension lest, in our wish to discourage them from baptizing, we may, through the severity of our decision, be a hindrance to those who are being saved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:35
verses.text: If they accept our baptism, do not allow this to distress us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:36
verses.text: We are by no means bound to return them the same favour, but only strictly to obey canons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:37
verses.text: On every ground let it be enjoined that those who come to us from their baptism be anointed in the presence of the faithful, and only on these terms approach the mysteries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:38
verses.text: I am aware that I have received into episcopal rank Izois and Saturninus from the Encratite following.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:39
verses.text: I am precluded therefore from separating from the Church those who have been united to their company, inasmuch as, through my acceptance of the bishops, I have promulgated a kind of canon of communion with them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:40
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:41
verses.text: The woman who purposely destroys her unborn child is guilty of murder.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:42
verses.text: With us there is no nice enquiry as to its being formed or unformed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:43
verses.text: In this case it is not only the being about to be born who is vindicated, but the woman in her attack upon herself; because in most cases women who make such attempts die.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:44
verses.text: The destruction of the embryo is an additional crime, a second murder, at all events if we regard it as done with intent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:45
verses.text: The punishment, however, of these women should not be for life, but for the term of ten years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:46
verses.text: And let their treatment depend not on mere lapse of time, but on the character of their repentance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:47
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:48
verses.text: A deacon who commits fornication after his appointment to the diaconate is to be deposed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:49
verses.text: But, after he has been rejected and ranked among the laity, he is not to be excluded from communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:50
verses.text: For there is an ancient canon that those who have fallen from their degree are to be subjected to this kind of punishment alone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:51
verses.text: Herein, as I suppose, the ancient authorities followed the old rule "Thou shalt not avenge twice for the same thing".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:52
verses.text: There is this further reason too, that laymen, when expelled from the place of the faithful, are from time to time restored to the rank whence they have fallen; but the deacon undergoes once for all the lasting penalty of deposition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:53
verses.text: His deacon's orders not being restored to him, they rested at this one punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:54
verses.text: So far is this as regards what depends on law laid down.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:55
verses.text: But generally a truer remedy is the departure from sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:56
verses.text: Wherefore that man will give me full proof of his cure who, after rejecting grace for the sake of the indulgence of the flesh, has then, through bruising of the flesh and the enslaving of it by means of self control, abandoned the pleasures whereby he was subdued.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:57
verses.text: We ought therefore to know both what is of exact prescription and what is of custom; and, in cases which do not admit of the highest treatment, to follow the traditional direction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:58
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:59
verses.text: In the case of trigamy and polygamy they laid down the same rule, in proportion, as in the case of digamy; namely one year for digamy (some authorities say two years); for trigamy men are separated for three and often for four years; but this is no longer described as marriage at all, but as polygamy; nay rather as limited fornication.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:60
verses.text: It is for this reason that the Lord said to the woman of Samaria, who had five husbands, "he whom thou now hast is not thy husband".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:61
verses.text: He does not reckon those who had exceeded the limits of a second marriage as worthy of the title of husband or wife.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:62
verses.text: In cases of trigamy we have accepted a seclusion of five years, not by the canons, but following the precept of our predecessors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:63
verses.text: Such offenders ought not to be altogether prohibited from the privileges of the Church; they should be considered deserving of hearing after two or three years, and afterwards of being permitted to stand in their place; but they must be kept from the communion of the good gift, and only restored to the place of communion after showing some fruit of repentance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:64
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:65
verses.text: Heretics repenting at death ought to be received; yet to be received, of course, not indiscriminately, but on trial of exhibition of true repentance and of producing fruit in evidence of their zeal for salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:66
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:67
verses.text: The fornication of canonical persons is not to be reckoned as wedlock, and their union is to be completely dissolved, for this is both profitable for the security of the Church and will prevent the heretics from having a ground of attack against us, as though we induced men to join us by the attraction of liberty to sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:68
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:69
verses.text: Abusers of themselves with mankind, and with beasts, as also murderers, wizards, adulterers, and idolaters, are deserving of the same punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:70
verses.text: Whatever rule you have in the case of the rest, observe also in their case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:71
verses.text: There can, however, be no doubt that we ought to receive those who have repented of impurity committed in ignorance for thirty years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:72
verses.text: In this case there is ground for forgiveness in ignorance, in the spontaneity of confession, and the long extent of time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:73
verses.text: Perhaps they have been delivered to Satan for a whole age of man that they may learn not to behave unseemly; wherefore order them to be received without delay, specially if they shed tears to move your mercy, and shew a manner of living worthy of compassion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:74
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:75
verses.text: The man who in a rage has taken up a hatchet against his own wife is a murderer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:76
verses.text: But it is what I should have expected from your intelligence that you should very properly remind me to speak on these points more fully, because a wide distinction must be drawn between cases where there is and where there is not intent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:77
verses.text: A case of an act purely unintentional, and widely removed from the purpose of the agent, is that of a man who throws a stone at a dog or a tree, and hits a man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:78
verses.text: The object was to drive off the beast or to shake down the fruit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:79
verses.text: The chance comer falls fortuitously in the way of the blow, and the act is unintentional.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:80
verses.text: Unintentional too is the act of any one who strikes another with a strap or a flexible stick, for the purpose of chastising him, and the man who is being beaten dies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:81
verses.text: In this case it must be taken into consideration that the object was not to kill, but to improve, the offender.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:82
verses.text: Further, among unintentional acts must be reckoned the case of a man in a fight who when warding off an enemy's attack with cudgel or hand, hits him without mercy in some vital part, so as to injure him, though not quite to kill him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:83
verses.text: This, however, comes very near to the intentional; for the man who employs such a weapon in self defence, or who strikes without mercy, evidently does not spare his opponent, because he is mastered by passion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:84
verses.text: In like manner the case of any one who uses a heavy cudgel, or a stone too big for a man to stand, is reckoned among the unintentional, because he does not do what he meant: in his rage he deals such a blow as to kill his victim, yet all he had in his mind was to give him a thrashing, not to do him to death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:85
verses.text: If, however, a man uses a sword, or anything of the kind, he has no excuse: certainly none if he throws his hatchet.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:86
verses.text: For he does not strike with the hand, so that the force of the blow may be within his own control, but throws, so that from the weight and edge of the iron, and the force of the throw, the wound cannot fail to be fatal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:87
verses.text: On the other hand acts done in the attacks of war or robbery are distinctly intentional, and admit of no doubt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:88
verses.text: Robbers kill for greed, and to avoid conviction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:89
verses.text: Soldiers who inflict death in war do so with the obvious purpose not of fighting, nor chastising, but of killing their opponents.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:90
verses.text: And if any one has concocted some magic philtre for some other reason, and then causes death, I count this as intentional.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:91
verses.text: Women frequently endeavour to draw men to love them by incantations and magic knots, and give them drugs which dull their intelligence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:92
verses.text: Such women, when they cause death, though the result of their action may not be what they intended, are nevertheless, on account of their proceedings being magical and prohibited, to be reckoned among intentional homicides.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:93
verses.text: Women also who administer drugs to cause abortion, as well as those who take poisons to destroy unborn children, are murderesses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:94
verses.text: So much on this subject.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:95
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:96
verses.text: The sentence of the Lord that it is unlawful to withdraw from wedlock, save on account of fornication, applies, according to the argument, to men and women alike.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:97
verses.text: Custom, however, does not so obtain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:98
verses.text: Yet, in relation with women, very strict expressions are to be found; as, for instance, the words of the apostle "He which is joined to a harlot is one body" and of Jeremiah, If a wife "become another man's shall he return unto her again? shall not that land be greatly polluted?" And again, "He that hath an adulteress is a fool and impious".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:99
verses.text: Yet custom ordains that men who commit adultery and are in fornication be retained by their wives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:100
verses.text: Consequently I do not know if the woman who lives with the man who has been dismissed can properly be called an adulteress; the charge in this case attaches to the woman who has put away her husband, and depends upon the cause for which she withdrew from wedlock.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:101
verses.text: In the case of her being beaten, and refusing to submit, it would be better for her to endure than to be separated from her husband; in the case of her objecting to pecuniary loss, even here she would not have sufficient ground.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:102
verses.text: If her reason is his living in fornication we do not find this in the custom of the church; but from an unbelieving husband a wife is commanded not to depart, but to remain, on account of the uncertainty of the issue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:103
verses.text: "For what knowest thou, O wife, whether thou shalt save thy husband?" Here then the wife, if she leaves her husband and goes to another, is an adulteress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:104
verses.text: But the man who has been abandoned is pardonable, and the woman who lives with such a man is not condemned.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:105
verses.text: But if the man who has deserted his wife goes to another, he is himself an adulterer because he makes her commit adultery; and the woman who lives with him is an adulteress, because she has caused another woman's husband to come over to her.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:106
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:107
verses.text: Those who swear that they will not receive ordination, declining orders upon oath, must not be driven to perjure themselves, although there does seem to be a canon making concessions to such persons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:108
verses.text: Yet I have found by experience that perjurers never turn out well.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:109
verses.text: Account must however be taken of the form of the oath, its terms, the frame of mind in which it was taken, and the minutest additions made to the terms, since, if no ground of relief can anywhere be found, such persons must be dismissed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:110
verses.text: The case, however, of Severus, I mean of the presbyter ordained by him, does seem to me to allow of relief of this kind, if you will permit it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:111
verses.text: Give directions for the district placed under Mestia, to which the man was appointed, to be reckoned under Vasoda.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:112
verses.text: Thus he will not forswear himself by not departing from the place, and Longinus, having Cyriacus with him, will not leave the Church unprovided for, nor himself be guilty of neglect of work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:113
verses.text: I moreover shall not be held guilty of taking action in contravention of any canons by making a concession to Cyriacus who had sworn that he would remain at Mindana and yet accepted the transfer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:114
verses.text: His return will be in accordance with his oath, and his obedience to the arrangement will not be reckoned against him as perjury, because it was not added to his oath that he would not go, even a short time, from Mindana, but would remain there for the future.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:115
verses.text: Severus, who pleads forgetfulness, I shall pardon, only telling him that One who knows what is secret will not overlook the ravaging of His Church by a man of such a character; a man who originally appoints uncanonically, then imposes oaths in violation of the Gospel, then tells a man to perjure himself in the matter of his transfer, and last of all lies in pretended forgetfulness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:116
verses.text: I am no judge of hearts; I only judge by what I hear; let us leave vengeance to the Lord, and ourselves pardon the common human error of forgetfulness, and receive the man without question.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:117
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:118
verses.text: The man who is guilty of unintentional homicide has given sufficient satisfaction in eleven years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:119
verses.text: We shall, without doubt, observe what is laid down by Moses in the case of wounded men, and shall not hold a murder to have been committed in the case of a man who lies down after he has been struck, and walks again leaning on his staff.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:120
verses.text: If, however, he does not rise again after he has been struck, nevertheless, from there being no intent to kill, the striker is a homicide, but an unintentional homicide.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:121
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:122
verses.text: The canon absolutely excludes digamists from the ministry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:123
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:124
verses.text: Homicide in war is not reckoned by our Fathers as homicide; I presume from their wish to make concession to men fighting on behalf of chastity and true religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:125
verses.text: Perhaps, however, it is well to counsel that those whose hands are not clean only abstain from communion for three years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:126
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:127
verses.text: A taker of usury, if he consent to spend his unjust gain on the poor, and to be rid for the future of the plague of covetousness, may be received into the ministry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:128
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:129
verses.text: I am astonished at your requiring exactitude in Scripture, and arguing that there is something forced in the diction of the interpretation which gives the meaning of the original, but does not exactly render what is meant by the Hebrew word.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:130
verses.text: Yet I must not carelessly pass by the question started by an enquiring mind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:131
verses.text: At the creation of the world, birds of the air and the fishes of the sea had the same origin; for both kinds were produced from the water.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:132
verses.text: The reason is that both have the same characteristics.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:133
verses.text: The latter swim in the water, the former in the air.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:134
verses.text: They are therefore mentioned together.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:135
verses.text: The form of expression is not used without distinction, but of all that lives in the water it is used very properly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:136
verses.text: The birds of the air and the fishes of the sea are subject to man; and not they alone, but all that passes through the paths of the sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:137
verses.text: For every water-creature is not a fish, as for instance the sea monsters, whales, sharks, dolphins, seals, even sea-horses, sea-dogs, saw-fish, sword-fish, and sea-cows; and, if you like, sea nettles, cockles and all hard-shelled creatures of whom none are fish, and all pass through the paths of the sea; so that there are three kinds, birds of the air, fishes of the sea, and all water-creatures which are distinct from fish, and pass through the paths of the sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:138
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:139
verses.text: Naaman was not a great man with the Lord, but with his lord; that is, he was one of the chief princes of the King of the Syrians.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 188:140
verses.text: Read your Bible carefully, and you will find the answer to your question there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:1
verses.text: Letter CLXXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:2
verses.text: To Eustathius the physician.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:3
verses.text: Humanity is the regular business of all you who practise as physicians.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:4
verses.text: And, in my opinion, to put your science at the head and front of life's pursuits is to decide reasonably and rightly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:5
verses.text: This at all events seems to be the case if man's most precious possession, life, is painful and not worth living, unless it be lived in health, and if for health we are dependent on your skill.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:6
verses.text: In your own case medicine is seen, as it were, with two right hands; you enlarge the accepted limits of philanthropy by not confining the application of your skill to men's bodies, but by attending also to the cure of the diseases of their souls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:7
verses.text: It is not only in accordance with popular report that I thus write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:8
verses.text: I am moved by the personal experience which I have had on many occasions and to a remarkable degree at the present time, in the midst of the unspeakable wickedness of our enemies, which has flooded our life like a noxious torrent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:9
verses.text: You have most skilfully dispersed it and by pouring in your soothing words have allayed the inflammation of my heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:10
verses.text: Having regard to the successive and diversified attacks of my enemies against me, I thought that I ought to keep silence and to bear their successive assaults without reply, and without attempting to contradict foes armed with a lie, that terrible weapon which too often drives its point through the heart of truth herself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:11
verses.text: You did well in urging me not to abandon the defence of truth, but rather to convict our calumniators, lest haply, by the success of lies, many be hurt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:13
verses.text: In adopting an unexpected attitude of hatred against me my opponents seem to be repeating the old story in aesop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:14
verses.text: He makes the wolf bring certain charges against the lamb, as being really ashamed to seem to kill a creature who had done him no harm without some reasonable pretext; then when the lamb easily rebuts the slander, the wolf, none the less, continues his attack, and, though defeated in equity, comes off winner in biting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:15
verses.text: Just so with those who seem to count hatred to me as a virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:16
verses.text: They will perhaps blush to hate me without a cause, and so invent pleas and charges against me, without abiding by any of their allegations, but urging as the ground of their detestation now this, now that, and now something else.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:17
verses.text: In no single case is their malice consistent; but when they are baulked in one charge they cling to another and, foiled in this, have recourse to a third; and if all their accusations are scattered they do not drop their ill-will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:18
verses.text: They say that I preach three Gods, dinning the charge into the ears of the mob and pressing the calumny plausibly and persistently Nevertheless, truth is fighting on my side; and both in public to all the world, and in private to all whom I meet, I prove that I anathematize every one who maintains three Gods and do not even allow him to be a Christian.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:19
verses.text: No sooner do they hear this than Sabellius is handy for them to urge against me, and it is noised abroad that my teaching is tainted with his error.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:20
verses.text: Once more I hold out in my defence my wonted weapon of truth, and demonstrate that I shudder at Sabellianism as much as at Judaism.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:22
verses.text: What then? After all these efforts were they tired? Did they leave off? Not at all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:23
verses.text: They are charging me with innovation, and base their charge on my confession of three hypostases, and blame me for asserting one Goodness, one Power, one Godhead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:24
verses.text: In this they are not wide of the truth, for I do so assert.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:25
verses.text: Their complaint is that their custom does not accept this, and that Scripture does not agree.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:26
verses.text: What is my reply? I do not consider it fair that the custom which obtains among them should be regarded as a law and rule of orthodoxy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:27
verses.text: If custom is to be taken in proof of what is right, then it is certainly competent for me to put forward on my side the custom which obtains here.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:28
verses.text: If they reject this, we are clearly not bound to follow them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:29
verses.text: Therefore let God-inspired Scripture decide between us; and on whichever side be found doctrines in harmony with the word of God, in favour of that side will be cast the vote of truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:30
verses.text: What then is the charge? Two points are advanced at one and the same time in the accusations levelled against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:31
verses.text: I am accused on the one hand of parting the hypostases asunder; on the other of never using in the plural any one of the nouns relating to the Divinity, but of always speaking in the singular number of one Goodness, as I have already said; of one Power; one Godhead; and so on.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:32
verses.text: As to the parting of the hypostases, there ought to be no objection nor opposition on the part of those who assert in the case of the divine nature a distinction of essences.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:33
verses.text: For it is unreasonable to maintain three essences and to object to three hypostases.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:34
verses.text: Nothing, then, is left but the charge of using words of the divine nature in the singulars.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:36
verses.text: I have quite a little difficulty in meeting the second charge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:37
verses.text: Whoever condemns those who assert that the Godhead is one, must of necessity agree with all who maintain many godheads, or with those who maintain that there is none.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:38
verses.text: No third position is conceivable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:39
verses.text: The teaching of inspired Scripture does not allow of our speaking of many godheads, but, wherever it mentions the Godhead, speaks of it in the singular number; as, for instance, "in him dwelleth all the fulness of the Godhead bodily".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:40
verses.text: And again; "for the invisible things of him from the creation of the world are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even his eternal power and Godhead".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:41
verses.text: If, then, to multiply godheads is the special mark of the victims of polytheistic error, and to deny the Godhead altogether is to fall into atheism, what sense is there in this charge against me of confessing one Godhead? But they make a plainer disclosure of the end they have in view; namely, in the case of the Father to agree that He is God, and consenting in like manner that the Son be honoured with the attribute of Godhead; but to refuse to comprehend the Spirit, though reckoned with Father and with Son in the idea of Godhead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:42
verses.text: They allow that the power of the Godhead extends from the Father to the Son, but they divide the nature of the Spirit from the divine glory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:43
verses.text: Against this view, to the best of my ability, I must enter a brief defence of my own position.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:45
verses.text: What, then, is my argument? In delivering the Faith of Salvation to those who are being made disciples in His doctrine, the Lord conjoins with Father and with Son the Holy Spirit also.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:46
verses.text: That which is conjoined once I maintain to be conjoined everywhere and always.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:47
verses.text: There is no question here of a ranking together in one respect and isolation in others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:48
verses.text: In the quickening power whereby our nature is transformed from the life of corruption to immortality, the power of the Spirit is comprehended with Father and with Son, and in many other instances, as in the conception of the good, the holy, the eternal, the wise, the right, the supreme, the efficient, and generally in all terms which have the higher meaning, He is inseparably united.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:49
verses.text: Wherefrom I judge it right to hold that the Spirit, thus conjoined with Father and Son in so many sublime and divine senses, is never separated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:50
verses.text: Indeed I am unaware of any degrees of better or worse in the terms concerning the divine nature, nor can I imagine its being reverent and right to allow the Spirit a participation in those of lesser dignity, while He is judged unworthy of the higher.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:51
verses.text: For all conceptions and terms which regard the divine are of equal dignity one with another, in that they do not vary in regard to the meaning of the subject matter to which they are applied.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:52
verses.text: Our thought is not led to one subject by the attribution of good, and to another by that of wise, powerful, and just; mention any attributes you will, the thing signified is one and the same.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:53
verses.text: And if you name God, you mean the same Being whom you understood by the rest of the terms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:54
verses.text: Granting, then, that all the terms applied to the divine nature are of equal force one with another in relation to that which they describe, one emphasizing one point and another another, but all bringing our intelligence to the contemplation of the same object; what ground is there for conceding to the Spirit fellowship with Father and Son in all other terms, and isolating Him from the Godhead alone? There is no escape from the position that we must either allow the fellowship here, or refuse it everywhere.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:55
verses.text: & If He is worthy in every other respect, He is certainly not unworthy in this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:56
verses.text: If, as our opponents argue, He is too insignificant to be allowed fellowship with Father and with Son in Godhead, He is not worthy to share any single one of the divine attributes: for when the terms are carefully considered, and compared with one another, by the help of the special meaning contemplated in each, they will be found to involve nothing less than the title of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:57
verses.text: A proof of what I say lies in the fact that even many inferior objects are designated by this name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:58
verses.text: Nay, Holy Scripture does not even shrink from using this term in the case of things of a totally opposite character, as when it applies the title god to idols.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:59
verses.text: "Let the gods," it is written, "who have not made heaven and earth, be taken away, and cast beneath the earth;" and again, "the gods of the nations are idols".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:60
verses.text: And the witch, when she called up the required spirits for Saul, is said to have seen gods.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:61
verses.text: Balaam too, an augur and seer, with the oracles in his hand, as Scripture says, when he had got him the teaching of the demons by his divine ingenuity, is described by Scripture as taking counsel with God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:62
verses.text: From many similar instances in Holy Scripture it may be proved that the name of God has no pre-eminence over other words which are applied to the divine, since, as has been said, we find it employed without distinction even in the case of things of quite opposite character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:63
verses.text: On the other hand we are taught by Scripture that the names holy, incorruptible, righteous, and good, are nowhere indiscriminately used of unworthy objects.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:64
verses.text: It follows, then, that if they do not deny that the Holy Spirit is associated with the Son and with the Father, in the names which are specially applied, by the usage of true religion, to the divine nature alone, there is no reasonable ground for refusing to allow the same association in the case of that word alone which, as I have shown, is used as a recognised homonym even of demons and idols.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:66
verses.text: But they contend that this title sets forth the nature of that to which it is applied; that the nature of the Spirit is not a nature shared in common with that of Father and of Son; and that, for this reason, the Spirit ought not to be allowed the common use of the name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:67
verses.text: It is, therefore, for them to show by what means they have perceived this variation in the nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:68
verses.text: If it were indeed possible for the divine nature to be contemplated in itself; could what is proper to it and what is foreign to it be discovered by means of visible things; we should then certainly stand in no need of words or other tokens to lead us to the apprehension of the object of the enquiry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:69
verses.text: But the divine nature is too exalted to be perceived as objects of enquiry are perceived, and about things which are beyond our knowledge we reason on probable evidence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:70
verses.text: We are therefore of necessity guided in the investigation of the divine nature by its operations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:71
verses.text: Suppose we observe the operations of the Father, of the Son, of the Holy Ghost, to be different from one another, we shall then conjecture, from the diversity of the operations that the operating natures are also different.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:72
verses.text: For it is impossible that things which are distinct, as regards their nature, should be associated as regards the form of their operations; fire does not freeze; ice does not warm; difference of natures implies difference of the operations proceeding from them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:73
verses.text: Grant, then, that we perceive the operation of Father, Son and Holy Ghost to be one and the same, in no respect showing difference or variation; from this identity of operation we necessarily infer the unity of the nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:75
verses.text: The Father, the Son and the Holy Ghost alike hallow, quicken, enlighten, and comfort.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:76
verses.text: No one will attribute a special and peculiar operation of hallowing to the operation of the Spirit, after hearing the Saviour in the Gospel saying to the Father about His disciples, sanctify them in Thy name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:77
verses.text: In like manner all other operations are equally performed, in all who are worthy of them, by the Father and by the Son and by the Holy Ghost; every grace and virtue, guidance, life, consolation, change into the immortal, the passage into freedom and all other good things which come down to man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:78
verses.text: Nay even the dispensation which is above us in relation to the creature considered both in regard to intelligence and sense, if indeed it is possible for any conjecture concerning what lies above us to be formed from what we know, is not constituted apart from the operation and power of the Holy Ghost, every individual sharing His help in proportion to the dignity and need of each.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:79
verses.text: Truly the ordering and administration of beings above our nature is obscure to our perception; nevertheless any one, arguing from what is known to us, would find it more reasonable to conclude that the power of the Spirit operates even in those beings, than that He is excluded from the government of supramundane things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:80
verses.text: So to assert is to advance a blasphemy bare and unsupported; it is to support absurdity on fallacy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:81
verses.text: On the other hand to agree that even the world beyond us is governed by the power of the Spirit, as well as by that of the Father and of the Son, is to advance a contention, supported on the plain testimony of what is seen in human life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:82
verses.text: Identity of operation in the case of Father and of Son and of Holy Ghost clearly proves invariability of nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:83
verses.text: It follows that, even if the name of Godhead does signify nature, the community of essence proves that this title is very properly applied to the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:85
verses.text: I am, however, at a loss to understand how our opponents with all their ingenuity can adduce the title of Godhead in proof of nature, as though they had never heard from Scripture that nature does not result from institution and appointment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:86
verses.text: Moses was made a god of the Egyptians when the divine voice said, "See I have made thee a god to Pharaoh.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:87
verses.text: The title therefore does give proof of a certain authority of oversight or of action.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:88
verses.text: The divine nature, on the other hand, in all the words which are contrived, remains always inexplicable, as I always teach.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:89
verses.text: We have learnt that it is beneficent, judicial, righteous, good, and so on; and so have been taught differences of operations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:90
verses.text: But we are, nevertheless, unable to understand the nature of the operator through our idea of the operations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:91
verses.text: Let any one give an account of each one of these names, and of the actual nature to which they are applied, and it will be found that the definition will not in both cases be the same.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:92
verses.text: And where the definition is not identical the nature is different.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:93
