verses.text: There is, then, a distinction to be observed between the essence, of which no explanatory term has yet been discovered, and the meaning of the names applied to it in reference to some operation or dignity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:94
verses.text: That there should be no difference in the operations we infer from the community of terms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:95
verses.text: But, we derive no clear proof of variation in nature, because, as has been said, identity of operations indicates community of nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 189:96
verses.text: If then Godhead be the name of an operation, we say that the Godhead is one, as there is one operation of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost; if, however, as is popularly supposed, the name of Godhead indicates nature, then, since we find no variation in the nature, we reasonably define the Holy Trinity to be of one Godhead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:1
verses.text: Letter CXC.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:4
verses.text: The interest which you have shewn in the affairs of the Isaurian Church is only what might have been expected from that zeal and propriety of conduct which so continually rouses my admiration of you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:5
verses.text: The most careless observer must at once perceive that it is in all respects more advantageous for care and anxiety to be divided among several bishops.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:6
verses.text: This has not escaped your observation, and you have done well in noting, and in acquainting me with, the position of affairs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:7
verses.text: But it is not easy to find fit men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:8
verses.text: While, then, we are desirous of having the credit that comes of numbers, and cause God's Church to be more effectively administered by more officers, let us be careful lest we unwittingly bring the word into contempt on account of the unsatisfactory character of the men who are called to office, and accustom the laity to indifference.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:9
verses.text: You yourself know well that the conduct of the governed is commonly of a piece with that of those who are set over them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:10
verses.text: Perhaps therefore it might be better to appoint one well approved man, though even this may not be an easy matter, to the supervision of the whole city, and entrust him with the management of details on his own responsibility.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:11
verses.text: Only let him be a servant of God, "a workman that needeth not to be ashamed," not "looking on his own things," but on the things of the most, "that they be saved".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:12
verses.text: If he finds himself overweighted with responsibility, he will associate other labourers for the harvest with himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:13
verses.text: If only we can find such a man, I own that I think the one worth many, and the ordering of the cure of souls in this way likely to be attended at once with more advantage to the Churches and with less risk to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:14
verses.text: If, however, this course prove difficult, let us first do our best to appoint superintendents to the small townships or villages which have of old been episcopal sees.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:15
verses.text: Then afterwards we will appoint once more the [bishop] of the city.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:16
verses.text: Unless we take this course the man appointed may prove a hindrance to subsequent administration, and from his wish to rule over a larger diocese, and his refusal to accept the ordination of the bishops, we may find ourselves suddenly involved in a domestic quarrel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:17
verses.text: If this course is difficult, and time does not allow, see to it that the Isaurian bishop is strictly kept within his own bounds by ordaining some of his immediate neighbours.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:18
verses.text: In the future it will be reserved for us to give to the rest bishops at the proper season, after we have carefully examined those whom we ourselves may judge to be most fit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:20
verses.text: I have asked George, as you requested.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:21
verses.text: He replies as you reported.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:22
verses.text: In all this we must remain quiet, casting the care of the house on the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:23
verses.text: For I put my trust in the Holy God that He will by my aid grant to him deliverance from his difficulties in some other way, and to me to live my life without trouble.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:24
verses.text: If this cannot be, be so good as to send me word yourself as to what part I must look after, that I may begin to ask this favour of each of my friends in power, either for nothing, or for some moderate price, as the Lord may prosper me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:25
verses.text: I have, in accordance with your request, written to brother Valerius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:26
verses.text: Matters at Nyssa are going on as they were left by your reverence, and, by the aid of your holiness, are improving.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:27
verses.text: Of those who were then separated from me some have gone off to the court, and some remain waiting for tidings from it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:28
verses.text: The Lord is able as well to frustrate the expectations of these latter as to make the return of the former useless.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:30
verses.text: Philo, on the authority of some Jewish tradition, explains the manna to have been of such a nature that it changed with the taste of the eater: that of itself it was like millet seed boiled in honey; it served sometimes for bread, sometimes for meat, either of birds or beasts; at other times for vegetables, according to each man's liking; even for fish so that the flavour of each separate kind was exactly reproduced in the eater's mouth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:31
verses.text: Scripture recognises chariots containing three riders, because while other chariots contained two, the driver and the man-at-arms, Pharaoh's held three, two men-at-arms, and one to hold the reins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:32
verses.text: Sympius has written me a letter expressive of respect and communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:33
verses.text: The letter which I have written in reply I am sending to your holiness, that you may send it on to him if you quite approve of it, with the addition of some communication from yourself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 190:34
verses.text: May you, by the loving kindness of the Holy One, be preserved for me and for the Church of God, in good health, happy in the Lord, and ever praying for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:1
verses.text: Letter CXCI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:3
verses.text: On reading the letter of your reverence I heartily thanked God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:4
verses.text: I did so because I found in your expressions traces of ancient affection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:5
verses.text: You are not like the majority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:6
verses.text: You did not persist in refusing to begin an affectionate correspondence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:7
verses.text: You have learned the greatness of the prize promised to the saints for humility, and so you have chosen, by taking the second place, to get before me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:8
verses.text: Among Christians such are the conditions of victory, and it is he who is content to take the second place who wins a crown.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:9
verses.text: But I must not be behindhand in this virtuous rivalry, and so I thus salute your reverence in return; and inform you as to how I am minded, in that, since agreement in the faith is established among us, there is nothing further to prevent our being one body and one spirit, as we have been called in one hope of our calling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:10
verses.text: It is for you, then, of your charity to follow up a good beginning to rally men of like mind to stand at your side, and to appoint both time and place for meeting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:11
verses.text: Thus, by God's grace, through mutual accommodation we may govern the Churches by the ancient kind of love; receiving as our own members brothers coming from the other side, sending as to our kin, and in turn receiving as from our own kin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:12
verses.text: Such, indeed, was once the boast of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:13
verses.text: Brothers from each Church, travelling from one end of the world to the other, were provided with little tokens, and found all men fathers and brothers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:14
verses.text: This is a privilege whereof, like all the rest, the enemy of Christ's Churches has robbed us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:15
verses.text: We are confined each in his own city, and every one looks at his neighbour with distrust.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:16
verses.text: What more is to be said but that our love has grown cold, whereby alone our Lord has told us that His disciples are distinguished? First of all, if you will, do you become known to one another, that I may know with whom I am to be in agreement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:17
verses.text: Thus by common consent we will fix on some place convenient to both, and, at a season suitable for travelling, we will hasten to meet one another; the Lord will direct us in the way.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:18
verses.text: Farewell.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:19
verses.text: Be of good cheer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:20
verses.text: Pray for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 191:21
verses.text: May you be granted to me by the grace of the Holy One?.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 192:1
verses.text: Letter CXCII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 192:2
verses.text: To Sophronius the Master.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 192:3
verses.text: With your extraordinary zeal in good deeds you have written to me to say that you yourself owe me double thanks; first, for getting a letter from me, and secondly, for doing me a service.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 192:4
verses.text: What thanks, then, must not I owe you, both for reading your most delightful words, and for finding what I hoped for so quickly accomplished! The message was exceedingly gratifying on its own account, but it gave me much greater gratification from the fact that you were the friend to whom I owed the boon.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 192:5
verses.text: God grant that ere long I may see you, and return you thanks in words, and enjoy the great pleasure of your society.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:1
verses.text: Letter CXCIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:2
verses.text: To Meletius the Physician.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:3
verses.text: I am not able to flee from the discomforts of winter so well as cranes are, although for foreseeing the future I am quite as clever as a crane.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:4
verses.text: But as to liberty of life the birds are almost as far ahead of me as they are in the being able to fly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:5
verses.text: In the first place I have been detained by certain worldly business; then I have been so wasted by constant and violent attacks of fever that there does seem something thinner even than I was,—I am thinner than ever.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:6
verses.text: Besides all this, bouts of quartan ague have gone on for more than twenty turns.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:7
verses.text: Now I do seem to be free from fever, but I am in such a feeble state that I am no stronger than a cobweb.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:8
verses.text: Hence the shortest journey is too far for me, and every breath of wind is more dangerous to me than big waves to those at sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:9
verses.text: I have no alternative but to hide in my hut and wait for spring, if only I can last out so long, and am not carried off beforehand by the internal malady of which I am never rid.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:10
verses.text: If the Lord saves me with His mighty hand, I shall gladly betake myself to your remote region, and gladly embrace a friend so dear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 193:11
verses.text: Only pray that my life may be ordered as may be best for my soul's good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:1
verses.text: Letter CXCIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:2
verses.text: To Zoilus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:3
verses.text: What are you about, most excellent sir, in anticipating me in humility? Educated as you are, and able to write such a letter as you have sent, you nevertheless ask for forgiveness at my hands, as though you were engaged in some undertaking rash and beyond your position.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:4
verses.text: But a truce to mockery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:5
verses.text: Continue to write to me on every occasion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:6
verses.text: Am I not wholly illiterate? It is delightful to read the letters of an eloquent writer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:7
verses.text: Have I learned from Scripture how good a thing is love? I count intercourse with a loving friend invaluable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:8
verses.text: And I do hope that you may tell me of all the good gifts which I pray for you; the best of health, and the prosperity of all your house.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:9
verses.text: Now as to my own affairs, my condition is not more endurable than usual.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:10
verses.text: It is enough to tell you this and you will understand the bad state of my health.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:11
verses.text: It has indeed reached such extreme suffering as to be as difficult to describe as to experience, if indeed your own experience has fallen short of mine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 194:12
verses.text: But it is the work of the good God to give me power to bear in patience whatever trials are inflicted on me for my own good at the hands of our merciful Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 195:1
verses.text: Letter CXCV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 195:2
verses.text: To Euphronius, bishop of Colonia Armeniae.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 195:3
verses.text: Colonia, which the Lord has placed under your authority, is far out of the way of ordinary routes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 195:4
verses.text: The consequence is that, although I am frequently writing to the rest of the brethren in Armenia Minor, I hesitate to write to your reverence, because I have no expectation of finding any one to convey my letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 195:5
verses.text: Now, however, that I am hoping either for your presence, or that my letter will be sent on to you by some of the bishops to whom I have written, I thus write and salute you by letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 195:6
verses.text: I wish to tell you that I seem to be still alive, and at the same time to exhort you to pray for me, that the Lord may lessen my afflictions, and lift from me the heavy load of pain which now presses like a cloud upon my heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 195:7
verses.text: I shall have this relief if He will only grant a quick restoration to those godly bishops who are now punished for their faithfulness to true religion by being scattered all abroad.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 196:1
verses.text: Letter CXCVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 196:2
verses.text: To Aburgius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 196:3
verses.text: Rumour, messenger of good news, is continually reporting how you dart across, like the stars, appearing now here, now there, in the barbarian regions; now supplying the troops with provisions, now appearing in gorgeous array before the emperor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 196:4
verses.text: I pray God that your doings may prosper as they deserve, and that you may achieve eminent success.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 196:5
verses.text: I pray that, so long as I live and breathe this air, (for my life now is no more than drawing breath), our country may from time to time behold you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:1
verses.text: Letter CXCVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:2
verses.text: To Ambrose, bishop of Milan.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:4
verses.text: The gifts of the Lord are ever great and many; in greatness beyond measure, in number incalculable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:5
verses.text: To those who are not insensible of His mercy one of the greatest of these gifts is that of which I am now availing myself, the opportunity allowed us, far apart in place though we be, of addressing one another by letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:6
verses.text: He grants us two means of becoming acquainted; one by personal intercourse, another by epistolary correspondence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:7
verses.text: Now I have become acquainted with you through what you have said.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:8
verses.text: I do not mean that my memory is impressed with your outward appearance, but that the beauty of the inner man has been brought home to me by the rich variety of your utterances, for each of us "speaketh out of the abundance of the heart".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:9
verses.text: I have given glory to God, Who in every generation selects those who are well-pleasing to Him; Who of old indeed chose from the sheepfold a prince for His people; Who through the Spirit gifted Amos the herdman with power and raised him up to be a prophet; Who now has drawn forth for the care of Christ's flock a man from the imperial city, entrusted with the government of a whole nation, exalted in character, in lineage, in position, in eloquence, in all that this world admires.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:10
verses.text: This same man has flung away all the advantages of the world, counting them all loss that he may gain Christ, and has taken in his hand the helm of the ship, great and famous for its faith in God, the Church of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:11
verses.text: Come, then, O man of God; not from men have you received or been taught the Gospel of Christ; it is the Lord Himself who has transferred you from the judges of the earth to the throne of the Apostles; fight the good fight; heal the infirmity of the people, if any are infected by the disease of Arian madness; renew the ancient footprints of the Fathers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:12
verses.text: You have laid the foundation of affection towards me; strive to build upon it by the frequency of your salutations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:13
verses.text: Thus shall we be able to be near one another in spirit, although our earthly homes are far apart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:15
verses.text: By your earnestness and zeal in the matter of the blessed bishop Dionysius you testify all your love to the Lord, your honour for your predecessors, and your zeal for the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:16
verses.text: For our disposition towards our faithful fellow-servants is referred to the Lord Whom they have served.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:17
verses.text: Whoever honours men that have contended for the faith proves that he has like zeal for it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:18
verses.text: One single action is proof of much virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:19
verses.text: I wish to acquaint your love in Christ that the very zealous brethren who have been commissioned by your reverence to act for you in this good work have won praise for all the clergy by the amiability of their manners; for by their individual modesty and conciliatoriness they have shewn the sound condition of all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:20
verses.text: Moreover, with all zeal and diligence they have braved an inclement season; and with unbroken perseverance have persuaded the faithful guardians of the blessed body to transmit to them the custody of what they have regarded as the safeguard of their lives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:21
verses.text: And you must understand that they are men who would never have been forced by any human authority or sovereignty, had not the perseverance of these brethren moved them to compliance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:22
verses.text: No doubt a great aid to the attainment of the object desired was the presence of our well beloved and reverend son Therasius the presbyter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:23
verses.text: He voluntarily undertook all the toil of the journey; he moderated the energy of the faithful on the spot; he persuaded opponents by his arguments; in the presence of priests and deacons, and of many others who fear the Lord, he took up the relics with all becoming reverence, and has aided the brethren in their preservation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:24
verses.text: These relics do you receive with a joy equivalent to the distress with which their custodians have parted with them and sent them to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:25
verses.text: Let none dispute; let none doubt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:26
verses.text: Here you have that unconquered athlete.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:27
verses.text: These bones, which shared in the conflict with the blessed soul, are known to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:28
verses.text: These bones He will crown, together with that soul, in the righteous day of His requital, as it is written, "we must stand before the judgment seat of Christ, that each may give an account of the deeds he has done in the body".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:29
verses.text: One coffin held that honoured corpse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:30
verses.text: None other lay by his side.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:31
verses.text: The burial was a noble one; the honours of a martyr were paid him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:32
verses.text: Christians who had welcomed him as a guest and then with their own hands laid him in the grave, have now disinterred him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:33
verses.text: They have wept as men bereaved of a father and a champion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:34
verses.text: But they have sent him to you, for they put your joy before their own consolation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:35
verses.text: Pious were the hands that gave; scrupulously careful were the hands that received.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:36
verses.text: There has been no room for deceit; no room for guile.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:37
verses.text: I bear witness to this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 197:38
verses.text: Let the untainted truth be accepted by you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:1
verses.text: Letter CXCVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:3
verses.text: After the letter conveyed to me by the officiales I have received one other despatched to me later.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:4
verses.text: I have not sent many myself, for I have not found any one travelling in your direction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:5
verses.text: But I have sent more than the four, among which also were those conveyed to me from Samosata after the first epistle of your holiness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:6
verses.text: These I have sealed and sent to our honourable brother Leontius, peraequator of Nicaea, urging that by his agency they may be delivered to the steward of the household of our honourable brother Sophronius, that he may see to their transmission to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:7
verses.text: As my letters are going through many hands, it is likely enough that because one man is very busy or very careless, your reverence may never get them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:8
verses.text: Pardon me, then, I beseech you, if my letters are few.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:9
verses.text: With your usual intelligence you have properly found fault with me for not sending, as I ought, a courier of my own when there was occasion for doing so; but you must understand that we have had a winter of such severity that all the roads were blocked till Easter, and I had no one disposed to brave the difficulties of the journey.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:10
verses.text: For although our clergy do seem very numerous, they are men inexperienced in travelling because they never traffic, and prefer not to live far away from home, the majority of them plying sedentary crafts, whereby they get their daily bread.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:11
verses.text: The brother whom I have now sent to your reverence I have summoned from the country, and employed in the conveyance of my letter to your holiness, that he may both give you clear intelligence as to me and my affairs, and, moreover, by God's grace, bring me back plain and prompt information about you and yours.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:12
verses.text: Our dear brother Eusebius the reader has for some time been anxious to hasten to your holiness, but I have kept him here for the weather to improve.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:13
verses.text: Even now I am under no little anxiety lest his inexperience in travelling may cause him trouble, and bring on some illness; for he is not robust.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:15
verses.text: I need say nothing to you by letter about the innovations of the East, for the brothers can themselves give you accurate information.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:16
verses.text: You must know, my honoured friend, that, when I was writing these words, I was so ill that I had lost all hope of life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:17
verses.text: It is impossible for me to enumerate all my painful symptoms, my weakness, the violence of my attacks of fever, and my bad health in general.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:18
verses.text: One point only may be selected.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 198:19
verses.text: I have now completed the time of my sojourn in this miserable and painful life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:1
verses.text: Letter CXCIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:2
verses.text: Canonica Secunda.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:3
verses.text: To Amphilochius, concerning the Canons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:4
verses.text: I wrote some time ago in reply to the questions of your reverence, but I did not send the letter, partly because from my long and dangerous illness I had not time to do so; partly because I had no one to send with it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:5
verses.text: I have but few men with me who are experienced in travelling and fit for service of this kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:6
verses.text: When you thus learn the causes of my delay, forgive me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:7
verses.text: I have been quite astonished at your readiness to learn and at your humility.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:8
verses.text: You are entrusted with the office of a teacher, and yet you condescend to learn, and to learn of me, who pretend to no great knowledge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:9
verses.text: Nevertheless, since you consent, on account of your fear of God, to do what another man might hesitate to do, I am bound for my part to go even beyond my strength in aiding your readiness and righteous zeal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:10
verses.text: XVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:11
verses.text: You asked me about the presbyter Bianor—can he be admitted among the clergy, because of his oath? I know that I have already given the clergy of Antioch a general sentence in the case of all those who had sworn with him; namely, that they should abstain from the public congregations, but might perform priestly functions in private.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:12
verses.text: Moreover, he has the further liberty for the performance of his ministerial functions, from the fact that his sacred duties lie not at Antioch, but at Iconium; for, as you have written to me yourself, he has chosen to live rather at the latter than at the former place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:13
verses.text: The man in question may, therefore, be received; but your reverence must require him to shew repentance for the rash readiness of the oath which he took before the unbeliever, being unable to bear the trouble of that small peril.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:14
verses.text: XVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:15
verses.text: Concerning fallen virgins, who, after professing a chaste life before the Lord, make their vows vain, because they have fallen under the lusts of the flesh, our fathers, tenderly and meekly making allowance for the infirmities of them that fall, laid down that they might be received after a year, ranking them with the digamists.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:16
verses.text: Since, however, by God's grace the Church grows mightier as she advances, and the order of virgins is becoming more numerous, it is my judgment that careful heed should be given both to the act as it appears upon consideration, and to the mind of Scripture, which may be discovered from the context.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:17
verses.text: Widowhood is inferior to virginity; consequently the sin of the widows comes far behind that of the virgins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:18
verses.text: Let us see what Paul writes to Timothy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:19
verses.text: "The young widows refuse: for when they have begun to wax wanton against Christ, they will marry; having damnation because they have cast off their first faith".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:20
verses.text: If, therefore, a widow lies under a very heavy charge, as setting at naught her faith in Christ, what must we think of the virgin, who is the bride of Christ, and a chosen vessel dedicated to the Lord? It is a grave fault even on the part of a slave to give herself away in secret wedlock and fill the house with impurity, and, by her wicked life, to wrong her owner; but it is forsooth far more shocking for the bride to become an adulteress, and, dishonouring her union with the bridegroom, to yield herself to unchaste indulgence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:21
verses.text: The widow, as being a corrupted slave, is indeed condemned; but the virgin comes under the charge of adultery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:22
verses.text: We call the man who lives with another man's wife an adulterer, and do not receive him into communion until he has ceased from his sin; and so we shall ordain in the case of him who has the virgin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:23
verses.text: One point, however, must be determined beforehand, that the name virgin is given to a woman who voluntarily devotes herself to the Lord, renounces marriage, and embraces a life of holiness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:24
verses.text: And we admit professions dating from the age of full intelligence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:25
verses.text: For it is not right in such cases to admit the words of mere children.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:26
verses.text: But a girl of sixteen or seventeen years of age, in full possession of her faculties, who has been submitted to strict examination, and is then constant, and persists in her entreaty to be admitted, may then be ranked among the virgins, her profession ratified, and its violation rigorously punished.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:27
verses.text: Many girls are brought forward by their parents and brothers, and other kinsfolk, before they are of full age, and have no inner impulse towards a celibate life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:28
verses.text: The object of the friends is simply to provide for themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:29
verses.text: Such women as these must not be readily received, before we have made public investigation of their own sentiments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:30
verses.text: XIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:31
verses.text: I do not recognise the profession of men, except in the case of those who have enrolled themselves in the order of monks, and seem to have secretly adopted the celibate life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:32
verses.text: Yet in their case I think it becoming that there should be a previous examination, and that a distinct profession should be received from them, so that whenever they may revert to the life of the pleasures of the flesh, they may be subjected to the punishment of fornicators.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:33
verses.text: XX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:34
verses.text: I do not think that any condemnation ought to be passed on women who professed virginity while in heresy, and then afterwards preferred marriage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:35
verses.text: "What things soever the law saith, it saith to them who are under the law".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:36
verses.text: Those who have not yet put on Christ's yoke do not recognise the laws of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:37
verses.text: They are therefore to be received in the church, as having remission in the case of these sins too, as of all, from their faith in Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:38
verses.text: As a general rule, all sins formerly committed in the catechumenical state are not taken into account.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:39
verses.text: The Church does not receive these persons without baptism; and it is very necessary that in such cases the birthrights should be observed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:40
verses.text: XXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:41
verses.text: If a man living with a wife is not satisfied with his marriage and falls into fornication, I account him a fornicator, and prolong his period of punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:42
verses.text: Nevertheless, we have no canon subjecting him to the charge of adultery, if the sin be committed against an unmarried woman.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:43
verses.text: For the adulteress, it is said, "being polluted shall be polluted," and she shall not return to her husband: and "He that keepeth an adulteress is a fool and impious".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:44
verses.text: He, however, who has committed fornication is not to be cut off from the society of his own wife.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:45
verses.text: So the wife will receive the husband on his return from fornication, but the husband will expel the polluted woman from his house.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:46
verses.text: The argument here is not easy, but the custom has so obtained.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:47
verses.text: XXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:48
verses.text: Men who keep women carried off by violence, if they carried them off when betrothed to other men, must not be received before removal of the women and their restoration to those to whom they were first contracted, whether they wish to receive them, or to separate from them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:49
verses.text: In the case of a girl who has been taken when not betrothed, she ought first to be removed, and restored to her own people, and handed over to the will of her own people whether parents, or brothers, or any one having authority over her.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:50
verses.text: If they choose to give her up, the cohabitation may stand; but, if they refuse, no violence should be used.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:51
verses.text: In the case of a man having a wife by seduction, be it secret or by violence, he must be held guilty of fornication.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:52
verses.text: The punishment of fornicators is fixed at four years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:53
verses.text: In the first year they must be expelled from prayer, and weep at the door of the church; in the second they may be received to sermon; in the third to penance; in the fourth to standing with the people, while they are withheld from the oblation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:54
verses.text: Finally, they may be admitted to the communion of the good gift.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:55
verses.text: XXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:56
verses.text: Concerning men who marry two sisters, or women who marry two brothers a short letter of mine has been published, of which I have sent a copy to your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:57
verses.text: The man who has taken his own brother's wife is not to be received until he have separated from her.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:58
verses.text: XXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:59
verses.text: A widow whose name is in the list of widows, that is, who is supported by the Church, is ordered by the Apostle to be supported no longer when she marries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:60
verses.text: There is no special rule for a widower.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:61
verses.text: The punishment appointed for digamy may suffice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:62
verses.text: If a widow who is sixty years of age chooses again to live with a husband, she shall be held unworthy of the communion of the good gift until she be moved no longer by her impure desire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:63
verses.text: If we reckon her before sixty years, the blame rests with us, and not with the woman.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:64
verses.text: XXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:65
verses.text: The man who retains as his wife the woman whom he has violated, shall be liable to the penalty of rape, but it shall be lawful for him to have her to wife.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:66
verses.text: XXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:67
verses.text: Fornication is not wedlock, nor yet the beginning of wedlock.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:68
verses.text: Wherefore it is best, if possible, to put asunder those who are united in fornication.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:69
verses.text: If they are set on cohabitation, let them admit the penalty of fornication.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:70
verses.text: Let them be allowed to live together, lest a worse thing happen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:71
verses.text: XXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:72
verses.text: As to the priest ignorantly involved in an illegal marriage, I have made the fitting regulation, that he may hold his seat, but must abstain from other functions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:73
verses.text: For such a case pardon is enough.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:74
verses.text: It is unreasonable that the man who has to treat his own wounds should be blessing another, for benediction is the imparting of holiness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:75
verses.text: How can he who through his fault, committed in ignorance, is without holiness, impart it to another? Let him bless neither in public nor in private, nor distribute the body of Christ to others, nor perform any other sacred function, but, content with his seat of honour, let him beseech the Lord with weeping, that his sin, committed in ignorance, may be forgiven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:76
verses.text: XXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:77
verses.text: It has seemed to me ridiculous that any one should make a vow to abstain from swine's flesh.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:78
verses.text: Be so good as to teach men to abstain from foolish vows and promises.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:79
verses.text: Represent the use to be quite indifferent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:80
verses.text: No creature of God, received with thanksgiving, is to be rejected.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:81
verses.text: The vow is ridiculous; the abstinence unnecessary.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:82
verses.text: XXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:83
verses.text: It is especially desirable that attention should be given to the case of persons in power who threaten on oath to do some hurt to those under their authority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:84
verses.text: The remedy is twofold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:85
verses.text: In the first place, let them be taught not to take oaths at random: secondly, not to persist in their wicked determinations.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:86
verses.text: Any one who is arrested in the design of fulfilling an oath to injure another ought to shew repentance for the rashness of his oath, and must not confirm his wickedness under the pretext of piety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:87
verses.text: Herod was none the better for fulfilling his oath, when, of course only to save himself from perjury, he became the prophet's murderer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:88
verses.text: Swearing is absolutely forbidden, and it is only reasonable that the oath which tends to evil should be condemned.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:89
verses.text: The swearer must therefore change his mind, and not persist in confirming his impiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:90
verses.text: Consider the absurdity of the thing a little further.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:91
verses.text: Suppose a man to swear that he will put his brother's eyes out: is it well for him to carry his oath into action? Or to commit murder? or to break any other commandment? "I have sworn, and I will perform it," not to sin, but to "keep thy righteous judgments".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:92
verses.text: It is no less our duty to undo and destroy sin, than it is to confirm the commandment by immutable counsels.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:93
verses.text: XXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:94
verses.text: As to those guilty of abduction we have no ancient rule, but I have expressed my own judgment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:95
verses.text: The period is three years; the culprits and their accomplices to be excluded from service.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:96
verses.text: The act committed without violence is not liable to punishment, whenever it has not been preceded by violation or robbery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:97
verses.text: The widow is independent, and to follow or not is in her own power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:98
verses.text: We must, therefore, pay no heed to excuses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:99
verses.text: XXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:100
verses.text: A woman whose husband has gone away and disappeared, and who marries another, before she has evidence of his death, commits adultery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:101
verses.text: Clerics who are guilty of the sin unto death are degraded from their order, but not excluded from the communion of the laity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:102
verses.text: Thou shalt not punish twice for the same fault.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:103
verses.text: XXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:104
verses.text: Let an indictment for murder be preferred against the woman who gives birth to a child on the road and pays no attention to it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:105
verses.text: XXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:106
verses.text: Women who had committed adultery, and confessed their fault through piety, or were in any way convicted, were not allowed by our fathers to be publicly exposed, that we might not cause their death after conviction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:107
verses.text: But they ordered that they should be excluded from communion till they had fulfilled their term of penance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:108
verses.text: XXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:109
verses.text: In the case of a man deserted by his wife, the cause of the desertion must be taken into account.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:110
verses.text: If she appear to have abandoned him without reason, he is deserving of pardon, but the wife of punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:111
verses.text: Pardon will be given to him that he may communicate with the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:112
verses.text: XXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:113
verses.text: Soldiers' wives who have married in their husbands' absence will come under the same principle as wives who, when their husbands have been on a journey, have not waited their return.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:114
verses.text: Their case, however, does admit of some concession on the ground of there being greater reason to suspect death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:115
verses.text: XXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:116
verses.text: The man who marries after abducting another man's wife will incur the charge of adultery for the first case; but for the second will go free.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:117
verses.text: XXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:118
verses.text: Girls who follow against their fathers' will commit fornication; but if their fathers are reconciled to them, the act seems to admit of a remedy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:119
verses.text: They are not however immediately restored to communion, but are to be punished for three years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:120
verses.text: XXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:121
verses.text: The woman who lives with an adulterer is an adulteress the whole time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:122
verses.text: XL.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:123
verses.text: The woman who yields to a man against her master's will commits fornication; but if afterwards she accepts free marriage, she marries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:124
verses.text: The former case is fornication; the latter marriage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:125
verses.text: The covenants of persons who are not independent have no validity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:126
verses.text: XLI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:127
verses.text: The woman in widowhood, who is independent, may dwell with a husband without blame, if there is no one to prevent their cohabitation; for the Apostle says; "but if her husband be dead, she is at liberty to be married to whom she will; only in the Lord".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:128
verses.text: XLII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:129
verses.text: Marriages contracted without the permission of those in authority, are fornication.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:130
verses.text: If neither father nor master be living the contracting parties are free from blame; just as if the authorities assent to the cohabitation, it assumes the fixity of marriage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:131
verses.text: XLIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:132
verses.text: He who smites his neighbour to death is a murderer, whether he struck first or in self defence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:133
verses.text: XLIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:134
verses.text: The deaconess who commits fornication with a heathen may be received into repentance and will be admitted to the oblation in the seventh year; of course if she be living in chastity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:135
verses.text: The heathen who, after he has believed, takes to idolatry, returns to his vomit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:136
verses.text: We do not, however, give up the body of the deaconess to the use of the flesh, as being consecrated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:137
verses.text: XLV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:138
verses.text: If any one, after taking the name of Christianity, insults Christ, he gets no good from the name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:139
verses.text: XLVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:140
verses.text: The woman who unwillingly marries a man deserted at the time by his wife, and is afterwards repudiated, because of the return of the former to him, commits fornication, but involuntarily.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:141
verses.text: She will, therefore, not be prohibited from marriage; but it is better if she remain as she is.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:142
verses.text: XLVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:143
verses.text: Encratitae, Saccophori, and Apotactitae are not regarded in the same manner as Novatians, since in their case a canon has been pronounced, although different; while of the former nothing has been said.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:144
verses.text: All these I re-baptize on the same principle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:145
verses.text: If among you their re-baptism is forbidden, for the sake of some arrangement, nevertheless let my principle prevail.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:146
verses.text: Their heresy is, as it were, an offshoot of the Marcionites, abominating, as they do, marriage, refusing wine, and calling God's creature polluted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:147
verses.text: We do not therefore receive them into the Church, unless they be baptized into our baptism.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:148
verses.text: Let them not say that they have been baptized into Father, Son and Holy Ghost, inasmuch as they make God the author of evil, after the example of Marcion and the rest of the heresies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:149
verses.text: Wherefore, if this be determined on, more bishops ought to meet together in one place and publish the canon in these terms, that action may be taken without peril, and authority given to answers to questions of this kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:150
verses.text: XLVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:151
verses.text: The woman who has been abandoned by her husband, ought, in my judgment, to remain as she is.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:152
verses.text: The Lord said, "If any one leave his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, he causeth her to commit adultery;" thus, by calling her adulteress, He excludes her from intercourse with another man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:153
verses.text: For how can the man being guilty, as having caused adultery, and the woman, go without blame, when she is called adulteress by the Lord for having intercourse with another man?  XLIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:154
verses.text: Suffering violation should not be a cause of condemnation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:155
verses.text: So the slave girl, if she has been forced by her own master, is free from blame.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:156
verses.text: L.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:157
verses.text: There is no law as to trigamy: a third marriage is not contracted by law.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:158
verses.text: We look upon such things as the defilements of the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 199:159
verses.text: But we do not subject them to public condemnation, as being better than unrestrained fornication.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:1
verses.text: Letter CC.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:3
verses.text: I am attacked by sickness after sickness, and all the work given me, not only by the affairs of the Church, but by those who are troubling the Church, has detained me during the whole winter, and up to the present time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:4
verses.text: It has been therefore quite impossible for me to send any one to you or to pay you a visit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:5
verses.text: I conjecture that you are similarly situated; not, indeed, as to sickness, God forbid; may the Lord grant you continued health for carrying out His commandments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:6
verses.text: But I know that the care of the Churches gives you the same distress as it does me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:7
verses.text: I was now about to send some one to get me accurate information about your condition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:8
verses.text: But when my well beloved son Meletius, who is moving the newly enlisted troops, reminded me of the opportunity of my saluting you by him, I gladly accepted the occasion to write and had recourse to the kind services of the conveyor of my letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:9
verses.text: He is one who may himself serve instead of a letter, both because of his amiable disposition, and of his being well acquainted with all which concerns me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:10
verses.text: By him, then, I beseech your reverence especially to pray for me, that the Lord may grant to me a riddance from this troublesome body of mine; to His Churches, peace; and to you, rest; and, whenever you have settled the affairs of Lycaonia in apostolic fashion, as you have began, an opportunity to visit also this place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:11
verses.text: Whether I be sojourning in the flesh, or shall have been already bidden to take my departure to the Lord, I hope that you will interest yourself in our part of the world, as your own, as indeed it is, strengthening all that is weak, rousing all that is slothful and, by the help of the Spirit Which abides in you, transforming everything into a condition well pleasing to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:12
verses.text: My very honourable sons, Meletius and Melitius, whom you have known for some time, and know to be devoted to yourself, keep in your good care and pray for them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:13
verses.text: This is enough to keep them in safety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:14
verses.text: Salute in my name, I beg you, all who are with your holiness, both all the clergy, and all the laity under your pastoral care, and my very religious brothers and fellow ministers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:15
verses.text: Bear in mind the memory of the blessed martyr Eupsychius, and do not wait for me to mention him again.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:16
verses.text: Do not take pains to come on the exact day, but anticipate it, and so give me joy, if I be yet living on this earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 200:17
verses.text: Till then may you, by the grace of the Holy One, be preserved for me and for God's Churches, enjoying health and wealth in the Lord, and praying for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 201:1
verses.text: Letter CCI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 201:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 201:3
verses.text: I long to meet you for many reasons, that I may have the benefit of your advice in the matters I had in hand, and that on beholding you after a long interval I may have some comfort for your absence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 201:4
verses.text: But since both of us are prevented by the same reasons, you by the illness which has befallen you, and I by the malady of longer standing which has not yet left me, let us, if you will, each forgive the other, that both may free ourselves from blame.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 202:1
verses.text: Letter CCII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 202:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 202:3
verses.text: Under other circumstances I should think it a special privilege to meet with your reverence, but above all now, when the business which brings us together is of such great importance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 202:4
verses.text: But so much of my illness as still clings to me is enough to prevent my stirring ever so short a distance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 202:5
verses.text: I tried to drive as far as the martyrs and had a relapse almost into my old state.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 202:6
verses.text: You must therefore forgive me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 202:7
verses.text: If the matter can be put off for a few days, I will, by God's grace join you, and share your anxieties.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 202:8
verses.text: If the business presses, do, by God's help, what has to be done; but reckon me as present with you and as participating in your worthy deeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 202:9
verses.text: May you, by the grace of the Holy One, be preserved to God's Church, strong and joyous in the Lord, and praying for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:1
verses.text: Letter CCIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:2
verses.text: To the bishops of the sea coast.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:3
verses.text: I have had a strong desire to meet you, but from time to time some hindrance has supervened and prevented my fulfilling my purpose.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:4
verses.text: I have either been hindered by sickness, and you know well how, from my early manhood to my present old age, this ailment has been my constant companion, brought up with me, and chastising me, by the righteous judgment of God, Who ordains all things in wisdom; or by the cares of the Church, or by struggles with the opponents of the doctrines of truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:5
verses.text: [Up to this day I live in much affliction and grief, having the feeling present before me, that you are wanting to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:6
verses.text: For when God tells me, who took on Him His sojourn in the flesh for the very purpose that, by patterns of duty, He might regulate our life, and might by His own voice announce to us the Gospel of the kingdom,—when He says, 'By this shall all men know that ye are my disciples, if ye love one another,' and whereas the Lord left His own peace to His disciples as a farewell gift, when about to complete the dispensation in the flesh, saying, 'Peace I leave with you, My peace I give you,' I cannot persuade myself that without love to others, and without, as far as rests with me, peaceableness towards all, I can be called a worthy servant of Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:7
verses.text: I have waited a long while for the chance of your love paying us a visit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:8
verses.text: For ye are not ignorant that we, being exposed to all, as rocks running out in the sea, sustain the fury of the heretical waves, which, in that they break around us, do not cover the district behind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:9
verses.text: I say "we" in order to refer it, not to human power, but to the grace of God, Who, by the weakness of men shows His power, as says the prophet in the person of the Lord, 'Will ye not fear Me, who have placed the sand as a boundary to the sea?' for by the weakest and most contemptible of all things, the sand, the Mighty One has bounded the great and full sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:10
verses.text: Since, then, this is our position, it became your love to be frequent in sending true brothers to visit us who labour with the storm, and more frequently letters of love, partly to confirm our courage, partly to correct any mistake of ours.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:11
verses.text: For we confess that we are liable to numberless mistakes, being men, and living in the flesh.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:13
verses.text: But hitherto, very honourable brethren, you have not given me my due; and this for two reasons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:14
verses.text: Either you failed to perceive the proper course; or else, under the influence of some of the calumnies spread abroad about me, you did not think me deserving of being visited by you in love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:15
verses.text: Now, therefore, I myself take the initiative.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:16
verses.text: I beg to state that I am perfectly ready to rid myself, in your presence, of the charges urged against me, but only on condition that my revilers are admitted to stand face to face with me before your reverences.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:17
verses.text: If I am convicted, I shall not deny my error.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:18
verses.text: You, after the conviction, will receive pardon from the Lord for withdrawing yourselves from the communion of me a sinner.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:19
verses.text: The successful accusers, too, will have their reward in the publication of my secret wickedness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:20
verses.text: If, however, you condemn me before you have the evidence before you, I shall be none the worse, barring the loss I shall sustain of a possession I hold most dear—your love: while you, for your part, will suffer the same loss in losing me, and will seem to be running counter to the words of the Gospel: "Doth our law judge any man before it hear him?" The reviler, moreover, if he adduce no proof of what he says, will be shewn to have got nothing from his wicked language but a bad name for himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:21
verses.text: For what name can be properly applied to the slanderer except that which he professes to bear by the very conduct of which he is guilty? Let the reviler, therefore, appear not as slanderer, but as accuser; nay, I will not call him accuser, I will rather regard him as a brother, admonishing in love, and producing conviction for my amendment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:22
verses.text: And you must not be hearers of calumny, but triers of proof.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:23
verses.text: Nor must I be left uncured, because my sin is not being made manifest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:25
verses.text: Let not this consideration influence you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:26
verses.text: 'We dwell on the sea, we are exempt from the sufferings of the generality, we need no succour from others; so what is the good to us of foreign communion?' For the same Lord Who divided the islands from the continent by the sea, bound the island Christians to those of the continent by love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:27
verses.text: Nothing, brethren, separates us from each other, but deliberate estrangement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:28
verses.text: We have one Lord, one faith, the same hope.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:29
verses.text: The hands need each other; the feet steady each other.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:30
verses.text: The eyes possess their clear apprehension from agreement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:31
verses.text: We, for our part, confess our own weakness, and we seek your fellow feeling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:32
verses.text: For we are assured, that though ye are not present in body, yet by the aid of prayer, ye will do us much benefit in these most critical times.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:33
verses.text: It is neither decorous before men, nor pleasing to God, that you should make avowals which not even the Gentiles adopt, which know not God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:34
verses.text: Even they, as we hear, though the country they live in be sufficient for all things, yet, on account of the uncertainty of the future, make much of alliances with each other, and seek mutual intercourse as being advantageous to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:35
verses.text: Yet we, the sons of fathers who have laid down the law that by brief notes the proofs of communion should be carried about from one end of the earth to the other, and that all should be citizens and familiars with all, now sever ourselves from the whole world, and are neither ashamed at our solitariness, nor shudder that on us is fallen the fearful prophecy of the Lord, 'Because of lawlessness abounding, the love of the many shall wax cold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:37
verses.text: Do not, most honourable brethren, do not suffer this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:38
verses.text: Rather, by letters of peace and by salutations of love, comfort me for the past.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:39
verses.text: You have made a wound in my heart by your former neglect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:40
verses.text: Soothe its anguish, as it were, by a tender touch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:41
verses.text: Whether you wish to come to me, and examine for yourselves into the truth of what you hear of my infirmities, or whether by the addition of more lies my sins are reported to you to be yet more grievous, I must accept even this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:42
verses.text: I am ready to welcome you with open hands and to offer myself to the strictest test, only let love preside over the proceedings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:43
verses.text: Or if you prefer to indicate any spot in your own district to which I may come and pay you the visit which is due, submitting myself, as far as may be, to examination, for the healing of the past, and the prevention of slander for the future, I accept this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:44
verses.text: Although my flesh is weak, yet, as long as I breathe, I am responsible for the due discharge of every duty which may tend to the edification of the Churches of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:45
verses.text: Do not, I beseech you, make light of my entreaty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:46
verses.text: Do not force me to disclose my distress to others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:47
verses.text: Hitherto, brethren, as you are well aware, I have kept my grief to myself, for I blush to speak of your alienation from me to those of our communion who are at a distance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:48
verses.text: I shrink at once from paining them and from gratifying those who hate me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:49
verses.text: I alone am writing this now; but I send in the name of all the brethren in Cappadocia, who have charged me not to employ any chance messenger, but some one who, in case I should, from my anxiety not to be too prolix, leave out any points of importance, might supply them with the intelligence wherewith God has gifted him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:50
verses.text: I refer to my beloved and reverend fellow presbyter Petrus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 203:51
verses.text: Welcome him in love, and send him forth to me in peace, that he may be a messenger to me of good things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:1
verses.text: Letter CCIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:2
verses.text: To the Neocaesareans.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:4
verses.text: [There has been a long silence on both sides, revered and well-beloved brethren, just as if there were angry feelings between us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:5
verses.text: Yet who is there so sullen and implacable towards the party which has injured him, as to lengthen out the resentment which has begun in disgust through almost a whole life of man?] This [is happening in our case, no just occasion of estrangement existing, as far as I myself know, but on the contrary, there being, from the first, many strong reasons for the closest friendship and unity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:6
verses.text: The greatest and first is this, our Lord's command, pointedly saying, "By this shall all men know that ye are my disciples if ye have love one to another".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:7
verses.text: ] Again, the apostle clearly sets before us the good of charity where he tells us that love is the fulfilling of the law; and again where he says that charity is a good thing to be preferred to all great and good things, in the words, "Though I speak with tongues of men and of angels and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass or a tinkling cymbal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:8
verses.text: And though I have the gift of prophecy and understand all mysteries, and all knowledge; and though I have all faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:9
verses.text: And though I bestow all my goods to feed the poor and though I give my body to be burnt and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:10
verses.text: Not that each of the points enumerated could be performed without love, but that the Holy One wishes, as He Himself has said, to attribute to the commandment super-eminent excellency by the figure of hyperbole.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:12
verses.text: [Next, if it tend much towards intimacy to have the same teachers, there are to you and to me the same teachers of God's mysteries, and spiritual Fathers, who from the beginning were the founders of your Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:13
verses.text: I mean the great Gregory, and all who succeeding in order to the throne of your episcopate, like stars rising one after another, have tracked the same course, so as to leave the tokens of the heavenly polity most clear to all who desire them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:14
verses.text: ] And if natural relationships are not to be despised, but are greatly conducive to unbroken union and fellowship, these rights also exist naturally for you and me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:15
verses.text: [Why is it, then, O venerable among cities, for through you I address the whole city, that no civil writing comes from you, no welcome voice, but your ears are open to those who aim at slander?] I am therefore the more bound to groan, the more I perceive the end they have in view.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:16
verses.text: There is no doubt as to who is the originator of the slander.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:17
verses.text: He is known by many evil deeds, but is best distinguished by this particular wickedness, and it is for this reason that the sin is made his name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:18
verses.text: But you must put up with my plain speaking.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:19
verses.text: You have opened both ears to my slanderers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:20
verses.text: You heartily welcome all you hear without any enquiry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:21
verses.text: Not one of you distinguishes between lies and truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:22
verses.text: Who ever suffered for lack of wicked accusations when struggling all alone? Who was ever convicted of lying in the absence of his victim? What plea does not sound plausible to the hearers when the reviler persists that such and such is the case, and the reviled is neither present nor hears what is urged against him? Does not even the accepted custom of this world teach you, in reference to these matters, that if any one is to be a fair and impartial hearer, he must not be entirely led away by the first speaker, but must wait for the defence of the accused, that so truth may be demonstrated by a comparison of the arguments on both sides? "Judge righteous judgment".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:23
verses.text: This precept is one of those most necessary for salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:25
verses.text: When I say this I am not forgetful of the words of the Apostle, who fled from human tribunals and reserved the defence of all his life for the unerring judgment seat, when he said, "With me it is a very small thing that I should be judged of you or of man's judgment".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:26
verses.text: Your ears have been preoccupied by lying slanders, slanders that have touched my conduct, slanders that have touched my faith in God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:27
verses.text: Nevertheless, knowing, as I do, that three persons at once are injured by the slanderer, his victim, his hearer, and himself; as to my own wrong, I would have held my tongue, be sure; not because I despise your good opinion, (how could I, writing now as I do and earnestly pleading as I do that I may not lose it?) but because I see that of the three sufferers the one who is least injured is myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:28
verses.text: It is true that I shall be robbed of you, but you are being robbed of the truth, and he who is at the bottom of all this is parting me from you, but he is alienating himself from the Lord, inasmuch as no one can be brought near to the Lord by doing what is forbidden.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:29
verses.text: Rather then for your sakes than for mine, rather to rescue you from unendurable wrong am I pleading.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:30
verses.text: For who could suffer a worse calamity than the loss of the most precious of all things, the truth?  4.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:31
verses.text: [What say I, brethren? Not that I am a sinless person; not that my life is not full of numberless faults.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:32
verses.text: I know myself; and indeed I cease not my tears for my sins, if by any means I may be able to appease my God, and to escape the punishment threatened against them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:33
verses.text: But this I say: let him who judges me, hunt for motes in my eye, if he can say that his own is clear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:34
verses.text: ] I own, brethren, that I need the care of the sound and healthy, and need much of it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:35
verses.text: If he cannot say that it is clear, and the clearer it is the less will he say so—(for it is the part of the perfect not to exalt themselves; if they do they will certainly come under the charge of the pride of the Pharisee, who, while justifying himself, condemned the publican) let him come with me to the physician; let him not "judge before the time until the Lord come, who both will bring to light the hidden things of darkness, and will make manifest the counsels of the hearts".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:36
verses.text: Let him remember the words, "Judge not, and ye shall not be judged;" and "Condemn not, and ye shall not be condemned".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:37
verses.text: [In a word, brethren, if my offences admit of cure, why does not such an one obey the teacher of the Churches, "Reprove, exhort, rebuke"? If, on the other hand, my iniquity be past cure, why does he not withstand me to the face, and, by publishing my transgressions, deliver the Churches from the mischief which I bring on them?] Do not put up with the calumny uttered against me within the teeth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:38
verses.text: This is the abuse which any slave-girl from the grindstone might utter; this is the kind of fine shewing-off you might expect from any street vagabond; their tongues are whetted for any slander.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:39
verses.text: But [there are bishops; let appeal be made to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:40
verses.text: There is a clergy in each of God's dioceses; let the most eminent be assembled.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:41
verses.text: Let whoso will, speak freely, that I may have to deal with a charge, not a slander.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:42
verses.text: ] Let my secret wickedness be brought into full view; let me no longer be hated, but admonished as a brother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:43
verses.text: It is more just that we sinners should be pitied by the blessed and the sinless, than that we should be treated angrily.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:45
verses.text: [If the fault be a point of faith, let the document be pointed out to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:46
verses.text: Again, let a fair and impartial inquiry be appointed.
