verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:47
verses.text: Let the accusation be read; let it be brought to the test, whether it does not arise from ignorance in the accuser, not from blame in the matter of the writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:48
verses.text: For right things often do not seem such to those who are deficient in accurate judgment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:49
verses.text: Equal weights seem unequal when the arms of the balance are of different sizes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:50
verses.text: ] Men whose sense of taste is destroyed by sickness, sometimes think honey sour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:51
verses.text: A diseased eye does not see many things which do exist, and notes many things which do not exist.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:52
verses.text: The same thing frequently takes place with regard to the force of words, when the critic is inferior to the writer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:53
verses.text: The critic ought really to set out with much the same training and equipment as the author.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:54
verses.text: A man ignorant of agriculture is quite incapable of criticising husbandry, and the distinctions between harmony and discord can only be adequately judged by a trained musician.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:55
verses.text: But any one who chooses will set up for a literary critic, though he cannot tell us where he went to school, or how much time was spent in his education, and knows nothing about letters at all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:56
verses.text: I see clearly that, even in the case of the words of the Holy Spirit, the investigation of the terms is to be attempted not by every one, but by him who has the spirit of discernment, as the Apostle has taught us, in the differences of gifts;—"For to one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom; to another the word of knowledge by the same Spirit; to another faith by the same Spirit; to another the gift of healing by the same Spirit; to another the working of miracles; to another prophecy; to another discerning of spirits".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:57
verses.text: If, therefore, my gifts are spiritual, he who wishes to judge them must shew proof of his own possession of the gift of "discerning of spirits".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:58
verses.text: If, on the contrary, as he calumniously contends, my gifts are of the wisdom of this world, let him shew that he is an adept in this world's wisdom, and I will submit myself to his verdict.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:59
verses.text: And [let no one suppose that I am making excuses to evade the charge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:60
verses.text: I put it into your hands, dearest brethren, to investigate for yourselves the points alleged against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:61
verses.text: Are you so slow of intelligence as to be wholly dependent upon advocates for the discovery of the truth? If the points in question seem to you to be quite plain of themselves, persuade the jesters to drop the dispute.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:62
verses.text: [If there be anything you do not understand, put questions to me, through appointed persons who will do justice to me; or ask of me explanations in writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:63
verses.text: And take all kinds of pains that nothing may be left unsifted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:65
verses.text: What clearer evidence can there be of my faith, than that I was brought up by my grandmother, blessed woman, who came from you? I mean the celebrated Macrina who taught me the words of the blessed Gregory; which, as far as memory had preserved down to her day, she cherished herself, while she fashioned and formed me, while yet a child, upon the doctrines of piety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:66
verses.text: And when I gained the capacity of thought, my reason being matured by full age, I travelled over much sea and land, and whomsoever I found walking in the rule of godliness delivered, those I set down as fathers,] and made them my soul's guides in my journey to God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:67
verses.text: And up to this day, by the grace of Him who has called me in His holy calling to the knowledge of Himself, I know of no doctrine opposed to the sound teaching having sunk into my heart; nor was my soul ever polluted by the ill-famed blasphemy of Arius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:68
verses.text: If I have ever received into communion any who have come from that teacher, hiding their unsoundness deep within them, or speaking words of piety, or, at any rate, not opposing what has been said by me, it is on these terms that I have admitted them; and I have not allowed my judgment concerning them to rest wholly with myself, but have followed the decisions given about them by our Fathers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:69
verses.text: For after receiving the letter of the very blessed Father Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria, which I hold in my hand, and shew to any one who asks, wherein he has distinctly declared that any one expressing a wish to come over from the heresy of the Arians and accepting the Nicene Creed, is to be received without hesitation and difficulty, citing in support of his opinion the unanimous assent of the bishops of Macedonia and of Asia; I, considering myself bound to follow the high authority of such a man and of those who made the rule, and with every desire on my own part to win the reward promised to peacemakers, did enroll in the lists of communicants all who accepted that creed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:71
verses.text: [The fair thing would be to judge of me, not from one or two who do not walk uprightly in the truth, but from the multitude of bishops throughout the world, connected with me by the grace of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:72
verses.text: Make enquiries of Pisidians, Lycaonians, Isaurians, Phrygians of both provinces, Armenians your neighbours, Macedonians, Achaeans, Illyrians, Gauls, Spaniards, the whole of Italy, Sicilians, Africans, the healthy part of Egypt, whatever is left of Syria; all of whom send letters to me, and in turn receive them from me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:73
verses.text: ] From these letters, alike from all which are despatched from them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:74
verses.text: and from all which go out from us to them, you may learn that we are all of one mind, and of one opinion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:75
verses.text: [Whoso shuns communion with me, it cannot escape your accuracy, cuts himself off from the whole Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:76
verses.text: Look round about, brethren, with whom do you hold communion? If you will not receive it from me, who remains to acknowledge you? Do not reduce me to the necessity of counselling anything unpleasant concerning a Church so dear to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:77
verses.text: ] There are things now which I hide in the bottom of my heart, in secret groaning over and bewailing the evil days in which we live, in that the greatest Churches which have long been united to one another in brotherly love, now, without any reason, are in mutual opposition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:78
verses.text: Do not, oh! do not, drive me to complain of these things to all who are in communion with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:79
verses.text: Do not force me to give utterance to words which hitherto I have kept in check by reflection and have hidden in my heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:80
verses.text: Better were it for me to be removed and the Churches to be at one, than that God's people should suffer such evil through our childish ill-will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:81
verses.text: [Ask your fathers, and they will tell you that though our districts were divided in position, yet in mind they were one, and were governed by one sentiment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 204:82
verses.text: Intercourse of the people was frequent; frequent the visits of the clergy; the pastors, too, had such mutual affection, that each used the other as teacher and guide in things pertaining to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 205:1
verses.text: Letter CCV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 205:2
verses.text: To Elpidius the bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 205:3
verses.text: Once again I have started the well-beloved presbyter Meletius to carry my greeting to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 205:4
verses.text: I had positively determined to spare him, on account of the weakness which he has voluntarily brought upon himself, by bringing his body into subjection for the sake of the gospel of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 205:5
verses.text: But I have judged it fitting to salute you by the ministry of such men as he is, able to supply of themselves all the shortcomings of my letter, and to become, alike to writer and recipient, a kind of living epistle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 205:6
verses.text: I am also carrying out the very strong wish, which he has always had, to see your excellency, ever since he has had experience of the high qualities you possess.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 205:7
verses.text: So now I have besought him to travel to you, and through him I discharge the debt of the visit I owe you, and beseech you to pray for me and for the Church of God, that the Lord may grant me deliverance from the injuries of the enemies of the Gospel, and to pass my life in peace and quiet.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 205:8
verses.text: Nevertheless, if you in your wisdom, think it needful that we should travel to the same spot, and meet the rest of our right honourable brother bishops of the sea board regions, do you yourself point out a suitable place and time where and when this meeting may take place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 205:9
verses.text: Write to our brethren to the end that each and all may, at the appointed time, leave the business they may have in hand, and may be able to effect something for the edification of the Churches of God, do away with the pain which we now suffer from our mutual suspicions, and establish love, without which the Lord Himself has ordained that obedience to every commandment must be of none effect.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:1
verses.text: Letter CCVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:2
verses.text: To Elpidius the bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:3
verses.text: Consolatory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:4
verses.text: Now, most of all, do I feel my bodily infirmity, when I see how it stands in the way of my soul's good.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:5
verses.text: Had matters gone as I hoped, I should not now be speaking to you by letter or by messenger, but should in my own person have been paying the debt of affection and enjoying spiritual advantage face to face.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:6
verses.text: Now, however, I am so situated that I am only too glad if I am able even to move about in my own country in the necessary visitation of parishes in my district.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:7
verses.text: But may the Lord grant to you both strength and a ready will, and to me, in addition to my eager desire, ability to enjoy your society when I am in the country of Comana.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:8
verses.text: I am afraid lest your domestic trouble may be some hindrance to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:9
verses.text: For I have learnt of your affliction in the loss of your little boy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:10
verses.text: To a grandfather his death cannot but be grievous.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:11
verses.text: On the other hand to a man who has attained to so high a degree of virtue, and alike from his experience of this world and his spiritual training knows what human nature is, it is natural that the removal of those who are near and dear should not be wholly intolerable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:12
verses.text: The Lord requires from us what He does not require from every one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:13
verses.text: The common mass of mankind lives by habit, but the Christian's rule of life is the commandment of the Lord, and the example of holy men of old, whose greatness of soul was, above all, exhibited in adversity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:14
verses.text: To the end, then, that you may yourself leave to them that come after you an example of fortitude and of genuine trust in what we hope for, show that you are not vanquished by your grief, but are rising above your sorrows, patient in affliction, and rejoicing in hope.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:15
verses.text: Pray let none of these things be a hindrance to our hoped for meeting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:16
verses.text: Children, indeed, are held blameless on account of their tender age; but you and I are under the responsibility of serving the Lord, as He commands us, and in all things to be ready for the administration of the affairs of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 206:17
verses.text: For the due discharge of that duty the Lord has reserved great rewards for faithful and wise stewards.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:1
verses.text: Letter CCVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:2
verses.text: To the clergy of Neocaesarea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:3
verses.text: You all concur in hating me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:4
verses.text: To a man you have followed the leader of the war against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:5
verses.text: I was therefore minded to say not a word to any one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:6
verses.text: I determined that I would write no friendly letter; that I would start no communication, but keep my sorrow in silence to myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:7
verses.text: Yet it is wrong to keep silence in the face of calumny; not that by contradiction we may vindicate ourselves, but that we may not allow a lie to travel further and its victims to be harmed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:8
verses.text: I have therefore thought it necessary to put this matter also before you all, and to write a letter to you, although, when I recently wrote to all the presbyterate in common, you did not do me the honour to send me a reply.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:9
verses.text: Do not, my brethren, gratify the vanity of those who are filling your minds with pernicious opinions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:10
verses.text: Do not consent to look lightly on, when, to your knowledge, God's people are being subverted by impious teaching.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:11
verses.text: None but Sabellius the Libyan and Marcellus the Galatian have dared to teach and write what the leaders of your people are attempting to bring forward among you as their own private discovery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:12
verses.text: They are making a great talk about it, but they are perfectly powerless to give their sophisms and fallacies even any colour of truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:13
verses.text: In their harangues against me they shrink from no wickedness, and persistently refuse to meet me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:14
verses.text: Why? Is it not because they are afraid of being convicted for their own wicked opinions? Yes; and in their attacks upon me they have become so lost to all sense of shame as to invent certain dreams to my discredit while they falsely accuse my teaching of being pernicious.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:15
verses.text: Let them take upon their own heads all the visions of the autumn months; they can fix no blasphemy on me, for in every Church there are many to testify to the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:17
verses.text: When they are asked the reason for this furious and truceless war, they allege psalms and a kind of music varying from the custom which has obtained among you, and similar pretexts of which they ought to be ashamed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:18
verses.text: We are, moreover, accused because we maintain men in the practice of true religion who have renounced the world and all those cares of this life, which the Lord likens to thorns that do not allow the word to bring forth fruit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:19
verses.text: Men of this kind carry about in the body the deadness of Jesus; they have taken up their own cross, and are followers of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:20
verses.text: I would gladly give my life if these really were my faults, and if I had men with me owning me as teacher who had chosen this ascetic life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:21
verses.text: I hear that virtue of this kind is to be found now in Egypt, and there are, peradventure, some men in Palestine whose conversation follows the precepts of the Gospel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:22
verses.text: I am told too that some perfect and blessed men are to be found in Mesopotamia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:23
verses.text: We, in comparison with the perfect, are children.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:24
verses.text: But if women also have chosen to live the Gospel life, preferring virginity to wedlock, leading captive the lust of the flesh, and living in the mourning which is called blessed, they are blessed in their profession wherever they are to be found.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:25
verses.text: We, however, have few instances of this to show, for with us people are still in an elementary stage and are being gradually brought.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:26
verses.text: to piety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:27
verses.text: If any charges of disorder are brought against the life of our women I do not undertake to defend them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:28
verses.text: One thing, however, I do say and that is, that these bold hearts, these unbridled mouths are ever fearlessly uttering what Satan, the father of lies, has hitherto been unable to say.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:29
verses.text: I wish you to know that we rejoice to have assemblies of both men and women, whose conversation is in heaven and who have crucified the flesh with the affections and lusts thereof; they take no thought for food and raiment, but remain undisturbed beside their Lord, continuing night and day in prayer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:30
verses.text: Their lips speak not of the deeds of men: they sing hymns to God continually, working with their own hands that they may have to distribute to them that need.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:32
verses.text: Now as to the charge relating to the singing of psalms, whereby my calumniators specially scare the simpler folk, my reply is this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:33
verses.text: The customs which now obtain are agreeable to those of all the Churches of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:34
verses.text: Among us the people go at night to the house of prayer, and, in distress, affliction, and continual tears, making confession to God, at last rise from their prayers and begin to sing psalms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:35
verses.text: And now, divided into two parts, they sing antiphonally with one another, thus at once confirming their study of the Gospels, and at the same time producing for themselves a heedful temper and a heart free from distraction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:36
verses.text: Afterwards they again commit the prelude of the strain to one, and the rest take it up; and so after passing the night in various psalmody, praying at intervals as the day begins to dawn, all together, as with one voice and one heart, raise the psalm of confession to the Lord, each forming for himself his own expressions of penitence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:37
verses.text: If it is for these reasons that you renounce me, you will renounce the Egyptians; you will renounce both Libyans, Thebans, Palestinians, Arabians, Phoenicians, Syrians, the dwellers by the Euphrates; in a word all those among whom vigils, prayers, and common psalmody have been held in honour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:39
verses.text: But, it is alleged, these practices were not observed in the time of the great Gregory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:40
verses.text: My rejoinder is that even the Litanies which you now use were not used in his time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:41
verses.text: I do not say this to find fault with you; for my prayer would be that every one of you should live in tears and continual penitence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:42
verses.text: We, for our part, are always offering supplication for our sins, but we propitiate our God not as you do, in the words of mere man, but in the oracles of the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:43
verses.text: And what evidence have you that this custom was not followed in the time of the great Gregory? You have kept none of his customs up to the present time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:44
verses.text: Gregory did not cover his head at prayer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:45
verses.text: How could he? He was a true disciple of the Apostle who says, "Every man praying or prophesying, having his head covered, dishonoureth his head".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:46
verses.text: And "a man indeed ought not to cover his head forasmuch as he is the image of God".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:47
verses.text: Oaths were shunned by Gregory, that pure soul, worthy of the fellowship of the Holy Ghost, content with yea and nay, in accordance with the commandment of the Lord Who said, "I say unto you swear not at all".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:48
verses.text: Gregory could not bear to call his brother a fool, for he stood in awe of the threat of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:49
verses.text: Passion, wrath, and bitterness never proceeded out of his mouth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:50
verses.text: Railing he hated, because it leads not to the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:51
verses.text: Envy and arrogance had been shut out of that guiltless soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:52
verses.text: He would never have stood at the altar before being reconciled to his brother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:53
verses.text: A lie, or any word designed to slander any one, he abominated, as one who knew that lies come from the devil, and that the Lord will destroy all that utter a lie.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:54
verses.text: If you have none of these things, and are clear of all, then are you verily disciples of the disciple of the Lord; if not, beware lest, in your disputes about the mode of singing psalms, you are straining at the gnat and setting at naught the greatest of the commandments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:55
verses.text: I have been driven to use these expressions by the urgency of my defence, that you may be taught to cast the beam out of your own eyes before you try to remove other men's motes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:56
verses.text: Nevertheless, I am conceding all, although there is nothing that is not searched into before God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:57
verses.text: Only let great matters prevail, and do not allow innovations in the faith to make themselves heard.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:58
verses.text: Do not disregard the hypostases.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:59
verses.text: Do not deny the name of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:60
verses.text: Do not put a wrong meaning on the words of Gregory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 207:61
verses.text: If you do so, as long as I breathe and have the power of utterance, I cannot keep silence, when I see souls being thus destroyed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 208:1
verses.text: Letter CCVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 208:2
verses.text: To Eulancius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 208:3
verses.text: You have been long silent, though you have very great power of speech, and are well trained in the art of conversation and of exhibiting yourself by your eloquence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 208:4
verses.text: Possibly it is Neocaesarea which is the cause of your not writing to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 208:5
verses.text: I suppose I must take it as a kindness if those who are there do not remember me, for, as I am informed by those who report what they hear, the mention made of me is not kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 208:6
verses.text: You, however, used to be one of those who were disliked for my sake, not one of those who dislike me for the sake of others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 208:7
verses.text: I hope this description will continue to fit you, that wherever you are you will write to me, and will have kindly thoughts of me, if you care at all for what is fair and right.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 208:8
verses.text: It is certainly fair that those who have been first to show affection should be paid in their own coin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 209:1
verses.text: Letter CCIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 209:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 209:3
verses.text: It is your lot to share my distress, and to do battle on my behalf.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 209:4
verses.text: Herein is proof of your manliness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 209:5
verses.text: God, who ordains our lives, grants to those who are capable of sustaining great fights greater opportunity of winning renown.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 209:6
verses.text: You truly have risked your own life as a test of your valour in your friend's behalf, like gold in the furnace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 209:7
verses.text: I pray God that other men may be made better; that you may remain what you are, and that you will not cease to find fault with me, as you do, and to charge me with not writing often to you, as a wrong on my part which does you very great injury.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 209:8
verses.text: This is an accusation only made by a friend.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 209:9
verses.text: Persist in demanding the payment of such debts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 209:10
verses.text: I am not so very unreasonable in paying the claims of affection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:1
verses.text: Letter CCX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:2
verses.text: To the notables of Neocaesarea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:3
verses.text: I am really under no obligation to publish my own mind to you, or to state the reasons for my present sojourn where I am; it is not my custom to indulge in self advertisement, nor is the matter worth publicity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:4
verses.text: I am not, I think, following my own inclinations; I am answering the challenge of your leaders.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:5
verses.text: I have always striven to be ignored more earnestly than popularity hunters strive after notoriety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:6
verses.text: But, I am told, the ears of everybody in your town are set a thrilling, while certain tale-mongers, creators of lies, hired for this very work, are giving you a history of me and my doings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:7
verses.text: I therefore do not think that I ought to overlook your being exposed to the teaching of vile intention and foul tongue; I think that I am bound to tell you myself in what position I am placed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:8
verses.text: From my childhood I have been familiar with this spot, for here I was brought up by my grandmother; hither I have often retreated, and here I have spent many years, when endeavouring to escape from the hubbub of public affairs, for experience has taught me that the quiet and solitude of the spot are favourable to serious thought.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:9
verses.text: Moreover as my brothers are now living here, I have gladly retired to this retreat, and have taken a brief breathing time from the press of the labours that beset me, not as a centre from which I might give trouble to others, but to indulge my own longing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:11
verses.text: Where then is the need of having recourse to dreams and of hiring their interpreters, and making me matter for talk over the cups at public entertainments? Had slander been launched against me in any other quarter, I should have called you to witness to prove what I think, and now I ask every one of you to remember those old days when I was invited by your city to take charge of the education of the young, and a deputation of the first men among you came to see me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:12
verses.text: Afterwards, when you all crowded round me, what were you not ready to give? what not to promise? Nevertheless you were not able to keep me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:13
verses.text: How then could I, who at that time would not listen when you invited me, now attempt to thrust myself on you uninvited? How could I, who when you complimented and admired me, avoided you, have been intending to court you now that you calumniate me? Nothing of the kind, sirs; I am not quite so cheap.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:14
verses.text: No man in his senses would go on board a boat without a steersman, or get alongside a Church where the men sitting at the helm are themselves stirring up tempest and storm.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:15
verses.text: Whose fault was it that the town was all full of tumult, when some were running away with no one after them, and others stealing off when no invader was near, and all the wizards and dream-tellers were flourishing their bogeys? Whose fault was it else? Does not every child know that it was the mob-leaders'? The reasons of their hatred to me it would be bad taste on my part to recount; but they are quite easy for you to apprehend.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:16
verses.text: When bitterness and division have come to the last pitch of savagery, and the explanation of the cause is altogether groundless and ridiculous, then the mental disease is plain, dangerous indeed to other people's comfort, but greatly and personally calamitous to the patient.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:17
verses.text: And there is one charming point about them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:18
verses.text: Torn and racked with inward agony as they are, they cannot yet for very shame speak out about it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:19
verses.text: The state they are in may be known not only from their behaviour to me, but from the rest of their conduct.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:20
verses.text: If it were unknown, it would not much matter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:21
verses.text: But the veritable cause of their shunning communication with me may be unperceived by the majority among you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:22
verses.text: Listen; and I will tell you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:24
verses.text: There is going on among you a movement ruinous to the faith, disloyal to the apostolical and evangelical dogmas, disloyal too to the tradition of Gregory the truly great, and of his successors up to the blessed Musonius, whose teaching is still ringing in your ears.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:25
verses.text: For those men, who, from fear of confutation, are forging figments against me, are endeavouring to renew the old mischief of Sabellius, started long ago, and extinguished by the tradition of the great Gregory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:26
verses.text: But do you bid goodbye to those wine-laden heads, bemuddled by the swelling fumes that mount from their debauch, and from me who am wide awake and from fear of God cannot keep silence, hear what plague is rife among you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:27
verses.text: Sabellianism is Judaism imported into the preaching of the Gospel under the guise of Christianity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:28
verses.text: For if a man calls Father Son and Holy Ghost one thing of many faces, and makes the hypostasis of the three one, what is this but to deny the everlasting pre-existence of the Only begotten? He denies too the Lord's sojourn among men in the incarnation, the going down into hell, the resurrection, the judgment; he denies also the proper operations of the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:29
verses.text: And I hear that even rasher innovations than those of the foolish Sabellius are now ventured on among you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:30
verses.text: It is said, and that on the evidence of ear witnesses, that your clever men go to such an extreme as to say that there is no tradition of the name of the Only-begotten, while of the name of the adversary there is; and at this they are highly delighted and elated, as though it were a discovery of their own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:31
verses.text: For it is said, "I came in my Father's name and ye received me not; if another shall come in his own name, him ye will receive".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:32
verses.text: And because it is said, "Go ye and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost," it is obvious, they urge, that the name is one, for it is not "in the names," but "in the name".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:34
verses.text: I blush so to write to you, for the men thus guilty are of my own blood; and I groan for my own soul, in that, like boxers fighting two men at once, I can only give the truth its proper force by hitting with my proofs, and knocking down, the errors of doctrine on the right and on the left.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:35
verses.text: On one side I am attacked by the Anomoean: on the other by the Sabellian.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:36
verses.text: Do not, I implore you, pay any attention to these abominable and impotent sophisms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:37
verses.text: Know that the name of Christ which is above every name is His being called Son of God, as Peter says, "There is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:38
verses.text: And as to the words "I came in my Father's name," it is to be understood that He so says describing His Father as origin and cause of Himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:39
verses.text: And if it is said "Go and baptize in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost," we must not suppose that here one name is delivered to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:40
verses.text: For just as he who said Paul and Silvanus and Timothy mentioned three names, and coupled them one to the other by the word "and," so He who spoke of the name of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, mentioned three, and united them by the conjunction, teaching that with each name must be understood its own proper meaning; for the names mean things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:41
verses.text: And no one gifted with even the smallest particle of intelligence doubts that the existence belonging to the things is peculiar and complete in itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:42
verses.text: For of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost there is the same nature and one Godhead; but these are different names, setting forth to a us the circumscription and exactitude of the meanings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:43
verses.text: For unless the meaning of the distinctive qualities of each be unconfounded, it is impossible for the doxology to be adequately offered to Father, Son, and Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:44
verses.text: If, however, they deny that they so say, and so teach, my object is attained.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:45
verses.text: Yet I see that this denial is no easy matter, because of our having many witnesses who heard these things said.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:46
verses.text: But let bygones be bygones; let them only be sound now.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:47
verses.text: If they persist in the same old error I must proclaim your calamity even to other Churches, and get letters written to you from more bishops.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:48
verses.text: In my efforts to break down this huge mass of impiety now gradually and secretly growing, I shall either effect something towards the object I have in view; or at least my present testimony will clear me of guilt in the judgment day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:50
verses.text: They have already inserted these expressions in their own writings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:51
verses.text: They sent them first to the man of God, Meletius, bishop, and after receiving from him a suitable reply, like mothers of monsters, ashamed of their natural deformities, these men themselves brought forth and bring up their disgusting offspring in appropriate darkness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:52
verses.text: They made an attempt too by letter on my dear friend Anthimus, bishop of Tyana, on the ground that Gregory had said in his exposition of the faith that Father and Son are in thought two, but in hypostasis one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:53
verses.text: The men who congratulate themselves on the subtilty of their intelligence could not perceive that this is said not in reference to dogmatic opinion, but in controversy with aelian.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:54
verses.text: And in this dispute there are not a few copyists' blunders, as, please God, I shall shew in the case of the actual expressions used.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:55
verses.text: But in his endeavour to convince the heathen, he deemed it needless to be nice about the words he employed; he judged it wiser sometimes to make concessions to the character of the subject who was being persuaded, so as not to run counter to the opportunity given him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:56
verses.text: This explains how it is that you may find there many expressions which now give great support to the heretics, as for instance "creature" and "thing made" and the like.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:57
verses.text: But those who ignorantly criticise these writings refer to the question of the Godhead much that is said in reference to the conjunction with man; as is the case with this passage which they are hawking about.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:58
verses.text: For it is indispensable to have clear understanding that, as he who fails to confess the community of the essence or substance falls into polytheism, so he who refuses to grant the distinction of the hypostases is carried away into Judaism.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:59
verses.text: For we must keep our mind stayed, so to say, on certain underlying subject matter, and, by forming a clear impression of its distinguishing lines, so arrive at the end desired.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:60
verses.text: For suppose we do not bethink us of the Fatherhood, nor bear in mind Him of whom this distinctive quality is marked off, how can we take in the idea of God the Father? For merely to enumerate the differences of Persons is insufficient; we must confess each Person to have a natural existence in real hypostasis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:61
verses.text: Now Sabellius did not even deprecate the formation of the persons without hypostasis, saying as he did that the same God, being one in matter, was metamorphosed as the need of the moment required, and spoken of now as Father, now as Son, and now as Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:62
verses.text: The inventors of this unnamed heresy are renewing the old long extinguished error; those, I mean, who are repudiating the hypostases, and denying the name of the Son of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:63
verses.text: They must give over uttering iniquity against God, or they will have to wail with them that deny the Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:65
verses.text: I have felt compelled to write to you in these terms, that you may be on your guard against the mischief arising from bad teaching.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:66
verses.text: If we may indeed liken pernicious teachings to poisonous drugs, as your dream-tellers have it, these doctrines are hemlock and monkshood, or any other deadly to man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:67
verses.text: It is these that destroy souls; not my words, as this shrieking drunken scum, full of the fancies of their condition, make out.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:68
verses.text: If they had any sense they ought to know that in souls, pure and cleansed from all defilement, the prophetic gift shines clear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:69
verses.text: In a foul mirror you cannot see what the reflexion is, neither can a soul preoccupied with cares of this life, and darkened with the passions of the lust of the flesh, receive the rays of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:70
verses.text: Every dream is not a prophecy, as says Zechariah, "The Lord shall make bright clouds, and give them showers of rain,…for the idols have spoken vanity and the diviners have told false dreams".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:71
verses.text: Those who, as Isaiah says, dream and love to sleep in their bed forget that an operation of error is sent to "the children of disobedience".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:72
verses.text: And there is a lying spirit, which arose in false prophecies, and deceived Ahab.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:73
verses.text: Knowing this they ought not to have been so lifted up as to ascribe the gift of prophecy to themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:74
verses.text: They are shewn to fall far short even of the case of the seer Balaam; for Balaam when invited by the king of Moab with mighty bribes brooked not to utter a word beyond the will of God, nor to curse Israel whom the Lord cursed not.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:75
verses.text: If then their sleep-fancies do not tally with the commandments of the Lord, let them be content with the Gospels.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:76
verses.text: The Gospels need no dreams to add to their credit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:77
verses.text: The Lord has sent His peace to us, and left us a new commandment, to love one another, but dreams bring strife and division and destruction of love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 210:78
verses.text: Let them therefore not give occasion to the devil to attack their souls in sleep; nor make their imaginations of more authority than the instruction of salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 211:1
verses.text: Letter CCXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 211:2
verses.text: To Olympius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 211:3
verses.text: Truly when I read your excellency's letter I felt unwonted pleasure and cheerfulness; and when I met your well-beloved sons, I seemed to behold yourself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 211:4
verses.text: They found me in the deepest affliction, but they so behaved as to make me forget the hemlock, which your dreamers and dream mongers are carrying about to my hurt, to please the people who have hired them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 211:5
verses.text: Some letters I have already sent; others, if you like, shall follow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 211:6
verses.text: I only hope that they may be of some advantage to the recipients.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:1
verses.text: Letter CCXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:2
verses.text: To Hilarius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:4
verses.text: You can imagine what I felt, and in what state of mind I was, when I came to Dazimon and found that you had left a few days before my arrival.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:5
verses.text: From my boyhood I have held you in admiration, and, therefore, ever since our old school days, have placed a high value on intercourse with you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:6
verses.text: But another reason for my doing so is that nothing is so precious now as a soul that loves the truth, and is gifted with a sound judgment in practical affairs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:7
verses.text: This, I think, is to be found in you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:8
verses.text: I see most men, as in the hippodrome, divided into factions, some for one side and some for another, and shouting with their parties.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:9
verses.text: But you are above fear, flattery, and every ignoble sentiment, and so naturally look at truth with an unprejudiced eye.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:10
verses.text: And I see that you are deeply interested in the affairs of the Churches, about which you have sent me a letter, as you have said in your last.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:11
verses.text: I should like to know who took charge of the conveyance of this earlier epistle, that I may know who has wronged me by its loss.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:12
verses.text: No letter from you on this subject has yet reached me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:14
verses.text: How much, then, would I not have given to meet you, that I might tell you all my troubles? When one is in pain it is, as you know, some alleviation, even to describe it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:15
verses.text: How gladly would I have answered your questions, not trusting to lifeless letters, but in my own person, narrating each particular.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:16
verses.text: The persuasive force of living words is more efficient and they are not so susceptible as letters to attack and to misrepresentation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:17
verses.text: For now no one has left anything untried, and the very men in whom I put the greatest confidence, men, who when I saw them among others, I used to think something more than human, have received documents written by some one, and have sent them on, whatever they are, as mine, and on their account are calumniating me to the brethren as though there is nothing now that pious and faithful men ought to hold in greater abhorrence than my name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:18
verses.text: From the beginning it has been my object to live unknown, to a degree not reached by anyone who has considered human infirmity; but now, just as though on the other hand it had been my purpose to make myself notorious to the world, I have been talked about all over the earth, and I may add all over the sea too.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:19
verses.text: For men, who go to the last limit of impiety, and are introducing into the Churches the godless opinion of Unlikeness, are waging war against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:20
verses.text: Those too who hold the via media, as they think, and, though they start from the same principles, do not follow out their logical consequences, because they are so opposed to the view of the majority, are equally hostile to me, overwhelming me to the utmost of their ability with their reproaches, and abstaining from no insidious attacks against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:21
verses.text: But the Lord has made their endeavours vain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:22
verses.text: Is not this a grievous state of things? Must it not make my life painful? I have at all events one consolation in my troubles, my bodily infirmity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:23
verses.text: This I am sure will not suffer me to remain much longer in this miserable life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:24
verses.text: No more on this point.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:25
verses.text: You too I exhort, in your bodily infirmity, to bear yourself bravely and worthy of the God Who has called us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 212:26
verses.text: If He sees us accepting our present circumstances with thanksgiving, He will either put away our troubles as He did Job's, or will requite us with the glorious crowns of patience in the life to come.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:1
verses.text: Letter CCXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:4
verses.text: May the Lord, Who has brought me prompt help in my afflictions, grant you the help of the refreshment wherewith you have refreshed me by writing to me, rewarding you for your consolation of my humble self with the real and great gladness of the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:5
verses.text: For I was indeed downcast in soul when I saw in a great multitude the almost brutish and unreasonable insensibility of the people, and the inveterate and ineradicable unsatisfactoriness of their leaders.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:6
verses.text: But I saw your letter; I saw the treasure of love which it contained; then I knew that He Who ordains all our lives had made some sweet consolation shine on me in the bitterness of my life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:7
verses.text: I therefore salute your holiness in return, and exhort you, as is my wont, not to cease to pray for my unhappy life, that I may never, drowned in the unrealities of this world, forget God, "who raiseth up the poor out of the dust;" that I may never be lifted up with pride and fall into the condemnation of the devil; that I may never be found by the Lord neglectful of my stewardship and asleep; never discharging it amiss, and wounding the conscience of my fellow-servants; and, never companying with the drunken, suffer the pains threatened in God's just judgment against wicked stewards.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:8
verses.text: I beseech you, therefore, in all your prayers to pray God that I may be watchful in all things; that I may be no shame or disgrace to the name of Christ, in the revelation of the secrets of my heart, in the great day of the appearing of our Saviour Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:10
verses.text: Know then that I am expecting to be summoned by the wickedness of the heretics to the court, in the name of peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:11
verses.text: Learn too that on being so informed, this bishop wrote to me to hasten to Mesopotamia, and, after assembling together those who in that country are of like sentiments with us, and are strengthening the state of the Church, to travel in their company to the emperor.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:12
verses.text: But perhaps my health will not be good enough to allow me to undertake a journey in the winter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:13
verses.text: Indeed, hitherto I have not thought the matter pressing, unless you advise it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:14
verses.text: I shall therefore await your counsel that my mind may be made up.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 213:15
verses.text: Lose no time then, I beg you, in making known to me, by means of one of our trusty brethren, what course seems best to the divinely guided intelligence of your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:1
verses.text: Letter CCXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:2
verses.text: To Count Terentius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:4
verses.text: When I heard that your excellency had again been compelled to take part in public affairs, I was straightway distressed (for the truth must be told) at the thought of how contrary to your mind it must be that you after once giving up the anxieties of official life, and allowing yourself leisure for the care of your soul, should again be forced back into your old career.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:5
verses.text: But then I bethought me that peradventure the Lord has ordained that your lordship should again appear in public from this wish to grant the boon of one alleviation for the countless pains which now beset the Church in our part of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:6
verses.text: I am, moreover, cheered by the thought that I am about to meet your excellency once again before I depart this life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:8
verses.text: But a further rumour has reached me that you are in Antioch, and are transacting the business in hand with the chief authorities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:9
verses.text: And, besides this, I have heard that the brethren who are of the party of Paulinus are entering on some discussion with your excellency on the subject of union with us; and by "us" I mean those who are supporters of the blessed man of God, Meletius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:10
verses.text: I hear, moreover, that the Paulinians are carrying about a letter of the Westerns, assigning to them the episcopate of the Church in Antioch, but speaking under a false impression of Meletius, the admirable bishop of the true Church of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:11
verses.text: I am not astonished at this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:12
verses.text: They are totally ignorant of what is going on here; the others, though they might be supposed to know, give an account to them in which party is put before truth; and it is only what one might expect that they should either be ignorant of the truth, or should even endeavour to conceal the reasons which led the blessed Bishop Athanasius to write to Paulinus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:13
verses.text: But your excellency has on the spot those who are able to tell you accurately what passed between the bishops in the reign of Jovian, and from them I beseech you to get information.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:14
verses.text: I accuse no one; I pray that I may have love to all, and "especially unto them who are of the household of faith;" and therefore I congratulate those who have received the letter from Rome.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:15
verses.text: And, although it is a grand testimony in their favour, I only hope it is true and confirmed by facts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:16
verses.text: But I shall never be able to persuade myself on these grounds to ignore Meletius, or to forget the Church which is under him, or to treat as small, and of little importance to the true religion, the questions which originated the division.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:17
verses.text: I shall never consent to give in, merely because somebody is very much elated at receiving a letter from men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:18
verses.text: Even if it had come down from heaven itself, but he does not agree with the sound doctrine of the faith, I cannot look upon him as in communion with the saints.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:20
verses.text: Consider well, my excellent friend, that the falsifiers of the truth, who have introduced the Arian schism as an innovation on the sound faith of the Fathers, advance no other reason for refusing to accept the pious opinion of the Fathers than the meaning of the homoousion which they hold in their wickedness, and to the slander of the whole faith, alleging our contention to be that the Son is consubstantial in hypostasis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:21
verses.text: If we give them any opportunity by our being carried away by men who propound these sentiments and their like, rather from simplicity than from malevolence, there is nothing to prevent our giving them an unanswerable ground of argument against ourselves and confirming the heresy of those whose one end is in all their utterances about the Church, not so much to establish their own position as to calumniate mine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:22
verses.text: What more serious calumny could there be? What better calculated to disturb the faith of the majority than that some of us could be shewn to assert that there is one hypostasis of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost? We distinctly lay down that there is a difference of Persons; but this statement was anticipated by Sabellius, who affirms that God is one by hypostasis, but is described by Scripture in different Persons, according to the requirements of each individual case; sometimes under the name of Father, when there is occasion for this Person; sometimes under the name of Son when there is a descent to human interests or any of the operations of the oeconomy; and sometimes under the Person of Spirit when the occasion demands such phraseology.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:23
verses.text: If, then, any among us are shewn to assert that Father, Son and Holy Ghost are one in substance, while we maintain the three perfect Persons, how shall we escape giving clear and incontrovertible proof of the truth of what is being asserted about us?  4.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:24
verses.text: The non-identity of hypostasis and ousia is, I take it, suggested even by our western brethren, where, from a suspicion of the inadequacy of their own language, they have given the word ousia in the Greek, to the end that any possible difference of meaning might be preserved in the clear and unconfounded distinction of terms.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:25
verses.text: If you ask me to state shortly my own view, I shall state that ousia has the same relation to hypostasis as the common has to the particular.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:26
verses.text: Every one of us both shares in existence by the common term of essence (ousia) and by his own properties is such an one and such an one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:27
verses.text: In the same manner, in the matter in question, the term ousia is common, like goodness, or Godhead, or any similar attribute; while hypostasis is contemplated in the special property of Fatherhood, Sonship, or the power to sanctify.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:28
verses.text: If then they describe the Persons as being without hypostasis, the statement is per se absurd; but if they concede that the Persons exist in real hypostasis, as they acknowledge, let them so reckon them that the principle of the homoousion may be preserved in the unity of the Godhead, and that the doctrine preached may be the recognition of true religion, of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, in the perfect and complete hypostasis of each of the Persons named.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:29
verses.text: Nevertheless, there is one point which I should like to have pressed on your excellency, that you and all who like you care for the truth, and honour the combatant in the cause of true religion, ought to wait for the lead to be taken in bringing about this union and peace by the foremost authorities in the Church, whom I count as pillars and foundations of the truth and of the Church, and reverence all the more because they have been sent away for punishment, and have been exiled far from home.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 214:30
verses.text: Keep yourself, I implore you, clear of prejudice, that in you, whom God has given me as a staff and support in all things, I may be able to find rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 215:1
verses.text: Letter CCXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 215:2
verses.text: To the Presbyter Dorotheus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 215:3
verses.text: I took the earliest opportunity of writing to the most admirable Count Terentius, thinking it better to write to him on the subject in hand by means of strangers, and being anxious that our very dear brother Acacius shall not be inconvenienced by any delay.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 215:4
verses.text: I have therefore given my letter to the government treasurer, who is travelling by the imperial post, and I have charged him to shew the letter to you first.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 215:5
verses.text: I cannot understand how it is that no one has told you that the road to Rome is wholly impracticable in winter, the country between Constantinople and our own regions being full of enemies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 215:6
verses.text: If the route by sea must be taken, the season will be favourable; if indeed my God-beloved brother Gregory consents to the voyage and to the commission concerning these matters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 215:7
verses.text: For my own part, I do not know who can go with him, and am aware that he is quite inexperienced in ecclesiastical affairs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 215:8
verses.text: With a man of kindly character he may get on very well, and be treated with respect, but what possible good could accrue to the cause by communication between a man proud and exalted, and therefore quite unable to hear those who preach the truth to him from a lower standpoint, and a man like my brother, to whom anything like mean servility is unknown?.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:1
verses.text: Letter CCXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:2
verses.text: To Meletius, bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:3
verses.text: Many other journeys have taken me from home.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:4
verses.text: I have been as far as Pisidia to settle the matters concerning the brethren in Isauria in concert with the Pisidian bishops.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:5
verses.text: Thence I journeyed into Pontus, for Eustathius had caused no small disturbance at Dazimon, and had caused there a considerable secession from our church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:6
verses.text: I even went as far as the home of my brother Peter, and, as this is not far from Neocaesarea, there was occasion of considerable trouble to the Neocaesareans, and of much rudeness to myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:7
verses.text: Some men fled when no one was in pursuit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:8
verses.text: And I was supposed to be intruding uninvited, simply to get compliments from the folk there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:9
verses.text: As soon as I got home, after contracting a severe illness from the bad weather and my anxieties, I straightway received a letter from the East to tell me that Paulinus had had certain letters from the West addressed to him, in acknowledgement of a sort of higher claim; and that the Antiochene rebels were vastly elated by them, and were next preparing a form of creed, and offering to make its terms a condition of union with our Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:10
verses.text: Besides all this it was reported to me that they had seduced to their faction that most excellent man Terentius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 216:11
verses.text: I wrote to him at once as forcibly as I could, to induce him to pause; and I tried to point out their disingenuousness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:1
verses.text: Letter CCXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, the Canons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:3
verses.text: On my return from a long journey (for I have been into Pontus on ecclesiastical business, and to visit my relations) with my body weak and ill, and my spirits considerably broken, I took your reverence's letter into my hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:4
verses.text: No sooner did I receive the tokens of that voice which to me is of all voices the sweetest, and of that hand that I love so well, than I forgot all my troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:5
verses.text: And if I was made so much more cheerful by the receipt of your letter, you ought to be able to conjecture at what value I price your actual presence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:6
verses.text: May this be granted me by the Holy One, whenever it may be convenient to you and you yourself send me an invitation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:7
verses.text: And if you were to come to the house at Euphemias it would indeed be pleasant for me to meet you, escaping from my vexations here, and hastening to your unfeigned affection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:8
verses.text: Possibly also for other reasons I may be compelled to go as far as Nazianzus by the sudden departure of the very God-beloved bishop Gregory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:9
verses.text: How or why this has come to pass, so far I have no information.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:10
verses.text: The man about whom I had spoken to your excellency, and whom you expected to be ready by this time, has, you must know, fallen ill of a lingering disease, and is moreover now suffering from an affection of the eyes, arising from his old complaint and from the illness which has now befallen him, and he is quite unfit to do any work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:11
verses.text: I have no one else with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:12
verses.text: It is consequently better, although the matter was left by them to me, for some one to be put forward by them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:13
verses.text: And indeed one cannot but think that the expressions were used merely as a necessary form, and that what they really wished was what they originally requested, that the person selected for the leadership should be one of themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:14
verses.text: If there is any one of the lately baptized, whether Macedonius approve or not, let him be appointed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:15
verses.text: You will instruct him in his duties, the Lord, Who in all things cooperates with you, granting you His grace for this work also.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:16
verses.text: LI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:17
verses.text: As to the clergy, the Canons have enjoined without making any distinction that one penalty is assigned for the lapsed,—ejection from the ministry, whether they be in orders or remain in the ministry which is conferred without imposition of hands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:18
verses.text: LII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:19
verses.text: The woman who has given birth to a child and abandoned it in the road, if she was able to save it and neglected it, or thought by this means to hide her sin, or was moved by some brutal and inhuman motive, is to be judged as in a case of murder.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:20
verses.text: If, on the other hand, she was unable to provide for it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:21
verses.text: and the child perish from exposure and want of the necessities of life, the mother is to be pardoned.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:22
verses.text: LIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:23
verses.text: The widowed slave is not guilty of a serious fall if she adopts a second marriage under colour of rape.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:24
verses.text: She is not on this ground open to accusation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:25
verses.text: It is rather the object than the pretext which must be taken into account, but it is clear that she is exposed to the punishment of digamy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:26
verses.text: LIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:27
verses.text: I know that I have already written to your reverence, so far as I can, on the distinctions to be observed in cases of involuntary homicide, and on this point I can say no more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:28
verses.text: It rests with your intelligence to increase or lessen the severity of the punishment as each individual case may require.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:29
verses.text: LV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:30
verses.text: Assailants of robbers, if they are outside, are prohibited from the communion of the good thing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:31
verses.text: If they are clerics they are degraded from their orders.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:32
verses.text: For, it is said, "All they that take the sword shall perish with the sword".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:33
verses.text: LVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:34
verses.text: The intentional homicide, who has afterwards repented, will be excommunicated from the sacrament for twenty years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:35
verses.text: The twenty years will be appointed for him as follows: for four he ought to weep, standing outside the door of the house of prayer, beseeching the faithful as they enter in to offer prayer in his behalf, and confessing his own sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:36
verses.text: After four years he will be admitted among the hearers, and during five years will go out with them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:37
verses.text: During seven years he will go out with the kneelers, praying.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:38
verses.text: During four years he will only stand with the faithful, and will not take part in the oblation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:39
verses.text: On the completion of this period he will be admitted to participation of the sacrament.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:40
verses.text: LVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:41
verses.text: The unintentional homicide will be excluded for ten years from the sacrament.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:42
verses.text: The ten years will be arranged as follows: For two years he will weep, for three years he will continue among the hearers; for four he will be a kneeler; and for one he will only stand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:43
verses.text: Then he will be admitted to the holy rites.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:44
verses.text: LVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:45
verses.text: The adulterer will be excluded from the sacrament for fifteen years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:46
verses.text: During four he will be a weeper, and during five a hearer, during four a kneeler, and for two a slander without communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:47
verses.text: LIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:48
verses.text: The fornicator will not be admitted to participation in the sacrament for seven years; weeping two, hearing two, kneeling two, and standing one: in the eighth he will be received into communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:49
verses.text: LX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:50
verses.text: The woman who has professed virginity and broken her promise will complete the time appointed in the case of adultery in her continence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:51
verses.text: The same rule will be observed in the case of men who have professed a solitary life and who lapse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:52
verses.text: LXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:53
verses.text: The thief, if he have repented of his own accord and charged himself, shall only be prohibited from partaking of the sacrament for a year; if he be convicted, for two years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:54
verses.text: The period shall be divided between kneeling and standing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:55
verses.text: Then let him be held worthy of communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:56
verses.text: LXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:57
verses.text: He who is guilty of unseemliness with males will be under discipline for the same time as adulterers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:58
verses.text: LXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:59
verses.text: He who confesses his iniquity in the case of brutes shall observe the same time in penance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:60
verses.text: LXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:61
verses.text: Perjurers shall be excommunicated for ten years; weeping for two, hearing for three, kneeling for four, and standing only during one year; then they shall be held worthy of communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:62
verses.text: LXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:63
verses.text: He who confesses magic or sorcery shall do penance for the time of murder, and shall be treated in the same manner as he who convicts himself of this sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:64
verses.text: LXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:65
verses.text: The tomb breaker shall be excommunicated for ten years, weeping for two, hearing for three, kneeling for four, standing for one, then he shall be admitted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:66
verses.text: LXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:67
verses.text: Incest with a sister shall incur penance for the same time as murder.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:68
verses.text: LXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:69
verses.text: The union of kindred within the prohibited degrees of marriage, if detected as having taken place in acts of sin, shall receive the punishment of adultery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:70
verses.text: LXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:71
verses.text: The Reader who has intercourse with his betrothed before marriage, shall be allowed to read after a year's suspension, remaining without advancement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:72
verses.text: If he has had secret intercourse without betrothal, he shall be deposed from his ministry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:73
verses.text: So too the minister.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:74
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:75
verses.text: The deacon who has been polluted in lips, and has confessed his commission of this sin, shall be removed from his ministry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:76
verses.text: But he shall be permitted to partake of the sacrament together with the deacons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:77
verses.text: The same holds good in the case of a priest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:78
verses.text: If any one be detected in a more serious sin, whatever be his degree, he shall be deposed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:79
verses.text: LXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:80
verses.text: Whoever is aware of the commission of any one of the aforementioned sins, and is convicted without having confessed, shall be under punishment for the same space of time as the actual perpetrator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:81
verses.text: LXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:82
verses.text: He who has entrusted himself to soothsayers, or any such persons, shall be under discipline for the same time as the homicide.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:83
verses.text: LXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:84
verses.text: He who has denied Christ, and sinned against the mystery of salvation, ought to weep all his life long, and is bound to remain in penitence, being deemed worthy of the sacrament in the hour of death, through faith in the mercy of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:85
verses.text: LXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:86
verses.text: If, however, each man who has committed the former sins is made good, through penitence, he to whom is committed by the loving-kindness of God the power of loosing and binding will not be deserving of condemnation, if he become less severe, as he beholds the exceeding greatness of the penitence of the sinner, so as to lessen the period of punishment, for the history in the Scriptures informs us that all who exercise penitence with greater zeal quickly receive the loving-kindness of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:87
verses.text: LXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:88
verses.text: The man who has been polluted with his own sister, either on the father's or the mother's side, must not be allowed to enter the house of prayer, until he has given up his iniquitous and unlawful conduct.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:89
verses.text: And, after he has come to a sense of that fearful sin, let him weep for three years standing at the door of the house of prayer, and entreating the people as they go in to prayer that each and all will mercifully offer on his behalf their prayers with earnestness to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:90
verses.text: After this let him be received for another period of three years to hearing alone, and while hearing the Scriptures and the instruction, let him be expelled and not be admitted to prayer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:91
verses.text: Afterwards, if he has asked it with tears and has fallen before the Lord with contrition of heart and great humiliation, let kneeling be accorded to him during other three years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:92
