verses.text: Thus, when he shall have worthily shown the fruits of repentance, let him be received in the tenth year to the prayer of the faithful without oblation; and after standing with the faithful in prayer for two years, then, and not till then, let him be held worthy of the communion of the good thing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:93
verses.text: LXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:94
verses.text: The same rule applies to those who take their own daughters in law.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:95
verses.text: LXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:96
verses.text: He who abandons the wife, lawfully united to him, is subject by the sentence of the Lord to the penalty of adultery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:97
verses.text: But it has been laid down as a canon by our Fathers that such sinners should weep for a year, be hearers for two years, in kneeling for three years, stand with the faithful in the seventh; and thus be deemed worthy of the oblation, if they have repented with tears.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:98
verses.text: LXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:99
verses.text: Let the same rule hold good in the case of those who marry two sisters, although at different times.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:100
verses.text: LXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:101
verses.text: Men who rage after their stepmothers are subject to the same canon as those who rage after their sisters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:102
verses.text: LXXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:103
verses.text: On polygamy the Fathers are silent, as being brutish and altogether inhuman.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:104
verses.text: The sin seems to me worse than fornication.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:105
verses.text: It is therefore reasonable that such sinners should be subject to the canons; namely a year's weeping, three years kneeling and then reception.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:106
verses.text: LXXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:107
verses.text: During the invasion of the barbarians many men have sworn heathen oaths, tasted things unlawfully offered them in magic temples and so have broken their faith in God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:108
verses.text: Let regulations be made in the case of these men in accordance with the canons laid down by our Fathers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:109
verses.text: Those who have endured grievous tortures and have been forced to denial, through inability to sustain the anguish, may be excluded for three years, hearers for two, kneelers for three, and so be received into communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:110
verses.text: Those who have abandoned their faith in God, laying hands on the tables of the demons and swearing heathen oaths, without under going great violence, should be excluded for three years, hearers for two.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:111
verses.text: When they have prayed for three years as kneelers, and have stood other three with the faithful in supplication, then let them be received into the communion of the good thing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:112
verses.text: LXXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:113
verses.text: As to perjurers, if they have broken their oaths under violent compulsion, they are under lighter penalties and may therefore be received after six years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:114
verses.text: If they break their faith without compulsion, let them be weepers for two years, hearers for three, pray as kneelers for five, during two be received into the communion of prayer, without oblation, and so at last, after giving proof of due repentance, they shall be restored to the communion of the body of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:115
verses.text: LXXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:116
verses.text: Consulters of soothsayers and they who follow heathen customs, or bring persons into their houses to discover remedies and to effect purification, should fall under the canon of six years.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:117
verses.text: After weeping a year, hearing a year, kneeling for three years and standing with the faithful for a year so let them be received.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:118
verses.text: LXXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:119
verses.text: I write all this with a view to testing the fruits of repentance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:120
verses.text: I do not decide such matters absolutely by time, but I give heed to the manner of penance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:121
verses.text: If men are in a state in which they find it hard to be weaned from their own ways and choose rather to serve the pleasures of the flesh than to serve the Lord, and refuse to accept the Gospel life, there is no common ground between me and them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:122
verses.text: In the midst of a disobedient and gainsaying people I have been taught to hear the words "Save thy own soul".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:123
verses.text: Do not then let us consent to perish together with such sinners.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:124
verses.text: Let us fear the awful judgment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:125
verses.text: Let us keep before our eyes the terrible day of the retribution of the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:126
verses.text: Let us not consent to perish in other men's sins, for if the terrors of the Lord have not taught us, if so great calamities have not brought us to feel that it is because of our iniquity that the Lord has abandoned us, and given us into the hands of barbarians, that the people have been led captive before our foes and given over to dispersion, because the bearers of Christ's name have dared such deeds; if they have not known nor understood that it is for these reasons that the wrath of God has come upon us, what common ground of argument have I with them?  But we ought to testify to them day and night, alike in public and in private.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:127
verses.text: Let us not consent to be drawn away with them in their wickedness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:128
verses.text: Let us above all pray that we may do them good, and rescue them from the snare of the evil one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 217:129
verses.text: If we cannot do this, let us at all events do our best to save our own souls from everlasting damnation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:1
verses.text: Letter CCXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:3
verses.text: Brother aelianus has himself completed the business concerning which he came, and has stood in need of no aid from me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:4
verses.text: I owe him, however, double thanks, both for bringing me a letter from your reverence and for affording me an opportunity of writing to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:5
verses.text: By him, therefore, I salute your true and unfeigned love, and beseech you to pray for me more than ever now, when I stand in such need of the aid of your prayers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:6
verses.text: My health has suffered terribly from the journey to Pontus and my sickness is unendurable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:7
verses.text: One thing I have long been anxious to make known to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:8
verses.text: I do not mean to say that I have been so affected by any other cause as to forget it, but now I wish to put you in mind to send some good man into Lycia, to enquire who are of the right faith, for peradventure they ought not to be neglected, if indeed the report is true, which has been brought to me by a pious traveller from thence, that they have become altogether alienated from the opinion of the Asiani and wish to embrace communion with us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:9
verses.text: If any one is to go let him enquire at Corydala for Alexander, the late monk, the bishop; at Limyra for Diotimus, and at Myra for Tatianus, Polemo, and Macarius presbyters; at Patara for Eudemus, the bishop; at Telmessus for Hilarius, the bishop; at Phelus for Lallianus, the bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:10
verses.text: Of these and of more besides I have been informed that they are sound in the faith, and I have been grateful to God that even any in the Asian region should be clear of the heretic's pest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:11
verses.text: If, then, it be possible, let us in the meanwhile make personal enquiry about them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:12
verses.text: When we have obtained information I am for writing a letter, and am anxious to invite one of them to meet me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:13
verses.text: God grant that all may go well with that Church at Iconium, which is so dear to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 218:14
verses.text: Through you I salute all the honourable clergy and all who are associated with your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:1
verses.text: Letter CCXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:2
verses.text: To the clergy of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:3
verses.text: The Lord ordereth "all things in measure and weight," and brings on us the temptations which do not exceed our power to endure them, but tests all that fight in the cause of true religion by affliction, not suffering them to be tempted above that they are able to bear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:4
verses.text: He gives tears to drink in great measure to all who ought to show whether in their affections they are preserving their gratitude to Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:5
verses.text: Especially in His dispensation concerning you has He shown His loving-kindness, not suffering such a persecution to be brought on you by your enemies as might turn some of you aside, or cause you to swerve from the faith of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:6
verses.text: He has matched you with adversaries who are of small importance and easy to be repelled, and has prepared the prize for your patience in your victory over them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:7
verses.text: But the common enemy of our life, who, in his wiles, strives against the goodness of God, because he has seen that, like a strong wall, you are despising attack from without, has devised, as I hear, that there should arise among yourselves mutual offences and quarrels.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:8
verses.text: These indeed, at the outset, are insignificant and easy of cure; as time goes on, however, they are increased by contention and are wont to result in irremediable mischief.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:9
verses.text: I have, therefore, undertaken to exhort you by this letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:10
verses.text: Had it been possible, I would have come myself and supplicated you in person.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:11
verses.text: But this is prevented by present circumstances, and so, in lieu of supplication, I hold out this letter to you, that you may respect my entreaty, may put a stop to your mutual rivalries, and may soon send me the good news that all cause of offence among you is at an end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:13
verses.text: I am very anxious that you should know that he is great before God who humbly submits to his neighbour and submits to charges against himself, without having cause for shame, even though they are not true, that he may bring the great blessing of peace upon God's Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:14
verses.text: I hope that there will arise among you a friendly rivalry, as to who shall first be worthy of being called God's son, after winning this rank for himself because of his being a peacemaker.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:15
verses.text: A letter has also been written to you by your very God-beloved bishop as to the course which you ought to pursue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:16
verses.text: He will write again what it belongs to him to say.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:17
verses.text: But I too, because of its having been already allowed me to be near you, cannot disregard your position.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:18
verses.text: So on the arrival of the very devout brother Theodorus the sub-deacon, and his report that your Church is in distress and disturbance, being deeply grieved and much pained at heart, I could not endure to keep silence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:19
verses.text: I implore you to fling away all controversy with one another, and to make peace, that you may avoid giving pleasure to you opponents and destroying the boast of the Church, which is now noised abroad throughout the world, that you all, as you are ruled by one soul and heart, so live in one body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:20
verses.text: Through your reverences I salute all the people of God, both those in rank and office and the rest of the clergy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:21
verses.text: I exhort you to keep your old character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 219:22
verses.text: I can ask for nothing more than this because by the exhibition of your good works you have anticipated and made impossible any improvement on them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:1
verses.text: Letter CCXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:2
verses.text: To the Beraeans.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:3
verses.text: The Lord has given great consolation to all who are deprived of personal intercourse in allowing them to communicate by letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:4
verses.text: By this means, it is true, we cannot learn the express image of the body, but we can learn the disposition of the very soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:5
verses.text: Thus on the present occasion, when I had received the letter of your reverences, I at the same moment recognised you, and took your love towards me into my heart, and needed no long time to create intimacy with you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:6
verses.text: The disposition shewn in your letter was quite enough to enkindle in me affection for the beauty of your soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:7
verses.text: And, besides your letter, excellent as it was, I had a yet plainer proof of how things are with you from the amiability of the brethren who have been the means of communication between us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:8
verses.text: The well-beloved and reverend presbyter Acacius, has told me much in addition to what you have written, and has brought before my eyes the conflict you have to keep up day by day, and the stoutness of the stand you are making for the true religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:9
verses.text: He has thus so moved my admiration, and roused in me so earnest a desire of enjoying the good qualities in you, that I do pray the Lord that a time may come when I may know you and yours by personal experience.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:10
verses.text: He has told me of the exactitude of those of you who are entrusted with the ministry of the altar, and moreover of the harmonious agreement of all the people, and the generous character and genuine love towards God of the magistrates and chief men of your city.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:11
verses.text: I consequently congratulate the Church on consisting of such members, and pray that spiritual peace may be given to you in yet greater abundance, to the end that in quieter times you may derive enjoyment from your labours in the day of affliction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:12
verses.text: For sufferings that are painful while they are being experienced are naturally often remembered with pleasure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:13
verses.text: For the present I beseech you not to faint.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:14
verses.text: Do not despair because your troubles follow so closely one upon another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:15
verses.text: Your crowns are near: the help of the Lord is near.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:16
verses.text: Do not let all you have hitherto undergone go for nothing; do not nullify a struggle which has been famous over all the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:17
verses.text: Human life is but of brief duration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:18
verses.text: "All flesh is grass, and all the goodliness thereof is as the flower of the field.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:19
verses.text: …The grass withereth, the flower fadeth; but the word of our God shall stand for ever".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:20
verses.text: Let us hold fast to the commandment that abideth, and despise the unreality that passeth away.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:21
verses.text: Many Churches have been cheered by your example.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:22
verses.text: In calling new champions into the field you have won for yourselves a great reward, though you knew it not.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 220:23
verses.text: The Giver of the prize is rich, and is able to reward you not unworthily for your brave deeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 221:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 221:2
verses.text: To the Beraeans.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 221:3
verses.text: You were previously known to me, my dear friends, by your far-famed piety, and by the crown won by your confession in Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 221:4
verses.text: Peradventure one of you may ask in reply who can have carried these tidings of us so far? The Lord Himself; for He puts His worshippers like a lamp on a lamp-stand, and makes them shine throughout the whole world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 221:5
verses.text: Are not winners in the games wont to be made famous by the prize of victory, and craftsmen by the skilful design of their work? Shall the memory of these and others like them abide for ever unforgotten, and shall not Christ's worshippers concerning whom the Lord says Himself, Them that honour me I will honour, be made famous and glorious by Him before all? Shall He not display the brightness of their radiant splendour as He does the beams of the sun? But I have been moved to greater longing for you by the letter which you have been good enough to send me, a letter in which, above and beyond your former efforts on behalf of the truth, you have been yet more lavish of your abounding and vigorous zeal for the true faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 221:6
verses.text: In all this I rejoice with you, and I pray with you that the God of the universe, Whose is the struggle and the arena, and Who gives the crown, may fill you with enthusiasm, may make your souls strong, and make your work such as to meet with His divine approval.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:2
verses.text: To the people of Chalcis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:3
verses.text: The letter of your reverences came upon me in an hour of affliction like water poured into the mouths of racehorses, inhaling dust with each eager breath at high noontide in the middle of the course.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:4
verses.text: Beset by trial after trial, I breathed again, at once cheered by your words and invigorated by the thought of your struggles to meet that which is before me with unflinching courage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:5
verses.text: For the conflagration which has devoured a great part of the East is already advancing by slow degrees into our own neighbourhood, and after burning everything round about us is trying to reach even the Churches in Cappadocia, already moved to tears by the smoke that rises from the ruins of our neighbours' homes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:6
verses.text: The flames have almost reached me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:7
verses.text: May the Lord divert them by the breath of His mouth, and stay this wicked fire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:8
verses.text: Who is such a coward, so unmanly, so untried in the athlete's struggles, as not to be nerved to the fight by your cheers, and pray to be hailed victor at your side? You have been the first to step into the arena of true religion; you have beaten off many an attack in bouts with the heretics; you have borne the strong hot wind of trial, both you who are leaders of the Church, to whom has been the ministry of the altar, and every individual of the laity, including those of higher rank.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:9
verses.text: For this in you is specially admirable and worthy of all praise, that you are all one in the Lord, some of you leaders in the march to what is good, others willingly following.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:10
verses.text: It is for this reason that you are too strong for the attack of your assailants, and allow no hold to your antagonists in any one of your members, wherefore day and night I pray the King of the ages to preserve the people in the integrity of their faith, and for them to preserve the clergy, like a head unharmed at the top, exercising its own watchful forethought for every portion of the body underneath.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:11
verses.text: For while the eyes discharge their functions, the hands can do their work as they ought, the feet can move without tripping, and no part of the body is deprived of due care.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:12
verses.text: I beseech you, then, to cling to one another, as you are doing and as you will do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:13
verses.text: I beseech you who are entrusted with the care of souls to keep each and all together, and to cherish them like beloved children.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:14
verses.text: I beseech the people to continue to show you the respect and honour due to fathers, that in the goodly order of your Church you may keep your strength and the foundation of your faith in Christ; that God's name may be glorified and the good gift of love increase and abound.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:15
verses.text: May I, as I hear of you, rejoice in your progress in God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:16
verses.text: If I am still bidden to sojourn in the flesh in this world, may I one day see you in the peace of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 222:17
verses.text: If I be now summoned to depart this life, may I see you in the radiant glory of the saints, together with all them who are accounted worthy through patience and showing forth of good works, with crowns upon your heads.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:2
verses.text: Against Eustathius of Sebasteia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:4
verses.text: There is a time to keep silence and a time to speak, is the saying of the Preacher.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:5
verses.text: Time enough has been given to silence, and now the time has come to open my mouth for the publication of the truth concerning matters that are, up to now, unknown.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:6
verses.text: The illustrious Job bore his calamities for a long time in silence, and ever showed his courage by holding out under the most intolerable sufferings, but when he had struggled long enough in silence, and had persisted in covering his anguish in the bottom of his heart, at last he opened his mouth and uttered his well-known words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:7
verses.text: In my own case this is now the third year of my silence, and my boast has become like that of the Psalmist, "I was as a man that heareth not and in whose mouth are no reproofs".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:8
verses.text: Thus I shut up in the bottom of my heart the pangs which I suffered on account of the calumnies directed against me, for calumny humbles a man, and calumny makes a poor man giddy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:9
verses.text: If, therefore, the mischief of calumny is so great as to cast down even the perfect man from his height, for this is what Scripture indicates by the word man, and by the poor man is meant he who lacks the great doctrines, as is the view also of the prophet when he says, "These are poor, therefore they shall not hear;…I will get me unto the great men," he means by poor those who are lacking in understanding; and here, too, he plainly means those who are not yet furnished in the inner man, and have not even come to the full measure of their age; it is these who are said by the proverb to be made giddy and tossed about.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:10
verses.text: Nevertheless I thought that I ought to bear my troubles in silence, waiting for some indication to come out of them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:11
verses.text: I did not even think that what was said against me proceeded from ill will; I thought it was the result of ignorance of the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:12
verses.text: But now I see that hostility increases with time, and that my slanderers are not sorry for what they said at the beginning, and do not take any trouble to make amends for the past, but go on and on and rally themselves together to attain their original object.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:13
verses.text: This was to make my life miserable and to devise means for sullying my reputation among the brethren.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:14
verses.text: I, therefore, no longer see safety in silence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:15
verses.text: I have bethought me of the words of Isaiah: "I have long time holden my peace, shall I always be still and refrain myself? I have been patient like a travailing woman".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:16
verses.text: God grant that I may both receive the reward of silence, and gain some strength to confute my opponents, and that thus, by confuting them, I may dry up the bitter torrent of falsehood that has gushed out against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:17
verses.text: So might I say, "My soul has passed over the torrent;" and, "If it had not been the Lord who was on our side when men rose up against us,…then they had swallowed us up quick, the water had drowned us".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:19
verses.text: Much time had I spent in vanity, and had wasted nearly all my youth in the vain labour which I underwent in acquiring the wisdom made foolish by God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:20
verses.text: Then once upon a time, like a man roused from deep sleep, I turned my eyes to the marvellous light of the truth of the Gospel, and I perceived the uselessness of "the wisdom of the princes of this world, that come to naught".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:21
verses.text: I wept many tears over my miserable life and I prayed that guidance might be vouchsafed me to admit me to the doctrines of true religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:22
verses.text: First of all was I minded to make some mending of my ways, long perverted as they were by my intimacy with wicked men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:23
verses.text: Then I read the Gospel, and I saw there that a great means of reaching perfection was the selling of one's goods, the sharing them with the poor, the giving up of all care for this life, and the refusal to allow the soul to be turned by any sympathy to things of earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:24
verses.text: And I prayed that I might find some one of the brethren who had chosen this way of life, that with him I might cross life's short and troubled strait.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:25
verses.text: And many did I find in Alexandria, and many in the rest of Egypt, and others in Palestine, and in Coele Syria, and in Mesopotamia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:26
verses.text: I admired their continence in living, and their endurance in toil; I was amazed at their persistency in prayer, and at their triumphing over sleep; subdued by no natural necessity, ever keeping their souls' purpose high and free, in hunger, in thirst, in cold, in nakedness, they never yielded to the body; they were never willing to waste attention on it; always, as though living in a flesh that was not theirs, they shewed in very deed what it is to sojourn for a while in this life, and what to have one's citizenship and home in heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:27
verses.text: All this moved my admiration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:28
verses.text: I called these men's lives blessed, in that they did in deed shew that they "bear about in their body the dying of Jesus".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:29
verses.text: And I prayed that I, too, as far as in me lay, might imitate them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:31
verses.text: So when I beheld certain men in my own country striving to copy their ways, I felt that I had found a help to my own salvation, and I took the things seen for proof of things unseen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:32
verses.text: And since the secrets in the hearts of each of us are unknown, I held lowliness of dress to be a sufficient indication of lowliness of spirit; and there was enough to convince me in the coarse cloak, the girdle, and the shoes of untanned hide.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:33
verses.text: And though many were for withdrawing me from their society, I would not allow it, because I saw that they put a life of endurance before a life of pleasure; and, because of the extraordinary excellence of their lives, I became an eager supporter of them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:34
verses.text: And so it came about that I would not hear of any fault being found with their doctrines, although many maintained that their conceptions about God were erroneous, and that they had become disciples of the champion of the present heresy, and were secretly propagating his teaching.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:35
verses.text: But, as I had never at any time heard these things with my own ears, I concluded that those who reported them were calumniators.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:36
verses.text: Then I was called to preside over the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:37
verses.text: Of the watchmen and spies, who were given me under the pretence of assistance and loving communion, I say nothing, lest I seem to injure my own cause by telling an incredible tale, or give believers an occasion for hating their fellows, if I am believed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:38
verses.text: This had almost been my own case, had I not been prevented by the mercy of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:39
verses.text: For almost every one became an object of suspicion to me, and smitten at heart as I was by wounds treacherously inflicted, I seemed to find nothing in any man that I could trust.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:40
verses.text: But so far there was, nevertheless, a kind of intimacy kept up between us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:41
verses.text: Once and again we held discussions on doctrinal points.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:42
verses.text: and apparently we seemed to agree and keep together.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:43
verses.text: But they began to find out that I made the same statements concerning my faith in God which they had always heard from me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:44
verses.text: For, if other things in me may move a sigh, this one boast at least I dare make in the Lord, that never for one moment have I held erroneous conceptions about God, or entertained heterodox opinions, which I have learnt later to change.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:45
verses.text: The teaching about God which I had received as a boy from my blessed mother and my grandmother Macrina, I have ever held with increased conviction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:46
verses.text: On my coming to ripe years of reason I did not shift my opinions from one to another, but carried out the principles delivered to me by my parents.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:47
verses.text: Just as the seed when it grows is first tiny and then gets bigger but always preserves its identity, not changed in kind though gradually perfected in growth, so I reckon the same doctrine to have grown in my case through gradually advancing stages.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:48
verses.text: What I hold now has not replaced what I held at the beginning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:49
verses.text: Let them search their own consciences.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:50
verses.text: Let these men who have now made me the common talk on the charge of false doctrine, and deafened all men's ears with the defamatory letters which they have written against me, so that I am compelled thus to defend myself, ask themselves if they have ever heard anything from me, differing from what I now say, and let them remember the judgment seat of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:52
verses.text: I am charged with blasphemy against God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:53
verses.text: Yet it is impossible for me to be convicted on the ground of any treatise concerning the Faith, which they urge against me, nor can I be charged on the ground of the utterances which I have from time to time delivered by word of mouth, without their being committed to writing, in the churches of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:54
verses.text: Not a single witness has been found to say that he has ever heard from me, when speaking in private, anything contrary to true religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:55
verses.text: If then I am not an unorthodox writer, if no fault can be found with my preaching, if I do not lead astray those who converse with me in my own home, on what ground am I being judged? But there is a new invention! Somebody, runs the charge, in Syria has written something inconsistent with true religion; and twenty years or more ago you wrote him a letter: so you are an accomplice of the fellow, and what is urged against him is urged against you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:56
verses.text: O truth-loving sir, I reply, you who have been taught that lies are the offspring of the devil; what has proved to you that I wrote that letter? You never sent; you never asked; you were never informed by me, who might have told you the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:57
verses.text: But if the letter was mine, how do you know that the document that has come into your hands now is of the same date as my letter? Who told you that it is twenty years old? How do you know that it is a composition of the man to whom my letter was sent? And if he was the composer, and I wrote to him, and my letter and his composition belong to the same date, what proof is there that I accepted it in my judgment, and that I hold those views?  5.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:58
verses.text: Ask yourself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:59
verses.text: How often did you visit me in my monastery on the Iris, when my very God-beloved brother Gregory was with me, following the same course of life as myself? Did you ever hear anything of the kind? Was there any appearance of such a thing, small or great? How many days did we spend in the opposite village, at my mother's, living as friend with friend, and discoursing together night and day? Did you ever find me holding any opinion of the kind? And when we went together to visit the blessed Silvanus, did we not talk of these things on the way? And at Eusinoe, when you were about to set out with other bishops for Lampsacus, was not our discourse about the faith? Were not your shorthand writers at my side the whole time while I was dictating my objections to the heresy? Were not your most faithful disciples there too? When I was visiting the brotherhood, and passing the night with them in their prayers, continually speaking and hearing of the things pertaining to God without dispute, was not the evidence which I gave of my sentiments exact and definite? How came you then to reckon this rotten and slender suspicion as of more importance than the experience of such a length of time?  What evidence of my frame of mind ought you to have preferred to your own? Has there been the slightest want of harmony in my utterances about the faith at Chalcedon, again and again at Heraclea, and at an earlier period in the suburb of Caesarea? Are they not all mutually consistent? I only except the increase in force of which I spoke just now, resulting from advance, and which is not to be regarded as a change from worse to better, but rather as a filling up of what was wanting in the addition of knowledge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:60
verses.text: How can you fail to bear in mind that the father shall not bear the iniquity of the son, nor the son bear the iniquity of the father, but each shall die in his own sin? I have neither father nor son slandered by you; I have had neither teacher nor disciple.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:61
verses.text: But if the sins of the parents must be made charges against their children, it is far fairer for the sins of Arius to be charged against his disciples; and, whoever begat the heretic Aetius, for the charges against the son to be applied to the father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:62
verses.text: If on the other hand it is unjust for any one to be accused for their sakes, it is far more unjust that I should be held responsible for the sake of men with whom I have nothing to do, even if they were in every respect sinners, and something worthy of condemnation has been written by them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:63
verses.text: I must be pardoned if I do not believe all that is urged against them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:64
verses.text: since my own experience shows me how very easy it is for accusers to slip into slander.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:66
verses.text: Even if they did come forward to accuse me, because they had been deceived, and thought that I was associated with the writers of those words of Sabellius which they are carrying about, they were guilty of unpardonable conduct in straightway attacking and wounding me, when I had done them no wrong, before they had obtained plain proof.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:67
verses.text: I do not like to speak of myself as bound to them in the closest intimacy; or of them as being evidently not led by the Holy Spirit, because of their cherishing false suspicions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:68
verses.text: Much anxious thought must be taken, and many sleepless nights must be passed, and with many tears must the truth be sought from God, by him who is on the point of cutting himself off from a brother's friendship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:69
verses.text: Even the rulers of this world, when they are on the point of sentencing some evil doer to death, draw the veil aside, and call in experts for the examination of the case, and consume considerable time in weighing the severity of the law against the common fault of humanity, and with many a sigh and many a lament for the stern necessity of the case, proclaim before all the people that they are obeying the law from necessity, and not passing sentence to gratify their own wishes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:70
verses.text: How much greater care and diligence, how much more counsel, ought to be taken by one who is on the point of breaking off from long established friendship with a brother! In this case there is only a single letter and that of doubtful genuineness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:71
verses.text: It would be quite impossible to argue that it is known by the signature, for they possess not the original, but only a copy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:72
verses.text: They depend on one single document and that an old one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:73
verses.text: It is now twenty years since anything has been written to that person.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:74
verses.text: Of my opinions and conduct in the intervening time I can adduce no better witnesses than the very men who attack and accuse me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:76
verses.text: But the real reason of separation is not this letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:77
verses.text: There is another cause of alienation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:78
verses.text: I am ashamed to mention it; and I would have been for ever silent about it had not recent events compelled me to publish all their mind for the sake of the good of the mass of the people.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:79
verses.text: Good men have thought that communion with me was a bar to the recovery of their authority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:80
verses.text: Some have been influenced by the signature of a certain creed which I proposed to them, not that I distrusted their sentiments, I confess, but because I wished to do away with the suspicions which the more part of the brethren who agree with me entertained of them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:81
verses.text: Accordingly, to avoid anything arising from that confession to prevent their being accepted by the present authorities, they have renounced communion with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:82
verses.text: This letter was devised by an after-thought as a pretext for the separation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:83
verses.text: A very plain proof of what I say is, that after they had denounced me, and composed such complaints against me as suited them, they sent round their letters in all directions before communicating with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:84
verses.text: Their letter was in the possession of others who had received it in the course of transmission and who were on the point of sending it on seven days before it had reached my hands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:85
verses.text: The idea was that it would be handed from one to another and so would be quickly distributed over the whole country.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:86
verses.text: This was reported to me at the time by those who were giving me clear information of all their proceedings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 223:87
verses.text: But I determined to hold my tongue until the Revealer of all secrets should publish their doings by plain and incontrovertible demonstration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:2
verses.text: To the presbyter Genethlius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:4
verses.text: I have received your reverence's letter and I am delighted at the title which you have felicitously applied to the writing which they have composed in calling it "a writing of divorcement".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:5
verses.text: What defence the writers will be able to make before the tribunal of Christ, where no excuse will avail, I am quite unable to conceive.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:6
verses.text: After accusing me, violently running me down, and telling tales in accordance not with the truth but with what they wished to be true, they have assumed a great show of humility, and have accused me of haughtiness for refusing to receive their envoys.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:7
verses.text: They have written, as they have, what is all—or nearly all—for I do not wish to exaggerate,—lies, in the endeavour to persuade men rather than God, and to please men rather than God, with Whom nothing is more precious than truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:8
verses.text: Moreover into the letter written against me they have introduced heretical expressions, and have concealed the author of the impiety, in order that most of the more unsophisticated might be deceived by the calumny got up against me, and suppose the portion introduced to be mine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:9
verses.text: For nothing is said by my ingenious slanderers as to the name of the author of these vile doctrines, and it is left for the simple to suspect that these inventions, if not their expression in writing, is due to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:10
verses.text: Now that you know all this, I exhort you not to be perturbed yourselves, and to calm the excitement of those who are agitated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:11
verses.text: I say this although I know that it will not be easy for my defence to be received, because I have been anticipated by the vile calumnies uttered against me by persons of influence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:13
verses.text: Now as to the point that the writings going the round as mine are not mine at all, the angry feeling felt against me so confuses their reason that they cannot see what is profitable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:14
verses.text: Nevertheless, if the question were put to them by yourselves, I do think that they would not reach such a pitch of obstinate perversity as to dare to utter the lie with their own lips, and allege the document in question to be mine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:15
verses.text: And if it is not mine, why am I being judged for other men's writings? But they will urge that I am in communion with Apollinarius, and cherish in my heart perverse doctrines of this kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:16
verses.text: Let them be asked for proof.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:17
verses.text: If they are able to search into a man's heart, let them say so; and do you admit the truth of all that they say about everything.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:18
verses.text: If on the other hand, they are trying to prove my being in communion on plain and open grounds, let them produce either a canonical letter written by me to him, or by him to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:19
verses.text: Let them shew that I have held intercourse with his clergy, or have ever received any one of them into the communion of prayer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:20
verses.text: If they adduce the letter written now five and twenty years ago, written by layman to layman, and not even this as I wrote it, but altered (God knows by whom), then recognise their unfairness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:21
verses.text: No bishop is accused if, while he was a layman, he wrote something somewhat incautiously on an indifferent matter; not anything concerning the Faith, but a mere word of friendly greeting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:22
verses.text: Possibly even my opponents are known to have written to Jews and to Pagans, without incurring any blame.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:23
verses.text: Hitherto no one has ever been judged for any such conduct as that on which I am being condemned by these strainers-out of gnats.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:24
verses.text: God, who knows men's hearts, knows that I never wrote these things, nor sanctioned them, but that I anathematize all who hold the vile opinion of the confusion of the hypostases, on which point the most impious heresy of Sabellius has been revived.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:25
verses.text: And all the brethren who have been personally acquainted with my insignificant self know it equally well.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:26
verses.text: Let those very men who now vehemently accuse me, search their own consciences, and they will own that from my boyhood I have been far removed from any doctrine of the kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:28
verses.text: If any one enquires what my opinion is, he will learn it from the actual little document, to which is appended their own autograph signature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:29
verses.text: This they wish to destroy, and they are anxious to conceal their own change of position in slandering me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:30
verses.text: For they do not like to own that they have repented of their subscription to the tract I gave them; while they charge me with impiety from the idea that no one perceives that their disruption from me is only a pretext, while in reality they have departed from that faith which they have over and over again owned in writing, before many witnesses, and have lastly received and subscribed when delivered to them by me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:31
verses.text: It is open to any one to read the signatures and to learn the truth from the document itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:32
verses.text: Their intention will be obvious, if, after reading the subscription which they gave me, any one reads the creed which they gave Gelasius, and observes what a vast difference there is between the two confessions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:33
verses.text: It would be better for men who so easily shift their own position, not to examine other men's motes but to cast out the beam in their own eye.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:34
verses.text: I am making a more complete defence on every point in another letter; this will satisfy readers who want fuller assurance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:35
verses.text: Do you, now that you have received this letter, put away all despondency, and confirm the love to me, which makes me eagerly long for union with you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:36
verses.text: Verily it is a great sorrow to me, and a pain in my heart that cannot be assuaged, if the slanders uttered against me so far prevail as to chill your love and to alienate us from one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 224:37
verses.text: Farewell.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:2
verses.text: To Demosthenes, as from the synod of bishops.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:3
verses.text: I am always very thankful to God and to the emperor, under whose rule we live, when I see the government of my country put into the hands of one who is not only a Christian, but is moreover correct in life and a careful guardian of the laws according to which our life in this world is ordered.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:4
verses.text: I have had special reason for offering this gratitude to God and to our God-beloved emperor on the occasion of your coming among us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:5
verses.text: I have been aware that some of the enemies of peace have been about to stir your august tribunal against me, and have been waiting to be summoned by your excellency that you might learn the truth from me; if indeed your high wisdom condescends to consider the examination of ecclesiastical matters to be within your province.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:6
verses.text: The tribunal overlooked me, but your excellency, moved by the reproaches of Philochares, ordered my brother and fellow-minister Gregory to be haled before your judgment seat.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:7
verses.text: He obeyed your summons; how could he do otherwise? But he was attacked by pain in the side, and at the same time, in consequence of a chill, was attacked by his old kidney complaint.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:8
verses.text: He has therefore been compelled, forcibly detained by your soldiers as he was, to be conveyed to some quiet spot, where he could have his maladies attended to, and get some comfort in his intolerable agony.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:9
verses.text: Under these circumstances we have combined to approach your lordship with the entreaty that you will feel no anger at the postponement of the trial.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:10
verses.text: The public interests have not in any way suffered through our delay, nor have those of the Church been injured.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:11
verses.text: If there is any question of the wasteful expenditure of money, the treasurers of the Church funds are there, ready to give an account to any one who likes, and to exhibit the injustice of the charges advanced by men who have braved the careful hearing of the case before you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:12
verses.text: For they can have no difficulty in making the truth clear to any one who seeks it from the actual writings of the blessed bishop himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:13
verses.text: If there is any other point of canonical order which requires investigation, and your excellency deigns to undertake to hear and to judge it, it will be necessary for us all to be present, because, if there has been a failure in any point of canonical order, the responsibility lies with the consecrators and not with him who is forcibly compelled to undertake the ministry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:14
verses.text: We therefore petition you to reserve the hearing of the case for us in our own country, and not to compel us to travel beyond its borders, nor force us to a meeting with bishops with whom we have not yet come to agreement on ecclesiastical questions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:15
verses.text: I beg you also to be merciful to my own old age and ill health.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:16
verses.text: You will learn by actual investigation, if it please God, that no canonical rule be it small or great was omitted in the appointment of the bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 225:17
verses.text: I pray that under your administration unity and peace may be brought about with my brethren; but so long as this does not exist it is difficult for us even to meet, because many of our simpler brethren suffer from our mutual disputes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:2
verses.text: To the ascetics under him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:3
verses.text: It may be that the holy God will grant me the joy of a meeting with you, for I am ever longing to see you and hear about you, because in no other thing do I find rest for my soul than in your progress and perfection in the commandments of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:4
verses.text: But so long as this hope remains unrealized I feel bound to visit you through the instrumentality of our dear and God-fearing brethren, and to address you, my beloved friends, by letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:5
verses.text: Wherefore I have sent my reverend and dear brother and fellow-worker in the Gospel, Meletius the presbyter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:6
verses.text: He will tell you my yearning affection for you, and the anxiety of my soul, in that, night and day, I beseech the Lord in your behalf, that I may have boldness in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ through your salvation, and that when your work is tried by the just judgment of God you may shine forth in the brightness of the saints.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:7
verses.text: At the same time the difficulties of the day cause me deep anxiety, for all Churches have been tossed to and fro, and all souls are being sifted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:8
verses.text: Some have even opened their mouths without any reserve against their fellow servants.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:9
verses.text: Lies are boldly uttered, and the truth has been hidden.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:10
verses.text: The accused are being condemned without a trial, and the accusers are believed without evidence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:11
verses.text: I had heard that many letters are being carried about against myself, stinging, gibbeting, and attacking me for matters about which I have my defence ready for the tribunal of truth; and I had intended to keep silence, as indeed I have done; for now for three years I have been bearing the blows of calumny and the whips of accusation, content to think that I have the Lord, Who knows all secrets, as witness of its falsehood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:12
verses.text: But I see now that many men have silence as a corroboration of these slanders, and have formed the idea that my silence was due, not to my longsuffering, but to my inability to open my lips in opposition to the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:13
verses.text: For these reasons I have attempted to write to you, beseeching your love in Christ not to accept these partial calumnies as true, because, as it is written, the law judges no man unless it have heard and known his actions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:15
verses.text: Nevertheless before a fair judge the facts themselves are a sufficient demonstration of the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:16
verses.text: Wherefore, even if I be silent, you can look at events.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:17
verses.text: The very men who are now indicting me for heterodoxy have been seen openly numbered with the heretical faction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:18
verses.text: The very accusers who condemn me for other men's writings, are plainly contravening their own confessions, given to me by them in writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:19
verses.text: Look at the conduct of the exhibitors of this audacity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:20
verses.text: It is their invariable custom to go over to the party in power, to trample on their weaker friends, and to court the strong.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:21
verses.text: The writers of those famous letters against Eudoxius and all his faction, the senders of them to all the brotherhood, the protesters that they shun their communion as fatal to souls, and would not accept the votes given for their deposition, because they were given by heretics, as they persuaded me then,—these very men, completely forgetful of all this, have joined their faction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:22
verses.text: No room for denial is left them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:23
verses.text: They laid their mind bare when they embraced private communion with them at Ancyra, when they had not yet been publicly received by them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:24
verses.text: Ask them, then, if Basilides, who gave communion to Ecdicius, is now orthodox, why when returning from Dardania, did they overthrow his altars in the territory of Gangra, and set up their own tables? Why have they comparatively recently attacked the churches of Amasea and Zela and appointed presbyters and deacons there themselves? If they communicate with them as orthodox, why do they attack them as heretical? If they hold them to be heretical, how is it that they do not shun communion with them? Is it not, my honourable brethren, plain even to the intelligence of a child, that it is always with a view to some personal advantage that they endeavour to calumniate or to give support? So they have stood off from me, not because I did not write in reply (which is alleged to be the main ground of offence), nor because I did not receive the chorepiscopi whom they assert they sent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:25
verses.text: Those who are trumping up the tale will render an account to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:26
verses.text: One man, Eustathius, was sent and gave a letter to the court of the vicar, and spent three days in the city.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:27
verses.text: When he was on the point of going home, it is said that he came to my house late in the evening, when I was asleep.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:28
verses.text: On hearing that I was asleep, he went away; he did not come near me on the next day, and after thus going through the mere form of discharging his duty to me, departed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:29
verses.text: This is the charge under which I am guilty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:30
verses.text: This is the sin against which these long-suffering people have neglected to weigh the previous service wherein I served them in love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:31
verses.text: For this error they have made their wrath against me so severe that they have caused me to be denounced in all the Churches throughout the world—at least, that is, wherever they could.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:33
verses.text: But of course this is not the real cause of our separation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:34
verses.text: It was when they found that they would recommend themselves to Euzoius if they were alienated from me, that they devised these pretences.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:35
verses.text: The object was to find some ground of recommendation with the authorities for their attack upon me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:36
verses.text: Now they are beginning to run down even the Nicene Creed, and nickname me Homoousiast, because in that creed the Only begotten Son is said to be homoousios with God the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:37
verses.text: Not that one essence is divided into two kindred parts; God forbid! This was not the meaning of that holy and God-beloved synod; their meaning was that what the Father is in essence, such is the Son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:38
verses.text: And thus they themselves have explained it to us, in the phrase Light of Light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:39
verses.text: Now it is the Nicene Creed, brought by themselves from the west, which they presented to the Synod at Tyana, by which they were received.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:40
verses.text: But they have an ingenious theory as to changes of this kind; they use the words of the creed as physicians use a remedy for the particular moment, and substitute now one and now another to suit particular diseases.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:41
verses.text: The unsoundness of such a sophism it is rather for you to consider than for me to prove.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:42
verses.text: For "the Lord will give you understanding" to know what is the right doctrine, and what the crooked and perverse.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:43
verses.text: If indeed we are to subscribe one creed to-day and another tomorrow, and shift with the seasons, then is the declaration false of him who said, "One Lord, one faith, one baptism".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:44
verses.text: But if it is true, then "Let no man deceive you with [these] vain words".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:45
verses.text: They falsely accuse me of introducing novelties about the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:46
verses.text: Ask what the novelty is.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:47
verses.text: I confess what I have received, that the Paraclete is ranked with Father and Son, and not numbered with created beings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:48
verses.text: We have made profession of our faith in Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, and we are baptized in the name of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:49
verses.text: Wherefore we never separate the Spirit from conjunction with the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:50
verses.text: For our mind, enlightened by the Spirit, looks at the Son, and in Him, as in an image, beholds the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:51
verses.text: And I do not invent names of myself, but call the Holy Ghost Paraclete; nor do I consent to destroy His due glory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:52
verses.text: These are truly my doctrines.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:53
verses.text: If any one wishes to accuse me for them, let him accuse me; let my persecutor persecute me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:54
verses.text: Let him who believes in the slanders against me be ready for the judgment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:55
verses.text: "The Lord is at hand".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:56
verses.text: "I am careful for nothing".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:58
verses.text: If any one in Syria is writing, this is nothing to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:59
verses.text: For it is said "By thy words thou shalt be justified, and by thy words thou shalt be condemned".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:60
verses.text: Let my own words judge me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:61
verses.text: Let no one condemn me for other men's errors nor adduce letters written twenty years ago in proof that I would allow communion to the writers of such things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:62
verses.text: Before these things were written, and before any suspicion of this kind had been stirred against them, I did write as layman to layman.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:63
verses.text: I wrote nothing about the faith in any way like that which they are now carrying about to calumniate me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:64
verses.text: I sent nothing but a mere greeting to return a friendly communication, for I shun and anathematize as impious alike all who are affected with the unsoundness of Sabellius, and all who maintain the opinions of Arius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:65
verses.text: If any one says that Father, Son, and Holy Ghost are the same, and supposes one thing under several names, and one hypostasis described by three persons, I rank such an one as belonging to the faction of the Jews.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:66
verses.text: Similarly, if any one says that the Son is in essence unlike the Father, or degrades the Holy Ghost into a creature, I anathematize him, and say that he is coming near to the heathen error.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:67
verses.text: But it is impossible for the mouths of my accusers to be restrained by my letter; rather is it likely that they are being irritated at my defence, and are getting up new and more violent attacks against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:68
verses.text: But it is not difficult for your ears to be guarded.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:69
verses.text: Wherefore, as far as in you lies, do as I bid you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:70
verses.text: Keep your heart clear and unprejudiced by their calumnies; and insist on my rendering an account to meet the charges laid against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:71
verses.text: If you find that truth is on my side do not yield to lies; if on the other hand you feel that I am feeble in defending myself, then believe my accusers as being worthy of credit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:72
verses.text: They pass sleepless nights to do me mischief.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:73
verses.text: I do not ask this of you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:74
verses.text: They are taking to a commercial career, and turning their slanders against me into a means of profit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:75
verses.text: I implore you on the other hand to stop at home, and to lead a decorous life, quietly doing Christ's work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:76
verses.text: I advise you to avoid communication with them, for it always tends to the perversion of their hearers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 226:77
verses.text: I say this that you may keep your affection for the uncontaminated, may preserve the faith of the Fathers in its integrity, and may appear approved before the Lord as friends of the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:2
verses.text: Consolatory, to the clergy of Colonia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:3
verses.text: What is so goodly and honourable before God and men as perfect love, which, as we are told by the wise teacher, is the fulfilling of the law? I therefore approve of your warm affection for your bishop, for, as to an affectionate son the loss of a good father is unendurable, so Christ's Church cannot bear the departure of a pastor and teacher.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:4
verses.text: Thus, in your exceeding affection for your bishop, you are giving proof of a good and noble disposition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:5
verses.text: But this your good will towards your spiritual father is to be approved so long as it is shewn in reason and moderation; once let it begin to overstep this line, and it is no longer descrying of the same commendation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:6
verses.text: In the case of your very God-beloved brother, our fellow-minister Euphronius, good government has been shewn by those to whom has been committed the administration of the Church; they have acted as the occasion compelled them, to the gain alike of the Church to which he has been removed and of yourselves from whom he has been taken.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:7
verses.text: Do not look at this as merely of man's ordaining, nor as having been originated by the calculations of men who regard earthly things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:8
verses.text: Believe that those to whom the anxious care of the Churches belongs have acted, as they have, with the aid of the Holy Spirit; impress this inception of the proceedings on your hearts and do your best to perfect it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:9
verses.text: Accept quietly and thankfully what has happened, with the conviction that all, who refuse to accept what is ordered in God's Churches by the Churches, are resisting the ordinance of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:10
verses.text: Do not enter into a dispute with your Mother Church at Nicopolis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:11
verses.text: Do not exasperate yourselves against those who have taken the anxious responsibility of your souls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:12
verses.text: In the firm establishment of things at Nicopolis your part in them may also be preserved; but if some disturbance affects them, though you have protectors beyond number, with the head the heart will be destroyed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:13
verses.text: It is like men who live on the riverside; when they see some one far up the stream making a strong dam against the current, they know that, in stopping the inrush of the current, he is providing for their safety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:14
verses.text: Just so those who have now undertaken the weight of the care of the Churches, by protecting the rest, are proving for your own security.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:15
verses.text: You will be sheltered from every storm, while others have to bear the brunt of the attack.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:16
verses.text: But you ought also to consider this; he has not cast you off; he has taken others into his charge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:17
verses.text: I am not so invidious as to compel the man, who is able to give a share of his good gifts to others, also to confine his favour to you, and to limit it to your own city.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:18
verses.text: A man who puts a fence round a spring, and spoils the outpour of the waters, is not free from the disease of envy, and it is just the same with him who tries to prevent the further flow of abundant teaching.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:19
verses.text: Let him have some care for Nicopolis too, and let your interests be added to his anxieties there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:20
verses.text: He has received an addition of labour, but there is no diminution in his diligence on your behalf.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:21
verses.text: I am really distressed at one thing that you have said, which seems to me quite extravagant, namely, that if you cannot obtain your object, you will betake yourselves to the tribunals, and put the matter into the hands of men, the great object of whose prayers is the overthrow of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:22
verses.text: Take heed lest men, carried away by unwise passions, persuade you, to your hurt, to put in any plea before the courts, and so some catastrophe may ensue, and the weight of the result fall upon the heads of those who have occasioned it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:23
verses.text: Take my advice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:24
verses.text: It is offered you in a fatherly spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:25
verses.text: Consent to the arrangement with the very God-beloved bishops, which has been made in accordance with God's will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:26
verses.text: Wait for my arrival.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 227:27
verses.text: When I am with you, with God's help, I will give you in person all the exhortations which it has been impossible for me to express in my letter, and will do my utmost to give you all possible consolation, not by word but in deed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:2
verses.text: To the magistrates of Colonia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:3
verses.text: I have received your lordships' letter, and offered thanks to God most holy, that you, occupied as you are with affairs of state, should not put those of the Church in the second place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:4
verses.text: I am grateful to think that every one of you has shewn anxiety as though he were acting in his own private interest, nay, in defence of his own life, and that you have written to me in your distress at the removal of your very God-beloved bishop Euphronius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:5
verses.text: Nicopolis has not really stolen him from you; were she pleading her cause before a judge she might say that she was recovering what is her own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:6
verses.text: If honourably treated she will tell you, as becomes an affectionate mother, that she will share with you the Father who will give a portion of his grace to each of you: he will not suffer the one to be in any way harmed by the invasion of their adversaries, and at the same time will not deprive you, the other, of the care to which you have been accustomed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:7
verses.text: Bethink you then of the emergency of the time; apply your best intelligence to understand how good government necessitates a certain course of action; and then pardon the bishops who have adopted this course for the establishment of the Churches of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:8
verses.text: Suggest to yourselves what is becoming you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:9
verses.text: Your own intelligence needs no instruction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:10
verses.text: You know how to adopt the counsels of those who love you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:11
verses.text: It is only natural that you should be unaware of many of the questions that are being agitated, because of our being situated far away in Armenia; but we who are in the midst of affairs and have our ears dinned every day on all sides with news of Churches that are being overthrown, are in deep anxiety lest the common enemy, in envy at the protracted peace of our life, should be able to sow his tares in your ground too, and Armenia, as well as other places, be given over to our adversaries to devour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:12
verses.text: For the present be still, as not refusing to allow your neighbours to share with you the use of a goodly vessel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 228:13
verses.text: Ere long, if the Lord allow me to come to you, you shall, if it seem necessary to you, receive yet greater consolation for what has come to pass.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:2
verses.text: To the clergy of Nicopolis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:3
verses.text: I am sure that a work done by one or two pious men is not done without the cooperation of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:4
verses.text: For when nothing merely human is put before us, when holy men are moved to action with no thought of their own personal gratification, and with the sole object of pleasing God, it is plain that it is the Lord Who is directing their hearts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:5
verses.text: When spiritually-minded men take the lead in counsel, and the Lord's people follow them with consentient hearts, there can be no doubt that their decisions are arrived at with the participation of our Lord Jesus Christ, Who poured out His blood for the Churches' sake.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:6
verses.text: You are therefore right in supposing that our very God-beloved brother and fellow minister Poemenius, who arrived among you at an opportune moment, and discovered this means of consoling you, has been divinely moved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:7
