verses.text: I not only praise his discovery of the right course to take; I much admire the firmness with which, without allowing any delay to intervene, so as to slacken the energy of the petitioners, or to give the opposite party an opportunity of taking precautions, and to set in motion the counterplots of secret foes, he at once crowned his happy course with a successful conclusion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:8
verses.text: The Lord of His especial grace keep him and his, so that the Church, as becomes her, may remain in a succession in no way degenerate, and not give place to the evil one, who now, if ever, is vexed at the firm establishment of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:10
verses.text: I have also written at length to exhort our brethren at Colonia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:11
verses.text: You, moreover, are bound rather to put up with their frame of mind than to increase their irritation, as though you despised them for their insignificance, or provoked them to a quarrel by your contempt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:12
verses.text: It is only natural for disputants to act without due counsel, and to manage their own affairs ill with the object of vexing their opponents.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:13
verses.text: And no one is so small as not to be now able to give an occasion, to those who want an occasion, for great troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:14
verses.text: I do not speak at random.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:15
verses.text: I speak from my own experience of my own troubles.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:16
verses.text: From these may God keep you in answer to your prayers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 229:17
verses.text: Pray also for me, that I may have a successful journey, and, on my arrival, may share your joy in your present pastor, and with you may find consolation at the departure of our common father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:2
verses.text: To the magistrates of Nicopolis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:3
verses.text: The government of the Churches is carried on by those to whom the chief offices in them have been entrusted, but their hands are strengthened by the laity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:4
verses.text: The measures which lay with the God-beloved bishops have been taken.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:5
verses.text: The rest concerns you, if you deign to accord a hearty reception to the bishop who has been given you, and to make a vigorous resistance to attacks from outside.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:6
verses.text: For nothing is so likely to cause discouragement to all, whether rulers or the rest who envy your peaceful position, as agreement in affection to the appointed bishop, and firmness in maintaining your ground.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:7
verses.text: They are likely to despair of every evil attempt, if they see that their counsels are accepted neither by clergy nor by laity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:8
verses.text: Bring it about then that your own sentiments as to the right may be shared by all the city, and so speak to the citizens, and to all the inhabitants of the district, in confirmation of their good sentiments, that the genuineness of your love to God may be everywhere known.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:9
verses.text: I trust that it may be permitted me one day to visit and inspect a Church which is the nursing mother of true religion, honoured by me as a metropolis of orthodoxy, because it has from of old been under the government of men right honourable and the elect of God, who have held fast to "the faithful word as we have been taught".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:10
verses.text: You have approved him who has just been appointed as worthy of these predecessors, and I have agreed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:11
verses.text: May you be preserved by God's grace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 230:12
verses.text: May He scatter the evil counsels of our enemies, and fix in your souls strength and constancy to preserve what has been rightly determined on.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:3
verses.text: I find few opportunities of writing to your reverence, and this causes me no little trouble.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:4
verses.text: It is just the same as if, when it was in my power to see you and enjoy your society very often, I did so but seldom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:5
verses.text: But it is impossible for me to write to you because so few travel hence to you, otherwise there is no reason why my letter should not be a kind of journal of my life, to tell you, my dear friend, everything that happens to me day by day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:6
verses.text: It is a comfort to me to tell you my affairs, and I know that you care for nothing more than for what concerns me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:7
verses.text: Now, however, Elpidius is going home to his own master, to refute the calumnies falsely got up against him by certain enemies, and he has asked me for a letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:8
verses.text: I therefore salute your reverence by him and commend to you a man who deserves your protection, at once for the sake of justice and for my own sake.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:9
verses.text: Although I could say nothing else in his favour, yet, because he has made it of very great importance to be the bearer of my letter, reckon him among our friends, and remember me and pray for the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:10
verses.text: You must know that my very God-beloved brother is in exile, for he could not endure the annoyance caused him by shameless persons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:11
verses.text: Doara is in a state of agitation, for the fat sea monster is throwing everything into confusion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:12
verses.text: My enemies, as I am informed by those who know, are plotting against me at court.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:13
verses.text: But hitherto the hand of the Lord has been over me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:14
verses.text: Only pray that I be not abandoned in the end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:15
verses.text: My brother is taking things quietly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:16
verses.text: Doara has received the old muleteer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:17
verses.text: She can do no more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:18
verses.text: The Lord will scatter the counsels of my enemies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:19
verses.text: The one cure for all my troubles present and to come is to set eyes on you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:20
verses.text: If you possibly can, while I am still alive, do come to see me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:21
verses.text: The book on the Spirit has been written by me, and is finished, as you know.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:22
verses.text: My brethren here have prevented me from sending it to you written on paper, and have told me that they had your excellency's orders to engross it on parchment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:23
verses.text: Not, then, to appear to do anything against your injunctions, I have delayed now, but I will send it a little later, if only I find any suitable person to convey it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 231:24
verses.text: May you be granted to me and to God's Church by the kindness of the Holy One, in all health and happiness, and praying for me to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:3
verses.text: Every day that brings me a letter from you is a feast day, the very greatest of feast days.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:4
verses.text: And when symbols of the feast are brought, what can I call it but a feast of feasts, as the old law used to speak of Sabbath of Sabbaths? I thank the Lord that you are quite well, and that you have celebrated the commemoration of the economy of salvation in a Church at peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:5
verses.text: I have been disturbed by some troubles; and have not been without distress from the fact of my God-beloved brother being in exile.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:6
verses.text: Pray for him that God may one day grant him to see his Church healed from the wounds of heretical bites.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:7
verses.text: Do come to see me while I am yet upon this earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:8
verses.text: Act in accordance with your own wishes and with my most earnest prayers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:9
verses.text: I may be allowed to be astonished at the meaning of your blessings, inasmuch as you have mysteriously wished me a vigorous old age.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:10
verses.text: By your lamps you rouse me to nightly toil; and by your sweet meats you seem to pledge yourself securely that all my body is in good case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:11
verses.text: But there is no munching for me at my time of life, for my teeth have long ago been worn away by time and bad health.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 232:12
verses.text: As to what you have asked me there are some replies in the document I send you, written to the best of my ability, and as opportunity has allowed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, in reply to certain questions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:3
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:4
verses.text: I know that I have myself heard of this, and I am aware of the constitution of mankind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:5
verses.text: What shall I say? The mind is a wonderful thing, and therein we possess that which is after the image of the Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:6
verses.text: And the operation of the mind is wonderful; in that, in its perpetual motion, it frequently forms imaginations about things non-existent as though they were existent, and is frequently carried straight to the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:7
verses.text: But there are in it two faculties; in accordance with the view of us who believe in God, the one evil, that of the daemons which draws us on to their own apostasy; and the divine and the good, which brings us to the likeness of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:8
verses.text: When, therefore, the mind remains alone and unaided, it contemplates small things, commensurate with itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:9
verses.text: When it yields to those who deceive it, it nullifies its proper judgment, and is concerned with monstrous fancies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:10
verses.text: Then it considers wood to be no longer wood, but a god; then it looks on gold no longer as money, but as an object of worship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:11
verses.text: If on the other hand it assents to its diviner part, and accepts the boons of the Spirit, then, so far as its nature admits, it becomes perceptive of the divine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:12
verses.text: There are, as it were, three conditions of life, and three operations of the mind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:13
verses.text: Our ways may be wicked, and the movements of our mind wicked; such as adulteries, thefts, idolatries, slanders, strife, passion, sedition, vain-glory, and all that the apostle Paul enumerates among the works of the flesh.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:14
verses.text: Or the soul's operation is, as it were, in a mean, and has nothing about it either damnable or laudable, as the perception of such mechanical crafts as we commonly speak of as indifferent, and, of their own character, inclining neither towards virtue nor towards vice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:15
verses.text: For what vice is there in the craft of the helmsman or the physician? Neither are these operations in themselves virtues, but they incline in one direction or the other in accordance with the will of those who use them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:16
verses.text: But the mind which is impregnated with the Godhead of the Spirit is at once capable of viewing great objects; it beholds the divine beauty, though only so far as grace imparts and its nature receives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:18
verses.text: Let them dismiss, therefore, these questions of dialectics and examine the truth, not with mischievous exactness but with reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:19
verses.text: The judgment of our mind is given us for the understanding of the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:20
verses.text: Now our God is the very truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:21
verses.text: So the primary function of our mind is to know one God, but to know Him so far as the infinitely great can be known by the very small.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:22
verses.text: When our eyes are first brought to the perception of visible objects, all visible objects are not at once brought into sight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:23
verses.text: The hemisphere of heaven is not beheld with one glance, but we are surrounded by a certain appearance, though in reality many things, not to say all things, in it are unperceived;—the nature of the stars, their greatness, their distances, their movements, their conjunctions, their intervals, their other conditions, the actual essence of the firmament, the distance of depth from the concave circumference to the convex surface.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:24
verses.text: Nevertheless, no one would allege the heaven to be invisible because of what is unknown; it would be said to be visible on account of our limited perception of it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:25
verses.text: It is just the same in the case of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:26
verses.text: If the mind has been injured by devils it will be guilty of idolatry, or will be perverted to some other form of impiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:27
verses.text: But if it has yielded to the aid of the Spirit, it will have understanding of the truth, and will know God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:28
verses.text: But it will know Him, as the Apostle says, in part; and in the life to come more perfectly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:29
verses.text: For "when that which is perfect is come, then that which is in part shall be done away".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 233:30
verses.text: The judgment of the mind is, therefore, good and given us for a good end—the perception of God; but it operates only so far as it can.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:2
verses.text: To the same, in answer to another question.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:3
verses.text: Do you worship what you know or what you do not know? If I answer, I worship what I know, they immediately reply, What is the essence of the object of worship? Then, if I confess that I am ignorant of the essence, they turn on me again and say, So you worship you know not what.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:4
verses.text: I answer that the word to know has many meanings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:5
verses.text: We say that we know the greatness of God, His power, His wisdom, His goodness, His providence over us, and the justness of His judgment; but not His very essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:6
verses.text: The question is, therefore, only put for the sake of dispute.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:7
verses.text: For he who denies that he knows the essence does not confess himself to be ignorant of God, because our idea of God is gathered from all the attributes which I have enumerated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:8
verses.text: But God, he says, is simple, and whatever attribute of Him you have reckoned as knowable is of His essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:9
verses.text: But the absurdities involved in this sophism are innumerable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:10
verses.text: When all these high attributes have been enumerated, are they all names of one essence? And is there the same mutual force in His awfulness and His loving-kindness, His justice and His creative power, His providence and His foreknowledge, and His bestowal of rewards and punishments, His majesty and His providence? In mentioning any one of these do we declare His essence? If they say, yes, let them not ask if we know the essence of God, but let them enquire of us whether we know God to be awful, or just, or merciful.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:11
verses.text: These we confess that we know.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:12
verses.text: If they say that essence is something distinct, let them not put us in the wrong on the score of simplicity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:13
verses.text: For they confess themselves that there is a distinction between the essence and each one of the attributes enumerated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:14
verses.text: The operations are various, and the essence simple, but we say that we know our God from His operations, but do not undertake to approach near to His essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:15
verses.text: His operations come down to us, but His essence remains beyond our reach.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:17
verses.text: But, it is replied, if you are ignorant of the essence, you are ignorant of Himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:18
verses.text: Retort, If you say that you know His essence, you are ignorant of Himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:19
verses.text: A man who has been bitten by a mad dog, and sees a dog in a dish, does not really see any more than is seen by people in good health; he is to be pitied because he thinks he sees what he does not see.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:20
verses.text: Do not then admire him for his announcement, but pity him for his insanity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:21
verses.text: Recognise that the voice is the voice of mockers, when they say, if you are ignorant of the essence of God, you worship what you do not know.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:22
verses.text: I do know that He exists; what His essence is, I look at as beyond intelligence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:23
verses.text: How then am I saved? Through faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:24
verses.text: It is faith sufficient to know that God exists, without knowing what He is; and "He is a rewarder of them that seek Him".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:25
verses.text: So knowledge of the divine essence involves perception of His incomprehensibility, and the object of our worship is not that of which we comprehend the essence, but of which we comprehend that the essence exists.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:27
verses.text: And the following counter question may also be put to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:28
verses.text: "No man hath seen God at any time, the Only-begotten which is in the bosom hath declared him".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:29
verses.text: What of the Father did the Only-begotten Son declare? His essence or His power? If His power, we know so much as He declared to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:30
verses.text: If His essence, tell me where He said that His essence was the being unbegotten? When did Abraham worship? Was it not when he believed? And when did he believe? Was it not when he was called? Where in this place is there any testimony in Scripture to Abraham's comprehending? When did the disciples worship Him? Was it not when they saw creation subject to Him? It was from the obedience of sea and winds to Him that they recognised His Godhead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:31
verses.text: Therefore the knowledge came from the operations, and the worship from the knowledge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:32
verses.text: "Believest thou that I am able to do this?" "I believe, Lord;" and he worshipped Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:33
verses.text: So worship follows faith, and faith is confirmed by power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:34
verses.text: But if you say that the believer also knows, he knows from what he believes; and vice versa he believes from what he knows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:35
verses.text: We know God from His power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 234:36
verses.text: We, therefore, believe in Him who is known, and we worship Him who is believed in.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:2
verses.text: To the same, in answer to another question.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:4
verses.text: Which is first in order, knowledge or faith? I reply that generally, in the case of disciples, faith precedes knowledge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:5
verses.text: But, in our teaching, if any one asserts knowledge to come before faith, I make no objection; understanding knowledge so far as is within the bounds of human comprehension.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:6
verses.text: In our lessons we must first believe that the letter a is said to us; then we learn the characters and their pronunciation, and last of all we get the distinct idea of the force of the letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:7
verses.text: But in our belief about God, first comes the idea that God is.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:8
verses.text: This we gather from His works.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:9
verses.text: For, as we perceive His wisdom, His goodness, and all His invisible things from the creation of the world, so we know Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:10
verses.text: So, too, we accept Him as our Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:11
verses.text: For since God is the Creator of the whole world, and we are a part of the world, God is our Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:12
verses.text: This knowledge is followed by faith, and this faith by worship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:14
verses.text: But the word knowledge has many meanings, and so those who make sport of simpler minds, and like to make themselves remarkable by astounding statements (just like jugglers who get the balls out of sight before men's very eyes), hastily included everything in their general enquiry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:15
verses.text: Knowledge, I say, has a very wide application, and knowledge may be got of what a thing is, by number, by bulk, by force, by its mode of existence, by the period of its generation, by its essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:16
verses.text: When then our opponents include the whole in their question, if they catch us in the confession that we know, they straightway demand from us knowledge of the essence; if, on the contrary, they see us cautious as to making any assertion on the subject, they affix on us the stigma of impiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:17
verses.text: I, however, confess that I know what is knowable of God, and that I know what it is which is beyond my comprehension.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:18
verses.text: So if you ask me if I know what sand is, and I reply that I do, you will obviously be slandering me, if you straightway ask me the number of the sand; inasmuch as your first enquiry bore only on the form of sand, while your second unfair objection bore upon its number.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:19
verses.text: The quibble is just as though any one were to say, Do you know Timothy? Oh, if you know Timothy you know his nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:20
verses.text: Since you have acknowledged that you know Timothy, give me an account of Timothy's nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:21
verses.text: Yes; but I at the same time both know and do not know Timothy, though not in the same way and in the same degree.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:22
verses.text: It is not that I do not know in the same way in which I do know; but I know in one way and am ignorant in one way.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:23
verses.text: I know him according to his form and other properties; but I am ignorant of his essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:24
verses.text: Indeed, in this way too, I both know, and am ignorant of, myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:25
verses.text: I know indeed who I am, but, so far as I am ignorant of my essence I do not know myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:27
verses.text: Let them tell me in what sense Paul says, "Now we know in part"; do we know His essence in part, as knowing parts of His essence? No.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:28
verses.text: This is absurd; for God is without parts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:29
verses.text: But do we know the whole essence? How then "When that which is perfect is come, then that which is in part shall be done away".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:30
verses.text: Why are idolaters found fault with? Is it not because they knew God and did not honour Him as God? Why are the "foolish Galatians" reproached by Paul in the words, "After that ye have known God, or rather are known of God, how turn ye again to the weak and beggarly elements?" How was God known in Jewry? Was it because in Jewry it was known what His essence is? "The ox," it is said, "knoweth his owner".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:31
verses.text: According to your argument the ox knows his lord's essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:32
verses.text: "And the ass his master's crib".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:33
verses.text: So the ass knows the essence of the crib, but "Israel doth not know me".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:34
verses.text: So, according to you, Israel is found fault with for not knowing what the essence of God is.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:35
verses.text: "Pour out thy wrath upon the heathen that have not known thee," that is, who have not comprehended thy essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:36
verses.text: But, I repeat, knowledge is manifold—it involves perception of our Creator, recognition of His wonderful works, observance of His commandments and intimate communion with Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:37
verses.text: All this they thrust on one side and force knowledge into one single meaning, the contemplation of God's essence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:38
verses.text: Thou shalt put them, it is said, before the testimony and I shall be known of thee thence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:39
verses.text: Is the term, "I shall be known of thee," instead of, "I will reveal my essence"? "The Lord knoweth them that are his".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:40
verses.text: Does He know the essence of them that are His, but is ignorant of the essence of those who disobey Him? "Adam knew his wife".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:41
verses.text: Did he know her essence? It is said of Rebekah "She was a virgin, neither had any man known her," and "How shall this be seeing I know not a man?" Did no man know Rebekah's essence? Does Mary mean "I do not know the essence of any man"? Is it not the custom of Scripture to use the word "know" of nuptial embraces? The statement that God shall be known from the mercy seat means that He will be known to His worshippers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 235:42
verses.text: And the Lord knoweth them that are His, means that on account of their good works He receives them into intimate communion with Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:2
verses.text: To the same Amphilochius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:4
verses.text: Enquiry has already frequently been made concerning the saying of the gospels as to our Lord Jesus Christ's ignorance of the day and of the hour of the end; an objection constantly put forward by the Anomoeans to the destruction of the glory of the Only-Begotten, in order to show Him to be unlike in essence and subordinate in dignity; inasmuch as, if He know not all things, He cannot possess the same nature nor be regarded as of one likeness with Him, who by His own prescience and faculty of forecasting the future has knowledge coextensive with the universe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:5
verses.text: This question has now been proposed to me by your intelligence as a new one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:6
verses.text: I can give in reply the answer which I heard from our fathers when I was a boy, and which on account of my love for what is good, I have received without question.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:7
verses.text: I do not expect that it can undo the shamelessness of them that fight against Christ, for where is the reasoning strong enough to stand their attack? It may, however, suffice to convince all that love the Lord, and in whom the previous assurance supplied them by faith is stronger than any demonstration of reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:8
verses.text: Now "no man" seems to be a general expression, so that not even one person is excepted by it, but this is not its use in Scripture, as I have observed in the passage "there is none good but one, that is, God".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:9
verses.text: For even in this passage the Son does not so speak to the exclusion of Himself from the good nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:10
verses.text: But, since the Father is the first good, we believe the words "no man" to have been uttered with the understood addition of "first".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:11
verses.text: So with the passage "No man knoweth the Son but the Father;" even here there is no charge of ignorance against the Spirit, but only a testimony that knowledge of His own nature naturally belongs to the Father first.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:12
verses.text: Thus also we understand "No man knoweth," to refer to the Father the first knowledge of things, both present and to be, and generally to exhibit to men the first cause.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:13
verses.text: Otherwise how can this passage fall in with the rest of the evidence of Scripture, or agree with the common notions of us who believe that the Only-Begotten is the image of the invisible God, and image not of the bodily figure, but of the very Godhead and of the mighty qualities attributed to the essence of God, image of power, image of wisdom, as Christ is called "the power of God and the wisdom of God"? Now of wisdom knowledge is plainly a part; and if in any part He falls short, He is not an image of the whole; and how can we understand the Father not to have shewn that day and that hour—the smallest portion of the ages—to Him through Whom He made the ages? How can the Creator of the universe fall short of the knowledge of the smallest portion of the things created by Him? How can He who says, when the end is near, that such and such signs shall appear in heaven and in earth, be ignorant of the end itself? When He says, "The end is not yet".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:14
verses.text: He makes a definite statement, as though with knowledge and not in doubt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:15
verses.text: Then further, it is plain to the fair enquirer that our Lord says many things to men, in the character of man; as for instance, "give me to drink" is a saying of our Lord, expressive of His bodily necessity; and yet the asker was not soulless flesh, but Godhead using flesh endued with soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:16
verses.text: So in the present instance no one will be carried beyond the bounds of the interpretation of true religion, who understands the ignorance of him who had received all things according to the oeconomy, and was advancing with God and man in favour and wisdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:18
verses.text: It would be worthy of your diligence to set the phrases of the Gospel side by side, and compare together those of Matthew and those of Mark, for these two alone are found in concurrence in this passage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:19
verses.text: The wording of Matthew is "of that day and hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels of heaven, but my Father only".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:20
verses.text: That of Mark runs, "But of that day and that hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels which are in heaven, neither the Son, but the Father".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:21
verses.text: What is noticeable in these passages is this; that Matthew says nothing about the ignorance of the Son, and seems to agree with Mark as to sense in saying "but my Father only".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:22
verses.text: Now I understand the word "only" to have been used in contradistinction to the angels, but that the Son is not included with His own servants in ignorance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:23
verses.text: He could not say what is false Who said "All things that the Father hath are Mine," but one of the things which the Father hath is knowledge of that day and of that hour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:24
verses.text: In the passage in Matthew, then, the Lord made no mention of His own Person, as a matter beyond controversy, and said that the angels knew not and that His Father alone knew, tacitly asserting the knowledge of His Father to be His own knowledge too, because of what He had said elsewhere, "as the Father knoweth me even so know I the Father," and if the Father has complete knowledge of the Son, nothing excepted, so that He knows all knowledge to dwell in Him, He will clearly be known as fully by the Son with all His inherent wisdom and all His knowledge of things to come.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:25
verses.text: This modification, I think, may be given to the words of Matthew, "but my Father only".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:26
verses.text: Now as to the words of Mark, who appears distinctly to exclude the Son from the knowledge, my opinion is this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:27
verses.text: No man knoweth, neither the angels of God; nor yet the Son would have known unless the Father had known: that is, the cause of the Son's knowing comes from the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:28
verses.text: To a fair hearer there is no violence in this interpretation, because the word "only" is not added as it is in Matthew.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:29
verses.text: Mark's sense, then, is as follows: of that day and of that hour knoweth no man, nor the angels of God; but even the Son would not have known if the Father had not known, for the knowledge naturally His was given by the Father.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:30
verses.text: This is very decorous and becoming the divine nature to say of the Son, because He has, His knowledge and His being, beheld in all the wisdom and glory which become His Godhead, from Him with Whom He is consubstantial.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:32
verses.text: As to Jeconias, whom the prophet Jeremiah declares in these words to have been rejected from the land of Judah, "Jeconias was dishonoured like a vessel for which there is no more use; and because he was cast out he and his seed; and none shall rise from his seed sitting upon the throne of David and ruling in Judah," the matter is plain and clear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:33
verses.text: On the destruction of Jerusalem by Nebuchadnezzar, the kingdom had been destroyed, and there was no longer an hereditary succession of reigns as before.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:34
verses.text: Nevertheless, at that time, the deposed descendants of David were living in captivity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:35
verses.text: On the return of Salathiel and Zerubbabel the supreme government rested to a greater degree with the people, and the sovereignty was afterwards transferred to the priesthood, on account of the intermingling of the priestly and royal tribes; whence the Lord, in things pertaining to God, is both King and High Priest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:36
verses.text: Moreover, the royal tribe did not fail until the coming of the Christ; nevertheless, the seed of Jeconias sat no longer upon the throne of David.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:37
verses.text: Plainly it is the royal dignity which is described by the term "throne".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:38
verses.text: You remember the history, how all Judaea, Idumaea, Moab, both the neighbouring regions of Syria and the further countries up to Mesopotamia, and the country on the other side as far as the river of Egypt, were all tributary to David.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:39
verses.text: If then none of his descendants appeared with a sovereignty so wide, how is not the word of the prophet true that no one of the seed of Jeconias should any longer sit upon the throne of David, for none of his descendants appears to have attained this dignity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:40
verses.text: Nevertheless, the tribe of Judah did not fail, until He for whom it was destined came.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:41
verses.text: But even He did not sit upon the material throne.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:42
verses.text: The kingdom of Judaea was transferred to Herod, the son of Antipater the Ascalonite, and his sons who divided Judaea into four principalities, when Pilate was Procurator and Tiberius was Master of the Roman Empire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:43
verses.text: It is the indestructible kingdom which he calls the throne of David on which the Lord sat.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:44
verses.text: He is the expectation of the Gentiles and not of the smallest division of the world, for it is written, "In that day there shall be a root of Jesse which shall stand for an ensign of the people; to it shall the Gentiles seek".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:45
verses.text: "I have called thee…for a covenant of the people for a light of the Gentiles"; and thus then God remained a priest although He did not receive the sceptre of Judah, and King of all the earth; so the blessing of Jacob was fulfilled, and in Him "shall all the nations of the earth be blessed," and all the nations shall call the Christ blessed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:47
verses.text: And as to the tremendous question put by the facetious Encratites, why we do not eat everything? Let this answer be given, that we turn with disgust from our excrements.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:48
verses.text: As far as dignity goes, to us flesh is grass; but as to distinction between what is and what is not serviceable, just as in vegetables, we separate the unwholesome from the wholesome, so in flesh we distinguish between that which is good and that which is bad for food.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:49
verses.text: Hemlock is a vegetable, just as vulture's flesh is flesh; yet no one in his senses would eat henbane nor dog's flesh unless he were in very great straits.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:50
verses.text: If he did, however, he would not sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:52
verses.text: Next as to those who maintain that human affairs are governed by fate, do not ask information from me, but stab them with their own shafts of rhetoric.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:53
verses.text: The question is too long for my present infirmity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:54
verses.text: With regard to emerging in baptism—I do not know how it came into your mind to ask such a question, if indeed you understood immersion to fulfil the figure of the three days.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:55
verses.text: It is impossible for any one to be immersed three times, without emerging three times.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:56
verses.text: We write the word φάγος paroxytone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:58
verses.text: The distinction between οὐσία and ὑπόστασις is the same as that between the general and the particular; as, for instance, between the animal and the particular man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:59
verses.text: Wherefore, in the case of the Godhead, we confess one essence or substance so as not to give a variant definition of existence, but we confess a particular hypostasis, in order that our conception of Father, Son and Holy Spirit may be without confusion and clear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:60
verses.text: If we have no distinct perception of the separate characteristics, namely, fatherhood, sonship, and sanctification, but form our conception of God from the general idea of existence, we cannot possibly give a sound account of our faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:61
verses.text: We must, therefore, confess the faith by adding the particular to the common.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:62
verses.text: The Godhead is common; the fatherhood particular.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:63
verses.text: We must therefore combine the two and say, "I believe in God the Father".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:64
verses.text: The like course must be pursued in the confession of the Son; we must combine the particular with the common and say "I believe in God the Son," so in the case of the Holy Ghost we must make our utterance conform to the appellation and say "in God the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:65
verses.text: Hence it results that there is a satisfactory preservation of the unity by the confession of the one Godhead, while in the distinction of the individual properties regarded in each there is the confession of the peculiar properties of the Persons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:66
verses.text: On the other hand those who identify essence or substance and hypostasis are compelled to confess only three Persons, and, in their hesitation to speak of three hypostases, are convicted of failure to avoid the error of Sabellius, for even Sabellius himself, who in many places confuses the conception, yet, by asserting that the same hypostasis changed its form to meet the needs of the moment, does endeavour to distinguish persons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:68
verses.text: Lastly as to your enquiry in what manner things neutral and indifferent are ordained for us, whether by some chance working by its own accord, or by the righteous providence of God, my answer is this: Health and sickness, riches and poverty, credit and discredit, inasmuch as they do not render their possessors good, are not in the category of things naturally good, but, in so far as in any way they make life's current flow more easily, in each case the former is to be preferred to its contrary, and has a certain kind of value.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:69
verses.text: To some men these things are given by God for stewardship's sake, as for instance to Abraham, to Job and such like.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:70
verses.text: To inferior characters they are a challenge to improvement.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:71
verses.text: For the man who persists in unrighteousness, after so goodly a token of love from God, subjects himself to condemnation without defence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:72
verses.text: The good man, however, neither turns his heart to wealth when he has it, nor seeks after it if he has it not.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:73
verses.text: He treats what is given him as given him not for his selfish enjoyment, but for wise administration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:74
verses.text: No one in his senses runs after the trouble of distributing other people's property, unless he is trying to get the praise of the world, which admires and envies anybody in authority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:75
verses.text: Good men take sickness as athletes take their contest, waiting for the crowns that are to reward their endurance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 236:76
verses.text: To ascribe the dispensation of these things to any one else is as inconsistent with true religion as it is with common sense.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:4
verses.text: I both wrote to your reverence by the vicar of Thrace, and sent other letters by one of the officers of the treasury of Philippopolis, who was starting from our country into Thrace, and begged him to take them on his departure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:5
verses.text: But the vicar never received my letter, for while I was visiting my diocese, he came into town in the evening and started early in the morning, so that the church officers did not know of his coming, and the letter remained at my house.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:6
verses.text: The treasurer, too, on account of some unexpected and urgent business, set out without seeing me or taking my letters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:7
verses.text: No one else could be found; so I remained, sorry at not being able to write to you and at not receiving any letter from your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:8
verses.text: Yet I was wishful, were it possible, to tell you all that happens to me day by day.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:9
verses.text: So many astonishing things happen as to need a daily narrative, and you may be sure that I would have written one, unless my mind had been diverted from its purpose by the pressure of events.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:11
verses.text: The first and greatest of my troubles was the visit of the Vicar.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:12
verses.text: As to whether he is a man really heretically minded I do not know; for I think that he is quite unversed in doctrine, and has not the slightest interest or experience in such things, for I see him day and night busy, both in body and soul, in other things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:13
verses.text: But he is certainly a friend of heretics; and he is not more friendly to them than he is ill-disposed to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:14
verses.text: He has summoned a synod of wicked men in mid-winter in Galatia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:15
verses.text: He has deposed Hypsinus and set up Ecdicius in his place.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:16
verses.text: He has ordered the removal of my brother on the accusation of one man, and that one quite insignificant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:17
verses.text: Then, after being occupied for some little time about the army, he came to us again breathing rage and slaughter, and, in one sentence, delivered all the Church of Caesarea to the Senate.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:18
verses.text: He settled for several days at Sebaste, separating friends from foes, calling those in communion with me senators, and condemning them to the public service, while he advanced the adherents of Eustathius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:19
verses.text: He has ordered a second synod of bishops of Galatia and Pontus to be assembled at Nyssa.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:20
verses.text: They have submitted, have met, and have sent to the Churches a man of whose character I do not like to speak; but your reverence can well understand what sort of a man he must be who would put himself at the disposal of such counsels of men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:21
verses.text: Now, while I am thus writing, the same gang have hurried to Sebaste to unite with Eustathius, and, with him, to upset the Church of Nicopolis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:22
verses.text: For the blessed Theodotus has fallen asleep.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:23
verses.text: Hitherto the Nicopolitans have bravely and stoutly resisted the vicar's first assault; for he tried to persuade them to receive Eustathius, and to accept their bishop on his appointment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:24
verses.text: But, on seeing them unwilling to yield, he is now trying, by yet more violent action, to effect the establishment of the bishop whom it has been attempted to give them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:25
verses.text: There is, moreover, said to be some rumoured expectation of a synod, by which means they mean to summon me to receive them into communion, or to be friendly with them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:26
verses.text: Such is the position of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:27
verses.text: As to my own health, I think it better to say nothing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 237:28
verses.text: I cannot bear not to tell the truth, and by telling the truth I shall only grieve you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:2
verses.text: To the presbyters of Nicopolis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:3
verses.text: I have received your letter, my reverend brethren, but it told me nothing that I did not already know, for the whole country round about was already full of the report announcing the disgrace of that one among you who has fallen, and through lust of vain glory has brought on himself very shameful dishonour, and has through his self-love lost the rewards promised to faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:4
verses.text: Nay, through the just hatred of them that fear the Lord he misses even that contemptible little glory for lust of which he has been sold to impiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:5
verses.text: By the character he has now shown he has very plainly proved, concerning all his life, that he has never at any time lived in hope of the promises laid up for us by the Lord, but, in all his transactions of human affairs, has used words of faith and mockery of piety, all to deceive every one whom he met.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:6
verses.text: But how are you injured? Are you any worse off for this than you were before? One of your number has fallen away, and if one or two others have gone with him, they are to be pitied for their fall, but, by God's grace, your body is whole.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:7
verses.text: The useless part has gone, and what is left has not suffered mutilation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:8
verses.text: You are haply distressed that you are driven without the walls, but you shall dwell under the protection of the God of Heaven, and the angel who watches over the Church has gone out with you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:9
verses.text: So they lie down in empty places day by day, bringing upon themselves heavy judgment through the dispersion of the people.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:10
verses.text: And, if in all this there is sorrow to be borne, I trust in the Lord that it will not be without its use to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:11
verses.text: Therefore, the more have been your trials, look for a more perfect reward from your just Judge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:12
verses.text: Do not take your present troubles ill.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:13
verses.text: Do not lose hope.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 238:14
verses.text: Yet a little while and your Helper will come to you and will not tarry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:1
verses.text: Letter CCXXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:4
verses.text: The Lord has granted me the privilege of now saluting your holiness by our beloved and very reverend brother, the presbyter Antiochus, of exhorting you to pray for me as you are wont, and offering in our communication by letter some consolation for our long separation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:5
verses.text: And, when you pray, I ask you to beg from the Lord this as the first and greatest boon, that I may be delivered from vile and wicked men, who have gained such power over the people that now I seem to see, indeed, a repetition of the events of the taking of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:6
verses.text: For the weaker grow the Churches the more does men's lust for power increase.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:7
verses.text: And now the very title of bishop has been conferred on wretched slaves, for no servant of God would choose to come forward in opposition to claim the see;—no one but miserable fellows like the emissaries of Anysius the creature of Euippius, and of Ecdicius of Parnassus: whoever has appointed him has sent into the Churches a poor means of aiding his own entry into the life to come.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:8
verses.text: They have expelled my brother from Nyssa, and into his place have introduced hardly a man—a mere scamp worth only an obol or two, but, so far as regards the ruin of the faith, a match for those who have put him where he is.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:9
verses.text: At the town of Doara they have brought shame upon the poor name of bishop, and have sent there a wretch, an orphans' domestic, a runaway from his own masters, to flatter a godless woman, who formerly used George as she liked, and now has got this fellow to succeed him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:10
verses.text: And who could properly lament the occurrences at Nicopolis? That unhappy Fronto did, indeed, for a while pretend to be on the side of the truth, but now he has shamefully betrayed both the faith and himself, and for the price of his betrayal has got a name of disgrace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:11
verses.text: He imagines that he has obtained from these men the rank of bishop; in reality he has become, by God's grace, the abomination of all Armenia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:12
verses.text: But there is nothing that they will not dare; nothing wherein they are at a loss for worthy accomplices.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:13
verses.text: But the rest of the news of Syria my brother knows better, and can tell you better, than I.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:15
verses.text: The news of the West you know already, on the recital of brother Dorotheus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:16
verses.text: What sort of letters are to be given him on his departure? Perhaps he will travel with the excellent Sanctissimus, who is full of enthusiasm, journeying through the East, and collecting letters and signatures from all the men of mark.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:17
verses.text: What ought to be written by them, or how I can come to an agreement with those who are writing, I do not know.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:18
verses.text: If you hear of any one soon travelling my way, be so good as to let me know.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:19
verses.text: I am moved to say, as Diomede said,  "Would God, Atrides, thy request were yet to undertake;  …he's proud enough".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:20
verses.text: Really lofty souls, when they are courted, get haughtier than ever.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:21
verses.text: If the Lord be propitious to us, what other thing do we need? If the anger of the Lord lasts on, what help can come to us from the frown of the West? Men who do not know the truth, and do not wish to learn it, but are prejudiced by false suspicions, are doing now as they did in the case of Marcellus, when they quarrelled with men who told them the truth, and by their own action strengthened the cause of heresy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:22
verses.text: Apart from the common document, I should like to have written to their Coryphaeus—nothing, indeed, about ecclesiastical affairs except gently to suggest that they know nothing of what is going on here, and will not accept the only means whereby they might learn it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:23
verses.text: I would say, generally, that they ought not to press hard on men who are crushed by trials.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:24
verses.text: They must not take dignity for pride.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 239:25
verses.text: Sin only avails to produce enmity against God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:1
verses.text: Letter CCXL.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:2
verses.text: To the Presbyters of Nicopolis.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:4
verses.text: You have done quite right in sending me a letter, and in sending it by the hands of one who, even if you had not written, would have been perfectly competent to give me considerable comfort in all my anxieties, and an authentic report as to the position of affairs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:5
verses.text: Many vague rumours were continually reaching me, and therefore I was desirous of getting information on many points from some one able to give it through accurate knowledge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:6
verses.text: Touching all these I have received a satisfactory and intelligent narrative from our well-beloved and honourable brother Theodosius the presbyter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:7
verses.text: I now write to your reverences the advice which I give myself, for in many respects our positions are identical; and that not only at the present moment, but in times gone by too, as many instances may prove.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:8
verses.text: Of some of these we possess records in writing; others we have received through unwritten recollection from persons acquainted with the facts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:9
verses.text: We know how, for the sake of the name of the Lord, trials have beset alike individuals and cities that have put their trust in Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:10
verses.text: Nevertheless, one and all have passed away, and the distress caused by the days of darkness has not been everlasting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:11
verses.text: For just as when hail-storm and flood, and all natural calamities, at once injure and destroy things that have no strength, while they are only themselves affected by falling on the strong, so the terrible trials set in action against the Church have been proved feebler than the firm foundation of our faith in Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:12
verses.text: The hail-storm has passed away; the torrent has rushed over its bed; clear sky has taken the place of the former, and the latter has left the course without water and dry, over which it travelled, and has disappeared in the deep.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:13
verses.text: So, too, in a little while the storm, now bursting upon us, will cease to be.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:14
verses.text: But this will be on the condition of our being willing not to look to the present, but to gaze in hope at the future somewhat further off.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:16
verses.text: Is the trial heavy, my brethren? Let us endure the toil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:17
verses.text: No one who shuns the blows and the dust of battle wins a crown.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:18
verses.text: Are those mockeries of the devil, and the enemies sent to attack us, insignificant? They are troublesome because they are his ministers, but contemptible because God has in them combined wickedness with weakness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:19
verses.text: Let us beware of being condemned for crying out too loud over a little pain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:20
verses.text: Only one thing is worth anguish, the loss of one's own self, when for the sake of the credit of the moment, if one can really call making a public disgrace of one's self credit, one has deprived one's self of the everlasting reward of the just.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:21
verses.text: You are children of confessors; you are children of martyrs; you have resisted sin unto blood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:22
verses.text: Use, each one of you, the examples of those near and dear to you to make you brave for true religion's sake.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:23
verses.text: No one of us has been torn by lashes; no one of us has suffered confiscation of his house; we have not been driven into exile; we have not suffered imprisonment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:24
verses.text: What great suffering have we undergone, unless peradventure it is grievous that we have suffered nothing, and have not been reckoned worthy of the sufferings of Christ? But if you are grieved because one whom I need not name occupies the house of prayer, and you worship the Lord of heaven and earth in the open air, remember that the eleven disciples were shut up in the upper chamber, when they that had crucified the Lord were worshipping in the Jews' far-famed temple.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:25
verses.text: Peradventure, Judas, who preferred death by hanging to life in disgrace, proved himself a better man than those who now meet universal condemnation without a blush.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:27
verses.text: Only do not be deceived by their lies when they claim to be of the right faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:28
verses.text: They are not Christians, but traffickers in Christ, always preferring their profit in this life to living in accordance with the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:29
verses.text: When they thought that they should get this empty dignity, they joined the enemies of Christ: now that they have seen the indignation of the people, they are once more for pretending orthodoxy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:30
verses.text: I do not recognise as bishop—I would not count among Christ's clergy—a man who has been promoted to a chief post by polluted hands, to the destruction of the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:31
verses.text: This is my decision.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:32
verses.text: If you have any part with me, you will doubtless think as I do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:33
verses.text: If you take counsel on your own responsibility, every man is master of his own mind, and I am innocent of this blood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:34
verses.text: I have written thus, not because I distrust you, but that by declaring my own mind I may strengthen some men's hesitation, and prevent any one from being prematurely received into communion, or after receiving the laying on of hands of our enemies, when peace is made, later on, trying to force me to enroll them in the ranks of the sacred ministry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 240:35
verses.text: Through you I salute the clergy of the city and diocese, and all the laity who fear the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 241:1
verses.text: Letter CCXLI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 241:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 241:3
verses.text: It is not to increase your distress that I am so lavish of painful topics in my letters to your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 241:4
verses.text: My object is to get some comfort for myself in the lamentations which are a kind of natural means of dispersing deep-seated pain whenever they are produced, and further to rouse you, my great-hearted friend, to more earnest prayer on behalf of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 241:5
verses.text: We know that Moses prayed continually for the people; yet, when his battle with Amalek had begun, he did not let down his hands from morning to evening, and the uplifting of the hands of the saint only ended with the end of the fight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:1
verses.text: Letter CCXLII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:2
verses.text: To the Westerns.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:4
verses.text: The Holy God has promised a happy of issue out of all their infirmities to those that trust in Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:5
verses.text: We, therefore, though we have been cut off in a mid-ocean of troubles, though we are tossed by the great waves raised up against us by the spirits of wickedness, nevertheless hold out in Christ Who strengthens us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:6
verses.text: We have not slackened the strength of our zeal for the Churches, nor, as though despairing of our salvation, while the billows in the tempest rise above our heads, do we look to be destroyed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:7
verses.text: On the contrary, we are still holding out with all possible earnestness, remembering how even he who was swallowed by the sea monster, because he did not despair of his life, but cried to the Lord, was saved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:8
verses.text: Thus too we, though we have reached the last pitch of peril, do not give up our hope in God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:9
verses.text: On every side we see His succour round about us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:10
verses.text: For these reasons now we turn our eyes to you, right honourable brethren.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:11
verses.text: In many an hour of our affliction we have expected that you would be at our side; and disappointed in that hope we have said to ourselves, "I looked for some to take pity and there was none; and for comforters but I found none".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:12
verses.text: Our sufferings are such as to have reached the confines of the empire; and since, when one member suffers, all the members suffer, it is doubtless right that your pity should be shown to us who have been so long in trouble.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:13
verses.text: For that sympathy, which we have hoped you of your charity feel for us, is caused less by nearness of place than by union of spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:15
verses.text: How comes it to pass then that we have received nothing of what is due to us by the law of love; no letter of consolation, no visit from brethren? This is now the thirteenth year since the war of heresy began against us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:16
verses.text: In this the Churches have suffered more tribulations than all those which are on record since Christ's gospel was first preached.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:17
verses.text: I am unwilling to describe these one by one, lest the feebleness of my narrative should make the evidence of the calamities less convincing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:18
verses.text: It is moreover the less necessary for me to tell you of them, because you have long known what has happened from the reports which will have reached you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:19
verses.text: The sum and substance of our troubles is this: the people have left the houses of prayer and are holding congregations in the wildernesses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:20
verses.text: It is a sad sight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:21
verses.text: Women, boys, old men, and those who are in other ways infirm, remain in the open air, in heavy rain, in the snow, the gales and the frost of winter as well as in summer under the blazing heat of the sun.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:22
verses.text: All this they are suffering because they refuse to have anything to do with the wicked leaven of Arius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:24
verses.text: How could mere words give you any clear idea of all this without your being stirred to sympathy by personal experience and the evidence of eyewitnesses? We implore you, therefore, to stretch out a helping hand to those that have already been stricken to the ground, and to send messengers to remind us of the prizes in store for the reward of all who patiently suffer for Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:25
verses.text: A voice that we are used to is naturally less able to comfort us than one which sounds from afar, and that one coming from men who over all the world are known by God's grace to be among the noblest; for common report everywhere represents you as having remained steadfast, without suffering a wound in your faith, and as having kept the deposit of the apostles inviolate.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:26
verses.text: This is not our case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:27
verses.text: There are among us some who, through lust of glory and that puffing up which is especially wont to destroy the souls of Christian men, have audaciously uttered certain novelties of expression with the result that the Churches have become like cracked pots and pans and have let in the inrush of heretical impurity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 242:28
verses.text: But do you, whom we love and long for, be to us as surgeons for the wounded, as trainers for the whole, healing the limb that is diseased, and anointing the limb that is sound for the service of the true religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:1
verses.text: Letter CCXLIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:2
verses.text: To the bishops of Italy and Gaul concerning the condition and confusion of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:4
verses.text: To his brethren truly God-beloved and very dear, and fellow ministers of like mind, the bishops of Gaul and Italy, Basil, bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:5
verses.text: Our Lord Jesus Christ, Who has deigned to style the universal Church of God His body, and has made us individually members one of another, has moreover granted to all of us to live in intimate association with one another, as befits the agreement of the members.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:6
verses.text: Wherefore, although we dwell far away from one another, yet, as regards our close conjunction, we are very near.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:7
verses.text: Since, then, the head cannot say to the feet, I have no need of you, you will not, I am sure, endure to reject us; you will, on the contrary, sympathize with us in the troubles to which, for our sins, we have been given over, in proportion as we rejoice together with you in your glorying in the peace which the Lord has bestowed on you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:8
verses.text: Ere now we have also at another time invoked your charity to send us succour and sympathy; but our punishment was not full, and you were not suffered to rise up to succour us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:9
verses.text: One chief object of our desire is that through you the state of confusion in which we are situated should be made known to the emperor of your part of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:10
verses.text: If this is difficult, we beseech you to send envoys to visit and comfort us in our affliction, that you may have the evidence of eyewitnesses of those sufferings of the East which cannot be told by word of mouth, because language is inadequate to give a clear report of our condition.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:12
verses.text: Persecution has come upon us, right honourable brethren, and persecution in the severest form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:13
verses.text: Shepherds are persecuted that their flocks may be scattered.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:14
verses.text: And the worst of all is that those who are being treated ill cannot accept their sufferings in proof of their testimony, nor can the people reverence the athletes as in the army of martyrs, because the name of Christians is applied to the persecutors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:15
verses.text: The one charge which is now sure to secure severe punishment is the careful keeping of the traditions of the Fathers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:16
verses.text: For this the pious are exiled from their homes, and are sent away to dwell in distant regions.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:17
verses.text: No reverence is shown by the judges of iniquity to the hoary head, to practical piety, to the life lived from boyhood to old age according to the Gospel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:18
verses.text: No malefactor is doomed without proof, but bishops have been convicted on calumny alone, and are consigned to penalties on charges wholly unsupported by evidence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:19
verses.text: Some have not even known who has accused them, nor been brought before any tribunal, nor even been falsely accused at all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:20
verses.text: They have been apprehended with violence late at night, have been exiled to distant places, and, through the hardships of these remote wastes, have been given over to death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:21
verses.text: The rest is notorious, though I make no mention of it—the flight of priests; the flight of deacons; the foraying of all the clergy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:22
verses.text: Either the image must be worshipped, or we are delivered to the wicked flame of whips.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:23
verses.text: The laity groan; tears are falling without ceasing in public and in private; all are mutually lamenting their woes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:24
verses.text: No one's heart is so hard as to lose a father, and bear the bereavement meekly.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:25
verses.text: There is a sound of them that mourn in the city—a sound in the fields, in the roads, in the deserts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:26
verses.text: But one voice is heard from all that utter sad and piteous words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:27
verses.text: Joy and spiritual gladness are taken away.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:28
verses.text: Our feasts are turned into mourning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:29
verses.text: Our houses of prayer are shut.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:30
verses.text: The altars of the spiritual service are lying idle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:31
verses.text: Christians no longer assemble together; teachers no longer preside.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:32
verses.text: The doctrines of salvation are no longer taught.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:33
verses.text: We have no more solemn assemblies, no more evening hymns, no more of that blessed joy of souls which arises in the souls of all that believe in the Lord at communions, and the imparting of spiritual boons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:34
verses.text: We may well say, "Neither is there at this time prince, or prophet, or reader, or offering, or incense, or place to sacrifice before thee, and to find mercy".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:36
verses.text: We are writing to those who know these things, for there is not a region of the world which is ignorant of our calamities.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:37
verses.text: Do not suppose that we are using these words as though to give information, or to recall ourselves to your recollection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:38
verses.text: We know that you could no more forget us than a mother forget the sons of her womb.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:39
verses.text: But all who are crushed by any weight of agony find some natural alleviation for their pain in uttering groans of distress, and it is for this that we are doing as we do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:40
verses.text: We get rid of the load of our grief in telling you of our manifold misfortunes, and in expressing the hope that you may haply be the more moved to pray for us, and may prevail on the Lord to be reconciled to us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:41
verses.text: And if these afflictions had been confined to ourselves, we might even have determined to keep silence, and to rejoice in our sufferings for Christ's sake, since "the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:42
verses.text: But at the present time we are alarmed, lest the mischief growing day by day, like a flame spreading through some burning wood, when it has consumed what is close at hand, may catch distant objects too.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:43
verses.text: The plague of heresy is spreading, and there is ground of apprehension lest, when it has devoured our Churches, it may afterwards creep on even so far as to the sound portion of your district.
