verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:44
verses.text: Peradventure it is because with us iniquity has abounded that we have been first delivered to be devoured by the cruel teeth of the enemies of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:45
verses.text: But the gospel of the kingdom began in our regions, and then went forth over all the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:46
verses.text: So, peradventure—and this is most probable—the common enemy of our souls, is striving to bring it about that the seeds of apostasy, originating in the same quarter, should be distributed throughout the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:47
verses.text: For the darkness of impiety plots to come upon the very hearts whereon the "light of the knowledge" of Christ has shone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:49
verses.text: Reckon then, as true disciples of the Lord, that our sufferings are yours.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:50
verses.text: We are not being attacked for the sake of riches, or glory, or any temporal advantages.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:51
verses.text: We stand in the arena to fight for our common heritage, for the treasure of the sound faith, derived from our Fathers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:52
verses.text: Grieve with us, all ye who love the brethren, at the shutting of the mouths of our men of true religion, and at the opening of the bold and blasphemous lips of all that utter unrighteousness against God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:53
verses.text: The pillars and foundation of the truth are scattered abroad.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:54
verses.text: We, whose insignificance has allowed of our being overlooked, are deprived of our right of free speech.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:55
verses.text: Do ye enter into the struggle, for the people's sake.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:56
verses.text: Do not think only of your being yourselves moored in a safe haven, where the grace of God gives you shelter from the tempest of the winds of wickedness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:57
verses.text: Reach out a helping hand to the Churches that are being buffeted by the storm, lest, if they be abandoned, they suffer complete shipwreck of the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:58
verses.text: Lament for us, in that the Only-begotten is being blasphemed, and there is none to offer contradiction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:59
verses.text: The Holy Ghost is being set at nought and he who is able to confute the error has been sent into exile.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:60
verses.text: Polytheism has prevailed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:61
verses.text: Our opponents own a great God and a small God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:62
verses.text: "Son" is no longer a name of nature, but is looked upon as a title of some kind of honour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:63
verses.text: The Holy Ghost is regarded not as complemental of the Holy Trinity, nor as participating in the divine and blessed Nature, but as in some sort one of the number of created beings, and attached to Father and Son, at mere haphazard and as occasion may require.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:64
verses.text: "Oh that my head were waters, and mine eyes a fountain of tears," and I will weep many days for the people who are being driven to destruction by these vile doctrines.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:65
verses.text: The ears of the simple are being led astray, and have now got used to heretical impiety.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:66
verses.text: The nurslings of the Church are being brought up in the doctrines of iniquity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:67
verses.text: What are they to do? Our opponents have the command of baptisms; they speed the dying on their way; they visit the sick; they console the sorrowful; they aid the distressed; they give succour of various kinds; they communicate the mysteries.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:68
verses.text: All these things, as long as the performance of them is in their hands, are so many ties to bind the people to their views.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:69
verses.text: The result will be that in a little time, even if some liberty be conceded to us, there is small hope that they who have been long under the influence of error will be recalled to recognition of the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:71
verses.text: Under these circumstances it would have been well for many of us to have travelled to your reverences, and to have individually reported each his own position.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:72
verses.text: You may now take as a proof of the sore straits in which we are placed the fact that we are not even free to travel abroad.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:73
verses.text: For if any one leaves his Church, even for a very brief space, he will leave his people at the mercy of those who are plotting their ruin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:74
verses.text: By God's mercy instead of many we have sent one, our very reverend and beloved brother the presbyter Dorotheus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:75
verses.text: He is fully able to supply by his personal report whatever has been omitted in our letter, for he has carefully followed all that has occurred, and is jealous of the right faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 243:76
verses.text: Receive him in peace, and speedily send him back to us, bringing us good news of your readiness to succour the brotherhood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:1
verses.text: Letter CCXLIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:2
verses.text: To Patrophilus, bishop of aegae.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:4
verses.text: I have read, and read with pleasure, the letter which you have sent by Strategius the presbyter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:5
verses.text: How should I not so read it, written as it is by a wise man, and dictated by a heart which has learned to observe the universal love taught by the commandment of the Lord? Possibly I am not unaware of the reasons which have hitherto kept you silent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:6
verses.text: You have been, as it were, amazed and astounded, at the idea of the change in the notorious Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:7
verses.text: Why, ever since he was a boy he did such and such service to such an one; at such and such times he did such and such things; he waged war against foes innumerable for the sake of his allegiance to one man; now he has become a totally different character; he has exchanged love for war; he is all that you have written; so you naturally shew considerable astonishment at the very unexpected turn of affairs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:8
verses.text: And if you have found some fault, I do not take it ill.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:9
verses.text: I am not so beyond correction as to be amazed at the affectionate rebukes of my brothers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:10
verses.text: Indeed so far was I from being vexed at your letter that it really almost made me laugh to think that when there were, as I thought, so many strong causes already existing to cement our friendship, you should have expressed such very great astonishment at the trifles which have been reported to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:11
verses.text: So truly have you suffered the fate of all those who omit to enquire into the nature of circumstances, and give heed to the men who are being discussed; of all who do not examine into the truth, but judge by the distinction of persons, in forgetfulness of the exhortion "Ye shall not respect persons in judgment".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:13
verses.text: Nevertheless, since God in judgment of man does not accept persons, I will not refuse to make known to you the defence which I have prepared for the great tribunal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:14
verses.text: On my side, from the beginning, there has been no cause of quarrel, either small or great; but men who hate me, for what reason is best known to themselves (I must not say a word about them), incessantly calumniated me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:15
verses.text: I cleared myself again and again of slanders.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:16
verses.text: There seemed no end to the matter, and no good came of my continual defence, because I was far away, and the authors of the false statements, being on the spot, were able by their calumnies against me to wound a susceptible heart, and one which has never learnt to keep one ear open for the absent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:17
verses.text: When the Nicopolitans, as you yourself are partly aware, were asking for some proof of faith, I determined to have recourse to the written document.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:18
verses.text: I thought that I should fulfil two objects at once; I expected both to persuade the Nicopolitans not to think ill of the man, and to shut the mouths of my calumniators, because agreement in faith would exclude slander on both sides.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:19
verses.text: Indeed the creed had been drawn up, and it was brought from me, and signed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:20
verses.text: After it had been signed, a place was appointed for a second meeting, and another date fixed, so that my brethren in the diocese might come together and be united with one another, and our communion for the future be genuine and sincere.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:21
verses.text: I, for my part, arrived at the appointed time, and, of the brethren who act with me, some were on the spot, and others were hurrying thither, all joyous and eager as though on the high road to peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:22
verses.text: Couriers and a letter from myself announced my arrival; for the spot appointed for the reception of those who were assembling was mine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:23
verses.text: But nobody appeared on the other side; no one came in advance; no one to announce the approach of the expected bishops.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:24
verses.text: So those who had been sent by me returned with the report of the deep dejection and the complaints of those who were assembled, as though a new creed had been promulgated by me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:25
verses.text: They were moreover said to be for deciding, that they certainly would not suffer their bishop to go over to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:26
verses.text: Then came a messenger bringing me a letter hastily drawn up, and containing no mention of the points originally agreed on.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:27
verses.text: My brother Theophilus, a man worthy of all respect and honour at my hands, sent one of his adherents, and made certain announcements, which he thought it not improper for him to utter, nor unbecoming in me to hear.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:28
verses.text: He did not condescend to write, not so much because he was afraid of being convicted on written evidence, as because he was anxious not to be compelled to address me as bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:29
verses.text: Assuredly his language was violent, and came from a heart a vehemently agitated.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:30
verses.text: Under these circumstances I departed abashed and depressed, not knowing what to answer to my questioners.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:31
verses.text: Then, without any long interval of time, there was the journey into Cilicia, the return thence, and forthwith a letter repudiating communion with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:33
verses.text: The cause of the rupture was the allegation that I wrote to Apollinarius and was in communion with the presbyter Diodorus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:34
verses.text: I never regarded Apollinarius as an enemy, and for some reasons I even respect him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:35
verses.text: But I never so far united myself to him as to take upon me the charges against him; indeed I have myself some accusations to bring against him after reading some of his books.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:36
verses.text: I do not know that I ever asked him for a book on the Holy Spirit, or received it on his sending: I am told that he has become a most copious writer, but I have read very few of his works.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:37
verses.text: I have not even time to investigate such matters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:38
verses.text: Indeed I shrink from admitting any of the more recent works, for my health does not even allow of my reading the inspired Scriptures with diligence and as I ought.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:39
verses.text: What, then, is it to me, if some one has written something displeasing to somebody else? Yet if one man is to render an account on behalf of another, let him who accuses me for Apollinarius' sake defend himself to me for the sake of Arius his own master and of Aetius his own disciple.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:40
verses.text: I never learnt anything from, nor taught anything to this man whose guilt is laid at my door.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:41
verses.text: Diodorus, as a nursling of the blessed Silvanus, I did receive from the beginning: I love him now and respect him on account of his grace of speech, whereby many who meet him are made the better men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:43
verses.text: At this letter I was affected in such a manner as might be expected, and astounded at so sudden and pleasant a change.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:44
verses.text: I felt quite unable to reply.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:45
verses.text: My heart could hardly beat; my tongue failed me, and my hand grew numb.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:46
verses.text: I felt like a poor creature (for the truth shall be told; yet it is pardonable); I all but fell into a state of misanthropy; I looked on every one with suspicion and thought that there was no charity to be found in mankind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:47
verses.text: Charity seemed a mere specious word, serving as a kind of decoration to those who use it, while no such sentiment was really to be found in the heart of man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:48
verses.text: Could it really be that one who seemed to have disciplined himself from boyhood to old age, could be so easily brutalized on such grounds, without a thought for me, without any idea that his experience of bygone years ought to have more weight than this wretched slander? Could he really, like an unbroken colt as yet untaught to carry his rider properly, on some petty suspicion rear and unseat his rider and fling to the ground what was once his pride? If so, what must be thought of the rest with whom I had no such strong ties of friendship, and who had given no such proofs of a well trained life? All this I turned over in my soul and continually revolved in my heart, or, shall I rather say my heart was turned over by these things fighting and pricking me at the recollection of them? I wrote no answer; not that I kept silence from contempt; do not think it of me my brother, for I am not defending myself to men but I speak before God in Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:49
verses.text: I kept silence from utter inability to say a word commensurate with my grief.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:51
verses.text: While I was in this position another letter came to me, addressed to a certain Dazizas, but in reality written to all the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:52
verses.text: This is obvious from its very rapid distribution, for in a few days it was delivered all over Pontus, and was travelling about Galatia; indeed it is said that the carriers of this good news traversed Bithynia, and reached the Hellespont itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:53
verses.text: What was written against me to Dazizas you are very well aware, for they do not reckon you as so far beyond the bounds of their friendship as to have left you alone undistinguished by this honour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:54
verses.text: However, if the letter has not reached you, I will send it to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:55
verses.text: In it you will find me charged with craft and treachery, with corruption of Churches and with ruin of souls.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:56
verses.text: The charge which they think the truest of all is, that I made that exposition of the faith for secret and dishonest reasons, not to do service to the Nicopolitans, but with the design of disingenously extracting a confession from them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:57
verses.text: Of all this the Lord is Judge.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:58
verses.text: What clear evidence can there be of the thoughts of the heart? One thing I do wonder at in them, that after signing the document presented by me, they show so much disagreement, that they confuse truth and falsehood to satisfy those who are accusing them, quite forgetful that their written confession of the Nicene Creed is preserved at Rome, and that they with their own hand delivered to the council at Tyana the document brought from Rome which is in my hands, and contains the same creed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:59
verses.text: They forgot their own address, when they came forward and bewailed the deceit by which they had been tricked into giving their adhesion to the document drawn up by the faction of Eudoxius, and so bethought them of the defence for that error, that they should go to Rome and there accept the creed of the Fathers, that so they might make amends, for the mischief they had done the Church by their agreement in evil, by their introduction of something better.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:60
verses.text: Now the very men who undertook long journeys for the faith's sake, and made all these fine speeches, are reviling me for walking craftily, and for playing the plotter under the cloke of love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:61
verses.text: It is plain from the Letter, now being carried about, that they have condemned the faith of Nicaea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:62
verses.text: They saw Cyzicus, and came home with another creed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:64
verses.text: But why say anything of mere verbal inconsistency? The practical proofs of their change of position afforded by their conduct are far stronger.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:65
verses.text: They refused to yield to the sentence of fifty bishops passed against them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:66
verses.text: They declined to resign the government of their Churches although the number of bishops assenting to the decree for their deposition was so many, on the alleged ground that they were not partakers of the Holy Ghost, and were not governing their Churches by the grace of God, but had clutched their dignity by the aid of human power, and through lust of vain glory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:67
verses.text: Now they are for receiving the men consecrated by these same persons as bishops.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:68
verses.text: I should like you to ask them in my stead, (although they despise all mankind, as bereft of eyes, ears, and common sense), to perceive the inconsistency of their conduct, what sentiments they do really entertain in their own hearts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:69
verses.text: How can there be two bishops, one deposed by Euippius, and the other consecrated by him? Both are the actions of the same man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:70
verses.text: Had he not been endowed with the grace bestowed upon Jeremiah to pull down and build again, to root out and to plant, he certainly would not have rooted the one out and planted the other.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:71
verses.text: Grant him the one and you must grant him the other.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:72
verses.text: Their one object, as it seems, is everywhere to look to their own advantage, and to regard every one who acts in accordance with their own wishes as a friend, while they treat any one who opposes them as an enemy, and spare no calumny to run him down.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:74
verses.text: What measures are they now taking against the Church? For the shiftiness of their originators, shocking; for the apathy of all who are affected by them, pitiable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:75
verses.text: By a respectable commission the children and grandchildren of Euippius have been summoned from distant regions to Sebasteia, and to them the people have been entrusted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:76
verses.text: They have taken possession of the altar.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:77
verses.text: They have been made the leaven of that Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:78
verses.text: I am persecuted by them as a Homoousiast.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:79
verses.text: Eustathius, who brought the Homoousion in the script from Rome to Tyana, although he was not able to get admitted into their much to be coveted communion, either because they feared, or respected the authority of, the large number of persons who had agreed in condemning him, is now in intimate alliance with them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:80
verses.text: I only hope that I may never have time enough on my hands to tell of all their doings—who were gathered together, how each one had been ordained, and from what kind of earlier life each arrived at his present dignity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:81
verses.text: I have been taught to pray "that my mouth may not utter the works of the men".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:82
verses.text: If you enquire you will learn these things for yourself, and, if they are hidden from you, they will not assuredly continue hidden from the judges.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:84
verses.text: I will not, however, omit to tell you, my dear friend, in what a state I have been.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:85
verses.text: Last year I suffered from a very violent fever, and came near to the gates of death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:86
verses.text: When, by God's mercy, I was restored, I was distressed at coming back to life, as I bethought me of all the troubles before me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:87
verses.text: I considered with myself for what reason, hidden in the depths of the wisdom of God, yet further days of life in the flesh had been allowed me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:88
verses.text: But when I heard of these matters I concluded that the Lord wished me to see the Churches at rest after the storm which they had previously suffered from the alienation of the men in whom, on account of their fictitious gravity of character, every confidence had been placed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:89
verses.text: Or peradventure the Lord designed to invigorate my soul, and to render it more vigilant for the future, to the end that, instead of giving heed to men, it might be made perfect through those precepts of the Gospel which do not share in the changes and chances of human seasons and circumstances, but abide for ever the same, as they were uttered by the blessed lips that cannot lie.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:91
verses.text: Men are like clouds, shifting hither and thither in the sky with the change of the winds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:92
verses.text: And of all men who have ever come within my experience these of whom I am speaking are the most unstable.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:93
verses.text: As to the other business of life, those who have lived with them may give evidence; but as to what is within my own knowledge, their inconsistency as regards the faith, I do not know that I have ever myself observed it or heard from any one else, of anything like it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:94
verses.text: Originally they were followers of Arius; then they went over to Hermogenes, who was diametrically opposed to the errors of Arius, as is evinced by the Creed originally recited by him at Nicaea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:95
verses.text: Hermogenes, fell asleep, and then they went over to Eusebius, the Coryphaeus, as we know on personal evidence, of the Arian ring.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:96
verses.text: Leaving this, for whatever reasons, they came home again, and once more concealed their Arian sentiments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:97
verses.text: After reaching the episcopate, to pass by what occurred in the interval, how many creeds did they put forth? One at Ancyra; another at Seleucia; another at Constantinople, the famous one; another at Lampsacus, then that of Nike in Thrace; and now again the creed of Cyzicus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:98
verses.text: Of this last I know nothing, except that I am told that they have suppressed the homoousion, and are supporting the like in essence, while they subscribe with Eunomius the blasphemies against the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:99
verses.text: Although all of the creeds which I have enumerated may not be opposed to one another, yet they alike exhibit the inconsistency of the men's minds, from their never standing by the same words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:100
verses.text: I have said nothing as to countless other points, but this that I do say is true.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:101
verses.text: Now that they have gone over to you, I beg you to write back by the same man, I mean our fellow presbyter Strategius, whether you have remained in the same mind towards me, or whether you have been alienated in consequence of your meeting them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:102
verses.text: For it was not likely that they would be silent, nor that you yourself, after writing to me as you have, would not use free speaking to them too.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:103
verses.text: If you remain in communion with me, it is well; it is what I would most earnestly pray for.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:104
verses.text: If they have drawn you over to them, it is sad.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 244:105
verses.text: How should separation from such a brother not be sad? If in nothing else, at least in bearing losses like this, we have been considerably tried at their hands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:1
verses.text: Letter CCXLV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:2
verses.text: To Theophilus the Bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:3
verses.text: It is some time since I received your letter, but I waited to be able to reply by some fit person; that so the bearer of my answer might supply whatever might be wanting in it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:4
verses.text: Now there has arrived our much beloved and very reverend brother Strategius, and I have judged it well to make use of his services, both as knowing my mind and able to convey news of me with due propriety and reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:5
verses.text: Know, therefore, my beloved and honoured friend, that I highly value my affection for you, and am not conscious so far as the disposition of my heart goes, of having at any time failed in it, although I have had many serious causes of reasonable complaint.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:6
verses.text: But I have decided to weigh the good against the bad, as in a balance, and to add my own mind where the better inclines.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:7
verses.text: Now changes have been made by those who should least of all have allowed anything of the kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:8
verses.text: Pardon me, therefore, for I have not changed my mind, if I have shifted any side, or rather I should say, I shall still be on the same side, but there are others who are continually changing it, and are now openly deserting to the foe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:9
verses.text: You yourself know what a value I put on their communion, so long as they were of the sound party.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:10
verses.text: If now I refuse to follow these, and shun all who think with them, I ought fairly to be forgiven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 245:11
verses.text: I put truth and my own salvation before everything.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 246:1
verses.text: Letter CCXLVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 246:2
verses.text: To the Nicopolitans.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 246:3
verses.text: I am filled with distress at seeing evil on the high road to success, while you, my reverend friends, are faint and failing under continuous calamity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 246:4
verses.text: But when again I bethink me of the mighty hand of God, and reflect that He knows how to raise up them that are broken down, to love the just, to crush the proud and to put down the mighty from their seats, then again my heart grows lighter by hope, and I know that through your prayers the calm that the Lord will show us will come soon.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 246:5
verses.text: Only grow not weary in prayer, but in the present emergency strive to give to all a plain example by deed of whatever you teach by word.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 247:1
verses.text: Letter CCXLVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 247:2
verses.text: To the Nicopolitans.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 247:3
verses.text: When I had read the letter of your holinesses, how did I not groan and lament that I had heard of these further troubles, of blows and insults inflicted on yourselves, of destruction of homes, devastation of the city, ruin of your whole country, persecution of the Church, banishment; of priests, invasion of wolves, and scattering of flocks.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 247:4
verses.text: But I have looked to the Lord in heaven, and have ceased to groan and weep, because I am perfectly well assured, as I hope you know too, that help will speedily come and that you will not be for ever forsaken.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 247:5
verses.text: What we have suffered, we have suffered for our sins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 247:6
verses.text: But our loving Lord will show us His own aid for the sake of His love and pity for the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 247:7
verses.text: Nevertheless, I have not omitted to beseech men in authority in person.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 247:8
verses.text: I have written to those at court, who love us, that the wrath of our ravening enemy may be stayed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 247:9
verses.text: I think, moreover, that from many quarters condemnation may fall upon his head, unless indeed these troublous times allow our public men no leisure for these matters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:1
verses.text: Letter CCXLVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:2
verses.text: To Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:3
verses.text: So far as my own wishes are concerned I am grieved at living at such a distance from your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:4
verses.text: But, as regards the peace of your own life, I thank the Lord Who has kept you out of this conflagration which has specially ravaged my diocese.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:5
verses.text: For the just Judge has sent me, in accordance with my works, a messenger of Satan, who is buffeting me severely enough, and is vigorously defending the heresy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:6
verses.text: Indeed to such a pitch has he carried the war against us, that he does not shrink even from shedding the blood of those who trust in God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:7
verses.text: You cannot fail to have heard that a man of the name of Asclepius, because he would not consent to communion with Doeg, has died under the blows inflicted on him by them, or rather, by their blows has been translated into life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:8
verses.text: You may suppose that the rest of their doings are of a piece with this; the persecutions of presbyters and teachers, and all that might be expected to be done by men abusing the imperial authority at their own caprice.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:9
verses.text: But, in answer to your prayers, the Lord will give us release from these things, and patience to bear the weight of our trials worthily of our hope in Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:10
verses.text: Pray write frequently to me of all that concerns yourself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:11
verses.text: If you find any one who can be trusted to carry you the book that I have finished, be so kind as to send for it, that so, when I have been cheered by your approval, I may send it on to others also.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 248:12
verses.text: By the grace of the Holy One may you be granted to me and to the Church of the Lord in good health rejoicing in the Lord, and praying for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 249:1
verses.text: Letter CCXLIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 249:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 249:3
verses.text: Commendatory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 249:4
verses.text: I congratulate this my brother, in being delivered from our troubles here and in approaching your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 249:5
verses.text: In choosing a good life with them that fear the Lord he has chosen a good provision for the life to come.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 249:6
verses.text: I commend him to your excellency and by him I beseech you to pray for my wretched life, to the end that I may be delivered from these trials and begin to serve the Lord according to the Gospel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:1
verses.text: Letter CCL.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:2
verses.text: To Patrophilus, bishop of aegae.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:3
verses.text: There has been some delay in my receiving your answer to my former letter; but it has reached me through the well-beloved Strategius, and I have given thanks to the Lord for your continuance in your love to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:4
verses.text: What you have now been kind enough to write on the same subject proves your good intentions, for you think as you ought, and you counsel me to my gain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:5
verses.text: But I see that my words will be extending too far, if I am to reply to everything written to me by your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:6
verses.text: I therefore say no more than this, that, if the blessing of peace goes no further than the mere name of peace, it is ridiculous to go on picking out here one and there another, and allow them alone a share in the boon, while others beyond number are excluded from it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:7
verses.text: But if agreement with mischievous men, under the appearance of peace, really does the harm an enemy might do to all who consent to it, then only consider who those men are who have been admitted to their companionship, who have conceived an unrighteous hatred against me; who but men of the faction not in communion with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:8
verses.text: There is no need now for me to mention them by name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:9
verses.text: They have been invited by them to Sebasteia; they have assumed the charge of the Church; they have performed service at the altar: they have given of their own bread to all the people, being proclaimed bishops by the clergy there, and escorted through all the district as saints and in communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:10
verses.text: If one must adopt the faction of these men, it is absurd to begin at the extremities, and not rather to hold intercourse with those that are their heads.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:11
verses.text: If then we are to count heretic and shun no one at all, why, tell me, do you separate yourself from the communion of certain persons? But if any are to be shunned, let me be told by these people who are so logically consistent in everything, to what party those belong whom they have invited over from Galatia to join them? If such things seem grievous to you, charge the separation on those who are responsible for it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:12
verses.text: If you judge them to be of no importance, forgive me for declining to be of the leaven of the teachers of wrong doctrine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 250:13
verses.text: Wherefore, if you will, have no more to do with those specious arguments, but with all openness confute them that do not walk aright in the truth of the Gospel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:1
verses.text: Letter CCLI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:2
verses.text: To the people of Evaesae.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:4
verses.text: My occupations are very numerous, and my mind is full of many anxious cares, but I have never forgotten you, my dear friends, ever praying my God for your constancy in the faith, wherein ye stand and have your boasting in the hope of the glory of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:5
verses.text: Truly nowadays it is hard to find, and extraordinary to see, a Church pure, unharmed by the troubles of the times, and preserving the apostolic doctrine in all its integrity and completeness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:6
verses.text: Such is your Church shewn at this present time by Him who in every generation makes manifest them that are worthy of His calling.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:7
verses.text: May the Lord grant to you the blessings of Jerusalem which is above, in return for your flinging back at the heads of the liars their slanders against me, and your refusal to allow them entry into your hearts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:8
verses.text: I know, and am persuaded in the Lord, that "your reward is great in heaven," even on account of this very conduct.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:9
verses.text: For you have wisely concluded among yourselves, as indeed is the truth, that the men who are "rewarding me evil for good, and hatred for my love," are accusing me now for the very same points which they are found to have themselves confessed and subscribed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:11
verses.text: Their presenting you with their own signatures for an accusation against me is not the only contradiction into which they have fallen.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:12
verses.text: They were unanimously deposed by the bishops assembled at Constantinople.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:13
verses.text: They refused to accept this deposition and appealed to a synod of impious men, refusing to admit the episcopacy of their judges, in order not to accept the sentence passed upon them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:14
verses.text: The reason alleged for their non-recognition was their being leaders of wicked heresy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:15
verses.text: All this happened nearly seventeen years ago.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:16
verses.text: The principal men of those who deposed them were Eudoxius, Euippius, George, Acacius, and others unknown to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:17
verses.text: The present tyrants of the churches are their successors, some ordained to fill their places, and others actually promoted by them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:19
verses.text: Now let those who charge me with unsound doctrine tell me in what way the men whose deposition they refused to accept were heretical.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:20
verses.text: Let them tell me in what way those promoted by them, and holding the same views as their fathers, are orthodox.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:21
verses.text: If Euippius was orthodox, how can Eustathius, whom he deposed, be other than a layman? If Euippius was a heretic, how can any one ordained by him be in communion with Eustathius now? But all this conduct, this trying to accuse men and set them up again, is child's play, got up against the Churches of God, for their own gain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:22
verses.text: When Eustathius was travelling through Paphlagonia, he overthrew the altars of Basilides of Paphlagonia, and used to perform divine service on his own tables.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:23
verses.text: Now he is begging Basilides to be admitted to communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:24
verses.text: He refused to communicate with our reverend brother Elpidius, because of his alliance with the Amasenes; and now he comes as a suppliant to the Amasenes, petitioning for alliance with them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:25
verses.text: Even ye yourselves know how shocking were his public utterances against Euippius: now he glorifies the holders of Euippius's opinions for their orthodoxy, if only they will cooperate in promoting his restitution.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:26
verses.text: And I am all the while being calumniated, not because I am doing any wrong, but because they have imagined that they will thus be recommended to the party at Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:27
verses.text: The character of those whom they sent for last year from Galatia, as being likely by their means to recover the free exercise of their episcopal powers, is only too well known to all who have lived even for a short time with them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:28
verses.text: I pray that the Lord may never allow me leisure to recount all their proceedings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:29
verses.text: I will only say that they have passed through the whole country, with the honour and attendance of bishops, escorted by their most honourable bodyguard and sympathizers; and have made a grand entry into the city, and held an assembly with all authority.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:30
verses.text: The people have been given over to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:31
verses.text: The altar has been given over to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:32
verses.text: How they went to Nicopolis, and could do nothing there of all that they had promised, and how they came, and what appearance they presented on their return, is known to those who were on the spot.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:33
verses.text: They are obviously taking every single step for their own gain and profit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:34
verses.text: If they say that they have repented, let them shew their repentance in writing; let them anathematize the Creed of Constantinople; let them separate from the heretics; and let them no longer trick the simple-minded.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:35
verses.text: So much for them and theirs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:37
verses.text: I, however, brethren beloved, small and insignificant as I am, but remaining ever by God's grace the same, have never changed with the changes of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:38
verses.text: My creed has not varied at Seleucia, at Constantinople, at Zela, at Lampsacus, and at Rome.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:39
verses.text: My present creed is not different from the former; it has remained ever one and the same.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:40
verses.text: As we received from the Lord, so are we baptized; as we are baptized, so we make profession of our faith; as we make profession of our faith, so do we offer our doxology, not separating the Holy Ghost from Father and Son, nor preferring Him in honour to the Father, or asserting Him to be prior to the Son, as blasphemers' tongues invent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:41
verses.text: Who could be so rash as to reject the Lord's commandment, and boldly devise an order of his own for the Names? But I do not call the Spirit, Who is ranked with Father and Son, a creature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:42
verses.text: I do not dare to call slavish that which is royal.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:43
verses.text: And I beseech you to remember the threat uttered by the Lord in the words, "All manner of sin and blasphemy shall be forgiven unto men; but the blasphemy against the Holy Ghost shall not be forgiven unto men, neither in this world, neither in the world to come".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:44
verses.text: Keep yourselves from dangerous teaching against the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:45
verses.text: "Stand fast in the faith".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:46
verses.text: Look over all the world, and see how small the part is which is unsound.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:47
verses.text: All the rest of the Church which has received the Gospel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:48
verses.text: from one end of the world to the other, abides in this sound and unperverted doctrine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 251:49
verses.text: From their communion I pray that I may never fall, and I pray that I may have part and lot with you in the righteous day of our Lord Jesus Christ, when He shall come to give to every one according to his conduct.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 252:1
verses.text: Letter CCLII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 252:2
verses.text: To the bishops of the Pontic Diocese.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 252:3
verses.text: The honours of martyrs ought to be very eagerly coveted by all who rest their hopes on the Lord, and more especially by you who seek after virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 252:4
verses.text: By your disposition towards the great and good among your fellow servants you are shewing your affection to our common Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 252:5
verses.text: Moreover, a special reason for this is to be found in the tie, as it were, of blood, which binds the life of exact discipline to those who have been made perfect through endurance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 252:6
verses.text: Since then Eupsychius and Damas and their company are most illustrious among martyrs, and their memory is yearly kept in our city and all the neighbourhood, the Church, calling on you by my voice, reminds you to keep up your ancient custom of paying a visit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 252:7
verses.text: A great and good work lies before you among the people, who desire to be edified by you, and are anxious for the reward dependent on the honour paid to the martyrs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 252:8
verses.text: Receive, therefore, my supplications, and consent of your kindness to give at the cost of small trouble to yourselves a great boon to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 253:1
verses.text: Letter CCLIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 253:2
verses.text: To the presbyters of Antioch.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 253:3
verses.text: The anxious care which you have for the Churches of God will to some extent be assuaged by our very dear and very reverend brother Sanctissimus the presbyter, when he has told you of the love and kindness felt for us by all the West.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 253:4
verses.text: But, on the other hand, it will be roused afresh and made yet keener, when he has told you in person what zeal is demanded by the present position of affairs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 253:5
verses.text: All other authorities have told us, as it were, by halves, the minds of men in the West, and the condition of things there.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 253:6
verses.text: He is very competent to understand men's minds, and to make exact enquiry into the condition of affairs, and he will tell you everything and will guide your good will through the whole business.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 253:7
verses.text: You have matter before you appropriate to the excellent will which you have always shewn in your anxiety on behalf of the Churches of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 254:1
verses.text: Letter CCLIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 254:2
verses.text: To Pelagius, bishop of the Syrian Laodicea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 254:3
verses.text: May the Lord grant me once again in person to behold your true piety and to supply in actual intercourse all that is wanting in my letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 254:4
verses.text: I am behindhand in beginning to write and must needs make many excuses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 254:5
verses.text: But we have with us the well beloved and reverend brother Sanctissimus, the presbyter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 254:6
verses.text: He will tell you everything, both our news and the news of the West.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 254:7
verses.text: You will be cheered by what you hear; but when he tells you of the troubles in which we are involved he will perhaps add some distress and anxiety to that which already besets your kindly soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 254:8
verses.text: Yet it is not to no purpose that affliction should be felt by you, able as you are to move the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 254:9
verses.text: Your anxiety will turn to our gain, and I know that we shall receive succour from God as long as we have the aid of your prayers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 254:10
verses.text: Pray, too, with me for release from my anxieties, and ask for some increase in my bodily strength; then the Lord will prosper me on my way to the fulfilment of my desires and to a sight of your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 255:1
verses.text: Letter CCLV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 255:2
verses.text: To Vitus, bishop of Charrae.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 255:3
verses.text: Would that it were possible for me to write to your reverence every day! For ever since I have had experience of your affection I have had great desire to converse with you, or, if this be impossible, at least to communicate with you by letter, that I may tell you my own news and learn in what state you are.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 255:4
verses.text: Yet we have not what we wish but what the Lord gives, and this we ought to receive with gratitude.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 255:5
verses.text: I have therefore thanked the holy God for giving me an opportunity for writing to your reverence on the arrival of our very well beloved and reverend brother Sanctissimus, the presbyter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 255:6
verses.text: He has had considerable trouble in accomplishing his journey, and will tell you with accuracy all that he has learnt in the West.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 255:7
verses.text: For all these things we ought to thank the Lord and to beseech Him to give us too the same peace and that we may freely receive one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 255:8
verses.text: Receive all the brethren in Christ in my name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:1
verses.text: Letter CCLVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:2
verses.text: To the very well beloved and reverend brethren the presbyters Acacius, Aetius, Paulus, and Silvanus; the deacons Silvinus and Lucius, and the rest of the brethren the monks, Basil, the bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:3
verses.text: News has reached me of the severe persecution carried on against you, and how directly after Easter the men who fast for strife and debate attacked your homes, and gave your labours to the flames, preparing for you indeed a house in the heavens, not made with hands, but for themselves laying up in store the fire which they had used to your hurt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:4
verses.text: I no sooner heard of this than I groaned over what had happened; pitying not you, my brethren, (God forbid!) but the men who are so sunk in wickedness as to carry their evil deeds to such an extent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:5
verses.text: I expected you all to hurry at once to the refuge prepared for you in my humble self; and I hoped that the Lord would give me refreshment in the midst of my continual troubles in embracing you, and in receiving on this inactive body of mine the noble sweat which you are dropping for the truth's sake, and so having some share in the prizes laid up for you by the Judge of truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:6
verses.text: But this did not enter into your minds, and you did not even expect any relief at my hands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:7
verses.text: I was therefore at least anxious to find frequent opportunities of writing to you, to the end that like those who cheer on combatants in the arena, I might myself by letter give you some encouragement in your good fight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:8
verses.text: For two reasons, however, I have not found this easy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:9
verses.text: In the first place, I did not know where you were residing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:10
verses.text: And, secondly, but few of our people travel in your direction.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:11
verses.text: Now the Lord has brought us the very well beloved and reverend brother Sanctissimus, the presbyter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:12
verses.text: By him I am able to salute you, and I beseech you to pray for me, rejoicing and exulting that your reward is great in heaven, and that you have freedom with the Lord to cease not day and night calling on Him to put an end to this storm of the Churches; to grant the shepherds to their flocks, and that the Church may return to her proper dignity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:13
verses.text: I am persuaded that if a voice be found to move our good God, He will not make His mercy afar off, but will now "with the temptation make a way to escape, that ye may be able to bear it".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 256:14
verses.text: Salute all the brethren in Christ in any name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:1
verses.text: Letter CCLVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:2
verses.text: To the monks harassed by the Arians.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:4
verses.text: I have thought it only right to announce to you by letter how I said to myself, when I heard of the trials brought upon you by the enemies of God, that in a time reckoned a time of peace you have won for yourselves the blessings promised to all who suffer persecution for the sake of the name of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:5
verses.text: In my judgment the war that is waged against us by our fellow countrymen is the hardest to bear, because against open and declared enemies it is easy to defend ourselves, while we are necessarily at the mercy of those who are associated with us, and are thus exposed to continual danger.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:6
verses.text: This has been your case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:7
verses.text: Our fathers were persecuted, but by idolaters their substance was plundered, their houses were overthrown, they themselves were driven into exile, by our open enemies, for Christ's name's sake.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:8
verses.text: The persecutors who have lately appeared, hate us no less than they, but, to the deceiving of many, they put forward the name of Christ, that the persecuted may be robbed of all comfort from its confession, because the majority of simpler folk, while admitting that we are being wronged, are unwilling to reckon our death for the truth's sake to be martyrdom.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:9
verses.text: I am therefore persuaded that the reward in store for you from the righteous Judge is yet greater than that bestowed on those former martyrs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:10
verses.text: They indeed both had the public praise of men, and received the reward of God; to you, though your good deeds are not less, no honours are given by the people.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:11
verses.text: It is only fair that the requital in store for you in the world to come should be far greater.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:13
verses.text: I exhort you, therefore, not to faint in your afflictions, but to be revived by God's love, and to add daily to your zeal, knowing that in you ought to be preserved that remnant of true religion which the Lord will find when He cometh on the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:14
verses.text: Even if bishops are driven from their Churches, be not dismayed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:15
verses.text: If traitors have arisen from among the very clergy themselves, let not this undermine your confidence in God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:16
verses.text: We are saved not by names, but by mind and purpose, and genuine love toward our Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:17
verses.text: Bethink you how in the attack against our Lord, high priests and scribes and elders devised the plot, and how few of the people were found really receiving the word.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:18
verses.text: Remember that it is not the multitude who are being saved, but the elect of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:19
verses.text: Be not then affrighted at the great multitude of the people who are carried hither and thither by winds like the waters of the sea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:20
verses.text: If but one be saved, like Lot at Sodom, he ought to abide in right judgment, keeping his hope in Christ unshaken, for the Lord will not forsake His holy ones.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:21
verses.text: Salute all the brethren in Christ from me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 257:22
verses.text: Pray earnestly for my miserable soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:1
verses.text: Letter CCLVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:2
verses.text: To Epiphanius the bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:4
verses.text: It has long been expected that, in accordance with the prediction of our Lord, because of iniquity abounding, the love of the majority would wax cold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:5
verses.text: Now experience has confirmed this expectation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:6
verses.text: But though this condition of things has already obtained among us here, it seems to be contradicted by the letter brought from your holiness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:7
verses.text: For verily it is no mere ordinary proof of love, first that you should remember an unworthy and insignificant person like myself; and secondly, that you should send to visit me brethren who are fit and proper ministers of a correspondence of peace.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:8
verses.text: For now, when every man is viewing every one else with suspicion, no spectacle is rarer than that which you are presenting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:9
verses.text: Nowhere is pity to be seen; nowhere sympathy; nowhere a brotherly tear for a brother in distress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:10
verses.text: Not persecutions for the truth's sake, not Churches with all their people in tears; not this great tale of troubles closing round us, are enough to stir us to anxiety for the welfare of one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:11
verses.text: We jump on them that are fallen; we scratch and tear at wounded places; we who are supposed to agree with one another launch the curses that are uttered by the heretics; men who are in agreement on the most important matters are wholly severed from one another on some one single point.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:12
verses.text: How, then, can I do otherwise than admire him who in such circumstances shews that his love to his neighbour is pure and guileless, and, though separated from me by so great a distance of sea and land, gives my soul all the care he can?  2.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:13
verses.text: I have been specially struck with admiration at your having been distressed even by the dispute of the monks on the Mount of Olives, and at your expressing a wish that some means might be found of reconciling them to one another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:14
verses.text: I have further been glad to hear that you have not been unaware of the unfortunate steps, taken by certain persons, which have caused disturbance among the brethren, and that you have keenly interested yourself even in these matters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:15
verses.text: But I have deemed it hardly worthy of your wisdom that you should entrust the rectification of matters of such importance to me: for I am not guided by the grace of God, because of my living in sin; I have no power of eloquence, because I have cheerfully withdrawn from vain studies; and I am not yet sufficiently versed in the doctrines of the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:16
verses.text: I have therefore already written to my beloved brethren at the Mount of Olives, our own Palladius, and Innocent the Italian, in answer to their letters to me, that it is impossible for me to make even the slightest addition to the Nicene Creed, except the ascription of Glory to the Holy Ghost, because our Fathers treated this point cursorily, no question having at that time arisen concerning the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:17
verses.text: As to the additions it is proposed to make to that Creed, concerning the incarnation of our Lord, I have neither tested nor accepted them, as being beyond my comprehension.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:18
verses.text: I know well that, if once we begin to interfere with the simplicity of the Creed, we shall embark on interminable discussion, contradiction ever leading us on and on, and shall but disturb the souls of simpler folk by the introduction of new phrases.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:20
verses.text: As to the Church at Antioch (I mean that which is in agreement in the same doctrine), may the Lord grant that one day we may see it united.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:21
verses.text: It is in peril of being specially open to the attacks of the enemy, who is angry with it because there the name of Christian first obtained.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:22
verses.text: There heresy is divided against orthodoxy, and orthodoxy is divided against herself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:23
verses.text: My position, however, is this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:24
verses.text: The right reverend bishop Meletius was the first to speak boldly for the truth, and fought that good fight in the days of Constantine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:25
verses.text: Therefore my Church has felt strong affection towards him, for the sake of that brave and firm stand, and has held communion with him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:26
verses.text: I, therefore, by God's grace, have held him to be in communion up to this time; and, if God will, I shall continue to do so.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:27
verses.text: Moreover the very blessed Pope Athanasius came from Alexandria, and was most anxious that communion should be established between Meletius and himself; but by the malice of counsellors their conjunction was put off to another season.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:28
verses.text: Would that this had not been so! I have never accepted communion with any one of those who have since been introduced into the see, not because I count them unworthy, but because I see no ground for the condemnation of Meletius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:29
verses.text: Nevertheless I have heard many things about the brethren, without giving heed to them, because the accused were not brought face to face with their accusers, according to that which is written, "Doth our law judge any man, before it hear him, and know what he doeth?" I cannot therefore at present write to them, right honourable brother, and I ought not to be forced to do so.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:30
verses.text: It will be becoming to your peaceful disposition not to cause union in one direction and disunion in another, but to restore the severed member to the original union.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:31
verses.text: First, then, pray; next, to the utmost of your ability, exhort, that ambition may be driven from their hearts, and that reconciliation may be effected between them both to restore strength to the Church, and to destroy the rage of our foes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:32
verses.text: It has given great comfort to my soul that, in addition to your other right and accurate statements in theology, you should acknowledge the necessity of stating that the hypostases are three.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:33
verses.text: Let the brethren at Antioch be instructed by you after this manner.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:34
verses.text: Indeed I am confident that they have been so instructed; for I am sure you would never have accepted communion with them unless you had carefully made sure of this point in them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:36
verses.text: The Magusaeans, as you were good enough to point out to me in your other letter, are here in considerable numbers, scattered all over the country, settlers having long ago been introduced into these parts from Babylon.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:37
verses.text: Their manners are peculiar, as they do not mix with other men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:38
verses.text: It is quite impossible to converse with them, inasmuch as they have been made the prey of the devil to do his will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:39
verses.text: They have no books; no instructors in doctrine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:40
verses.text: They are brought up in senseless institutions, piety being handed down from father to son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:41
verses.text: In addition to the characteristics which are open to general observation, they object to the slaying of animals as defilement, and they cause the animals they want for their own use to be slaughtered by other people.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:42
verses.text: They are wild after illicit marriages; they consider fire divine, and so on.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:43
verses.text: No one hitherto has told me any fables about the descent of the Magi from Abraham: they name a certain Zarnuas as the founder of their race.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 258:44
verses.text: I have nothing more to write to your excellency about them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 259:1
verses.text: Letter CCLIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 259:2
verses.text: To the monks Palladius and Innocent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 259:3
verses.text: From your affection for me you ought to be able to conjecture my affection for you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 259:4
verses.text: I have always desired to be a herald of peace, and, when I fail in my object, I am grieved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 259:5
verses.text: How could it be otherwise? I cannot feel angry with any one for this reason, because I know that the blessing of peace has long ago been withdrawn from us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 259:6
verses.text: If the responsibility for division lies with others, may the Lord grant that those who cause dissension may cease to do so.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 259:7
verses.text: I cannot even ask that your visits to me may be frequent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 259:8
verses.text: You have therefore no reason to excuse yourselves on this score.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 259:9
verses.text: I am well aware that men who have embraced the life of labour, and always provide with their own hands the necessities of life, cannot be long away from home; but, wherever you are, remember me, and pray for me that no cause of disturbance may dwell in my heart, and that I may be at peace with myself and with God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:1
verses.text: Letter CCLX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:2
verses.text: To Optimus the bishop.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:4
verses.text: Under any circumstances I should have gladly seen the good lads, on account of both a steadiness of character beyond their years, and their near relationship to your excellency, which might have led me to expect something remarkable in them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:5
verses.text: And, when I saw them approaching me with your letter, my affection towards them was doubled.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:6
verses.text: But now that I have read the letter, now that I have seen all the anxious care for the Church that there is in it, and the evidence it affords of your zeal in reading the divine Scriptures, I thank the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:7
verses.text: And I invoke blessings on those who brought me such a letter, and, even before them, on the writer himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:9
verses.text: You have asked for a solution of that famous passage which is everywhere interpreted in different senses, "Whosoever slayeth Cain will exact vengeance for seven sins".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:10
verses.text: Your question shews that you have yourself carefully observed the charge of Paul to Timothy, for you are obviously attentive to your reading.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:11
verses.text: You have moreover roused me, old man that I am, dull alike from age and bodily infirmity, and from the many afflictions which have been stirred up round about me and have weighed down my life.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:12
verses.text: Fervent in spirit as you are yourself, you are rousing me, now benumbed like a beast in his den, to some little wakefulness and vital energy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:13
verses.text: The passage in question may be interpreted simply and may also receive an elaborate explanation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:14
verses.text: The simpler, and one that may occur to any one off hand, is this: that Cain ought to suffer sevenfold punishment for his sins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:15
verses.text: For it is not the part of a righteous judge to define requital on the principle of like for like, but the originator of evil must pay his debt with addition, if he is to be made better by punishment and render other men wiser by his example.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:16
verses.text: Therefore, since it is ordained that Cain pay the penalty of his sin sevenfold, he who kills him, it is said, will discharge the sentence pronounced against him by the divine judgment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:17
verses.text: This is the sense that suggests itself to us on our first reading the passage.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:19
verses.text: But readers, gifted with greater curiosity, are naturally inclined to probe into the question further.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:20
verses.text: How, they ask, can justice be satisfied seven times? And what are the vengeances? Are they for seven sins committed? Or is the sin committed once and are there seven punishments for the one sin? Scripture continually assigns seven as the number of the remission of sins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:21
verses.text: "How often," it is asked, "shall my brother sin against me and I forgive him?" (It is Peter who is speaking to the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:22
verses.text: ) "Till seven times?" Then comes the Lord's answer, "I say not unto thee, until seven times, but, until seventy times seven".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:23
verses.text: Our Lord did not vary the number, but multiplied the seven, and so fixed the limit of the forgiveness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:24
verses.text: After seven years the Hebrew used to be freed from slavery.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:25
verses.text: Seven weeks of years used in old times to make the famous jubilee, in which the land rested, debts were remitted, slaves were set free, and, as it were, a new life began over again, the old life from age to age being in a sense completed at the number seven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:26
verses.text: These things are types of this present life, which revolves in seven days and passes by, wherein punishments of slighter sins are inflicted, according to the loving care of our good Lord, to save us from being delivered to punishment in the age that has no end.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:27
verses.text: The expression seven times is therefore introduced because of its connexion with this present world for men who love this world ought specially to be punished in the things for the sake of which they have chosen to live wicked lives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:28
verses.text: If you understand the vengeances to be for the sins committed by Cain, you will find those sins to be seven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:29
verses.text: Or if you understand them to mean the sentence passed on him by the Judge, you will not go far wrong.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:30
verses.text: To take the crimes of Cain: the first sin is envy at the preference of Abel; the second is guile, whereby he said to his brother, "Let us go into the field:" the third is murder, a further wickedness: the fourth, fratricide, a still greater iniquity: the fifth that he committed the first murder, and set a bad example to mankind: the sixth wrong in that he grieved his parents: the seventh, his lie to God; for when he was asked, "Where is Abel thy brother?" he replied, "I know not".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:31
verses.text: Seven sins were therefore avenged in the destruction of Cain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:32
verses.text: For when the Lord said, "Cursed is the earth which has opened to receive the blood of thy brother," and "groaning and trembling shall there be on the earth," Cain said, "If thou castest me out to-day from the earth, then from thy face shall I be hid, and groaning and trembling shall I lie upon the earth, and every one that findeth me shall slay me".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:33
verses.text: It is in answer to this that the Lord says, "Whosoever slayeth Cain will discharge seven vengeances".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:34
verses.text: Cain supposed that he would be an easy prey to every one, because of there being no safety for him in the earth (for the earth was cursed for his sake), and of his being deprived of the succour of God, Who was angry with him for the murder, and so of there being no help for him either from earth or from heaven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:35
verses.text: Therefore he said, "It shall come to pass that every one that findeth me shall slay me".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:36
verses.text: Scripture proves his error in the words, "Not so;" i-e: thou shalt not be slain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:37
verses.text: For to men suffering punishment, death is a gain, because it brings relief from their pain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:38
verses.text: But thy life shall be prolonged, that thy punishment may be made commensurate with thy sins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:39
verses.text: Since then the word ἐκδικούμενον may be understood in two senses; both the sin for which vengeance was taken, and the manner of the punishment, let us now examine whether the criminal suffered a sevenfold torment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:41
verses.text: The seven sins of Cain have been enumerated in what has been already said.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:42
verses.text: Now I ask if the punishments inflicted on him were seven, and I state as follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:43
verses.text: The Lord enquired 'Where is Abel thy brother?' not because he wished for information, but in order to give Cain an opportunity for repentance, as is proved by the words themselves, for on his denial the Lord immediately convicts him saying, "The voice of thy brother's blood crieth unto me".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:44
verses.text: So the enquiry, "Where is Abel thy brother?" was not made with a view to God's information, but to give Cain an opportunity of perceiving his sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:45
verses.text: But for God's having visited him he might have pleaded that he was left alone and had no opportunity given him for repentance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:46
verses.text: Now the physician appeared that the patient might flee to him for help.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:47
verses.text: Cain, however, not only fails to hide his sore, but makes another one in adding the lie to the murder.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:48
verses.text: "I know not.
