verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:49
verses.text: Am I my brother's keeper?" Now from this point begin to reckon the punishments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:50
verses.text: "Cursed is the ground for thy sake," one punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:51
verses.text: "Thou shalt till the ground".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:52
verses.text: This is the second punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:53
verses.text: Some secret necessity was imposed upon him forcing him to the tillage of the earth, so that it should never be permitted him to take rest when he might wish, but ever to suffer pain with the earth, his enemy, which, by polluting it with his brother's blood, he had made accursed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:54
verses.text: "Thou shalt till the ground".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:55
verses.text: Terrible punishment, to live with those that hate one, to have for a companion an enemy, an implacable foe.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:56
verses.text: "Thou shalt till the earth," that is, Thou shalt toil at the labours of the field, never resting, never released from thy work, day or night, bound down by secret necessity which is harder than any savage master, and continually urged on to labour.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:57
verses.text: "And it shall not yield unto thee her strength".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:58
verses.text: Although the ceaseless toil had some fruit, the labour itself were no little torture to one forced never to relax it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:59
verses.text: But the toil is ceaseless, and the labours at the earth are fruitless (for "she did not yield her strength") and this fruitlessness of labour is the third punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:60
verses.text: "Groaning and trembling shalt thou be on the earth".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:61
verses.text: Here two more are added to the three; continual groaning, and tremblings of the body, the limbs being deprived of the steadiness that comes of strength.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:62
verses.text: Cain had made a bad use of the strength of his body, and so its vigour was destroyed, and it tottered and shook, and it was hard for him to lift meat and drink to his mouth, for after his impious conduct, his wicked hand was no longer allowed to minister to his body's needs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:63
verses.text: Another punishment is that which Cain disclosed when he said, "Thou hast driven me out from the face of the earth, and from thy face shall I be hid".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:64
verses.text: What is the meaning of this driving out from the face of the earth? It means deprivation of the benefits which are derived from the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:65
verses.text: He was not transferred to another place, but he was made a stranger to all the good things of earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:66
verses.text: "And from thy face shall I be hid".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:67
verses.text: The heaviest punishment for men of good heart is alienation from God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:68
verses.text: "And it shall come to pass that every one that findeth me shall slay me".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:69
verses.text: He infers this from what has gone before.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:70
verses.text: If I am cast out of the earth, and hidden from thy face, it remains for me to be slain of every one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:71
verses.text: What says the Lord? Not so.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:72
verses.text: But he put a mark upon him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:73
verses.text: This is the seventh punishment, that the punishment should not be hid, but that by a plain sign proclamation should be made to all, that this is the first doer of unholy deeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:74
verses.text: To all who reason rightly the heaviest of punishments is shame.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:75
verses.text: We have learned this also in the case of the judgments, when "some" shall rise "to everlasting life, and some to shame and everlasting contempt".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:77
verses.text: Your next question is of a kindred character, concerning the words of Lamech to his wives; "I have slain a man to my wounding, and a young man to my hurt: if Cain shall be avenged sevenfold, truly Lamech seventy and sevenfold".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:78
verses.text: Some suppose that Cain was slain by Lamech, and that he survived to this generation that he might suffer a longer punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:79
verses.text: But this is not the case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:80
verses.text: Lamech evidently committed two murders, from what he says himself, "I have slain a man and a young man," the man to his wounding, and the young man to his hurt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:81
verses.text: There is a difference between wounding and hurt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:82
verses.text: And there is a difference between a man and a young man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:83
verses.text: "If Cain shall be avenged sevenfold, truly Lamech seventy and sevenfold".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:84
verses.text: It is right that I should undergo four hundred and ninety punishments, if God's judgment on Cain was just, that his punishments should be seven.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:85
verses.text: Cain had not learned to murder from another, and had never seen a murderer undergoing punishment.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:86
verses.text: But I, who had before my eyes Cain groaning and trembling, and the mightiness of the wrath of God, was not made wiser by the example before me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:87
verses.text: Wherefore I deserve to suffer four hundred and ninety punishments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:88
verses.text: There are, however, some who have gone so far as the following explanation, which does not jar with the doctrine of the Church; from Cain to the flood, they say, seven generations passed by, and the punishment was brought on the whole earth, because sin was everywhere spread abroad.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:89
verses.text: But the sin of Lamech requires for its cure not a Flood, but Him Who Himself takes away the sin of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:90
verses.text: Count the generations from Adam to the coming of Christ, and you will find, according to the genealogy of Luke, that the Lord was born in the seventy-seventh.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:91
verses.text: Thus I have investigated this point to the best of my ability, though I have passed by matters therein that might be investigated, for fear of prolonging my observations beyond the limits of my letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:92
verses.text: But for your intelligence little seeds are enough.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:93
verses.text: "Give instruction," it is said, "to a wise man, and he will be yet wiser".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:94
verses.text: "If a skilful man hear a wise word he will commend it, and add unto it".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:96
verses.text: About the words of Simeon to Mary, there is no obscurity or variety of interpretation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:97
verses.text: "And Simeon blessed them, and said unto Mary His mother, Behold, this Child is set for the fall and rising again of many in Israel; and for a sign which shall be spoken against; (yea, a sword shall pierce through thine own soul also,) that the thoughts of many hearts may be revealed".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:98
verses.text: Here I am astonished that, after passing by the previous words as requiring no explanation, you should enquire about the expression, "Yea, a sword shall pierce through thy own soul also".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:99
verses.text: To me the question, how the same child can be for the fall and rising again, and what is the sign that shall be spoken against, does not seem less perplexing than the question how a sword shall pierce through Mary's heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:101
verses.text: My view is, that the Lord is for falling and rising again, not because some fall and others rise again, but because in us the worst falls and the better is set up.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:102
verses.text: The advent of the Lord is destructive of our bodily affections and it rouses the proper qualities of the soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:103
verses.text: As when Paul says, "When I am weak, then I am strong," the same man is weak and is strong, but he is weak in the flesh and strong in the spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:104
verses.text: Thus the Lord does not give to some occasions of falling and to others occasions of rising.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:105
verses.text: Those who fall, fall from the station in which they once were, but it is plain that the faithless man never stands, but is always dragged along the ground with the serpent whom he follows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:106
verses.text: He has then nowhere to fall from, because he has already been cast down by his unbelief.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:107
verses.text: Wherefore the first boon is, that he who stands in his sin should fall and die, and then should live in righteousness and rise, both of which graces our faith in Christ confers on us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:108
verses.text: Let the worse fall that the better may have opportunity to rise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:109
verses.text: If fornication fall not, chastity does not rise.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:110
verses.text: Unless our unreason be crushed our reason will not come to perfection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:111
verses.text: In this sense he is for the fall and rising again of many.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:113
verses.text: For a sign that shall be spoken against.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:114
verses.text: By a sign, we properly understand in Scripture a cross.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:115
verses.text: Moses, it is said, set the serpent "upon a pole".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:116
verses.text: That is upon a cross.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:117
verses.text: Or else a sign is indicative of something strange and obscure seen by the simple but understood by the intelligent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:118
verses.text: There is no cessation of controversy about the Incarnation of the Lord; some asserting that he assumed a body, and others that his sojourn was bodiless; some that he had a passible body, and others that he fulfilled the bodily oeconomy by a kind of appearance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:119
verses.text: Some say that his body was earthly, some that it was heavenly; some that He pre-existed before the ages; some that He took His beginning from Mary.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:120
verses.text: It is on this account that He is a sign that shall be spoken against.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:122
verses.text: By a sword is meant the word which tries and judges our thoughts, which pierces even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of our thoughts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:123
verses.text: Now every soul in the hour of the Passion was subjected, as it were, to a kind of searching.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:124
verses.text: According to the word of the Lord it is said, "All ye shall be offended because of me".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:125
verses.text: Simeon therefore prophesies about Mary herself, that when standing by the cross, and beholding what is being done, and hearing the voices, after the witness of Gabriel, after her secret knowledge of the divine conception, after the great exhibition of miracles, she shall feel about her soul a mighty tempest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:126
verses.text: The Lord was bound to taste of death for every man—to become a propitiation for the world and to justify all men by His own blood.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:127
verses.text: Even thou thyself, who hast been taught from on high the things concerning the Lord, shalt be reached by some doubt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:128
verses.text: This is the sword.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:129
verses.text: "That the thoughts of many hearts may be revealed".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:130
verses.text: He indicates that after the offence at the Cross of Christ a certain swift healing shall come from the Lord to the disciples and to Mary herself, confirming their heart in faith in Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:131
verses.text: In the same way we saw Peter, after he had been offended, holding more firmly to his faith in Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 260:132
verses.text: What was human in him was proved unsound, that the power of the Lord might be shewn.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:2
verses.text: To the Sozopolitans.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:3
verses.text: I have received the letter which you, right honourable brethren, have sent me concerning the circumstances in which you are placed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:4
verses.text: I thank the Lord that you have let me share in the anxiety you feel as to your attention to things needful and deserving of serious heed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:5
verses.text: But I was distressed to hear that over and above the disturbance brought on the Churches by the Arians, and the confusion caused by them in the definition of the faith, there has appeared among you yet another innovation, throwing the brotherhood into great dejection, because, as you have informed me, certain persons are uttering, in the hearing of the faithful, novel and unfamiliar doctrines which they allege to be deduced from the teaching of Scripture.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:6
verses.text: You write that there are men among you who are trying to destroy the saving incarnation of our Lord Jesus Christ, and, so far as they can, are overthrowing the grace of the great mystery unrevealed from everlasting, but manifested in His own times, when the Lord, when He had gone through all things pertaining to the cure of the human race, bestowed on all of us the boon of His own sojourn among us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:7
verses.text: For He helped His own creation, first through the patriarchs, whose lives were set forth as examples and rules to all willing to follow the footsteps of the saints, and with zeal like theirs to reach the perfection of good works.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:8
verses.text: Next for succour He gave the Law, ordaining it by angels in the hand of Moses; then the prophets, foretelling the salvation to come; judges, kings, and righteous men, doing great works, with a mighty hand.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:9
verses.text: After all these in the last days He was Himself manifested ill the flesh, "made of a woman, made under the law, to redeem them that were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:11
verses.text: If, then, the sojourn of the Lord in flesh has never taken place, the Redeemer paid not the fine to death on our behalf, nor through Himself destroyed death's reign.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:12
verses.text: For if what was reigned over by death was not that which was assumed by the Lord, death would not have ceased working his own ends, nor would the sufferings of the God-bearing flesh have been made our gain; He would not have killed sin in the flesh: we who had died in Adam should not have been made alive in Christ; the fallen to pieces would not have been framed again; the shattered would not have been set up again; that which by the serpent's trick had been estranged from God would never have been made once more His own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:13
verses.text: All these boons are undone by those that assert that it was with a heavenly body that the Lord came among us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:14
verses.text: And if the God-bearing flesh was not ordained to be assumed of the lump of Adam, what need was there of the Holy Virgin? But who has the hardihood now once again to renew by the help of sophistical arguments and, of course, by scriptural evidence, that old dogma of Valentinus, now long ago silenced? For this impious doctrine of the seeming is no novelty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:15
verses.text: It was started long ago by the feeble-minded Valentinus, who, after tearing off a few of the Apostle's statements, constructed for himself this impious fabrication, asserting that the Lord assumed the "form of a servant," and not the servant himself, and that He was made in the "likeness," but that actual manhood was not assumed by Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:16
verses.text: Similar sentiments are expressed by these men who can only be pitied for bringing new troubles upon you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:18
verses.text: As to the statement that human feelings are transmitted to the actual Godhead, it is one made by men who preserve no order in their thoughts, and are ignorant that there is a distinction between the feelings of flesh, of flesh endowed with soul, and of soul using a body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:19
verses.text: It is the property of flesh to undergo division, diminution, dissolution; of flesh endowed with soul to feel weariness, pain, hunger, thirst, and to be overcome by sleep; of soul using body to feel grief, heaviness, anxiety, and such like.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:20
verses.text: Of these some are natural and necessary to every living creature; others come of evil will, and are superinduced because of life's lacking proper discipline and training for virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:21
verses.text: Hence it is evident that our Lord assumed the natural affections to establish His real incarnation, and not by way of semblance of incantation, and that all the affections derived from evil that besmirch the purity of our life, He rejected as unworthy of His unsullied Godhead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:22
verses.text: It is on this account that He is said to have been "made in the likeness of flesh of sin;" not, as these men hold, in likeness of flesh, but of flesh of sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:23
verses.text: It follows that He took our flesh with its natural afflictions, but "did no sin".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:24
verses.text: Just as the death which is in the flesh, transmitted to us through Adam, was swallowed up by the Godhead, so was the sin taken away by the righteousness which is in Christ Jesus, so that in the resurrection we receive back the flesh neither liable to death nor subject to sin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:25
verses.text: These, brethren, are the mysteries of the Church; these are the traditions of the Fathers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:26
verses.text: Every man who fears the Lord, and is awaiting God's judgment, I charge not to be carried away by various doctrines.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:27
verses.text: If any one teaches a different doctrine, and refuses to accede to the sound words of the faith, rejecting the oracles of the Spirit, and making his own teaching of more authority than the lessons of the Gospels, of such an one beware.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:28
verses.text: May the Lord grant that one day we may meet, so that all that my argument has let slip I may supply when we stand face to face! I have written little when there was much to say, for I did not like to go beyond my letter's bounds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 261:29
verses.text: At the same time I do not doubt that to all that fear the Lord a brief reminder is enough.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:2
verses.text: To the Monk Urbicius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:4
verses.text: You have done well to write to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:5
verses.text: You have shewn how great is the fruit of charity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:6
verses.text: Continue so to do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:7
verses.text: Do not think that, when you write to me, you need offer excuses.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:8
verses.text: I recognise my own position, and I know that by nature every man is of equal honour with the rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:9
verses.text: Whatever excellence there is in me is not of family, nor of superfluous wealth, nor of physical condition; it comes only of superiority in the fear of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:10
verses.text: What, then, hinders you from fearing the Lord yet more, and so, in this respect, being greater than I am? Write often to me, and acquaint me with the condition of the brotherhood with you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:11
verses.text: Tell me what members of the Church in your parts are sound, that I may know to whom I ought to write, and in whom I may confide.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:12
verses.text: I am told that there are some who are endeavouring to deprave the right doctrine of the Lord's incarnation by perverse opinions, and I therefore call upon them through you to hold off from those unreasonable views, which some are reported to me to hold.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:13
verses.text: I mean that God Himself was turned into flesh; that He did not assume, through the Holy Mary, the nature of Adam, but, in His own proper Godhead, was changed into a material nature.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:15
verses.text: This absurd position can be easily confuted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:16
verses.text: The blasphemy is its own conviction, and I therefore think that, for one who fears the Lord, the mere reminder is enough.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:17
verses.text: If He was turned, then He was changed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:18
verses.text: But far be it from me to say or think such a thing, when God has declared, "I am the Lord, I change not".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:19
verses.text: Moreover, how could the benefit of the incarnation be conveyed to us, unless our body, joined to the Godhead, was made superior to the dominion of death? If He was changed, He no longer constituted a proper body, such as subsisted after the combination with it of the divine body.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:20
verses.text: But how, if all the nature of the Only-begotten was changed, could the incomprehensible Godhead be circumscribed within the limit of the mass of a little body? I am sure that no one who is in his senses, and has the fear of God, is suffering from this unsoundness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:21
verses.text: But the report has reached me that some of your company are afflicted with this mental infirmity, and I have therefore thought it necessary, not to send you a mere formal greeting, but to include in my letter something which may even build up the souls of them that fear the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:22
verses.text: I therefore urge that these errors receive ecclesiastical correction, and that you abstain from communion with the heretics.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 262:23
verses.text: I know that we are deprived of our liberty in Christ by indifference on these points.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:2
verses.text: To the Westerns.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:4
verses.text: May the Lord God, in Whom we have put our trust, give to each of you grace sufficient to enable you to realize your hope, in proportion to the joy wherewith you have filled my heart, both by the letter which you have sent me by the hands of the well-beloved fellow-presbyters, and by the sympathy which you have felt for me in my distress, like men who have put on bowels of mercy, as you have been described to me by the presbyters afore-mentioned.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:5
verses.text: Although my wounds remain the same, nevertheless it does bring alleviation to me that I should have leeches at hand, able, should they find an opportunity, to apply rapid remedies to my hurts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:6
verses.text: Wherefore in return I salute you by our beloved friends, and exhort you, if the Lord puts it into your power to come to me, not to hesitate to visit me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:7
verses.text: For part of the greatest commandment is the visitation of the sick.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:8
verses.text: But if the good God and wise Dispenser of our lives reserves this boon for another season, at all events write to me whatever it is proper for you to write for the consolation of the oppressed and the lifting up of those that are crushed down.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:9
verses.text: Already the Church has suffered many severe blows, and great has been my affliction at them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:10
verses.text: Nowhere is there expectation of succour unless the Lord sends us a remedy by you who are his true servants.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:12
verses.text: The bold and shameless heresy of the Arians, after being publicly cut off from the body of the Church, still abides in its own error, and does not do us much harm because its impiety is notorious to all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:13
verses.text: Nevertheless men clad in sheep's clothing, and presenting a mild and amiable appearance, but within unsparingly ravaging Christ's flocks, find it easy to do hurt to the simpler ones, because they came out from us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:14
verses.text: It is these who are grievous and hard to guard against.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:15
verses.text: It is these that we implore your diligence to denounce publicly to all the Churches of the East; to the end that they may either turn to the right way and join with us in genuine alliance, or, if they abide in their perversity, may keep their mischief to themselves alone, and be unable to communicate their own plague to their neighbours by unguarded communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:16
verses.text: I am constrained to mention them by name, in order that you may yourselves recognise those who are stirring up disturbance here, and may make them known to our Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:17
verses.text: My own words are suspected by most men, as though I had an ill will towards them on account of some private quarrel.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:18
verses.text: You, however, have all the more credit with the people, in proportion to the distance that separates your home from theirs, besides the fact that you are gifted with God's grace to help those who are distressed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:19
verses.text: If more of you concur in uttering the same opinions, it is clear that the number of those who have expressed them will make it impossible to oppose their acceptance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:21
verses.text: One of those who have caused me great sorrow is Eustathius of Sebasteia in Lesser Armenia; formerly a disciple of Arius, and a follower of him at the time when he flourished in Alexandria, and concocted his infamous blasphemies against the Only-begotten, he was numbered among his most faithful disciples.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:22
verses.text: On his return to his own country he submitted a confession of the sound faith to Hermogenes, the very blessed Bishop of Caesarea, who was on the point of condemning him for false doctrine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:23
verses.text: Under these circumstances he was ordained by Hermogenes, and, on the death of that bishop, hastened to Eusebius of Constantinople, who himself yielded to none in the energy of his support of the impious doctrine of Arius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:24
verses.text: From Constantinople he was expelled for some reason or another, returned to his own country and a second time made his defence, attempting to conceal his impious sentiments and cloking them under a certain verbal orthodoxy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:25
verses.text: He no sooner obtained the rank of bishop than he straightway appeared writing an anathema on the Homoousion in the Arians' synod at Ancyra.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:26
verses.text: From thence he went to Seleucia and took part in the notorious measures of his fellow heretics.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:27
verses.text: At Constantinople he assented a second time to the propositions of the heretics.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:28
verses.text: On being ejected from his episcopate, on the ground of his former deposition at Melitine, he hit upon a journey to you as a means of restitution for himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:29
verses.text: What propositions were made to him by the blessed bishop Liberius, and to what he agreed, I am ignorant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:30
verses.text: I only know that he brought a letter restoring him, which he shewed to the synod at Tyana, and was restored to his see.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:31
verses.text: He is now defaming the very creed for which he was received; he is consorting with those who are anathematizing the Homoousion, and is prime leader of the heresy of the pneumatomachi.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:32
verses.text: As it is from the west that he derives his power to injure the Churches, and uses the authority given him by you to the overthrow of the many, it is necessary that his correction should come from the same quarter, and that a letter be sent to the Churches stating on what terms he was received, and in what manner he has changed his conduct and nullifies the favour given him by the Fathers at that time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:34
verses.text: Next comes Apollinarius, who is no less a cause of sorrow to the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:35
verses.text: With his facility of writing, and a tongue ready to argue on any subject, he has filled the world with his works, in disregard of the advice of him who said, "Beware of making many books".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:36
verses.text: In their multitude there are certainly many errors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:37
verses.text: How is it possible to avoid sin in a multitude of words? And the theological works of Apollinarius are founded on Scriptural proof, but are based on a human origin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:38
verses.text: He has written about the resurrection, from a mythical, or rather Jewish, point of view; urging that we shall return again to the worship of the Law, be circumcised, keep the Sabbath, abstain from meats, offer sacrifices to God, worship in the Temple at Jerusalem, and be altogether turned from Christians into Jews.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:39
verses.text: What could be more ridiculous? Or, rather, what could be more contrary to the doctrines of the Gospel? Then, further, he has made such confusion among the brethren about the incarnation, that few of his readers preserve the old mark of true religion; but the more part, in their eagerness for novelty, have been diverted into investigations and quarrelsome discussions of his unprofitable treatises.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:41
verses.text: As to whether there is anything objectionable about the conversation of Paulinus, you can say yourselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:42
verses.text: What distresses me is that he should shew an inclination for the doctrine of Marcellus, and unreservedly admit his followers to communion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:43
verses.text: You know, most honourable brethren, that the reversal of all our hope is involved in the doctrine of Marcellus, for it does not confess the Son in His proper hypostasis, but represents Him as having been sent forth, and as having again returned to Him from Whom He came; neither does it admit that the Paraclete has His own subsistence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:44
verses.text: It follows that no one could be wrong in declaring this heresy to be all at variance with Christianity, and in styling it a corrupt Judaism.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:45
verses.text: Of these things I implore you to take due heed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:46
verses.text: This will be the case if you will consent to write to all the Churches of the East that those who have perverted these doctrines are in communion with you, if they amend; but that if they contentiously determine to abide by their innovations, you are separated from them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:47
verses.text: I am myself well aware, that it had been fitting for me to treat of these matters, sitting in synod with you in common deliberation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:48
verses.text: But this the time does not allow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:49
verses.text: Delay is dangerous, for the mischief they have caused has taken root.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 263:50
verses.text: I have therefore been constrained to dispatch these brethren, that you may learn from them all that has been omitted in my letter, and that they may rouse you to afford the succour which we pray for to the Churches of the East.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:2
verses.text: To Barses, bishop of Edessa, in exile.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:3
verses.text: To Barses the bishop, truly God-beloved and worthy of all reverence and honour, Basil sends greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:4
verses.text: As my dear brother Domninus is setting out to you, I gladly seize the opportunity of writing, and I greet you by him, praying the holy God that we may be so long preserved in this life as to be permitted to see you, and to enjoy the good gifts which you possess.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:5
verses.text: Only pray, I beseech you, that the Lord may not deliver us for aye to the enemies of the Cross of Christ, but that He will keep His Churches, until the time of that peace which the just Judge Himself knows when He will bestow.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:6
verses.text: For He will bestow it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:7
verses.text: He will not always abandon us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:8
verses.text: As He limited seventy years for the period of captivity for the Israelites in punishment for their sins, so peradventure the Mighty One, after giving us up for some appointed time, will recall us once again, and will restore us to the peace of the beginning—unless indeed the apostasy is now nigh at hand, and the events that have lately happened are the beginnings of the approach of Antichrist.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:9
verses.text: If this be so, pray that the good Lord will either take away our afflictions, or preserve us through our afflictions unvanquished.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:10
verses.text: Through you I greet all those who have been thought worthy to be associated with you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:11
verses.text: All who are with me salute your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 264:12
verses.text: May you, by the grace of the Holy One, be preserved to the Church of God in good health, trusting in the Lord, and praying for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:2
verses.text: To Eulogius, Alexander, and Harpocration, bishops of Egypt, in exile.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:4
verses.text: In all things we find that the providence exercised by our good God over His Churches is mighty, and that thus the very things which seem to be gloomy, and do not turn out as we should like, are ordained for the advantage of most, in the hidden wisdom of God, and in the unsearchable judgments of His righteousness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:5
verses.text: Now the Lord has removed you from the regions of Egypt, and has brought you and established you in the midst of Palestine, after the manner of Israel of old, whom He carried away by captivity into the land of the Assyrians, and there extinguished idolatry through the sojourn of His saints.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:6
verses.text: Now too we find the same thing, when we observe that the Lord is making known your struggle for the sake of true religion, opening to you through your exile the arena of your blessed contests, and to all who see before them your noble constancy, giving the boon of your good example to lead them to salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:7
verses.text: By God's grace, I have heard of the correctness of your faith, and of your zeal for the brethren and that it is in no careless or perfunctory spirit that you provide what is profitable and necessary for salvation, and that you support all that conduces to the edification of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:8
verses.text: I have therefore thought it right that I should be brought into communion with your goodness, and be united to your reverences by letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:9
verses.text: For these reasons I have sent my very dear brother the deacon Elpidius, who not only conveys my letter, but is moreover fully qualified to announce to you whatever may have been omitted in my letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:11
verses.text: I have been specially moved to desire union with you by the report of the zeal of your reverences in the cause of orthodoxy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:12
verses.text: The constancy of your hearts has been stirred neither by multiplicity of books nor by variety of ingenious arguments.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:13
verses.text: You have on the contrary, recognised those who endeavoured to introduce innovations in opposition to the apostolic doctrines, and you have refused to keep silence concerning the mischief which they are causing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:14
verses.text: I have in truth found great distress among all who cleave to the peace of the Lord at the divers innovations of Apollinarius of Laodicea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:15
verses.text: He has all the more distressed me from the fact that he seemed at the beginning on our side.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:16
verses.text: A sufferer can in a certain sense endure what comes to him from an open enemy, even though it be exceedingly painful, as it is written, "For it was not an enemy that reproached me; then I could have borne it".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:17
verses.text: But it is intolerable, and beyond the power of comfort, to be wronged by a close and sympathetic friend.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:18
verses.text: Now that very man whom I have expected to have at my right hand in defence of the truth, I have found in many ways hindering those who are being saved, by seducing their minds and drawing them away from direct doctrine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:19
verses.text: What rash and hasty deed has he not done? What ill considered and dangerous argument has he not risked? Is not all the Church divided against herself, specially since the day when men have been sent by him to the Churches governed by orthodox bishops, to rend them asunder and to set up some peculiar and illegal service? Is not ridicule brought upon the great mystery of true religion when bishops go about without people and clergy, having nothing but the mere name and title, and effecting nothing for the advancement of the Gospel of peace and salvation? Are not his discourses about God full of impious doctrines, the old impiety of the insane Sabellius being now renewed by him in his writings? For if the works which are current among the Sebastenes are not the forgery of foes, and are really his composition, he has reached a height of impiety which cannot be surpassed, in saying that Father, Son, and Spirit are the same, and other dark pieces of irreverence which I have declined even to hear, praying that I may have nothing to do with those who have uttered them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:20
verses.text: Does he not confuse the doctrine of the incarnation? Has not the oeconomy of salvation been made doubtful to the many on account of his dark and cloudy speculations about it? To collect them all, and refute them, requires long time and much discussion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:21
verses.text: But where have the promises of the Gospel been blunted and destroyed as by his figments? So meanly and poorly has he dared to explain the blessed hope laid up for all who live according to the Gospel of Christ, as to reduce it to mere old wives' fables and doctrines of Jews.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:22
verses.text: He proclaims the renewal of the Temple, the observance of the worship of the Law, a typical high priest over again after the real High Priest, and a sacrifice for sins after the Lamb of God Who taketh away the sin of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:23
verses.text: He preaches partial baptisms after the one baptism, and the ashes of a heifer sprinkling the Church which, through its faith in Christ, has not spot or wrinkle, or any such thing; cleansing of leprosy after the painless state of the resurrection; an offering of jealousy when they neither marry nor are given in marriage; shew-bread after the Bread from heaven; burning lamps after the true Light.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:24
verses.text: In a word, if the law of the Commandments has been done away with by dogmas, it is plain that under these circumstances the dogmas of Christ will be nullified by the injunctions of the law.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:25
verses.text: At these things shame and disgrace have covered my face, and heavy grief hath filled my heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:26
verses.text: Wherefore, I beseech you, as skilful physicians, and instructed how to discipline antagonists with gentleness, to try and bring him back to the right order of the Church, and to persuade him to despise the wordiness of his own works; for he has proved the truth of the proverb "in the multitude of words there wanteth not sin".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:27
verses.text: Put boldly before him the doctrines of orthodoxy, in order that his amendment may be published abroad, and his repentance made known to his brethren.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:29
verses.text: It is also desirable that I should remind your reverence about the followers of Marcellus, in order that you may decide nothing in their case rashly or inconsiderately.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:30
verses.text: On account of his impious doctrines he has gone out from the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:31
verses.text: It is therefore necessary that his followers should only be received into communion on condition that they anathematize that heresy, in order that those who are united to me through you may be accepted by all the brethren.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:32
verses.text: And now most men are moved to no small grief on hearing that you have both received them and admitted them to ecclesiastical communion on their coming to your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:33
verses.text: Nevertheless you ought to have known that by God's grace you do not stand alone in the East, but have many in communion with you, who vindicate the orthodoxy of the Fathers, and who put forth the pious doctrine of the Faith at Nicaea.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:34
verses.text: The Westerns also all agree with you and with me, whose exposition of the Faith I have received and keep with me, assenting to their sound doctrine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:35
verses.text: You ought, then, to have satisfied all who are in agreement with you, that the action which is being taken may be ratified by the general consent, and that peace may not be broken by the acceptance of some while others are kept apart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:36
verses.text: Thus you ought to have at the same time seriously and gently taken counsel about matters which are of importance to all the Churches throughout the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:37
verses.text: Praise is not due to him who hastily determines any point, but rather to him who rules every detail firmly and unalterably, so that when his judgment is enquired into, even at a later time, it may be the more esteemed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:38
verses.text: This is the man who is acceptable both to God and man as one who guides his words with discretion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:39
verses.text: Thus I have addressed your reverence in such terms as are possible in a letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:40
verses.text: May the Lord grant that one day we may meet, that so, after arranging everything together with you for the government of the Churches, I may with you receive the reward prepared by the righteous Judge for faithful and wise stewards.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:41
verses.text: In the mean time be so good as to let me know with what intention you have received the followers of Marcellus, knowing this, that even if you secure everything, so far as you yourselves are concerned, you ought not to deal with a matter of such importance on your own sole responsibility.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 265:42
verses.text: It is further necessary that the Westerns, and those who are in communion with them in the East, should concur in the restoration of these men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:2
verses.text: To Petrus, bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:4
verses.text: You have very properly rebuked me, and in a manner becoming a spiritual brother who has been taught genuine love by the Lord, because I am not giving you exact and detailed information of all that is going on here, for it is both your part to be interested in what concerns me, and mine to tell you all that concerns myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:5
verses.text: But I must tell you, right honourable and well-beloved brother, that our continuous afflictions, and this mighty agitation which is now shaking the Churches, result in my taking all that is happening as a matter of course.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:6
verses.text: Just as in smithies where men whose ears are deafened get accustomed to the sound, so by the frequency of the strange tidings that reach me I have now grown accustomed to be undisturbed and undismayed at extraordinary events.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:7
verses.text: So the policy which has been for a long time pursued by the Arians to the detriment of the Church, although their achievements have been many and great and noised abroad through all the world, has nevertheless been endurable to me, because of their being the work of open foes and enemies of the word of truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:8
verses.text: It is when these men do something unusual that I am astonished, not when they attempt something great and audacious against true religion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:9
verses.text: But I am grieved and troubled at what is being done by men who feel and think with me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:10
verses.text: Yet their doings are so frequent and so constantly reported to me, that even they do not appear surprising.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:11
verses.text: So it comes about that I was not agitated at the recent disorderly proceedings, partly because I knew perfectly well that common report would carry them to you without my help, and partly because I preferred to wait for somebody else to give you disagreeable news.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:12
verses.text: And yet, further, I did not think it reasonable that I should show indignation at such proceedings, as though I were annoyed at suffering a slight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:13
verses.text: To the actual agents in the matter I have written in becoming terms, exhorting them, because of the dissension arising among some of the brethren there, not to fall away from charity, but to wait for the matter to be set right by those who have authority to remedy disorders in due ecclesiastical form.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:14
verses.text: That you should have so acted, stirred by honourable and becoming motives, calls for my commendation, and moves my gratitude to the Lord that there remains preserved in you a relic of the ancient discipline, and that the Church has not lost her own might in my persecution.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:15
verses.text: The canons have not suffered persecution as well as I.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:16
verses.text: Though importuned again by the Galatians, I was never able to give them an answer, because I waited for your decision.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:17
verses.text: Now, if the Lord so will and they will consent to listen to me, I hope that I shall be able to bring the people to the Church.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:18
verses.text: It cannot then be cast in my teeth that I have gone over to the Marcellians, and they on the contrary will become limbs of the body of the Church of Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:19
verses.text: Thus the disgrace caused by heresy will be made to disappear by the method I adopt, and I shall escape the opprobrium of having gone over to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:21
verses.text: I have also been grieved by our brother Dorotheus, because, as he has himself written, he has not gently and mildly reported everything to your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:22
verses.text: I set this down to the difficulty of the times.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:23
verses.text: I seem to be deprived by my sins of all success in my undertakings, if indeed the best of my brethren are proved ill-disposed and incompetent, by their failure to perform their duties in accordance with my wishes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:24
verses.text: On his return Dorotheus reported to me the conversation which he had had with your excellency in the presence of the very venerable bishop Damasus, and he caused me distress by saying that our God-beloved brethren and fellow-ministers, Meletius and Eusebius, had been reckoned among the Ariomaniacs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:25
verses.text: If their orthodoxy were established by nothing else, the attacks made upon them by the Arians are, to the minds of all right thinking people, no small proof of their rectitude.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:26
verses.text: Even your participation with them in sufferings endured for Christ's sake ought to unite your reverence to them in love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:27
verses.text: Be assured of this, right honourable sir, that there is no word of orthodoxy which has not been proclaimed by these men with all boldness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:28
verses.text: God is my witness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:29
verses.text: I have heard them myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:30
verses.text: I should not certainly have now admitted them to communion, if I had caught them tripping in the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:31
verses.text: But, if it seem good to you, let us leave the past alone.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:32
verses.text: Let us make a peaceful start for the future.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:33
verses.text: For we have need one of another in the fellowship of the members, and specially now, when the Churches of the East are looking to us, and will take your agreement as a pledge of strength and consolidation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 266:34
verses.text: If, on the other hand, they perceive that you are in a state of mutual suspicion, they will drop their hands, and slacken in their resistance to the enemies of the faith.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:2
verses.text: To Barses, bishop of Edessa, in exile.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:3
verses.text: For the sake of the affection which I entertain for you, I long to be with you, to embrace you, my dear friend, in person, and to glorify the Lord Who is magnified in you, and has made your honourable old age renowned among all them that fear Him throughout the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:4
verses.text: But severe sickness afflicts me, and to a greater degree than I can express in words, I am weighed down by the care of the Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:5
verses.text: I am not my own master, to go whither I will, and to visit whom I will.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:6
verses.text: Therefore I am trying to satisfy the longing I have for the good gifts in you by writing to you, and I beseech your reverence to pray for me and for the Church, that the Lord may grant to me to pass the remaining days or hours of my sojourn here without offence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:7
verses.text: May He permit me to see the peace of His Churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:8
verses.text: Of your fellow-ministers and fellow-athletes may I hear all that I pray for, and of yourself that you are granted such a lot as the people under you seek for by day and by night from the Lord of righteousness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:9
verses.text: I have not written often, not even so often as I ought, but I have written to your reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:10
verses.text: Possibly the brethren to whom I committed my greetings were not able to preserve them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:11
verses.text: But now that I have found some of my brethren travelling to your excellency, I have readily entrusted my letter to them, and I have sent some messages which I beg you to receive from my humility without disdain, and to bless me after the manner of the patriarch Isaac.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:12
verses.text: I have been much occupied, and have had my mind drowned in a multiplicity of cares.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:13
verses.text: So it may well be that I have omitted something which I ought to have said.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:14
verses.text: If so, do not reckon it against me; and do not be grieved.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:15
verses.text: Act in all things up to your own high character, that I, like every one else, may enjoy the fruit of your virtue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 267:16
verses.text: May you be granted to me and to the Church, in good health, rejoicing in the Lord, praying for me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, in exile.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:3
verses.text: Even in our time the Lord has taught us, by protecting with His great and powerful hand the life of your holiness, that He does not abandon His holy ones.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:4
verses.text: I reckon your case to be almost like that of the saint remaining unhurt in the belly of the monster of the deep, or that of the men who feared the Lord, living unscathed in the fierce fire.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:5
verses.text: For though the war is round about you on every side, He, as I hear, has kept you unharmed.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:6
verses.text: May the mighty God keep you, if I live longer, to fulfil my earnest prayer that I may see you! If not for me, may He keep you for the rest, who wait for your return as they might for their own salvation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:7
verses.text: I am persuaded that the Lord in His loving-kindness will give heed to the tears of the Churches, and to the sighs which all are heaving over you, and will preserve you in life until He grant the prayer of all who night and day are praying to Him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:8
verses.text: Of all the measures taken against you, up to the arrival of our beloved brother Libanius the deacon, I have been sufficiently informed by him while on his way.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:9
verses.text: I am anxious to learn what happened afterwards.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:10
verses.text: I hear that in the meanwhile still greater troubles have occurred where you are; about all this, sooner if possible, but, if not, at least by our reverend brother Paul the presbyter, on his return, may I learn, as I pray that I may, that your life is preserved safe and sound.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:11
verses.text: But on account of the report that all the roads are infested with thieves and deserters, I have been afraid to entrust anything to the brother's keeping, for fear of causing his death.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 268:12
verses.text: If the Lord grant a little quiet, (as I am told of the coming of the army), I will try to send you one of my own men, to visit you, to bring me back news of everything about you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:2
verses.text: To the wife of Arinthaeus, the General.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:3
verses.text: Consolatory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:5
verses.text: It had been only proper, and due to your affection, that I should have been on the spot, and have taken part in the present occurrences.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:6
verses.text: Thus I might have at once assuaged my own sorrow, and given some consolation to your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:7
verses.text: But my body will no longer endure long journeys, and so I am driven to approach you by letter, that I seem not to count what has happened as altogether of no interest to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:8
verses.text: Who has not mourned for that man? Who is so stony of heart as not to have shed a warm tear over him? I especially have been filled with mourning at the thought of all the marks of respect which I have received from him, and of the general protection which he has extended to the Churches of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:9
verses.text: Nevertheless, I have bethought me that he was human, and had done the work he had to do in this life, and now in the appointed time has been taken back again by God Who ordains our lots.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:10
verses.text: All this, I beseech you, in your wisdom, to take to heart, and to meet the event with meekness, and, so far as is possible, to endure your loss with moderation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:11
verses.text: Time may be able to soothe your heart, and allow the approach of reason.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:12
verses.text: At the same time your great love for your husband, and your goodness to all, lead me to fear that, from the very simplicity of your character, the wound of your grief may pierce you deeply, and that you may give yourself up entirely to your feelings.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:13
verses.text: The teaching of Scripture is always useful, and specially at times like this.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:14
verses.text: Remember, then, the sentence passed by our Creator.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:15
verses.text: By it all we who are dust shall return to dust.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:16
verses.text: No one is so great as to be superior to dissolution.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:18
verses.text: Your admirable husband was a good and great man, and his bodily strength rivalled the virtues of his soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:19
verses.text: He was unsurpassed, I must own, in both respects.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:20
verses.text: But he was human, and he is dead; like Adam, like Abel, like Noah, like Abraham, like Moses, or any one else of like nature that you can name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:21
verses.text: Let us not then complain because he has been taken from us.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:22
verses.text: Let us rather thank Him, who joined us to him, that we dwelt with him from the beginning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:23
verses.text: To lose a husband is a lot which you share with other women; but to have been united to such a husband is a boast which I do not think any other woman can make.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:24
verses.text: In truth our Creator fashioned that man for us as a model of what human nature ought to be.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:25
verses.text: All eyes were attracted towards him, and every tongue told of his deeds.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:26
verses.text: Painters and sculptors fell short of his excellence, and historians, when they tell the story of his achievements in war, seem to fall into the region of the mythical and the incredible.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:27
verses.text: Thus it has come about that most men have not even been able to give credit to the report conveying the sad tidings, or to accept the truth of the news that Arinthaeus is dead.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:28
verses.text: Nevertheless Arinthaeus has suffered what will happen to heaven and to sun and to earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:29
verses.text: He has died a bright death; not bowed down by old age; without losing one whit of his honour; great in this life; great in the life to come; deprived of nothing of his present splendour in view of the glory hoped for, because he washed away all the stain of his soul, in the very moment of his departure hence, in the laver of regeneration.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:30
verses.text: That you should have arranged and joined in this rite is cause of supreme consolation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:31
verses.text: Turn now your thoughts from the present to the future, that you may be worthy through good works to obtain a place of rest like his.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:32
verses.text: Spare an aged mother; spare a tender daughter, to whom you are now the sole comfort.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:33
verses.text: Be an example of fortitude to other women, and so regulate your grief that you may neither eject it from your heart, nor be overwhelmed by your distress.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 269:34
verses.text: Ever keep your eyes fixed on the great reward of patience, promised, as the requital of the deeds of this life, by our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 270:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 270:2
verses.text: Without Address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 270:3
verses.text: Concerning Raptus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 270:4
verses.text: I am distressed to find that you are by no means indignant at the sins forbidden, and that you seem incapable of understanding, how this raptus, which has been committed, is an act of unlawfulness and tyranny against society and human nature, and an outrage on free men.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 270:5
verses.text: I am sure that if you had all been of one mind in this matter, there would have been nothing to prevent this bad custom from being long ago driven out of your country.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 270:6
verses.text: Do thou at the present time shew the zeal of a Christian man, and be moved as the wrong deserves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 270:7
verses.text: Wherever you find the girl, insist on taking her away, and restore her to her parents, shut out the man from the prayers, and make him excommunicate.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 270:8
verses.text: His accomplices, according to the canon which I have already put forth, cut off, with all their household, from the prayers.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 270:9
verses.text: The village which received the girl after the abduction, and kept her, or even fought against her restitution, shut out with all its inhabitants from the prayers; to the end that all may know that we regard the ravisher as a common foe, like a snake or any other wild beast, and so hunt him out, and help those whom he has wronged.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, my comrade, to recommend Cyriacus the presbyter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:3
verses.text: At once and in haste, after your departure, I came to the town.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:4
verses.text: Why need I tell a man not needing to be told, because he knows by experience, how distressed I was not to find you? How delightful it would have been to me to see once more the excellent Eusebius, to embrace him, to travel once again in memory to our young days, and to be reminded of old times when for both of us there was one home, one hearth, the same schoolmaster, the same leisure, the same work, the same treats, the same hardships, and everything shared in common! What do you think I would not have given to recall all this by actually meeting you, to rid me of the heavy weight of my old age, and to seem to be turned from an old man into a lad again? But I have lost this pleasure.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:5
verses.text: At least of the privilege of meeting your excellency in correspondence, and of consoling myself by the best means at my disposal, I am not deprived.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:6
verses.text: I am so fortunate as to meet the very reverend presbyter Cyriacus.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:7
verses.text: I am ashamed to recommend him to you, and to make him, through me, your own, lest I seem to be performing a superfluous task in offering to you what you already possess and value as your own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:8
verses.text: But it is my duty to witness to the truth, and to give the best boons I have to those who are spiritually united to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:9
verses.text: I think that the man's blamelessness in his sacred position is well known to you; but I confirm it, for I do not know that any charge is brought against him by those who do not fear the Lord and are laying their hands upon all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:10
verses.text: Even if they had done anything of the kind, the man would not have been unworthy, for the enemies of the Lord rather vindicate the orders of those whom they attack than deprive them of any of the grace given them by the Spirit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:11
verses.text: However, as I said, nothing has even been thought of against the man.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:12
verses.text: Be so good then as to look upon him as a blameless presbyter, in union with me, and worthy of all reverence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 271:13
verses.text: Thus will you benefit yourself and gratify me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXXII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:2
verses.text: To Sophronius the magister officiorum.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:4
verses.text: It has been reported to me by Actiacus the deacon, that certain men have moved you to anger against me, by falsely stating me to be ill-disposed towards your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:5
verses.text: I cannot be astonished at a man in your position being followed by certain sycophants.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:6
verses.text: High position seems to be in some way naturally attended by miserable hangers-on of this kind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:7
verses.text: Destitute as they are of any good quality of their own whereby they may be known, they endeavour to recommend themselves by means of other people's ills.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:8
verses.text: Peradventure, just as mildew is a blight which grows in corn, so flattery stealing upon friendship is a blight of friendship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:9
verses.text: So, as I said, I am by no means astonished that these men should buzz about your bright and distinguished hearth, as drones do about the hives.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:10
verses.text: But what has moved my wonderment, and has seemed altogether astounding, is that a man like yourself, specially distinguished by the seriousness of your character, should have been induced to give both your ears to these people and to accept their calumny against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:11
verses.text: From my youth up to this my old age I have felt affection for many men, but I am not aware that I have ever felt greater affection for any one than for your excellency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:12
verses.text: Even had not my reason induced me to regard a man of such a character, our intimacy from boyhood would have sufficed to attach me to your soul.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:13
verses.text: You know yourself how much custom has to do with friendship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:14
verses.text: Pardon my deficiency, if I can show nothing worthy of this preference.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:15
verses.text: You will not ask some deed from me in proof of my good will; you will be satisfied with a temper of mind which assuredly prays for you that you may have all that is best.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:16
verses.text: May your fortunes never fall so low, as that you should need the aid of any one so insignificant as myself!  2.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:17
verses.text: How then was I likely to say anything against you, or to take any action in the matter of Memnonius? These points were reported to me by the deacon.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:18
verses.text: How could I put the wealth of Hymetius before the friendship of one so prodigal of his substance as you are? There is no truth in any of these things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:19
verses.text: I have neither said nor done anything against you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:20
verses.text: Possibly some ground may have been given for some of the lies that are being told, by my remarking to some of those who are causing disturbance, "If the man has determined to accomplish what he has in mind, then, whether you make disturbance or not, what he means to be done will certainly be done.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:21
verses.text: You will speak, or hold your tongues; it will make no difference.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:22
verses.text: If he changes his mind, beware how you defame my friend's honourable name.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:23
verses.text: Do not, under the pretence of zeal in your patron's cause, attempt to make some personal profit out of your attempts to threaten and alarm".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:24
verses.text: As to that person's making his will, I have never said one word, great or small, directly or indirectly, about the matter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:26
verses.text: You must not refuse to believe what I say, unless you regard me as quite a desperate character, who thinks nothing of the great sin of lying.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:27
verses.text: Put away all suspicion of me in relation to the business, and for the future reckon my affection for you as beyond the reach of all calumny.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:28
verses.text: Imitate Alexander, who received a letter, saying that his physician was plotting his death, at the very moment when he was just about to drink his medicine, and was so far from believing the slanderer that he at one and the same time read the letter and drank the draught.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 272:29
verses.text: I refuse to admit that I am in any way inferior to the men who have been famous for their friendship, for I have never been detected in any breach of mine; and, besides this, I have received from my God the commandment of love, and owe you love not only as part of mankind in general, but because I recognise you individually as a benefactor both of my country and of myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 273:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXXIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 273:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 273:3
verses.text: Concerning Hera.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 273:4
verses.text: I am sure that your excellency loves me well enough to regard all that concerns me as concerning you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 273:5
verses.text: Therefore I commend to your great kindness and high consideration my very reverend brother Hera, whom I do not merely call brother by any conventional phrase, but because of his boundless affection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 273:6
verses.text: I beseech you to regard him as though he were nearly connected with yourself, and, so far as you can, to give him your protection in the matters in which he requires your generous and thoughtful aid.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 273:7
verses.text: I shall then have this one more kindness to reckon in addition to the many which I have already received at your hands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 274:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 274:2
verses.text: To Himerius, the master.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 274:3
verses.text: That my friendship and affection for the very reverend brother Hera began when I was quite a boy, and has, by God's grace, continued up to my old age, no one knows better than yourself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 274:4
verses.text: For the Lord granted me the affection of your excellency at about the same time that He allowed me to become acquainted with Hera.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 274:5
verses.text: He now needs your patronage, and I therefore beseech and supplicate you to do a favour for the sake of our old affection, and to heed the necessity under which we now lie.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 274:6
verses.text: I beg you to make his cause your own, that he may need no other protection, but may return to me, successful in all that he is praying for.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 274:7
verses.text: Then to the many kindnesses which I have received at your hands I shall be able to add yet this one more.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 274:8
verses.text: I could not claim any favour more important to myself, or one more nearly touching my own interests.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 275:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 275:2
verses.text: Without address.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 275:3
verses.text: Concerning Hera.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 275:4
verses.text: You have anticipated my entreaties in your affection for my very reverend brother Hera, and you have been better to him than I could have prayed for you to be in the abundant honour which you have shewn him, and the protection which you have extended to him on every occasion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 275:5
verses.text: But I cannot allow his affairs to go unnoticed by a word, and I must beseech your excellency that for my sake you will add something to the interest you have shewn in him, and will send him back to his own country victorious over the revilings of his enemies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 275:6
verses.text: Now many are trying to insult the peacefulness of his life, and he is not beyond the reach of envy's shafts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 275:7
verses.text: Against his foes we shall find one sure means of safety, if you will consent to extend your protection over him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 276:1
verses.text: Letter CCLXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 276:2
verses.text: To the great Harmatius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 276:3
verses.text: The common law of human nature makes elders fathers to youngsters, and the special peculiar law of us Christians puts us old men in the place of parents to the younger.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 276:4
verses.text: Do not, then, think that I am impertinent or shew myself indefensibly meddlesome, if I plead with you on behalf of your son.
