verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXXXIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:2
verses.text: To a writer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:3
verses.text: Write straight, and make the lines straight.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:4
verses.text: Do not let your hand go too high or too low.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:5
verses.text: Avoid forcing the pen to travel slantwise, like aesop's crab.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:6
verses.text: Advance straight on, as if following the line of the carpenter's rule, which always preserves exactitude and prevents any irregularity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:7
verses.text: The oblique is ungraceful.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:8
verses.text: It is the straight which pleases the eye, and does not allow the reader's eyes to go nodding up and down like a swing-beam.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:9
verses.text: This has been my fate in reading your writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:10
verses.text: As the lines lie ladderwise, I was obliged, when I had to go from one to another, to mount up to the end of the last: then, when no connexion was to be found, I had to go back, and seek for the right order again, retreating and following the furrow, like Theseus in the story following Ariadne's thread.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 326:11
verses.text: Write straight, and do not confuse our mind by your slanting and irregular writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 327:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXXXV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 327:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 327:3
verses.text: I am really ashamed of sending you the Cappadocians one by one.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 327:4
verses.text: I should prefer to induce all our youths to devote themselves to letters and learning, and to avail themselves of your instruction in their training.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 327:5
verses.text: But it is impracticable to get hold of them all at once, while they choose what suits themselves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 327:6
verses.text: I therefore send you those who from time to time are won over; and this I do with the assurance that I am conferring on them a boon as great as that which is given by those who bring thirsty men to the fountain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 327:7
verses.text: The lad, whom I am now sending, will be highly valued for his own sake when he has been in your society.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 327:8
verses.text: He is already well known on account of his father, who has won a name among us both for rectitude of life and for authority in our community.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 327:9
verses.text: He is, moreover, a close friend of my own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 327:10
verses.text: To requite him for his friendship to me, I am conferring on his son the benefit of an introduction to you—a boon well worthy of being earnestly prayed for by all who are competent to judge of a man's high character.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXXXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basilius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:4
verses.text: After some little time a young Cappadocian has reached me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:5
verses.text: One gain to me is that he is a Cappadocian.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:6
verses.text: But this Cappadocian is one of the first rank.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:7
verses.text: This is another gain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:8
verses.text: Further, he brings me a letter from the admirable Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:9
verses.text: This is the greatest gain of all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:10
verses.text: You think that I have forgotten you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:11
verses.text: I had great respect for you in your youth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:12
verses.text: I saw you vying with old men in self-restraint, and this in a city teeming with pleasures.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:13
verses.text: I saw you already in possession of considerable learning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:14
verses.text: Then you thought that you ought also to see Athens, and you persuaded Celsus to accompany you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:15
verses.text: Happy Celsus, to be dear to you! Then you returned, and lived at home, and I said to myself, What, I wonder, is Basil about now? To what occupation has he betaken himself? Is he following the ancient orators, and practising in the courts? Or is he turning the sons of fortunate fathers into orators? Then there came those who reported to me that you were adopting a course of life better than any of these, and were, rather, bethinking you how you might win the friendship of God than heaps of gold, I blessed both you and the Cappadocians; you, for making this your aim; them, for being able to point to so noble a fellow-countryman.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:17
verses.text: I am aware that the Firmus, whom you mention, has continually won everywhere; hence his great power as a speaker.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:18
verses.text: But with all the eulogies that have been bestowed on him, I am not aware that he has ever received such praise as I have heard of in your letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:19
verses.text: For what a credit it is to him, that it should be you who declare that his reputation is inferior to none!  Apparently, you have despatched this young man to me before seeing Firminus; had you done so, your letters would not have failed to mention him.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:20
verses.text: What is Firminus now doing or intending to do? Is he still anxious to be married? Or is all that over now? Are the claims of the senate heavy on him? Is he obliged to stay where he is? Is there any hope of his taking to study again ? Let him send me an answer, and I trust it may be satisfactory.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:21
verses.text: If it be a distressing one, at least it will relieve him from seeing me at his door.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:22
verses.text: And if Firminus had been now at Athens, what would your senators have done? Would they have sent the Salaminia after him? You see that it is only by your fellow-countrymen that I am wronged.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:23
verses.text: Yet I shall never cease to love and praise the Cappadocians.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:24
verses.text: I should like them to be better disposed to me, but, if they continue to act as they do, I shall bear it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:25
verses.text: Firminus was four months with me, and was not a day idle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:26
verses.text: You will know how much he has acquired, and perhaps will not complain.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 328:27
verses.text: As to his being able to come here again, what ally can I call in? If your senators are right-minded, as men of education ought to be, they will honour me in the second case, since they grieved me in the first.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 329:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXXXVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 329:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 329:3
verses.text: Lo and behold, yet another Cappadocian has come to you; a son of my own! Yet my present position makes all men my sons.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 329:4
verses.text: On this ground he may be regarded as a brother of the former one, and worthy of the same attention alike from me his father, and from you his instructor—if really it is possible for these young men, who come from me, to obtain any further favours.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 329:5
verses.text: I do not mean that it is not possible for your excellency to give anything more to your old comrades, but because your services are so lavishly bestowed upon all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 329:6
verses.text: It will be sufficient for the lad before he gets experience if he be numbered among those who are intimately known to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 329:7
verses.text: I trust you may send him back to me worthy of my prayers and of your great reputation in learning and eloquence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 329:8
verses.text: He is accompanied by a young man of his own age, and of like zeal for instruction; a youth of good family, and closely associated with myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 329:9
verses.text: I am sure he will be in every way as well treated, though his means are smaller than is the case with the rest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXXXVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:3
verses.text: I know you will often write, "Here is another Cappadocian for you!" I expect that you will send me many.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:4
verses.text: I am sure that you are everywhere putting pressure on both fathers and sons by all your complimentary expressions about me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:5
verses.text: But it would not be kind on my part not to mention what happened about your good letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:6
verses.text: There were sitting with me not a few of our people of distinction, and among them the very excellent Alypius, Hierocles' cousin.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:7
verses.text: The messengers gave in the letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:8
verses.text: I read it right through without a word; then with a smile, and evidently gratified, I exclaimed, "I am vanquished!" "How? When? Where?" they asked.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:9
verses.text: "How is it that you are not distressed at being vanquished?" "I am beaten," I replied, "in beautiful letter writing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:10
verses.text: Basil has won.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:11
verses.text: But I love him; and so I am delighted".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:12
verses.text: On hearing this, they all wanted to hear of the victory from the letter itself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:13
verses.text: It was read by Alypius, while all listened.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:14
verses.text: It was voted that what I had said was quite true.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:15
verses.text: Then the reader went out, with the letter still in his hand, to shew it, I suppose, to others.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:16
verses.text: I had some difficulty in getting it back.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:17
verses.text: Go on writing others like it; go on winning.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:18
verses.text: This is for me to win.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:19
verses.text: You are quite right in thinking that my services are not measured by money.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:20
verses.text: Enough for him who has nothing to give, that he is as wishful to receive.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:21
verses.text: If I perceive any one who is poor to be a lover of learning, he takes precedence of the rich.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:22
verses.text: True, I never found such instructors; but nothing shall stand in the way of my being, at least in that respect, an improvement on mine.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 330:23
verses.text: Let no one, then, hesitate to come hither because he is poor, if only he possesses the one qualification of knowing how to work.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXXXIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:3
verses.text: What could not a sophist say? And such a sophist! One whose peculiar art is, whenever he likes, to make great things small, and to give greatness to small things! This is what you have shewn in my case.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:4
verses.text: That dirty little letter of mine, as, perhaps, you who live in all luxury of eloquence would call it, a letter in no way more tolerable than the one you hold in your hands now, you have so extolled as, forsooth, to be eaten by it, and to be yielding me the prize for composition! You are acting much as fathers do, when they join in their boys' games, and let the little fellows be proud of the victories which they have let them win without any loss to themselves, and with much gain to the children's emulation.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:5
verses.text: Really and truly the delight your speech must have given, when you were joking about me, must have been indescribable! It is as though some Polydamas or Milo were to decline the pancratium or a wrestling bout with me! After carefully examining, I have found no sign of weakness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:6
verses.text: So those who look for exaggeration are the more astonished at your being able to descend in sport to my level, than if you had led the barbarian in full sail over Athos.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:7
verses.text: I, however, my dear sir, am now spending my time with Moses and Elias, and saints like them, who tell me their stories in a barbarous tongue, and I utter what I learnt from them, true, indeed, in sense, though rude in phrase, as what I am writing testifies.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:8
verses.text: If ever I learned anything from you, I have forgotten it in the course of time.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:9
verses.text: But do you continue to write to me, and so suggest other topics for correspondence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:10
verses.text: Your letter will exhibit you, and will not convict me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:11
verses.text: I have already introduced to you the son of Anysius, as a son of my own.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:12
verses.text: If he is my son, he is the child of his father, poor, and a poor man's son.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 331:13
verses.text: What I am saying is well known to one who is wise as well as a sophist.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXL.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:3
verses.text: Had you been for a long time considering how best you could reply to my letter about yours, you could not in my judgment have acquitted yourself better than by writing as you have written now.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:4
verses.text: You call me a sophist, and you allege that it is a sophist's business to make small things great and great things small.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:5
verses.text: And you maintain that the object of my letter was to prove yours a good one, when it was not a good one, and that it was no better than the one which you have sent last, and, in a word that you have no power of expression, the books which you have now in hand producing no such effect, and the eloquence which you once possessed having all disappeared.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:6
verses.text: Now, in the endeavour to prove this, you have made this epistle too, which you are reviling, so admirable, that my visitors could not refrain from leaping with admiration as it was being read.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:7
verses.text: I was astonished that after your trying to run down the former one by this, by saying that the former one was like it, you have really complimented the former by it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:8
verses.text: To carry out your object, you ought to have made this one worse, that you might slander the former.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:9
verses.text: But it is not like you, I think, to do despite to the truth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:10
verses.text: It would have been done despite to, if you had purposely written badly, and not put out the powers you have.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:11
verses.text: It would be characteristic of you not to find fault with what is worthy of praise, lest in your attempt to make great things insignificant, your proceedings reduce you to the rank of the sophists.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:12
verses.text: Keep to the books which you say are inferior in style, though better in sense.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:13
verses.text: No one hinders you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:14
verses.text: But of the principles which are ever mine, and once were yours, the roots both remain and will remain, as long as you exist.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 332:15
verses.text: Though you water them ever so little, no length of time will ever completely destroy them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 333:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXLI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 333:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 333:3
verses.text: You have not yet ceased to be offended with me, and so I tremble as I write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 333:4
verses.text: If you have cared, why, my dear sir, do you not write? If you are still offended, a thing alien from any reasonable soul and from your own, why, while you are preaching to others, that they must not keep their anger till sundown, have you kept yours during many suns? Peradventure you have meant to punish me by depriving me of the sound of your sweet voice? Nay; excellent sir, be gentle, and let me enjoy your golden tongue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 334:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXLII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 334:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 334:3
verses.text: All who are attached to the rose, as might be expected in the case of lovers of the beautiful, are not displeased even at the thorns from out of which the flower blows.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 334:4
verses.text: I have even heard it said about roses by some one, perhaps in jest, or, it may be, even in earnest, that nature has furnished the bloom with those delicate thorns, like stings of love to lovers, to excite those who pluck them to intenser longing by these ingeniously adapted pricks.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 334:5
verses.text: But what do I mean by this introduction of the rose into my letter? You do not need telling, when you remember your own letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 334:6
verses.text: It had indeed the bloom of the rose, and, by its fair speech, opened out all spring to me; but it was bethorned with certain fault findings and charges against me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 334:7
verses.text: But even the thorn of your words is delightful to me, for it enkindles in me a greater longing for your friendship.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 335:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXLIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 335:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 335:3
verses.text: IF these are the words of an untrained tongue, what would you be if you would polish them? On your lips live fountains of words better than the flowing of springs.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 335:4
verses.text: I, on the contrary, if I am not daily watered, am silent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXLIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:3
verses.text: I am dissuaded from writing often to you, learned as you are, by my timidity and my ignorance.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:4
verses.text: But your persistent silence is different.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:5
verses.text: What excuse can be offered for it? If any one takes into account that you are slow to write to me, living as you do in the midst of letters, he will condemn you for forgetfulness of me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:6
verses.text: He who is ready at speaking is not unprepared to write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:7
verses.text: And if a man so endowed is silent, it is plain that he acts either from forgetfulness or from contempt.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:8
verses.text: I will, however, requite your silence with a greeting.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:9
verses.text: Farewell, most honoured sir.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:10
verses.text: Write if you like.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 336:11
verses.text: If you prefer it, do not write.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXLV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:3
verses.text: It is, I think, more needful for me to defend myself for not having begun to write to you long ago, than to offer any excuse for beginning now.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:4
verses.text: I am that same man who always used to run up whenever you put in an appearance, and who listened with the greatest delight to the stream of your eloquence; rejoicing to hear you; with difficulty tearing myself away; saying to my friends, This man is thus far superior to the daughters of Achelous, in that, like them, he soothes, but he does not hurt as they do.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:5
verses.text: Truly it is no great thing not to hurt; but this man's songs are a positive gain to the hearer.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:6
verses.text: That I should be in this state of mind, should think that I am regarded with affection, and should seem able to speak, and yet should not venture to write, is the mark of a man guilty of extreme idleness, and, at the same time, inflicting punishment on himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:7
verses.text: For it is clear that you will requite my poor little letter with a fine large one, and will take care not to wrong me again.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:8
verses.text: At this word, I fancy, many will cry out, and will crowd round with the shout, What! has Basil done any wrong—even a small wrong? Then so have oeacus, and Minos and his brother.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:9
verses.text: In other points I admit that you have won.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:10
verses.text: Who ever saw you that does not envy you? But in one thing you have sinned against me; and, if I remind you of it, induce those who are indignant thereat not to make a public outcry.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:11
verses.text: No one has ever come to you and asked a favour which it was easy to give, and gone away unsuccessful.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:12
verses.text: But I am one of those who have craved a boon without receiving it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:13
verses.text: What then did I ask? Often when I was with you in camp, I was desirous of entering, with the aid of your wisdom, into the depth of Homer's frenzy.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:14
verses.text: If the whole is impossible, I said, do you bring me to a portion of what I want.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:15
verses.text: I was anxious for a part, wherein, when things have gone ill with the Greeks, Agamemnon courts with gifts the man whom he has insulted.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:16
verses.text: When I so spoke, you laughed, because you could not deny that you could if you liked, but were unwilling to give.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 337:17
verses.text: Do I really seem to be wronged to you and to your friends, who were indignant at my saying that you were doing a wrong?.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 338:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXLVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 338:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 338:3
verses.text: You yourself will judge whether I have added anything in the way of learning to the young men whom you have sent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 338:4
verses.text: I hope that this addition, however little it be, will get the credit of being great, for the sake of your friendship towards me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 338:5
verses.text: But inasmuch as you give less praise to learning than to temperance and to a refusal to abandon our souls to dishonourable pleasures, they have devoted their main attention to this, and have lived, as indeed they ought, with due recollection of the friend who sent them hither.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 338:6
verses.text: So welcome what is your own, and give praise to men who by their mode of life have done credit both to you and to me.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 338:7
verses.text: But to ask you to be serviceable to them is like asking a father to be serviceable to his children.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 339:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXLVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 339:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 339:3
verses.text: Every bishop is a thing out of which it is very hard to get anything.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 339:4
verses.text: The further you have advanced beyond other people in learning, the more you make me afraid that you will refuse what I ask.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 339:5
verses.text: I want some rafters.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 339:6
verses.text: Any other sophist would have called them stakes, or poles, not because he wanted stakes or poles, but rather for shewing off his wordlets than out of any real need.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 339:7
verses.text: If you do not supply them, I shall have to winter in the open air.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 340:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXLVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 340:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 340:3
verses.text: If γριπίζειν is the same thing as to gain, and this is the meaning of the phrase which your sophistic ingenuity has got from the depths of Plato, consider, my dear sir, who is the more hard to be got from, I who am thus impaled by your epistolary skill, or the tribe of Sophists, whose craft is to make money out of their words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 340:4
verses.text: What bishop ever imposed tribute by his words? What bishop ever made his disciples pay taxes? It is you who make your words marketable, as confectioners make honey-cakes.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 340:5
verses.text: See how you have made the old man leap and bound! However, to you who make such a fuss about your declamations, I have ordered as many rafters to be supplied as there were fighters at Thermopylae, all of goodly length, and, as Homer has it, "long-shadowing," which the sacred Alphaeus has promised to restore.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 341:1
verses.text: Letter CCCXLIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 341:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 341:3
verses.text: Will you not give over, Basil, packing this sacred haunt of the Muses with Cappadocians, and these redolent of the frost and snow and all Cappadocia's good things? They have almost made me a Cappadocian too, always chanting their "I salute you".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 341:4
verses.text: I must endure, since it is Basil who commands.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 341:5
verses.text: Know, however, that I am making a careful study of the manners and customs of the country, and that I mean to metamorphose the men into the nobility and the harmony of my Calliope, that they may seem to you to be turned from pigeons into doves.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 342:1
verses.text: Letter CCCL.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 342:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 342:3
verses.text: Your annoyance is over.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 342:4
verses.text: Let this be the beginning of my letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 342:5
verses.text: Go on mocking and abusing me and mine, whether laughing or in earnest.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 342:6
verses.text: Why say anything about frost or snow, when you might be luxuriating in mockery? For my part, Libanius, that I may rouse you to a hearty laugh, I have written my letter enveloped in a snow-white veil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 342:7
verses.text: When you take the letter in your hand, you will feel how cold it is, and how it symbolizes the condition of the sender—kept at home and not able to put head out of doors.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 342:8
verses.text: For my house is a grave till spring comes and brings us back from death to life, and once more gives to us, as to plants, the boon of existence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 343:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 343:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 343:3
verses.text: Many, who have come to me from where you are, have admired your oratorical power.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 343:4
verses.text: They were remarking that there has been a very brilliant specimen of this, and a very great contest, as they alleged, with the result that all crowded together, and no one appeared in the whole city but Libanius alone in the lists, and everybody, young and old, listening.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 343:5
verses.text: For no one was willing to be absent—not a man of rank—not a distinguished soldier—not an artisan.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 343:6
verses.text: Even women hurried to be present at the struggle.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 343:7
verses.text: And what was it? What was the speech which brought together this vast assembly? I have been told that it contained a description of a man of peevish temper.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 343:8
verses.text: Pray lose no time in sending me this much admired speech, in order that I too may join in praising your eloquence.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 343:9
verses.text: If I am a praiser of Libanius without his works, what am I likely to become after receiving the grounds on which to praise him?.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 344:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 344:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 344:3
verses.text: Behold! I have sent you my speech, all streaming with sweat as I am! How should I be otherwise, when sending my speech to one who by his skill in oratory is able to shew that the wisdom of Plato and the ability of Demosthenes were belauded in vain? I feel like a gnat compared with an elephant.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 344:4
verses.text: How I shiver and shake, as I reckon up the day when you will inspect my performance I am almost out of my wits!.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 345:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 345:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 345:3
verses.text: I have read your speech, and have immensely admired it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 345:4
verses.text: O muses; O learning; O Athens; what do you not give to those who love you! What fruits do not they gather who spend even a short time with you! Oh for your copiously flowing fountain! What men all who drink of it are shewn to be! I seemed to see the man himself in your speech, in the company of his chattering little woman.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 345:5
verses.text: A living story has been written on the ground by Libanius, who alone has bestowed the gift of life upon his words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 346:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLIV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 346:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 346:3
verses.text: Now I recognise men's description of me! Basil has praised me, and I am hailed victor over all! Now that I have received your vote, I am entitled to walk with the proud gait of a man who haughtily looks down on all the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 346:4
verses.text: You have composed an oration against drunkenness.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 346:5
verses.text: I should like to read it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 346:6
verses.text: But I am unwilling to try to say anything clever.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 346:7
verses.text: When I have seen your speech it will teach me the art of expressing myself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 347:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLV.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 347:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 347:3
verses.text: Are you living at Athens, Basil? Have you forgotten yourself? The sons of the Caesareans could not endure to hear these things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 347:4
verses.text: My tongue was not accustomed to them.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 347:5
verses.text: Just as though I were treading some dangerous ground, and were struck at the novelty of the sounds, it said to me its father, "My father, you never taught this! This man is Homer, or Plato, or Aristotle, or Susarion.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 347:6
verses.text: He knows everything".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 347:7
verses.text: So far my tongue.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 347:8
verses.text: I only wish, Basil, that you could praise me in the same manner!.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 348:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 348:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 348:3
verses.text: I am delighted at receiving what you write, but when you ask me to reply, I am in a difficulty.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 348:4
verses.text: What could I say in answer to so Attic a tongue, except that I confess, and confess with joy, that I am a pupil of fishermen?.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 349:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLVII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 349:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 349:3
verses.text: What has made Basil object to the letter, the proof of philosophy? I have learned to make fun from you, but nevertheless your fun is venerable and, so to say, hoary with age.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 349:4
verses.text: But, by our very friendship, by our common pastimes, do away, I charge you, with the distress caused by your letter…in nothing differing.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 350:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLVIII.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 350:2
verses.text: Libanius to Basil.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 350:3
verses.text: Oh, for the old days in which we were all in all to one another! Now we are sadly separated! Ye have one another, I have no one like you to replace you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 350:4
verses.text: I hear that Alcimus in his old age is venturing on a young man's exploits, and is hurrying to Rome, after imposing on you the labour of remaining with the lads.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 350:5
verses.text: You, who are always so kind, will not take this ill.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 350:6
verses.text: You were not even angry with me for having to write first.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 351:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLIX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 351:2
verses.text: Basil to Libanius.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 351:3
verses.text: You, who have included all the art of the ancients in your own mind, are so silent, that you do not even let me get any gain in a letter.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 351:4
verses.text: I, if the art of Daedalus had only been safe, would have made me Icarus' wings and come to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 351:5
verses.text: But wax cannot be entrusted to the sun, and so, instead of Icarus' wings, I send you words to prove my affection.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 351:6
verses.text: It is the nature of words to indicate the love of the heart.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 351:7
verses.text: So far, words.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 351:8
verses.text: You do with them what you will, and, possessing all the power you do, are silent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 351:9
verses.text: But pray transfer to me the fountains of words that spring from your mouth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 352:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLX.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 352:2
verses.text: Of the Holy Trinity, the Incarnation, the invocation of Saints, and their Images.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 352:3
verses.text: According to the blameless faith of the Christians which we have obtained from God, I confess and agree that I believe in one God the Father Almighty; God the Father, God the Son, God the Holy Ghost; I adore and worship one God, the Three.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 352:4
verses.text: I confess to the oeconomy of the Son in the flesh, and that the holy Mary, who gave birth to Him according to the flesh, was Mother of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 352:5
verses.text: I acknowledge also the holy apostles, prophets, and martyrs; and I invoke them to supplication to God, that through them, that is, through their mediation, the merciful God may be propitious to me, and that a ransom may be made and given me for my sins.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 352:6
verses.text: Wherefore also I honour and kiss the features of their images, inasmuch as they have been handed down from the holy apostles, and are not forbidden, but are in all our churches.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 352:7
verses.text: Letters CCCLXI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:1
verses.text: Letter CCCLXVI.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:2
verses.text: Basil to Urbicius the monk, concerning continency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:3
verses.text: You do well in making exact definitions for us, so that we may recognise not only continency, but its fruit.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:4
verses.text: Now its fruit is the companionship of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:5
verses.text: For not to be corrupted, is to have part with God; just as to be corrupted is the companionship of the world.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:6
verses.text: Continency is denial of the body, and confession to God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:7
verses.text: It withdraws from anything mortal, like a body which has the Spirit of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:8
verses.text: It is without rivalry and envy, and causes us to be united to God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:9
verses.text: He who loves a body envies another.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:10
verses.text: He who has not admitted the disease of corruption into his heart, is for the future strong enough to endure any labour, and though he have died in the body, he lives in incorruption.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:11
verses.text: Verily, if I rightly apprehend the matter, God seems to me to be continency, because He desires nothing, but has all things in Himself.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:12
verses.text: He reaches after nothing, nor has any sense in eyes or ears; wanting nothing, He is in all respects complete and full.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:13
verses.text: Concupiscence is a disease of the soul; but continency is its health.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:14
verses.text: And continency must not be regarded only in one species, as, for instance, in matters of sensual love.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:15
verses.text: It must be regarded in everything which the soul lusts after in an evil manner, not being content with what is needful for it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:16
verses.text: Envy is caused for the sake of gold, and innumerable wrongs for the sake of other lusts.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:17
verses.text: Not to be drunken is continency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:18
verses.text: Not to overeat one's self is continency.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:19
verses.text: To subdue the body is continency, and to keep evil thoughts in subjection, whenever the soul is disturbed by any fancy false and bad, and the heart is distracted by vain cares.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:20
verses.text: Continency makes men free, being at once a medicine and a power, for it does not teach temperance; it gives it.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:21
verses.text: Continency is a grace of God.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:22
verses.text: Jesus seemed to be continency, when He was made light to land and sea; for He was carried neither by earth nor ocean, and just as He walked on the sea, so He did not weigh down the earth.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:23
verses.text: For if death comes of corruption, and not dying comes of not having corruption, then Jesus wrought not mortality but divinity.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:24
verses.text: He ate and drank in a peculiar manner, without rendering his food.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:25
verses.text: So mighty a power in Him was continency, that His food was not corrupted in Him, since He had no corruption.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:26
verses.text: If only there be a little continency in us, we are higher than all.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:27
verses.text: We have been told that angels were ejected from heaven because of concupiscence and became incontinent.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:28
verses.text: They were vanquished; they did not come down.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:29
verses.text: What could that plague have effected there, if an eye such as I am thinking of had been there? Wherefore I said, If we have a little patience, and do not love the world, but the life above, we shall be found there where we direct our mind.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:30
verses.text: For it is the mind, apparently, which is the eye that seeth unseen things.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:31
verses.text: For we say "the mind sees;" "the mind hears".

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:32
verses.text: I have written at length, though it may seem little to you.

verses.name: Basil The Great: Letters 354:33
verses.text: But there is meaning in all that I have said, and, when you have read it, you will see it.
